HEADLINE: Slovak Separatists Proud of Nazi Past

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I must quarrel with your March 19 report on Slovak separatism as inadequate to explain the hostility to be found in Slovak Bratislava toward Czech Prague. Although you cite a plethora of ethnographic figures to demonstrate the complicated admixture of the populations, you entirely neglect the central fact of the Slovak separatist movement. 
 You fail to mention the brief period of independent statehood presided over by the Rev. Josef Tiso under the domination of Hitler, following his post-Munich invasion of Czechoslovakia on March 14, 1939. You ignore Slovakia's wartime collaboration with Hitler. After liberation by the Red Army, wartime collaborators were tried and executed.
Under the tenure of Gustav Husak, a Slovak Communist, as Prime Minister at Prague from 1968, the province received an influx of developmental capital, creating polluting works for making steel, aluminum and chemicals, which, along with a gigantic munitions works, became unprofitable at the end of the cold war. Slovak unemployment rose in the lagging economy, and the separatists blamed the central government.
Last July, the separatists memorialized Father Tiso, placing a plaque in a church of a small mining town, which was blessed by the Roman Catholic bishop of Nitra. The outcry caused the Federal Parliament to set up an investigating commission to examine the history of the separatists, after which the town council ordered the plaque destroyed. Recently, President Vaclav Havel encountered hostility and derision in Bratislava on his investigative trip.
On my sixth visit in six years to Czechoslovakia last November, I obtained several significant interviews on this plaguing subject.
I found that the Slovak separatist leaders are young and vigorous, and wear blinders in pressing their own agenda aggressively. They have never presented an economic program for independence. They are deaf and blind to Prague's concession in creating a federated state of equal Czech and Slovak people, a forerunner of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for the Soviet Union's minority problems. They represent a small rightist minority among their people, who harbor fervor for their historic traditions.
 
SYLVIA E. CRANE
Princeton, N.J., March 19, 1991
 
The writer is the author of "Czechoslovakia: Anvil of the Cold War" (New York, 1990).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Volatile Trading In Collectible Cars

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
TWO years ago the prices of older exotic European cars like Ferrari, Aston Martin and Jaguar were skyrocketing, often doubling in a few months. Then early last year, the bottom dropped out of the market. Cars went unsold at auctions or were bid on only by owners trying to prop up the market.
"The Ferrari market is shattered," said Ed Jurist, owner of the Vintage Car Store in Nyack, N.Y., and a longtime trader of old, rare cars. "A 1972 Daytona that sold for $400,000 at the peak is only worth about $200,000 to $225,000 now. A 1986 512 Boxer that went for $340,000 is under $200,000 now." 
 Mr. Jurist said the rapid inflation in the value of some exotics had not been fueled by genuine collectors. "The market was pushed to artificial heights by speculators who were selling to each other," he said. "Then one decided he did not want to play and it all collapsed."
"People borrowed $500,000 to buy a Ferrari, expecting to sell it in a year for $1 million," said Dean Tezos, a New York collector. "The interest on that comes to $65,000 to $70,000 a year. That is not much if you are expecting to sell for $1 million, but it is not viable when the market is down."
Prices of many other collector cars, from plebeian Fords and Chevrolets to exotic imports, have softened as well, although not so sharply as for the Ferraris and Jaguars.
"We did a survey of people who dropped their subscriptions," said David Brownell, editor of Hemmings Motor News, which is aimed at collectors. "We found that people were holding off restoring cars because they were unsure of their financial situation or had lost their jobs and were in no position to buy a car."
But a weakened market can mean opportunities for bargain hunters. Mr. Tezos, for example, said he dropped out of the market in 1988 and 1989 but was back buying cars.
Experts in the field said some time-honored rules still hold. One is that "the price goes up if the top goes down." Since collectors typically drive their prized cars only in nice weather, convertibles typically command a steep price premium.
For example, Automotive Investor, a newsletter published by Liebert Inc. in New York, reports that a 1968 Ford Shelby Mustang GT350 in good condition sells for $20,000 to $25,000. A convertible of the same model commands from $40,000 to $45,000. Similarly, a 1957 Chrysler 300-C coupe is listed at $16,000 to $22,000. The convertible is $30,000 to $36,000.
Another rule of thumb is that some older cars represent middle-aged men's teen-age dream machines. One formula is: take the current year, subtract 45 to get back to the birth years of today's middle-aged men and add back 15 to 17 to get the years they fell in love with cars. Thus, interest in cars of the early 1950's is easing, while demand for early 1960's models is picking up.
"We think there is a real opportunity in Karmann Ghia convertibles," said Mary Ann Liebert, publisher of Automotive Investor. "You can get them for under $5,000 today, and we think that could double by the end of 1992." The sports car version of the venerable Volkswagen bug, Karmann Ghias were popular throughout the 1960's.
"There will always be a market for nostalgia cars," Mr. Jurist said. "People want the cars they associate with their youth."
The "muscle cars" of the 1960's are also attracting more interest, and therefore increasing in price. These were relatively modest sedans with huge engines installed to improve their performance.
For instance, a 1969 or 1970 Ford Boss Mustang with the 302-cubic-inch engine is listed by Automotive Investor at $14,500 to $16,500. The same car with a 429-cubic-inch engine lists from $38,000 to $45,000. A 1970 Dodge Challenger R/T with the standard engine ranges from $10,000 to $13,000; with a 426 engine, it is $42,000 to $50,000.
Price quotations are rough, since cars typically trade one at a time and there is no organized reporting mechanism. Collector-car auctions of hundreds of cars provide some indication of the market. But since owners often set minimum prices for cars and sometimes join the bidding to hold up price levels, it is not always clear where the bottom of the market is.
"Auction prices can be fiddled," Mr. Brownell said. "I take 10 to 15 percent off the reported prices."
And since each car is individual, the sale of one for a high price does not necessarily mean similar models will command the same price. "You have to know how many actual bidders there were for a car," Ms. Leibert said. "Maybe there were just one or two people who had to have a car and they bid it up. That does not mean there are 25 others out there.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Dollar Called Important As Factor in Fed Policy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The dollar, seemingly ignored by the Federal Reserve Board when it was weak, may be rising in importance as a policy consideration now that it is strong, credit market analysts say.
There are good economic and political reasons for the Fed to be concerned. 
 Export growth, one of the lone sources of consistent strength over the last year, is slowing. And the dollar's run-up against the German mark has been so sharp that the Bundesbank may be forced to raise German interest rates, which could push the cost of reunification to prohibitive levels.
 
Two Alternative Courses
 The Fed has at least two alternative courses if it wants to stem the dollar's rise: massively dumping dollars in the foreign exchange markets along with other central banks, or if it decides against intervention, it could ease domestic interest rates again.
"Bringing the dollar down has to have a higher priority" than previously, said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm. "I am hearing that export orders are starting to slow further, and given the debt overhang we have, the only real stimulus you are going to get from lower interest rates is in exports."
In a weekly letter to clients, William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, wrote that "since the Fed has consistently identified the trade sector as being extremely important to any recovery process in the United States, the credit authorities may now be more willing to lower interest rates to brake the dollar's upward climb" to sustain export momentum.
 
Not All Are Convinced
 Not all economists are convinced that the dollar's rise will have much influence on how the Fed conducts monetary policy.
"Our central bank normally cares about inflation or growth, depending on where we are in the business cycle," said Alan Sinai, president of Boston Company Economic Advisers. "Currency is a tangential concern. The strong dollar makes it easier for the Fed to ease if it wants to, but right now priority No. 1 is the economy."
Although the predominant evidence supports the view that the economy remains in recession, analysts who have been predicting that an upturn would begin by midyear have more reason to believe in their forecast than they did a month ago.
 
Houses and Economic Index
 Recent reports on housing starts and sales suggest conditions in that depressed sector of the economy may have bottomed out.
And Mr. Sinai noted that the increase of 1.1 percentage points in February's index of leading economic indicators was almost certain to be followed by another gain in March, given the run-up in stock prices, the growth in money supply and the sharp rise in consumer confidence that has occurred. Three straight months of gains in the index are almost always followed by an upturn in the economy, he said.
Even the optimists concede that more bad news is coming. And strong dollar or no, Mr. Chimerine and others said that the Fed was not likely to ease policy further unless bond yields fell in the face of additional signs of economic weakness.
Based on Wall Street forecasts, such signs will probably be seen this week, beginning with the March survey of the nation's purchasing managers, which is expected to be released today. Most analysts are expecting the report to show that although conditions in the manufacturing sector improved marginally from February, activity remains at a very low level.
 
Employment Data Due
 The most important news is not expected until Friday, however, when the Labor Department is scheduled to release March employment data. Based on recent trends in initial unemployment claims, John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service, projected that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 225,000 in March, following the February drop of 184,000.
A decline of that size would almost certainly push up the unemployment rate from its current level of 6.5 percent. And some analysts said that if the report also shows little growth in hourly wages, the Fed might be tempted to respond by easing policy further.
That view is far from uniform.
The Fed, which lowered short-term interest rates after the last two employment reports, is not likely to move again until it sees a slowing in broad-based inflation measures like the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index.
Analysts, who have been surprised and perplexed by the resilience of inflationary pressures in the midst of an economic downturn, expect to see an improvement in the March data, which are expected next week.

HEADLINE: Fed Kept Policy Steady in February

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The policy-making body of the Federal Reserve voted unanimously at its February meeting to leave credit policy unchanged, but with a tilt toward lower rates, minutes of the meeting show.
The Federal Open Market Committee agreed "that for now it was desirable to pause and assess the course of the economy and the effect of past policy actions," according to the minutes. 
 Members took into account the "considerable" credit easing in recent months and the discount-rate cut that took place a few days before the meeting, on Feb. 5 and 6. The minutes are released six to seven weeks after the meetings, which are private, are held; the minutes of the February meeting were released on Friday.
The open market committee is made up of the 7 board members and 5 of the 12 regional bank presidents. Only 11 market committee members voted at the February meeting because of a vacancy on the board.
All of the members agreed that the credit policy should remain unchanged, and most expressed a preference for continuing to adjust the policy toward pushing rates lower in the weeks ahead, the minutes said.
The minutes noted that interest rates had fallen but stated that some members thought sufficient time had not passed for the effects to be felt in the economy or in money-supply growth.
A number of members expressed concern that easing credit so soon after a cut on Feb. 1 in the discount rate, to 6 percent from 6.5 percent, would result in "undesirable downward pressure on the dollar in foreign exchange markets." The discount rate is the level at which the central bank lends money to commercial banks.
The dollar has firmed since the Persian Gulf war ended. The Fed lowered its target for the free-floating Federal funds rate to 6 percent, from 6.25 percent, on March 8, after the Government reported a steep climb in January in the unemployment rate.
The minutes show that several members at the February meeting wanted the committee to place "a high premium" on avoiding a deep recession.
Those members, the minutes said, "were more concerned about the severe consequences of a potentially deep and prolonged recession than those of a sharp rebound in the economy, especially given current financial strains and fragilities in the economy."

HEADLINE: A Troubled Operation PUSH Struggles to Focus Its Mission

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 31

 BODY:
Operation PUSH, the Chicago civil rights organization founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, is going through a period of upheaval, struggling to reshape its identity in the face of financial troubles and the resignation of its executive director, the Rev. Tyrone Crider.
PUSH leaders say they are reassessing strategy, stepping up fund raising and reorganizing the management of the 20-year-old organization, whose initials stand for People United to Serve Humanity. 
 In January, faced with a deficit of several hundred thousand dollars, the PUSH board announced the layoff of all 12 staff workers. The group has since raised more than $100,000, and officials say they hope to raise $1 million in the next 12 months.
The Rev. Henry Williamson, the new president and chief executive officer, said that PUSH had "put out the immediate financial fires" and that he hoped to rehire the workers soon. Most have continued as volunteers, he said.
 
'Time to Take Inventory'
 Robert T. Starks, an associate professor of political science at Northeastern Illinois University who has followed PUSH, said: "This is a critical period for the organization. Their major mission will remain the same, but it's a time to take inventory."
Mr. Crider resigned this month, citing personal reasons, in what was widely seen as a response to PUSH's problems. The board then created a 20-member team to develop criteria for hiring a new director and reorganizing. PUSH has also begun a nationwide membership drive, with a goal of 100,000 new members this year.
Although these moves seem to have been prompted by Mr. Crider's departure, many who have followed PUSH say the organization has floundered since 1989, when Mr. Jackson relinquished his leadership to move his legal residence to Washington.
Mr. Jackson was in Chicago today to deliver an Easter sermon to more than 1,000 people at the Carter Temple Church, where Mr. Williamson is pastor. Referring to the Crucifixion, Mr. Jackson said, "It wasn't the nails in His hands, painful as they were," but the fact that the people Jesus served had deserted Him. He urged the worshipers to contribute to PUSH.
 
Jackson Seen as the Key
 James Compton, president of the Chicago Urban League, said, "I tend to think that the key to the PUSH situation is the presence or lack of presence of Reverend Jackson."
But some who are familiar with PUSH have said privately that it was losing influence even before Mr. Jackson left. Critics have charged that the group, which has long pressed for affirmative action and other efforts on behalf of minority workers and businesses, caters to middle-class blacks.
Few prominent black Chicagoans will openly criticize PUSH. But a letter published in The Chicago Tribune last fall reflects the views of some detractors. It said, "The fact is that most blacks under 30 think of PUSH, along with several other civil rights organizations, as dinosaurs."
PUSH officials say such charges are untrue. They said PUSH's troubles rose from the downturn in the economy, which has heightened demands for the organization's services at the same time that contributions are down.
"We receive more than 150 calls each day," said the Rev. Willie Barrow, vice chairwoman of the PUSH board. Ms. Barrow said PUSH's financial troubles mirrored those of the corporate world.
 
Public Relations Failures
 But some public relations failures have hurt PUSH. Most prominent was a boycott of Nike Inc., the athletic-shoe manufacturer, over its hiring practices. Several prominent blacks opposed the boycott, which was widely perceived as a failure when Nike officials refused to negotiate with PUSH.
PUSH leaders argue that the boycott, which began in August, has forced Nike, as well as others in the athletic industry, to hire more blacks. Nike has formed an advisory board to review the company's minority recruitment.

HEADLINE: No Budget By Deadline In New York

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 31

 BODY:
As New York State enters a new fiscal year on Monday without a budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are mired in a severe dispute that focuses in large part on taxes -- not just how much more of them there should be but who exactly should pay them.
Even if the Governor and state lawmakers here fulfill pledges to rely on spending cuts to close most of a $6 billion deficit in a $29 billion budget, the gap is so large that they are still likely to approve major increases in taxes and fees for the third straight year. While the general fund budget, which includes mostly state tax revenues, is expected to be around $29 billion, the "all funds" budget, adding Federal money spent by the state, is expected to total about $51 billion.
 
 What divides them is deep disagreement over what tax increases would be least damaging to the state's economy, whose weak condition is closely linked to the state government's budget turmoil.
 
Most Basic Question
 The most basic question is whether new taxes should be broadly spread across the state or whether there is a way -- as many vocal constituencies, including major labor unions and the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus, are demanding -- to target wealthy taxpayers and corporations.
Governor Cuomo, to the consternation of some of his usual Democratic allies and the somewhat wary approval of conservative critics, has approached the budget this year determined to make major spending cuts and to reject dramatic tax increases for anyone, including the wealthy.
His budget plan avoids any increase in rates for the state's most familiar broad-based taxes: income, sales and corporate taxes. But it places a patchwork of new levies on items ranging from gasoline (10 cents a gallon) to out-of-state business telephone calls (2 percent surcharge) to snack foods (basically a nickel a package).
The Democrat with whom Governor Cuomo shares control over the budget-making process, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, has denounced many of Mr. Cuomo's taxes as regressive. People pay the same rates, he says, whether they are rich or poor.
In a move that helped put budget negotiations in chaos because it came just days before the April 1 deadline, Mr. Miller, under heavy pressure from many liberal Democrats in the Assembly, proposed doing away with most of Mr. Cuomo's taxes and replacing them with a $1 billion tempo rary rise in personal income tax rates. That increase, he said, would be more equitable because people in wealthier tax brackets would pay more.
Mr. Cuomo opposes that and other proposals to raise income-tax rates, although he insists that he believes putting much heavier taxes on the rich is a good idea -- if it is done in Washington, not in Albany. "Unlike the Federal Government," he said recently, "states are caught in a rough competitive struggle with one another."
Mr. Miller's budget plan also includes major spending cuts, but the tax increase would be used to soften many of those proposed by Mr. Cuomo, including reductions in aid to school districts and local governments. More starkly, it would divide the tax burden in different ways than Mr. Cuomo has proposed.
 
Tax Bite Compared
 Most lower-income people would wind up paying less under Mr. Miller's plan: those making less than $20,000, for instance, would pay an average of less than $4 more in income taxes, Assembly officials estimate, while under Mr. Cuomo's plan they would on average pay more than that in tax increases on gasoline and other items.
People at the other end of the economic scale would fare better with Mr. Cuomo's plan. Those making between $100,000 and $250,000 a year would pay an average of about $750 more in income taxes under the Assembly proposal, and those with incomes of more than $250,000 would pay more than $5,000 more each.
With the gas tax these same people would pay an additional $100 to $150 a year. And while some very wealthy people would have to contend with increased estate taxes and new taxes on the sale of million-dollar homes in Mr. Cuomo's proposal, it is clear that most upper-income taxpayers would pay less under his plan.
Mr. Miller's plan is not the only one whose proponents assert it is more progressive than the Governor's.
A proposal by the Public Employees Federation, one of the largest unions of state workers, would close some of the gap with $3 billion in new taxes, most of them on businesses. Personal income taxes would rise by nearly $1 billion, but only for people making more than $100,000 a year, who would pay an average of $3,000 more each.
Perhaps not surprisingly, many advocates for social programs who object bitterly to the cuts proposed by Mr. Cuomo describe higher taxes on the wealthy as an obvious and fair way to restore some of them.
"The Governor has abandoned any notion here of progressive taxation," said Russell Sykes, senior policy associate with the State Communities Aid Association, a nonprofit lobbying group. "I think he is painting himself into a corner where he is likely to do greater harm to the people and the economy he is professing to protect than if he was amenable to looking at some of the broader-based taxes."
Mr. Cuomo has presided over a series of major cuts in income taxes, whose maximum rate stood at 15 percent in the 1970's and is now at 7.875 percent, though he also warned lawmakers, including Mr. Miller, that they were going too low when they passed the last major round of cuts in 1987.
Despite that warning, the Governor has remained adamant that any rise in income-tax rates now, during a recession, would do damage because it would increase the flight of businesses and wealthy taxpayers out of the state.
"It's not a threat; it is a fact of life," Gerald C. Crotty, the Governor's chief of staff, said in an interview on Saturday. "It would be devastating to the economy, especially in New York City."
There is little question that tax rates influence businesses' decisions about where to locate, but their importance is difficult to measure against other factors, including the quality of government services like education and infrastructure.
In any event, New York already lags behind most states in creating new jobs and it has the second-highest combined state and local taxes of any state in the nation, after Alaska. Many analysts say raising rates by a significant amount might help close this year's budget deficit, but is unlikely to help in the long run.
Beyond that, trying to direct those taxes specifically at the wealthy is risky. "You may not have to worry about many people leaving the state, but the people you do have to worry about have a lot of economic clout," said Steven D. Gold, the director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York.
For the moment, the Assembly Speaker's proposal has bogged down budget negotiations. While both the Democratic Governor and the majority leader of Republican-controlled State Senate, Ralph J. Marino, have soundly rejected it, Mr. Miller is still pushing to have it considered.
And Mr. Marino, putting a further drag on the talks, has also been critical of the gasoline tax, which would bring in $500 million a year, without yet making clear what alternatives he has in mind.

HEADLINE: Foreign Stocks Gain, But U.S. Investors Lag

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
It was a good quarter for investors in foreign stock markets. But it was not so good for Americans.
Mexico's bourse again led the pack, rising 36.9 percent in local currency, and continuing its recent dominance of world market performance. And stock markets in Europe, even with a relatively weak performance by Germany, outperformed Wall Street, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. European markets rose 15.4 percent, compared with a 14.1 percent rise in the United States. The Tokyo market was up 13 percent in local currency. 
 At the same time, the dollar's rally of the last seven weeks cut into the gains of American investors, especially in Europe. Only in markets where the local currency is tied closely to the dollar or follows it, like Mexico, Hong Kong and Singapore, were investors spared this sharp reduction when gains were converted back into dollars. In dollar terms, Europe's local gain was cut to 3.3 percent and Japan's to 9.1 percent. But Mexico slipped to only 35.2 percent.
The victory in the Persian Gulf war was the common support for all markets. And the hope for an imminent economic recovery in the United States gave a push to Wall Street that seemed to move other markets around the world. Stock markets like France, Spain and Britain also benefited from actual and expected cuts in interest rates.
 
Gyrations in the Markets
 Some gyrations in the markets were the product of sudden shifts in focus. One day investors would look beyond recessions or economic slowdowns in many countries to recoveries. Then on the next day, a set of disappointing earnings would return them to the bad news of the moment.
Germany, where the Financial Times index rose 7.7 percent in marks, was the weakest performer of the major stock markets. For Americans, the dollar's rally turned the modest gain into a 5.2 percent loss. While the Frankfurt market rallied on the war victory, thoughts in Germany quickly turned to the growing economic problems in the former East Germany: rising unemployment and political protests. There is even the possibility now that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, could move to raise interest rates again because of the sharp fall of the mark against the dollar.
After Mexico, which continues to benefit from the opening up of its economy and the possibility of a free-trade zone with the United States, Hong Kong, up 24.8 percent in dollars, and Singapore, up 22.3 percent, were the top performers. Hong Kong has been one of the hottest markets all year. Investment managers plucked what they saw as good values in a market they said was somewhat insulated from the confrontation in the gulf. Singapore also benefited from investors who chose it for its good values and potential growth this year.
The surprise of the quarter was Sweden, a market that many managers were shying away from at the end of last year. But a decline in interest rates, a credible Government budget proposal packed with spending cuts and the victory in the war helped push the market up 17.2 percent in dollar terms.

HEADLINE: Macy Edges Away From Abyss

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS with ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Success is a relative thing, and nowhere is that clearer than at R. H. Macy & Company, the huge retailer, where the financial picture is finally starting to look brighter after more than two years of severe problems.
Once Macy measured success in rising market share and innovative retailing concepts. Now, hobbled by debts and recession and reduced to seeking permission from bankers for moves that its merchants once would have made on their own, Macy measures its success simply in survival short of bankruptcy. 
 By that narrow measure, Macy is looking better than at any time since its ill-advised $1.2 billion acquisitions of Bullock's and I. Magnin in 1988. If Macy does survive, that achievement will be in stark contrast to the bankruptcies of humbled rivals like Federated Department Stores, Allied Stores and Carter Hawley Hale.
 
Wall Street Turns Positive
 Wall Street, leery a few months ago, is now generally positive. "I'm a believer -- the company makes it," said Tom Razukas, an analyst with Fitch Investors Service, a credit-rating agency. He said that even using conservative estimates of future sales, he expected Macy to meet its obligations from its more than $4 billion in debt.
Within the close-knit world of Seventh Avenue's garment center, concerns have also abated. "I think Macy's is making some real progress," said John Pomerantz, the chairman of the Leslie Fay Companies, the New York-based clothing maker. "They're keeping their inventories low and cutting back on price promotions, which hurt gross profits. They're paying their bills on time. I think the worst is behind them."
The decision to cut back on promotions last Christmas improved Macy's profit margins but left it with sales 10 percent below those of the previous Christmas.
Macy needs to bring back customers, and it promises a striking increase in its television advertising starting in April, including sponsorship of New York Mets baseball. And it is working hard to emphasize inventory control to curtail markdowns and to reduce expenses.
Another sign that Macy has begun to get a good hold on its future is that it recently brought in two new finance experts -- Myron E. Ullman, a former managing director of Wharf Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong, and Diane P. Baker, formerly a corporate finance director at Salomon Brothers. Their assignment, essentially, is to free the company's chairman and chief executive, Edward S. Finkelstein, to focus his attention on merchandising and marketing, areas that are obviously important in the long run to Macy's success.
The company's executives have to find ways to cut the debt left over from Macy's own leveraged buyout in 1986 and the acquisitions two years later. Macy has begun doing so by buying back more than $300 million of its own bonds for less than half their face value. And when it completes a pending sale of its credit-card operations to GE Capital, the General Electric Company's finance unit, "we will have reduced total debt by approximately $2 billion," Macy executives said last month in announcing the latest bond purchases. Macy executives declined to be interviewed for this article.
In an interview two years after the Macy buyout, Mr. Finkelstein looked ahead to taking Macy public again and said he expected that doing so would provide the investors with "a good deal five to seven years hence." That would be in 1993 to 1995. In the process of selling additional stock to other investors in order to buy back high-interest bonds, Mr. Finkelstein's team reduced its percentage of ownership to 13 percent, from 19 percent.
The changing view of Macy has come not so much from its financial results -- Christmas was good only in contrast to a very bad 1989 season -- as from the voice of confidence from the institutional investors that control Macy. When a pending deal is completed, more than $202 million will have been invested in Macy stock since last fall. It is that cash that gave Macy the ability to buy back its bonds.
"Without that equity infusion, the industry might have been reluctant to ship them merchandise after Christmas," said Evan Mann, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Company. "With the equity they got, and the ability to buy back their debt, it will make them a healthier company."
 
The Bond Recovery
Prices Doubled, Even Quadrupled
The view that Macy will succeed is in sharp contrast to the outlook only last October. The pervasive disarray in the "junk bond" market, coupled with worries about Christmas sales in a recession, had sent Macy bond prices plunging. Anyone brave enough to have bought Macy bonds then would have locked up annual returns of 40 percent or more -- provided that Macy lived up to its obligations.
Since then, prices of Macy bonds have doubled and even quadrupled, and yields are back down to around 20 percent. That level, while signaling a brighter outlook, still shows that many investors do not believe Macy is out of the woods.
"They are still showing signs of a prolonged recession," said Mariel Clemensen, a vice president and bond analyst at Citicorp Securities Markets, who thinks the bond market prices reflect excessive optimism.
 
An Optimistic Forecast
 Nonetheless, as Walter F. Loeb, a New York retail analyst, put it: "Macy stores are still some of the most exciting in the department-store field. If the company can just stay ahead of its high debt and get through this difficult period, it will do very well when the retail environment picks up."
Nearly all highly leveraged companies report bottom-line losses, because the heavy interest payments on their debt typically push them into the red. In its case, Macy has not reported an annual profit since 1986, when management, together with institutional investors, bought the company.
But in leveraged companies, investors watch cash flow, which is defined in various ways. The most liberal definition is earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, known as Ebitda (eh-BEET-da). In fiscal 1987, which ended Aug. 1, 1987, Macy showed such cash flow at $797 million, though it reported a net loss of $13.8 million.
Cash flow defined this way leaves out some important factors. While highly leveraged companies seldom pay much in taxes, they do pay huge interest bills -- and still need to cover some capital investments. In fiscal 1987, Macy's cash flow was more than enough to cover all those contingencies, if not enough to produce a profit.
 
The Federated Debacle
Losing the Battle Was the Good News
Things were still looking good in the next fiscal year, even though business fell off after the 1987 stock market crash. It was then that Macy got caught up in the bidding war for Federated Department Stores.
The good news for Macy was that it lost the bidding war to Robert Campeau, a Canadian financier, who paid so much that Federated went bankrupt within two years along with Allied Stores, which the Campeau Corporation already owned.
The bad news was that Macy won a consolation prize, acquiring the Bullock's and I. Magnin chains of Federated. That strengthened Macy's position in California, which perhaps became stronger still this year when Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., a leading West Coast competitor, buckled under the heavy debt load it had taken on to avoid a takeover bid and filed for bankruptcy.
Macy has insisted that buying those stores was good for strategic reasons, but there is little doubt it overpaid. "They bought Magnin and Bullock's for 10 times cash flow," said Citicorp's Ms. Clemensen, adding that such stores are now probably worth only five times cash flow.
In the two and a half years since then, for which financial results have been reported, Macy has seen cash flow fall $126 million short of being enough to cover interest expenses and capital spending. It first slashed capital spending, but has more recently increased it.
 
Questions About Bullock's
 Precisely how well Macy has done running the California operations is not clear; Macy does not disclose results by store chain. But there are critics of Macy's decision to put Bullock's under the Macy Atlanta division. Under that change, marketing and merchandising are set in Atlanta for the California stores. "The crisp look and the comprehensive stocks of the old Bullock's under the previous ownership are gone now," said Herbert Mines, a New York retailing recruiter. "The competition loves it because Bullock's isn't the tough rival it used to be."
When Macy was an unquestioned leader in the department store world, much of its success seemed to be a result of its clever use of store brands, where it controlled the design and manufacture of goods and avoided the costs of middlemen. But some people think that with Macy's senior management, notably its chairman, Mr. Finkelstein, focuing on the financial issues of the buyout, the private-label operation was not watched closely enough.
"Macy will try this fall to feature many of the big supplier names in the business as it attempts to reduce much of its private-label emphasis," said Bud Konheim, head of Nicole Miller, the dress and sportswear maker. "They want a lot of high-profile names." He added that private labels were expected to account for 20 percent of sales, half the level that once prevailed.
 
The Challenge Ahead
Cash Flow Unlikely To Meet Expenses
After the disastrous 1989 Christmas season, Macy was determined to avoid having inventories that were too large, and it entered this last Christmas with 16 percent fewer goods on its shelves. With less merchandise to move, it had less need to cut prices, despite the recession in the Northeast, where Macy does most of its business.
Even with the drop in sales, cash flow was up and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization rose to $254 million, from $210 million a year earlier. That gain was enough to leave $32 million on hand after deducting all interest expenses and capital spending.
 
A Sign of Confidence
 It still seems inevitable, however, that this fiscal year, which ends in August, will be the second one in a row in which cash flow will not have been enough to meet all interest expenses and capital spending needs. Last week, Macy's banks agreed to relax some rules on interest payments to insure that Macy will avoid being in default on its bank loans.
One sign that Macy, and its bankers and equity investors, are confident about the future is that Macy has bought back the most junior of its bonds, ignoring its senior bonds. In that way, it was able to retire more debt at a lower cost, because the riskier junior debt had fallen further.
But it did nothing to offset the principal payments that will come due sooner. It is required to pay back $25 million of its $370 million in bank loans in June, and another $175 million by the end of this year. The sale of the credit-card operations will only partly cover that requirement.
Moreover, Macy must begin paying back part of the principal on its most senior bonds in 1994. But instead of buying some of them, it purchased bonds that do not require principal payments to begin until 1997 on one issue and 2002 on another.
Those requirements for debt service emphasize that Macy still faces a challenge, and some people say that Macy may have to sell more assets. Walter K. Levy, a York retail-marketing consultant in New York, speculated that it might seek to sell one or more of its specialty-store chains, and Macy has been seeking a buyer for a California office building it no longer needs.
"It would be good if Macy's could raise more equity or cash by selling a less-productive asset like the Macy Atlanta group," said Joanne Lagomsky, vice president for corporate finance for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit-rating agency. "The company needs more cash to meet its debt-service requirements."

HEADLINE: Louisiana Farmers, Finding Gold in Alligator Skins, Face a Changing Market

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORKED ISLAND, La.

 BODY:
Raywood Stelly opened the shed door on more than 200 small alligators, releasing their gamey aroma in a gush of suffocatingly hot, moist air.
"That's the smell of money," said Mr. Stelly in his thick Cajun accent as light streamed into the circular enclosure, sending the alligators slithering from their pool into wriggling piles along the walls. 
 In 1977 there were only three alligator farmers in Louisiana. Now Mr. Stelly is one among 126 in the state, putting Louisiana well ahead of Florida and Texas, which also have native alligator populations but fewer than 40 farms in all.
In that time alligator farming has grown through an unlikely combination of profit motive, concern for an endangered species and efforts to preserve the state's coastal marshes and inland swamps.
 
Humble Start, Elegant End
 "It has come from virtually nothing in a decade to amount to half the $51 million a year that the state derives from crayfish," said Larry Michaux, a spokesman for the Louisiana Department of Agriculture. And crayfish have been a staple of Cajun cuisine for more than 100 years.
Alligators are also slaughtered for their meat, but farmers estimate that the skin accounts for 85 percent of the market value, the meat for 15 percent. Of the 300,000 alligator skins sold worldwide each year, the United States produces 150,000, and most of them come from Louisiana.
But now the recession and the alligator farmers' own successes are posing a threat to alligator farming, whose product begins humbly with egg harvesting in swamps and bayous and ends up in glittering showcases like Hermes or Neiman-Marcus.
The market has become saturated with farm-bred skins 4 to 4 1/2 feet long -- the size on which most of the economic assumptions of alligator farming rest. But tanners, most of whom are overseas, are now seeking 6-to-9-foot skins because high-fashion items like handbags and attache cases require larger skins. In the United States such sizes are available only through annual state-regulated alligator-hunting seasons in Louisiana, Florida and Texas.
Prices for the farm-bred product have declined from a high of $35 a foot two years ago to about $23 a foot now, said Jack Montouncet, president of the Louisiana Alligator Farmers and Ranchers Association.
Don Ashley, a Florida-based consultant in the international market for alligator and other skins, said, "The industry is not on the rocks but it is definitely at a crossroads, and the farmers are going to have to adapt or face bankruptcy."
Among other things, Mr. Ashley said, alligator farmers will have to reorganize their farms to allow for a longer growing time, so they can produce a wider range of skin sizes. This will significantly alter the economics of the business.
In their efforts to adapt, the farmers are likely to look for help from biologists at Grand Chenier, where much of the research on techniques for raising alligators in Louisiana was developed. Grand Chenier, a village six miles inland from the Gulf of Mexico, is near the 85,000-acre state-run Rockefeller Wildlife Refuge in southwestern Louisiana and is 40 miles west of Mr. Stelly's farm at Forked Island.
Since 1963, biologists at the wildlife refuge have studied the alligator and devised ways to control the sex of embryos, methods of accelerating growth, the use of controlled environments to reduce stress, and the most efficient and economic regimens for stocking and feeding the animals.
Ted Joanen, a biologist who has worked on the project for more than 27 years, said the most important finding was that somewhere in the first 14 months after the laying of eggs, 83 percent of the eggs or young animals were lost to predators, storms, starvation, disease or other natural causes.
"There is a tremendous natural mortality in alligators," he said, "and so we recommended that that portion which was going to die in the wild anyway be used to build the farming industry."
Beginning in 1977, biologists at the refuge began scouring the treeless marshes by helicopter, looking for the distinctive brown mounds of dried wire grass and switch cane that are alligator nests.
Since that first harvesting of 10,000 eggs 14 years ago, the effort has grown tremendously. Last year nearly 300,000 eggs were harvested from two million acres of publicly and privately owned marshes and swamps, and sold to alligator farmers.
In that time the wild alligator population in Louisiana has increased from fewer than 200,000 to 750,000 today, Mr. Joanen said.
The preservation of the state's marshes and swamps has been another benefit of alligator farming, he said, adding, "We have managed the alligator as a resource and there has been mutual benefit for us, the animal and the environment."
Although alligator farming is by no means universally endorsed, it has generally been accepted and even applauded by many environmentalists. They see it as a way of productively managing the state's alligator population while creating a strong incentive for maintaining ecologically sensitive habitats.
 
On the Brink of Extinction
 Faced with possible extinction, the alligator was declared an endangered species in 1967, and alligator hunting was banned. As its population rebounded, restrictions on killing them were gradually removed, and in 1987 practically all restrictions disappeared nationally.
"There is still a perception in this country of the alligator as an endangered species," Mr. Ashley said . "At one time we had quality tanning and manufacturing facilities in this country, but with the classification of the alligator as endangered, most of them disappeared."
Fewer than 10 percent of the skins raised in the United States are now processed in the three tanneries that continue to operate in this country. Most are tanned and shaped into finished products in Europe. Seventy percent of the market for those products, Mr. Ashley said, is in Europe or Japan.
But now Mr. Stelly and other farmers fear that their salad days are coming to an end. As he walked among the corrugated metal sheds, he talked of what the future might hold.
"It was a pretty good business up until now," he said. "The price has dropped down, but I'm still moving my skins. I just don't know whether that will continue."
 
An Experiment in Diversity
 As a hedge against worse times, Mr. Stelly has begun to experiment with transferring some of the alligators that are being raised in sheds to outdoor ponds to grow for another year or so, until they are 6 to 7 feet long. In this way, he said, he can diversify his skin sizes without the high investment cost of new year-round heated sheds.
Even in this experiment he is relying on research from Mr. Joanen and other biologists at the refuge to determine the most efficient pond size and the number of alligators to place in each fenced-in pond.
The experiment with growing alligators in outdoor ponds could also lead to the development of his own alligator herd, Mr. Stelly said, if he decides to keep enough alligators until they reach 3 or 4 years of age, when they are old enough to breed.
Mr. Ashley said diversifying in this way would help many farmers weather the current downturn. But he added that he was also working with the state alligator farmers' association in developing a market for smaller skins, to be used in making items like wallets, key cases and compacts.
Mr. Montouncet, the president of the association, said that if the farmers were successful they could open up a bigger market for their expensive products in the United States and create the need for more tanning and manufacturing plants in this country.

The state is well ahead of Florida and Texas, with fewer than 40 farms in all, but a slump is forcing farmers to reassess their methods. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Hampshire Air Base to Close, Draining a City

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEWINGTON, N.H., March 31

 BODY:
Pease Air Force Base, one of the biggest military installations to fall under the Defense Department budget ax three years ago, is about to be the first to close.
The seaside base, which housed 3,700 military personnel and their dependents and employed about 1,000 civilians, will formally close Monday. It was eerily empty last week as the 90 or so people remaining packed to leave. 
 "It feels like a ghost town," said Master Sgt. Steve Campbell, among the last to leave. "It's dead. You go from 9,000 people to less than 100, That feels weird."
Lieut. Col. Harry Mandrose plans a news conference on Monday, his last act as commander of the 4,255-acre base.
 
First to Close
 Pease, which opened in 1956, is the first of 86 military installations nationwide to close under a three-year-old Federal effort to save money. On Monday, the Department of Defense is to make recommendations on closing more military bases, in accordance with a move by Congress last year.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will receive the recommendations and then pass his choices to the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission. Mr. Cheney is scheduled to announce his list at a news conference on April 11, a Pentagon spokesman said today.
President Bush will have until July 15 to approve the list or return it for changes. When he approves the list, it will then go to Congress for final action.
 
Home Base for Bombers
 After the Air Force leaves Pease, the New Hampshire Air National Guard will operate and maintain its airfield.
Pease has been home to the 509th Bombardment Wing, the successor of the 509th Composite Group of the Army Air Forces, which dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. Pease has housed B-29, B-52 and B-47 bombers and has deployed KC-135 refueling tankers and FB-111 fighter-bombers.
Eileen Foley, mayor of adjacent Portsmouth, said the loss to the local economy was far beyond the $340 million a year that the base cost the Federal Government.
Two schools shut down because base children accounted for one-fourth the city's student body. Nearby malls miss business and part-time employees from the base, Ms. Foley said.
"It just has been a very traumatic and dramatic experience for the whole city of Portsmouth, and we're going to miss them," she said.
The military personnel either retired or transferred to other bases.
 
Many Chose Base as Home
 Capt. Howard Snarr, who oversaw the closing, said Pease's location, 60 miles north of Boston on New Hampshire's coast, attracted more than the usual number of military "homesteaders," people who go to a base and stay.
Among them was Sgt. Jim Raggiani, 38 years old, who has been at Pease for five years and is now retiring.
"You're not too far from Boston, you got the ocean and you got the mountains," he said. "It's just an ideal assignment."
While Sergeant Raggiani mourns, 26-year-old Sgt. Chris Davis is glad to be leaving for a base closer to his Michigan home.
Sergeant Davis, a base electrician, said closing was toughest on Pease civilians faced with a weak job market.
"They'll walk into a building and look around," he said. "They'll sigh, they'll shake their heads and walk away."
The state is developing plans for the base that include a commercial airport, just one of many options being discussed for the land.
Pease has 1,500 houses and 1.2 million square feet of commercial, office, industrial and warehouse buildings.
All stand empty today as the last airmen brace to watch the base close.
"Some people were glad to leave. Me personally, I'm sad," Sergeant Raggiani mused. "I mean, this is my last assignment. It's my last hurrah."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1698 words

HEADLINE: Middle-Class Flight Feared By New York City Experts

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
With a job at an advertising agency and a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side, Matthew Luba settled into the life he had looked forward to. He was a New Yorker.
Now just four years later, he and his wife, Alison, who works in publishing, are settling into a contemporary four-bedroom house with a deck and a hot tub in northern Bergen County, N.J. The outdoor furniture is expected soon. 
 "Although I still enjoy many aspects of Manhattan, I don't see the city as a place I'm proud of," Mr. Luba said.
He does not worry about missing his friends. Many of them, he said, are moving from the city too.
 
Powerful Economic Forces
 New York City has long lured young people starting careers and, especially lately, immigrants starting new lives, two powerful economic forces. But it has always had defectors, particularly parents with children nearing school age and parents-to-be, many with middle- and upper-middle-class incomes.
In the postwar decades, when the suburbs were built, and in the 1970's, when the city's economy all but collapsed, the losses mounted. Now some planners and economists say there is a potential for more losses -- not just to the suburbs but also to places beyond the metropolitan region -- which could weaken the city's already fragile tax base and deprive it of people important for an economic revival.
Conditions seem ripe. The city's shrinking economy has resulted in a loss of more than 100,000 jobs since 1987. City Hall is hard pressed to maintain services many already regard as inadequate. The public school system is facing more spending cuts. And as the city becomes a less desirable place, taxes, especially property taxes, will likely rise, making it more expensive.
"When the economy turns down, it accentuates all of the negatives, providing a greater incentive for people here to move and cutting the incentive for people to move to New York," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The city could be caught, he said, by "both blades of the scissors."
Demography seems likely to play an increasingly important role in migration, though which way it cuts is unclear. In the 1990's, the number of New Yorkers between the ages of 35 and 44 is expected to surge by as much as 500,000, depending on how many of them the city holds and attracts. These are people in their prime working -- and tax-paying -- years, but in past decades the city's appeal to this group has been relatively weak.
 
'City Is Very Vulnerable'
 "If the New York economy doesn't snap back and the other regions do, the city is very vulnerable," said Emanuel Tobier, an economics professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. "The group that is in its prime years and is very mobile and willing to move is the one most affected by changes in the New York economy. It was sucked in in the 1980's, and it will move out again if the economy doesn't revive."
In the 1970's New York City lost 216,000 New Yorkers between the ages of 35 and 44 to migration, or nearly 24 percent. In comparison, it lost 2.7 percent of the 25-to-34 age group and 12.6 percent of the 45-to-54 age group.
In the 1980's, a Port Authority analysis of Census Bureau and birth and death records found, the 35-to-44 age group lost 223,000 members, or nearly 27 percent. Meanwhile, migration bolstered the 25-to-34 age group by 23.1 percent, or 279,000. The 45-to-54 age group was stable and the city's overall population grew.
In the 1990's, the Port Authority believes the net rate of migration for the 35-to-44 age group will remain about the same, but because the group as a whole will be larger due to an aging population, the city will lose an estimated 267,000 members of that group, 44,000 more than the previous decade.
Rosemary Scanlon, the Port Authority's chief economist, said the agency had factored two recessions into its projection, which also calls for continued strong in-migration of 25-to-34-year olds. She called it a "neutral forecast' based on assumptions that the city's job base would stabilize and that the suburbs were filling up. But, she added, "If structural conditions or worries over crime are really serious enough to affect people's location decisions, then this number is not going to hold."
The Port Authority does not break down its migration projections by race. But migration is a major factor in the shifting racial composition of the city's population, which for the first time, the Census Bureau reports, now has a majority comprised of minority groups.
 
Understates the Trend
 In the 1980's, the bureau found, non-Hispanic whites declined by 14.2 percent, to 43.2 percent of the population. Non-Hispanic blacks make up 25.2 percent of the population, Hispanic residents 24.4 percent and non-Hispanic Asians 6.9 percent.
City officials say that the census understates the trend and that its count missed hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, mostly minority-group members.
The migration rate is a function of two forces, people moving in and people moving out. Economic data from the 1980 census, the latest such information available, illustrate the impact the process can have on the city. From 1975 to 1980, about one million New Yorkers moved away and about 645,000 moved in, leaving a gap of 355,000. About 377,000 of those moving out had household incomes of $25,000 or more, but only 172,000 in that income group moved in. So out-migration was substantially higher among the affluent.
Of the one million people moving to New York State during that time, more than 40 percent were from Puerto Rico or abroad. Many of those people, who tended to have lower incomes, settled in New York City. In fact, the only income group for which more people moved into the city than left it had incomes below $10,000.
 
Two-Income Families
 In the long run, New York City's migration patterns will be shaped by the degree to which its faltering economy rebounds. It may also be that the increase in two-income families will slow departures, since those families might have to sacrifice a paycheck, spend twice as much time commuting or find two new jobs instead of one.
In the short run, the real-estate market seems likely to have an influence. The current weak market may trap New Yorkers in hard-to-sell cooperative apartments, while lower housing prices may lure others to the city. Then again, prices have fallen elsewhere, and the drop in mortgage rates may be an added temptation for city renters.
A compilation of out-of-state moves by nine major moving companies by the Household Goods Carrier Bureau, a trade association, appears to document both the soft real-estate market and the city's declining desirability. The number of moves to and from New York City has actually dropped from a peak in 1987, when there were 18,200 moves out and 13,149 moves in. Last year, there were 14,991 moves out and 8,772 moves in. But the ratio of outbound to inbound moves, which was 1.4 to 1 in 1986, stood at 1.7 to 1 by 1990.
The figures generally reflect moves paid for by corporations and more affluent individuals.
 
'More New York License Plates'
 The city's rising ratio of outbound moves suggests that as the housing market becomes more active, out-migration may have more impact. There may already be hints of this.
"There are a lot more New York license plates in our parking lot on the weekends," said Carol Rothe, vice president of the William F. Higgins agency in Hillsdale, N.J. She says New Yorkers are telling her they have decided to skip the next step -- moving to a larger apartment in the city -- and buy a house outside the city.
She could have been describing Mr. Luba, who lived in Manhattan briefly in the mid-80's, then spent two years in Chicago before returning to New York in 1987. He and his wife plan to have a family.
When the sponsor dropped out of the plan to convert their West End Avenue building to condominiums, they realized there was not enough to keep them in a city that Mr. Luba says is so dirty it "embarrasses him."
 
Did Not Want the Risk
 Even so, economics propelled the move to Bergen County. Having seen the effects of the city's slow real-estate market, the Lubas decided they did not want to risk buying a larger apartment and being trapped in it when they wanted to move a few years from now.
"I think it makes very good business sense," Mr. Luba said. "I'm really buying the house for the long term."
In past decades, the suburbs, which offered better schools and room for families to grow, lured people and jobs from the city. But the Household Carrier Association compilation, which did not include moves within New York State, found that in 1990 the states to which New York City residents were most likely to move were Florida and California. Connecticut and New Jersey ranked 12th and 13th, respectively, and migration rates from both those states have also been rising.
Partly because of its loss of middle- and upper-middle-class residents, the city has kept tax rates on one-, two-, and three-family homes down, at least relative to the burdens on commercial property. New York has held on to its middle class better than some other cities, and its economy flourished even after the exodus of the 70's. But now, there is strong pressure to increase property taxes, and business leaders are already complaining about the city's high costs.
New York City, then, is facing both large budget deficits and unhappy choices. Raise taxes on houses and risk alienating homeowners. Raise taxes on commercial property and risk driving out more businesses and jobs. Cut spending and reduce services and risk making the city even less desirable.
A few weeks ago, Vincent Tese, director of economic development for New York State, released a "worry list" of businesses concerned about conditions and costs in the city, including Smith Barney, Morgan Stanley, Prudential-Bache Securities, Bear Stearns and the Paramount Corporation.
"There are a lot of empty buildings here," he said of New York City. "There's a quiet exodus going on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York's shrinking economy, loss of jobs, reduction of city services and school budget cuts are some of the reasons people are leaving the city, economists say. HEADLINE: Fight to Save Salmon Starts Fight Over Water

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALMON, Idaho, March 27

 BODY:
A shout away from the point on the Continental Divide where Lewis and Clark crested the Rockies in 1805, another of the American West's wonder creatures is about to become extinct.
Like the bison, wolf and grizzly bear before it, the Pacific salmon has all but disappeared from this part of the country. Last year, only a single sockeye salmon made it to the alpine spawning grounds here, 900 river miles inland from the Pacific. 
 This Tuesday, the Federal Government is expected to propose that sockeye salmon and certain other strains of Pacific salmon be listed as endangered or threatened species, setting in motion a process that could affect electricity rates down the West Coast, economic prosperity in Seattle and Portland and growers of some of the nation's most bountiful agricultural crops.
 
Death in Dams' Turbines
 In simplest terms, the issue is water. The Columbia River, the West's biggest river in volume, was once a passageway for up to 16 million salmon a year. Now the river is backed up by a series of dams that deliver the cheapest electrical rates in the country but kill fish in astonishing numbers.
When mature salmon journey from ocean to spawning ground, they use fish ladders built into the dams to climb from low water to high. But young salmon, trying to make it downstream and out to sea, die by the hundreds of thousands in the dam's turbines, or waste away in the slack water behind the dams because there is not enough current to help them along.
The modern Northwest of airplane factories and irrigated orchards was built with power from Columbia River water. To save the salmon, the Columbia would have to behave like a river again, biologists say, and that could be accomplished by allowing water held back by the dams to flush through in a single surge every spring.
 
Symbol of the Northwest
 More than eight million acre feet of water, or enough to flood four Yellowstone Parks to a one-foot depth, would be needed to help flush the fish downstream during the spring migration, the experts say.
But most of that water is already spoken for, by utilities, farmers, water-skiers, cities. The consortium of public utilities that markets power from the Columbia has said electricity rates could rise by up to 33 percent if it has to greatly change the way it uses the dams.
"The salmon is the ultimate symbol of the Pacific Northwest," said Gov. Cecil D. Andrus of Idaho. "These stalwarts have fought all the obstacles we've put before them in order to return to the spawning grounds of their birth. We ought to be ashamed of ourselves if we can't save them."
The inclusion of five salmon species -- the Snake River sockeye, three kinds of upriver chinook, or king, and one downriver coho -- may be proposed for the endangered list. From California through Washington, nearly 200 strains of wild salmon are facing extinction, but the Columbia River salmon, gloried because of their size and importance to the region, are the first to be considered for an endangered designation.
If the designation becomes formal, a process that can take a year, the National Marine Fisheries Services will be able to order changes in dam operations, new limits on fishing or whatever else it may deem necessary to save the salmon. But officials who hope to avoid a drawn-out fight like the one over the northern spotted owl last year have been trying to devise a rescue plan before one is imposed.
 
'It Will Require Sacrifice'
 "Everybody west of the Mississippi who turns on a light switch is in some ways responsible for what happened and may in some ways end up paying for it," said Rolland A. Schmitten, the Western director of the National Marine Fisheries Services. "This doesn't mean we are going to start closing down dams or shutting down the whole West Coast fishery, but it will require sacrifice."
Worldwide, there is no shortage of salmon. Millions of them are raised on farms and are common in markets and restaurants on both coasts.
But what is at stake here are the huge and mysterious wild Pacific salmon, the source of Indian prosperity for nearly 10,000 years, and a fisherman's dream. In a ritual that scientists have yet to fully understand, but one that Indians consider a miracle from God, the fish return from years in the oceans to the cold mountain streams of their birth, where they spawn and die in the very spot where they were born.
It was one Idaho tribe, the Shoshone-Bannock, that set in motion the endangered species process when it petitioned the Government last year. Guaranteed by treaty the right to fish for salmon, the tribe has seen the fishes' numbers dwindle from the thousands to a mere handful -- not even enough for its annual religious ceremony.
 
'Basically Gone' in a Lifetime
 Here on the Continental Divide, the highest point the fish can reach as instinct drives them relentlessly upstream, sometimes to elevations of 7,000 feet, most Pacific salmon have disappeared.
In this town, thousands of miners used to be fed by the returning hordes of fish, which swam up the Columbia and its two big tributaries, the Snake and Salmon Rivers, to get here. Residents can show old pictures of families gathered around a fresh-caught fish as big as a 10-year-old boy.
"It makes me kind of embarrassed to live in a town called Salmon and manage a lake called Redfish when the things they are named for are basically gone," said Jim Lukens, a biologist with the Idaho Department of Fish and Game. "In one generation's time, we've managed to nearly kill this species that lived for 10,000 years."
The fish fascinated Lewis and Clark, who wrote glowing accounts of the Indian tribes here living off the wealth of returning salmon runs, as reliable as the seasons.
 
Dams the Biggest Killers
 Most biologists agree that the decline of certain runs of Pacific salmon could have been avoided. Although salmon are overfished in the ocean, taken by Americans off the coast and Japanese drift netters at sea, the biggest killers are the dams, which are operated by the Army Corps of Engineers.
From 1938 to 1975, eight Federal dams were built on the lower Columbia and Snake Rivers. They provide electricity for all the major cities of the Northwest, at a cost 40 percent below the national average. Heavy runoff from the mountains each spring enables the generation of surplus electricity for sale to Southern California, and the backed-up water is diverted to irrigate about 6.5 million acres in the Northwest that would otherwise be barren of fruits or vegetables.
With every new dam that went up, the salmon runs dwindled. Today, most of the Columbia fish come from hatcheries not far from Portland, Ore. But the future of the hatcheries, which propagate the fish by artificial means, is dependent on the variety of the genetic pool, and the wild upstream stocks of chinook and sockeye salmon are in the most trouble.
The policy makers who have been trying to restore fish runs have "been trying to play God, and now they realize they're not too good at it," said Bill Bakke, director of Oregon Trout, a conservation group.
 
Needed: More Water
 The dams, particularly four newer ones on the Snake River, are "a near-perfect fish-killing machine," said Edward Chaney, a resource consultant in Eagle, Idaho. "The fish are trapped by what is arguably the most costly and socially destructive engineering screw-up in the history of mankind."
Ten years ago, Congress ordered the utilities that use the dams to devise a plan for doubling the salmon runs. A billion dollars later, the companies have not met that goal. Some screens have been put up to keep fish out of the turbines. The Corps of Engineers' preferred method of saving fish has been to transport the young salmon downstream by barge or haul them by truck.
But what is really needed, say biologists, is more free-flowing water to strengthen the current in the spring. Before the 1930's, when the river was undammed, it would take a young fish about a week to make the 900-mile journey from Salmon to the sea, Federal studies found. Now, it takes about six weeks, and up to 97 percent of the fish that leave the spawning grounds die before they make it to the mouth of the Columbia.
In Governor Andrus's view, the ideal solution would be to eliminate certain dams. As a State Senator in 1964, he ceremoniously set off an explosion that blew up an obsolete dam in his state. This year, he proposed lowering the reservoirs of four Snake River dams to strengthen the currents. At a recent conference on the salmon problem -- where states, the Federal Government, utilities, fishermen, barge operators and virtually every other entity with an interest in the rivers was represented -- most participants agreed with the Idaho proposal.
 
Corps Stalls One Plan
 But the Corps of Engineers has refused to even test the plan. "There is no question the dams are a big part of the problem," said Wit Anderson, a corps manager on the Columbia River, "but everybody should have to make a sacrifice, not just us." He said the Snake River reservoirs could not be lowered because they were not designed to operate that way.
The corps's reluctance has drawn angry responses. "The Corps of Engineers continues to hide behind a bureaucratic curtain and pretend that it has no responsibility to change the very operations which are killing these fish," said Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. "I hope the decision makers in the Corps of Engineers wake up and realize that time is running out." The next migration begins in April.
Compared with the fight over the spotted owl, there has been very little opposition to saving salmon. Surveys and public hearings suggest that a large majority of people are willing to make some sacrifice to bring back the wild fish that used to swim in nearly every western-draining stream in the Northwest.
"This great river here is called the Salmon," said Gary Power, an Idaho Fish and Game biologist. "I hope the name doesn't become Our Mistake."

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Confidence and Will

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The Economist of London reports on the United States with more care and insight than any other foreign journal -- or most American papers. When it analyzes a large subject, it speaks with the sympathy of a friend but the detachment of a realist.
In the current issue The Economist has an extended article on blacks in America. It summarizes its conclusions in this statement: 
 "America is riding high on a wave of post-Gulf confidence, but one part of the country is still missing out: the poverty-ridden ghettos where millions of black Americans live. George Bush cannot afford to ignore them."
During the Persian Gulf war, some of us wondered aloud why it was that the United States could bring so much energy and commitment to war and so little, comparatively, to domestic problems. A President who had fumbled or avoided challenges at home was utterly decisive in the gulf conflict. An inert public became engaged.
Such comment was dismissed on the political right as the thinking of wimps or sob-sisters. But it is not so easy thus to dismiss The Economist, a magazine with a conservative outlook that expressed few doubts about the war.
The survey of black America begins with some statistics. They are familiar but still chilling.
The unemployment rate for blacks last year was 10.5 percent, twice that of whites. The leading cause of death among young black men in America is murder. By the official definition of poverty, 43 percent of black children are born poor. Two-thirds of black babies are born to unmarried mothers.
There is also a great black success story. In the last 30 years a black middle class has developed, growing from a tenth to more than a third of the black population.
The Economist does not explore how that happened, but it was undoubtedly the result at least in part of the removal of racial barriers. Blacks are welcome now in law firms and banks and other places where they were hardly ever seen before.
But while a middle class has grown, the picture has not improved at the lower end of the scale. About a third of all blacks live below the poverty line, a proportion unchanged for 20 years. An underclass made up in considerable part of blacks lives in decayed areas of America's inner cities.
One feature of ghetto life has grown strikingly worse in the last generation. The old Harlem had among its residents lawyers and businessmen and other leading figures: role models for the young and poor. Now they have virtually all left for desegregated middle-class neighborhoods.
That point was first made to me by Roger Wilkins, who contrasted growing up among authentic leaders as he did with the hopelessness and crime that are pervasive today. The Economist quotes William Julius Wilson of the University of Chicago to the same effect.
Poor inner-city neighborhoods, Professor Wilson says, now lack even the basic social models of responsibility and work. There are few jobs available, and vogue ideas such as enterprise zones seem to have little lasting effect.
The ghettos are a world apart, its young people growing up physically and psychologically separated from the American mainstream. But they deeply affect that mainstream, the quality of urban life, the economics of our cities and states. We are all in the same country.
Liberal and conservative Americans, white and black, probably agree more than they realize now on how to approach the daunting problems of the ghetto. Most would put more emphasis on jobs and job training and work incentives. Most would reject the ideas of black separatism. Most would do more for the health of poor children, and for their education in ways that work, like Head Start.
Why, then, is there no national commitment to fight the ills of the ghetto and the underclass? It cannot just be a shortage of money; we found money for the gulf war. It cannot be that wars have more definite objectives and neater endings; we are finding out in Iraq what a delusion that is.
No, the reason we do so little about our greatest domestic problem is a lack of political will: of courage. Perhaps our political leaders can take advice better from a friend abroad. Here is the way the Economist article ends:
"The slums in America's great cities are shameful. They are a damning indictment of the richest country in the world. The problems that fester in them are not peripheral; they constitute America's main domestic challenge today. . . .
"George Bush could now cash in on the country's post-war confidenceby launching another war on the black home-front. America cannot afford to let down its blacks for much longer."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
