HEADLINE: Price Fixing Isn't Always Gouging

 BODY:
Should a manufacturer ever be allowed to stop a retailer from cutting prices? No, said the Supreme Court in 1911, declaring any such attempts automatically illegal. No, say many consumers, fearing the demise of their favorite discounter.
But over the past decade many economists, and lately the Supreme Court, have come to a different conclusion: Minimum prices imposed by manufacturers -- known as vertical price restraints -- can sometimes help consumers by encouraging dealers to provide valuable information and services. 
 In two decisions during the 1980's, the Supreme Court ruled that efforts by manufacturers to prevent price cuts by dealers were not always illegal; in some circumstances, the question of whether the practice discriminated against the consumer was to be answered on a case-by-case basis.
Senator Howard Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat, is pushing a bill that would again make vertical price restraints illegal in virtually every case. At one time this page favored Mr. Metzenbaum's bill. But recent studies suggest that a blanket prohibition could be legislative overkill.
Vertical price restraints can be anti-consumer when rival dealers conspire to fix prices and use manufacturer-imposed price restraints to enforce the deal. Price restraints can also be used by rival manufacturers jointly to keep prices high. But these practices aren't common and would violate the antitrust laws with or without the Metzenbaum bill.
If manufacturers were trying to jack up prices, they wouldn't ordinarily use vertical price restraints. All they would need to do is charge all their dealers more. The purpose of vertical price restraints is to encourage better service to customers.
Buyers of products like computers and cameras need advice and information before making the purchase. Dealers who provide that service do so at considerable expense and risk. Consumers, educated for free, are then tempted to make the actual purchase, for a bare-bones price, from discounters who provide no such information. That can drive full-service dealers out of the market.
Manufacturers can help full-service dealers -- to the extent the law allows -- by prohibiting price cutting. That leaves dealers no other option than to compete for customers with better service. Yet not many manufacturers sell products that require extensive pre-sale services; most will continue to profit from sales to discount stores.
Mr. Metzenbaum argues for a blanket prohibition because a case-by-case review of vertical price restraints would be too impractical. Customers would not suffer, he claims, because the bill would not forbid manufacturers from requiring all dealers to provide information and marketing services. But case-by-case review of such non-price restraints would be every bit as difficult, probably harder.
Discounters have thrived despite the Supreme Court rulings. The system isn't broke; consumers aren't threatened. There are, however, circumstances when manufacturers have legitimate grounds for protecting full-service dealers. They should have the right.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: New York Can Handle Cuts Better Than Taxes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York State and City are running in place on their budget gaps, you report (news article, March 19). You quote "analysts" as saying -- straightforwardly, I would add -- that there is no comprehensive strategy for dealing with the budget crisis. On the contrary, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget makes difficult choices that nevertheless leave the essence of the state enterprise intact. 
 Yet some of the arguments that have crept into the debate are more insidious, masquerading as one thing and actually promoting an entirely different agenda. For example, the Citizens Budget Commission manages to sound responsible on the surface, but read carefully, its arguments show the bias of a group that is essentially anchored in Manhattan and does not represent the interests of the entire state. When Charles Brecher, research director for the commission, states, "Solving the Governor's budget problem with aid cuts is simply passing the problem onto the city and other localities," and "We should be shifting more of the tax burden onto a statewide basis," the real message is: let the rest of the state help keep New York City's real estate taxes down.
It's important to remember that any strategy raising broad-based income, sales and business taxes would damage the state's competitiveness in the long run, and on top of city taxes, would be particularly ruinous for New York City. Even with the cuts proposed by the Governor in his budget, New York will remain among the top five states in school spending; it will continue to have one of the best and most affordable systems of higher education in the country, and it will continue to be the most generous state in the country with total assistance to the arts.
The proposed spending cuts are painful, but the alternative of increasing broad-based taxes is downright dangerous.
 
VINCENT TESE
Director of Economic Development
New York, March 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Stocks Rose Broadly in Quarter

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The stock market just completed one of its strongest quarters since 1980. Investors, who stood on the sidelines after Iraq invaded Kuwait, gleefully dived back into the equity markets in the first quarter, which ended last week, after the American-led assault in the gulf seemed a success.
"This was the fourth-best quarter in the last 11 years," said Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of the Wall Street research house Birinyi Associates. "Given the kind of breadth, momentum and other indicators we have seen, you are not talking about a short-term or trading rally -- you are talking about a sustained market rise." 
 While a number of investment strategists do not believe that Wall Street's bears have been driven away by a stampede of bulls, there is a strong sense among traders and other experts that the market may have bottomed out amid the tension preceeding the Persian Gulf war.
 
Widespread Gains
 The rise was almost everywhere. Of the 3,604 stocks tracked by Media General Financial Services, 3,029 were up in the first quarter, while 480 were down and 95 were unchanged.
New York Stock Exchange issues were a strong beneficiary. Media General said that among the Big Board stocks on its list, 1,272 were up, with 165 down and 22 unchanged. The over-the-counter market also did well, with 1,400 stocks higher at the end of the quarter, 259 lower and 64 unchanged.
The performance of issues on the American Stock Exchange was similar. Media General said 357 issues on the Amex rose while 56 issues fell and 9 were unchanged.
But unlike many winners of the last decade, the gainers' success stemmed more from the fundamentals of the companies than from potential takeovers.
"The most pleasant aspect of the market's performance is that companies once again are being valued on their worth as performers, as operating companies, rather than on their vulnerability to a leveraged buyout or a takeover," said Jack A. Sullivan, a principal with Van Kasper & Company, a San Francisco-based investment bank and brokerage. "Good company performances are being rewarded no matter what the sector, and that is a very pleasant and healthy sign. At the same time, bad performances are being punished, and that also is a healthy sign."
Several trends emerged. A number of companies benefited either directly from business from the gulf war or from perceptions that they would get business because of the conflict.
Another trend was the rapid growth in companies involved in health care, including the top five performers on the American Stock Exchange. The gains reflected the generally frothy trading in health-care issues. While there were only 28 initial public offerings in the quarter, 5, totaling $112.9 million, were for health-care concerns, according to the Securities Data Company.
The big winner on the New York Stock Exchange was a retail company that survived the takeover battles of the 1980's. Venture Stores, once a division of the May Department Stores Company, operates more than 75 retail discount stores in the Midwest. The company has benefited from a trend toward discount stores, and its sales increased 10 percent in February compared with February 1990.
Despite the company's strong fundamentals, much of the gain came in a flurry of trading last week. Company officials said they had no corporate news to account for the advance.
One winner from the Persian Gulf war was Martech USA Inc., which provides a range of environmental cleanup services. The company, based in Anchorage, is known for its oil-spill response services. After the huge spill in the Persian Gulf, speculation swept the marketplace that the company could get contracts for cleanup work. The predictions proved correct.
The biggest loser on the Big Board was Laidlaw Inc., a solid-waste-services company that was hit by a flurry of bad news in the quarter. In March, company executives said that earnings for the second quarter would likely decline by more than 50 percent from the 1990 period, partly because of a slowing economy.
But Laidlaw, based in Burlington, Ontario, had other serious problems. Its waste-management subsidiary was accused of uncompetitive business practices by the Canadian Government. Canada's Bureau of Competition Policy said the contracts in question were unenforceable.
At the same time, Donald Jackson, president of Laidlaw, was reported to be facing civil charges of breach of trust. Trimac Ltd., based in Calgary, Alberta, was said to be suing Mr. Jackson for $20 million (Canadian), or $17.2 million (United States), for his handling of the 1986 sale of Trimac's waste-management subsidiary to Laidlaw.
At the American Stock Exchange, the biggest winner for the quarter was Medco Research Inc., a Los Angeles-based drug research and development company. Medco, which moved to the Amex from the over-the-counter market during the quarter, introduced a drug that it hopes will be used to replace cardiac treadmill tests for some heart patients, Medco also expects its first European sales this fall.
In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company showed that the rise in price occurred even as two corporate insiders were selling a combined total of more than 70,000 shares in the company.
Also, at the beginning of the quarter the company reported that the S.E.C. was conducting an informal fact-finding inquiry into the trading of Medco's stock on the over-the-counter market. In the filing, Medco said it had also asked the S.E.C. to investigate the activities of short sellers of the company's stock. Short sellers sell borrowed stock in anticipation of buying back an equal number of shares later at a lower price, thus making a profit. The filing did not elaborate on either inquiry.
 
A Biotech Winner
 The American exchange's biggest loser was Winthrop Insured Mortgage Investors II, a limited partnership, which agreed during the quarter to sell all of its remaining assets. The assets, six federally insured mortgages, were purchased from the partnership by the First Boston Corporation. The sale will result in a distribution of cash to shareholders, and the fund will be terminated.
On the over-the-counter market, the biggest winner was again a company in the health-care industry, Interpharm Laboratories Ltd. That Israeli company develops and produces biotechnology products for the health-care industry. The company showed strong earnings at the end of last year, compared with a loss in 1989.
The strong performance was spurred by penetration for its products in Italy. Also, the use of a new growth hormone manufactured by Interpharm, which is used in children with hormonal deficiencies, has soared in recent months.
Perhaps the biggest mystery of the quarter involved a company that was one of the biggest losers on the over-the-counter market. The Y & A Group, a St. Louis-based engineering concern specializing in electric utilities, saw its stock tumble when its president and chief executive, Malcolm Cheek, disappeared in March.
The disappearance, which prompted an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, came three days before the company disclosed that it expected a loss of $7 million for 1990, including $1 million of nonrecurring costs and up to $4 million of write-offs. The company had been profitable in 1989.
The news at Y & A came after the company decided in October to dismiss Deloitte & Touche as its independent accounting firm. In December, the firm hired KPMG Peat Marwick as its auditor.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 3, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about the performance of stocks in the first quarter misapplied The Times's guidelines in citing two stocks among the worst performers on the American Stock Exchange.
The prices of both Winthrop Insured Mortgage L.P. and GW Utilities fell because of extraordinary dividend payments, and investors in the companies did not suffer large losses. The Times's practice is to take such large payouts into account, removing companies from the lists.

HEADLINE: Oranjestad Journal;
Uneasy Caribbean Islands Warm to Motherlands

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ORANJESTAD, Aruba

 BODY:
In 1986, this small, scrubby island just off the coast of Venezuela broke away from an association of self-administered Dutch Caribbean possessions and confidently set out on a path expected to lead to full independence within 10 years.
But five years later, for all their satisfaction in having their own Governor, Prime Minister and flag, few among Aruba's 68,000 mostly prosperous residents, including the leaders of the governing party, now say they are prepared to see their island leave the Kingdom of the Netherlands in a final step toward complete autonomy. 
 Aruba's reluctance to become fully independent, far from an isolated case, reflects a sharp change in attitudes that has swept the Caribbean region, where the greatest number of the world's remaining nonindependent territories are clustered.
In all of the region's remaining European dependencies, including Aruba and its five former sister islands of the Netherlands Antilles, and Britain's six remaining islands, the cry for independence, for decades an unquestioned goal in third-world politics, has given way to an open desire to remain somehow attached to a colonizing power.
"What we are witnessing is the unraveling of a whole mental mindset," said Anthony P. Maingot, an expert on Caribbean politics at Florida International University in Miami. "Independence was once looked at in a linear way, with the assumption that everyone would seek it. Now, rather than a birthright, people are seeing it as a remedial right used to redress specific grievances like racism or oppression, and clearly not everyone out there wants it."
 
Idea 'Has Become Pretty Old'
 In the French departments of Guadeloupe, Martinique and French Guiana, whose incorporation by Paris in 1946 once faced loud, sporadically violent opposition, powerful independence movements have also lost much of their steam.
"The idea of independence has become pretty old here," said Jean-Pierre Chardon, a professor of geography and economics at the University of the Antilles and Guiana, in Martinique. "No one demands independence with any violence or urgency anymore."
While advocates of independence remain active in many of those islands, almost everywhere in recent years their cause has become politically unpopular. In many cases, the only remaining pressure for independence these days is the discreet, occasional prodding of colonial administrators in London and The Hague eager to trim expenses, which has provoked stiff resistance from their possessions.
"The British Virgin Islands will not be bullied, provoked, coerced or sweet-mouthed into independence," Ralph T. O'Neal, deputy chief minister for labor, said at a United Nations conference on decolonization last year in Barbados, capturing the mood of many islands that are not independent.
 
Some Expenses Are Spared
 For each of the French departments in this hemisphere, it has been estimated that well over half of all revenues come through Government employment or aid.
Like the Dutch dependencies, all of the British territories are spared expenses in areas like defense, education and anti-drug efforts by extensive cooperation programs with the colonizing power.
Diplomats in Britain say some of its dependencies, like Bermuda and the Cayman Islands, have per capita incomes that rival many developed countries and receive no direct financial aid. Others, like the British Virgin Islands and Anguilla, receive modest financial support.
The United States Senate recently killed a bill that would have authorized a referendum on the future of Puerto Rico, allowing the people there to choose between statehood and continued Commonwealth status -- according to opinion polls, the two most popular options -- or independence. Opinion surveys in the neighboring United States Virgin Islands, an unincorporated territory, have suggested that support for outright independence there is weak too.
Faced with the uncertainties common to thinly diversified economies and wary of threats as varied as takeover by drug cartels or violent coup attempts, residents of many islands throughout the region see continuing close ties with the colonizer as a bulwark against instability and decay.
The experience of Aruba, which last year successfully lobbied the Netherlands to cancel an agreement that would have automatically led to independence in 1996, reflects that of many of the region's territories.
Shortly after breaking away from the Netherlands Antilles in 1986, the island's leading employer, an Exxon oil refinery, closed, suddenly depriving Aruba of about half of its income. While the island has largely recovered by aggressively promoting tourism, its brush with insolvency created lasting doubts about going it alone in the world.
 
Close to the Ideal
 For the left-leaning Aruban Government, which already enjoys broad autonomy over political and fiscal matters, leaving responsibility for foreign affairs, defense and judiciary appeals to the Dutch approaches the ideal.
"To put it as simply as possible, we would like for the time being for things to remain as they are," said Franklin Oduber, the spokesman for the Aruban Government and brother of the Prime Minister. "I don't think many Arubans are anxious to get rid of the Dutch."
In Britain's seven remaining possessions in the region, including Bermuda, which is in the Atlantic Ocean, north of the Caribbean, independence movements have also fizzled.
Tony Thorndike, a Caribbean expert and chairman of the department of international affairs and politics at Staffordshire Polytechnic in England, said the remaining British dependencies "look at the post-independence experience of the surrounding islands, like Grenada, with its revolutionary violence, and Antigua, which is scandal-ridden, and don't particularly like what they see."
"Seek ye first the political kingdom has become rather passe," he said.

HEADLINE: In Europe, Too, Auto Sales Sag

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 1

 BODY:
Executives of Europe's major car manufacturers speak of the Germans these days with reverence, and for good reason: The booming German market is all that separates the European car industry from disaster.
Those who speak most reverently are executives of Volkswagen A.G. and the General Motors Corporation, whose companies are the strongest there. But with sagging markets elsewhere, those companies depending on the rest of Western Europe for most of their sales are threatened with a tough, if not terrible, year. 
 Industry executives expect 1991 car sales to fall by a range of 400,000 to 600,000, to about 12.9 million, for the first decline since 1984. Weakness was already evident last year, when sales rose by just 20,000, although the total of 13.42 million was a record. Excluding eastern German sales of 200,000, the count would have been off 1.6 percent.
 
Further Drop in Profits
 Price-cutting has hurt profits. Philip N. Ayton, an analyst at London-based Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Ltd., estimates that the combined European income of the Big Six producers -- Volkswagen, Fiat, Peugeot, General Motors, Ford and Renault -- fell by 27 percent in 1990, to $6.07 billion. "Profits could drop by 35 to 40 percent more this year," he said.
Car sales outside Germany fell 15 percent for the first two months of the year. "Margins are under pressure," said Giuseppe Perlo, vice president for marketing and product development at Fiat.
Profits from Europe are crucial for General Motors and the Ford Motor Company, which are expected to have huge losses in the United States this year. General Motors Europe reported record net income of $1.91 billion last year, ousting Ford as the fourth-largest seller of cars there. Ford of Europe -- plagued by a weak British market, strikes, a rough introduction for its new Escort and a loss of about 50 million ($96 million) at its Jaguar unit -- saw its net income plunge by nearly 88 percent last year, to $145 million.
Some analysts expect Ford to lose hundreds of millions of dollars this year. But L. Lindsey Halstead, chairman of Ford of Europe, predicts his division will earn more than in 1990. "I don't expect any phenomenal surge in finances, but I expect it to be a better year," he said.
Mr. Halstead said Ford remained committed to Jaguar's ambitious plans to develop new models, although Jaguar executives said they would delay some capital expenditures rather than ask Ford for more money.
G.M. is faring better, helped by a 17.9 percent market share in Germany last year that was second only to Volkswagen's 26.8 percent. Of the six major car makers in Western Europe, "we and Volkswagen are the only people whose factories are running full out," said Robert J. Eaton, president of General Motors Europe. G.M.'s two major European brands are Opel on the Continent and Vauxhall in Britain.
 
Saab Drain on G.M.
 With orders for more than 300,000 cars in Germany, G.M. executives hope to have nearly as good a year in Western Europe as in 1990, when they sold a record 1.6 million cars.
Mr. Eaton hesitated to predict higher earnings this year, but said that Saab Automobile A.B. would "very definitely not" drain G.M. as much as in 1990. G.M.'s half-ownership of the floundering Swedish company reduced G.M. Europe's earnings by $430 million last year.
Total new car sales in Germany, which totaled nearly 3.3 million in 1990, are now zipping along at an annual rate of 3.8 million to 4 million, said Louis R. Hughes, chairman of G.M.'s Opel division.
The German market's strength comes from monetary union and reunification, which allowed former East Germans to convert their savings into West German marks and buy Western cars. Although few eastern Germans can afford new cars, they have been snapping up used cars from western Germans, who, in turn, are buying new cars with a passion. The small Volkswagen Golf hatchback and G.M.'s small Opel Kadett are the nation's two biggest sellers.
Volkswagen's chairman, Carl Hahn, said his company had a five-to-six-month backlog of orders in Germany and had been increasing VW's share of several other markets. "It is always dangerous to forecast, but I daresay that our production to the end of the year is already sold," he said.
The German market is expected to cool in the second half of the year, a result of tax increases and rising unemployment in eastern Germany. By then, car executives hope for a rebound in the rest of Western Europe that will continue into 1992.
Executives hope the Persian Gulf war's end will bolster consumer confidence. "The gulf war had a dramatic effect on sales," said Frederic Saint-Geours, deputy director general of the Peugeot car division of France's Peugeot S.A. Executives also hope that high interest rates in Britain, Spain, Sweden and other nations will continue their recent declines.
 
Sales Plunge Not Ruled Out
 Some analysts are far more pessimistic. John Lawson, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd., said this year could turn into a catastrophe. Sales could plunge by 9 percent, or 1.2 million cars, he said. "Normally a drop of 6 or 7 percent is as bad as it gets," he said.
Even if other, weaker markets do rebound, it may come too late for those heavily dependent on markets outside Germany. Fiat, Peugeot, Ford, Renault, Volvo and Jaguar have all announced or begun production cuts, affecting more than 130,000 workers. Analysts predict lower earnings or large losses.
Many of these companies are also suffering from increased sales by the Japanese, who have more than 10 percent of the market. Toyota and Nissan have plants in Britain, while Ford and Mazda have formed a partnership to produce cars in Germany.
Outside Germany, car companies are battling for customers with rebates, low- and even no-interest loans and free optional equipment. And analysts say these wars could intensify as those who have been reluctant to join the fray decide they have no choice.
 
Fiat's Uncertain Fate
 "We had been very cautious on incentives but we recently decided to be more aggressive not only in Spain, France and Italy but everywhere in Europe," said Patrick Bessy, a Renault spokesman.
Industry executives and analysts continue to wonder whether Fiat, which has held merger talks over the years with a slew of major car makers, will be able to survive alone for long. The Italian company depends heavily on its home market, which accounts for 60 to 70 percent of its car sales.
While the Japanese are limited by quotas that allowed them only 2.1 percent of the Italian market last year, others are attacking. Fiat's share has sunk to about 48 percent, from 60 percent four years ago.
It also remains to be seen whether Volvo's alliance and cross investments with the larger Renault will enable both to survive independently. The share of the West European car market held by Renault, the state-controlled French company, dropped below 10 percent last year, as its worldwide earnings plunged 87 percent, to 1.21 billion francs ($236 million), from a record 9.29 billion francs ($1.61 billion) in 1989.
Volvo, hurt by the high costs of concentrating its plants in Sweden, is weaker, competitors say. Heavily dependent, like Saab, on the depressed American, British and Swedish markets, Volvo's car operations lost 855 million kronor ($149.5 million) last year and the division plans to cut its work force by 15 percent, or 4,500 people.
Many companies worry that their best days are past. Virtually everyone is optimistic that the unification of the European market will stimulate demand and that Eastern Europeans will eventually buy far more western cars.
But many in the industry say that everyone is invading everyone else's turf. Competition, capacity expansions and mounting Japanese ambitions in Europe could prevent the Big Six auto makers from enjoying the benefits of a growing market.
"I feel we are about to be bottoming out but we are quite hesitant to predict what kind of recovery there will be," said Dan Werbin, a Volvo executive vice president.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Hospital Pacts With Specialists

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
STATE courts have been redefining the professional rights of specialist physicians who have been barred from hospital facilities when their exclusive contracts were ended. The hospitals have usually prevailed but some state courts have sided with the doctors.
Hospital executives say they have the right, like any business, to award or cancel exclusive franchises for services, typically to run hospital operations like laboratories, X-ray facilities and emergency rooms. But the doctors say they, too, have rights, under the medical staff bylaws adopted by hospitals, which govern the appointments and professional activities of doctors in hospitals. 
 The court cases have pitted radiologists, anesthesiologists, pathologists and emergency room physicians against hospitals seeking to increase their share of the lucrative revenues that flow to the specialists. Until the mid-1980's, these physicians were usually employees of the hospitals. But then most hospitals encouraged them to become independent contractors as a business tactic, when the Federal Medicare program changed the basis of paying for hospital care.
Dr. Howard L. Lang, chairman of the hospital medical staff section of the American Medical Association, said physicians were increasingly concerned about hospitals that used economic criteria in deciding whether to let doctors use their facilities. Dr. Lang, a Greenbrae, Calif., obstetrician and gynecologist, said some hospitals even seemed to be refusing credentials to doctors viewed as poor business prospects because they had too many elderly or poor patients.
In other cases, hospitals have cut off doctors who compete with the hospital for patients at outside clinics and other hospitals, which the doctors sometimes own.
In one closely watched case, the Tennessee Supreme Court ruled last month against the Republic Health Corporation, a hospital chain based in Dallas. Republic had barred David Alfredson, a radiologist, from using diagnostic equipment in the Lewisburg Community Hospital, where he had worked under contract from 1981 to 1985.
The court said the hospital ended Dr. Alfredson's exclusive radiology agreement "without cause" on Jan. 1, 1986. The court held that the hospital had violated Dr. Alfredson's contract because it had "significantly reduced" his ability to work in the hospital without granting him a hearing as required under the medical staff bylaws.
Peggy Taylor, one of Dr. Alfredson's lawyers, said last week that the doctor would seek damages for the years he was barred from working in the hospital. Although the Republic Health chain only recently emerged from bankruptcy hearings, Ms. Taylor said that both Lewisburg and the hospital had prospered because of the new Saturn automobile plant in nearby Spring Hill.
Jeffrey D. Moseley, a lawyer for the Lewisburg Community Hospital, said the decision "really undercut" the institution's ability to make "a business judgment." And Frederick Entin, the general counsel of the American Hospital Association, said the Tennessee case "tells all hospitals and their attorneys to be careful" when they draft exclusive agreements with doctors.
Thomas W. Greeson, a lawyer with the American College of Radiology, a professional group that supported Dr. Alfredson, said state court decisions had been split over whether the medical staff bylaws protected a doctor, whose livelihood might be threatened by the loss of access he or she formerly had to a hospital facility.
Indeed, the Ohio Supreme Court recently declined to hear the case of a doctor barred from the emergency room at Good Samaritan Hospital in Dayton after his contract there was not renewed. Thomas Knoth, a lawyer for the hospital, said most courts had held in such cases that the medical staff bylaws applied mainly to questions of professional competence or misconduct, not to business arrangements with doctors.
In other recent cases, a New York court dismissed a lawsuit against Winthrop-University Hospital, in Mineola, L.I., that was brought by a group of Great Neck radiologists whose exclusive contract had been ended. And a group of California anesthesiologists lost their suit seeking reinstatement and damages from the Fresno Community Hospital and Medical Center.
In Florida, lawyers for American Medical International, a hospital chain based in Los Angeles, will go before an appeals court in West Palm Beach later this month to try to overturn a $19 million jury award to Dr. Zbigniew Scheller, a pathologist. He sued the hospital company when his contract, which granted him a percentage of laboratory receipts, was not renewed.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.N. Council Closer to Approving Iraq Resolution

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 1

 BODY:
The Security Council moved closer today to approving a tough new resolution that could officially end the gulf war later this week and allow the withdrawal of all remaining allied forces from southern Iraq, Western diplomats said.
The central question in its negotiations, however, is whether Iraq will accept onerous military and economic conditions in the American-sponsored draft of the resolution. 
 The United States appears to have the nine votes needed to approve the measure, these diplomats say. But the proposed resolution provides for a formal truce only after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq agrees to be bound by all its provisions.
Tonight, the United States representative to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said the Council could vote on the resolution as soon as Tuesday. But Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar predicted that the final vote would come Thursday.
 
Iraqi Is Hardly Pleased
 Iraq's United Nations representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, described the draft as "very objectionable," saying there is "a limit to the amount of coercion one country can apply to another." But he added that only the highest Iraqi leadership could decide what the nation's attitude will be if the Council adopts the resolution.
Asked what would happen if Iraq refuses to obey the resolution, Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said trade sanctions would remain in force "doing great and continuing damage to Iraq," but he made no prediction as to whether the allied forces would go home.
The resolution requires the Baghdad Government to destroy its most dangerous chemical and biological weapons and to compensate Kuwait for the damage its forces caused, while continuing to ban all sales of arms and dangerous military technology to Iraq for the indefinite future.
 
Food and Other Essentials
 It allows Iraq to start selling oil on the world market again, but earmarks an unspecified portion of these earnings for war reparations. And it continues to ban all nonessential imports like cars and television sets until the Council is satisfied with "the policies and practices of the Iraqi Government, including implementation of all relevant resolutions of the Security Council."
The draft allows Iraq to freely import food, promises rapid approval of requests to send other items for humanitarian purposes, and says that even before oil sanctions are fully lifted, Iraq may sell enough to pay for such essential imports.
The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- the five permanent Council members with a veto on decisions -- have already agreed to this tough draft, although it is unclear whether China will vote in favor or abstain.
Iraq has accepted all previous Security Council demands, agreeing to return stolen Kuwaiti property, send back prisoners of war and detainees, and accept financial liability for the damage caused by its invasion. But it did so at least in part because it wanted to stop the fighting.
While acceptance of the draft resolution's terms will bring an immediate cease-fire, ending any possibility that the allies might intervene to support the Iraqi rebels fighting in both the north and south of the country, it requires Iraq to accept a disputed 1963 border agreement it made with Kuwait before the United Nations would sendits peacekeepers and the allied forces would withdraw.
 
Frequent Review Process
 The Council will review the ban on civilian supplies every 60 days in the light of Iraq's policies.
While no one seriously doubts that the draft will be adopted, some objections have been raised.
On Sunday, for instance, the Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram, which sometimes reflects Government policy, criticized the provision requiring Iraq to destroy its special weapons, saying this should happen only in the framework of a general agreement to rid the entire region of such arms.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges by 32.67 to Close at 2,881.19

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices sank yesterday in sluggish trading as investors expressed concern that the economy was sagging badly.
The smaller stocks performed considerably better than the rest of the market. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average lost 32.67 points, or a bit more than 1 percent, to 2,881.19, and a broader measure, the Standard & Poor's 500, dropped about the same.
Two measurements of smaller stocks, the Nasdaq composite index and the American Stock Exchange's market-value index, slid about a third as much.
 
Trading Falls Off
 Trading fell yesterday to 144 million shares, down from an anemic 150.8 million on Thursday, the previous trading session; the exchanges were closed on Good Friday. Declines led advances about 5 to 3, and while 2 stocks dropped to new lows, 75 reached new highs.
One was United States Surgical, a producer of surgical staplers, which rose 4 1/2, to a new high of 115 3/4, after Kurt Kruger of Hambrecht & Quist recommended the stock. Robert Goldman of Dean Witter Reynolds had recommended it earlier.
Showing that the smaller stocks were holding up extremely well for the most part, even in a down market, the Russell 2000, the small-stock index, fell only four-tenths of a percent, to 170.31, down 0.69.
While new highs set during the day, rather than at the close, are not recognized for record-keeping purposes, the Russell index rose to a 1991 new high during the day, at 171.02. It had ended the Thursday session at a new high of 171.01.
Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said heavy computer-driven selling lopped nearly 14 points off the Dow blue chips.
Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the First Albany Corporation, attributed the market's slide largely to the economic index released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The group reported that the index of economic activity rose to 40 percent last month from 38.5 percent in February.
Mr. Johnson called the figure "not particularly encouraging."
H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist for Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said the index's first-quarter average of 38.7 was "consistent with a deep recession," though he added that he did not think the economy was in a deep recession.
Signs of a weak economy would typically be good for the stock market, prompting the Federal Reserve to pump money into banks to lower interest rates and strengthen the economy. But Mr. Heinemann argued that the purchasing managers' index by itself "is not going to have much influence on Fed policy." He maintained that the Fed would be "more apt to respond to a sharp decline in March employment, if there is one." The employment rate will be reported on Friday.
Mr. Heinemann said the Fed "has been moving very slowly and cautiously to date and hasn't done a great deal to counter the recession."
He added: "With the exception of today, the dollar has been extremely strong, suggesting that the dollar is in relatively short supply. If dollars were plentiful, they wouldn't be going up so rapidly. That's confirming evidence that money's not that easy yet."
 
Gains for Gold
 Gold prices jumped $3.30 an ounce yesterday, lifting gold shares broadly, if only a little. ASA Ltd., which has big South African interests, rose 1 1/8, to 45 5/8.
Chemicals, drugs, insurance, food and technology all posted large declines.
Digital Equipment slumped 4 1/4 in heavy trading, to 63 7/8, after analysts trimmed their earnings estimates. The computer maker said the recession had hurt its business.
I.B.M., which said last week that it would eliminate 14,000 jobs, fell 1 5/8, to 112 1/4, also in heavy trading, after IBM Japan Ltd. said profits fell 18.8 percent last year.
CBS fell 3 1/2, to 162 1/4, after The Wall Street Journal said the network might lay off 400 to 500 people. Time Warner slid 4, to 103 3/4, although except for the market's general weakness there did not appear to be news to account for the drop.
Mr. Johnson of First Albany said the purchasing managers' report suggested that the economy not only did poorly last month but had also continued to be weak.
He said the rise in stocks over the last few months had "promised us a recovery in the economy and in earnings." But, he added, "if you're looking for signs of a recovery, you probably won't find it -- and that's a little troubling."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Cutbacks by Network News Ground Bush's Press Plane

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
In a symbol of the financial retrenchment taking place throughout the network news business, the press plane covering the President of the United States was canceled by the White House for a trip last weekend after the networks significantly reduced their staffing on the Presidential fishing vacation.
Joe Peyronnin, the vice president of CBS News, called it "a sign of the times in network television." 
The cancellation of the press flight was the latest example of changes and reductions in news coverage at the networks, much of which are coming in reaction to enormous budget deficits rolled up by the news divisions during the war in the Persian Gulf, from both the cost of the coverage and the loss of advertising revenue during special broadcasts.
Each of the network news divisions has undergone a thorough review of staffing and capital expenditures in the wake of the losses, NBC alone estimated its losses at $55 million. Layoffs of correspondents and other news employees are expected to be announced in the next several weeks, especially at CBS, which is facing companywide budget cuts that one senior network executive said would total $150 million.
Next week, the networks will begin a monthlong cost-cutting experiment with CNN in pooling camera crews covering the President's daily activities. That pooling will extend to at least some of the President's travel schedule. Although CNN is planning to expand its worldwide coverage, it too is looking for ways to hold down spending.
The television news organizations decided independently last week that the President's weekend fishing trip to Isla Morada, Fla., could be covered by a greatly reduced staff using a pool crew. That decision indirectly led to the cancellation Friday of the charter flight of reporters that traditionally accompanies the President when he travels out of Washington. A representative of the White House travel office said it was the first time the press plane had been canceled in the 30 years he had helped schedule those flights.
The three broadcast networks have already cut the size of their news staffs by several hundred people each in the last five years and have reduced the number of their domestic and foreign bureaus. NBC News, for example, which had 1,362 staff members in 1986, is now down to 1,033, despite having more news programs on the air. And ABC, the leading network news division, has closed domestic bureaus in Boston, Chicago and Dallas and foreign bureaus in Frankfurt, Prague and Budapest -- consolidating them into one bureau in Berlin.
"It's all part of the same picture," Mr. Peyronnin said. "It is all a matter of economically prudent management trying to spend its dollars in a cost-effective way."
But Steve Friedman, the executive producer of the "NBC Nightly News," said. "We're doing this to save money, yes, but our role is changing, too. We're not in the overall killer-coverage business anymore. We're in the program business."
 
'One Picture of Bush'
 Mr. Friedman said the networks would increasingly cover stories based on the needs of specific news programs and less as a means of insuring that every event had a separate network presence. "We all had the one picture of Bush fishing in Florida if anybody wanted to use it," Mr. Friedman said.
Another senior network news executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the trip was not expected to make news. "This was a dog trip anyway," he said. "Nobody wanted to go on it." The executive said the decision to pull back from covering the President's trip was not setting a precedent.
But Jack Nelson, the Washington bureau chief of The Los Angeles Times, said reporters from print publications who had intended to take the press charter could not do so because, without full network participation, the trip became prohibitively expensive. News organizations pay for the seats on the press plane for their reporter or reporters, but unlike on a commercial airliner, the price per seat depends on the number of passengers. The fewer the passengers, the higher the cost per person.
 
More Than First Class
 The cost of the press flights has generally averaged out to about 50 percent more than it would cost to fly a commercial flight in first class, Mr. Peyronnin said. He added that the extra cost was used by the White House to set up telephones, copy speeches and perform other general services for the press.
Sean Walsh, an assistant White House press secretary, said that 70 to 80 journalists typically flew on the press plane that follows the President. Network news employees usually make up close to half that total.
This past weekend, Mr. Walsh said, the networks had signed up for only eight seats on the plane. Mr. Nelson of The Los Angeles Times said the White House first said the trip cost for each reporter would increase to about $2,000. But as print organizations declined to ride because of the cost, the amount continued to go up, he said, eventally reaching $16,000. At that price all organizations dropped out.
 
Flew on Commercial Flights
 News organizations then arranged to fly reporters to Florida on commercial flights. The network news organizations also sent additional crews to Florida, some from New York, some from the network's local television stations in Miami.
Mr. Peyronnin said the networks "are reviewing the costs of everything" in the wake of the war and what he called "changes in the television economy." The networks have all suffered from a soft marketpace for advertising.
Part of that review of costs, Mr. Peyronnin said, was the fact that the networks have been "all but underwriting the costs of the press planes because we have always assigned so many people to cover the President."
Mr. Friedman said the shrinking staffs and declining number of bureaus made it "much harder to do the job than it used to be in the old days when we had a complete menu to choose from." He said the new strategy was to fly correspondents to stories.

HEADLINE: German Economic Aide Slain; Red Army Faction Suspected

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany, April 1

 BODY:
Detlev Rohwedder, who headed the agency charged with privatizing the economy of the former East Germany and was a leading German manager, was shot to death in his home tonight, the authorities said.
An anonymous caller asserted responsibility in the name of the Red Army Faction, a far-left terrorist group. 
 Mr. Rohwedder's wife, Ehrgard, was wounded in the shooting, which occurred about 11:30 P.M., a German television station reported, quoting the police. It said her injuries were not life-threatening.
 
History of Killing
 Since its founding in the 1970's, the Red Army Faction has taken responsibility for the killings of more than 60 people, including many prominent Germans. Its victims include Alfred Herrhausen, chief of the Deutsche Bank, who was killed by a bomb in November 1989.
On Feb. 13, Red Army gunmen fired more than 250 shots at the United States Embassy in Bonn, but caused no injuries.
Rolf Hannich, a spokesman for the German federal prosecutor's office, said the claim of responsibility had been received by the Paris office of Agence France-Presse. The caller made no effort to explain the slaying.
 
Rebuilding a Static Economy
 Mr. Rohwedder, who was 59 years old, had the monumental task of reorganizing the eastern German economy. In the next few years, more than 8,000 former state companies are to be privatized. More than four million people are expected to lose their jobs in the process.
Mr. Rohwedder had gained prominence as one of West Germany's most capable managers as head of the Hoesch steel company, which he helped pull out of financial difficulties in the early 1980's.
The privatization organization headed by Mr. Rohwedder has been criticized by many eastern Germans for being too quick to shut down businesses, throwing people out of work, rather than trying to rescue the companies. Mass protests have shaken eastern Germany in recent weeks because of rising unemployment and a lack of improvement in living standards.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Will Lay Off 2,600; Agencies to Close 2 Days a Month

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 1

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that the state would begin sending layoff notices to 2,600 employees, or about 5 percent of the state work force, on Tuesday and that he would order most state agencies to close their doors two additional days a month beginning in July.
Mr. Weicker, appearing grim at a rare evening news conference that was broadcast live on local television stations, said the layoffs and other cuts were made necessary by the failure of unions representing state employees to offer long-term cuts in benefits and wages and by the state's huge deficit, which he said had to be addressed immediately, regardless of the pain. 
 "This isn't just a speech," Mr. Weicker said. "The layoff process is starting, unfortunately."
It will be the first emergency layoff of state workers in Connecticut since 1975, when Gov. Ella T. Grasso dismissed 500 state employees, and the largest layoff since at least the early 1950's, state officials said. The layoffs will save an estimated $62 million. Some workers will receive as little as two weeks' notice, though most will have four to six weeks' notice.
 
Union Talks to Continue
 Mr. Weicker said that talks with the unions would continue and that if some accommodation could be reached, those laid off could be called back to work. All of the layoff notices will be out within two weeks, the Governor's office said.
The two-day agency shutdowns, intended to save $26 million, will not affect agencies involved in health and public safety, like the state police, the Correction Department or the Departments of Mental Health and Mental Retardation. But some of the agencies most visible to the average state resident will close two extra days a month, like the Motor Vehicles and the Environmental Protection Departments.
More than 7,000 people work for the agencies involved and would lose pay if they were scheduled to work those days, Mr. Weicker said. It was unclear how the closings would be structured, but some require union negotiation. A spokesman for the group representing the employee unions, Robert J. Krzys, said the layoffs and two-day closings would be felt by the public and "deplored by the state employees."
"This announcement will make reaching an agreement much more difficult," he said.
The layoffs and department closings are part of a nine-part plan that includes some elements already announced by the Governor's office. Most require no legislative action, although the largest single provision -- a change in accounting procedures for the state pension system to save about $130 million next year -- requires a law change unless the unions simply renegotiate contracts under the new formula.
 
Estimated Savings
 The overall plan would save Connecticut about $276 million over the next fiscal year, or about $125 million less than what Mr. Weicker sought from the unions when he presented his budget in February.
The plan also includes $29 million in savings that Mr. Weicker said would be sought from union members whose contracts are about to expire. Most of the savings sought in Mr. Weicker's budget would have come from reopening negotiations with unions whose contracts have already been settled.
Another $14 million would come from a pay freeze and one-week-a-year unpaid furloughs for all managers, commissioners and deputy commissioners.
Mr. Weicker's budget seeks to cut about $1.2 billion in state spending and already includes 938 layoffs that were to begin July 1 but are now to start immediately. It would also overhaul most of the state's revenue system and would impose for the first time a 6 percent flat income tax on wages.
Connecticut faces a shortfall of $784 million in a $7 billion budget for the year ending June 30 and a gap of $1.7 billion in the preliminary budget for the next year, according to figures released today by the State Comptroller's office.
The projections represent a rise of nearly $80 million in the deficit in just the last month, mainly from declining collections from the taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains and increased Medicaid and welfare expenses attributed to the recession.
The precise effect of the layoffs on services is speculative. The agencies most severely affected include the University of Connecticut, which would lose 300 people out of 2,860 paid from the state's General Fund. The Transportation Department would lose an additional 295 workers beyond the 268 already included in the initial budget plan. The Historical Commission would lose 4 more of its 23 employees beyond the 2 already due to be dropped.
Other states have set even more painful goals. In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed laying off 7,000 state workers and eliminating 11,000 other state jobs. Massachusetts has announced plans to eliminate 7,600 jobs. Rhode Island began last month the first of 10 unpaid furlough days.

HEADLINE: GAMBLING RETURNS TO THE MISSISSIPPI

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 1

 BODY:
The stern faces of blackjack players, the whoops and shouts of winners and the resigned side glances of losers returned to the muddy water of the Mississippi River today for the first time since hard-drinking roughnecks ruled turn-of-the-century paddle wheelers.
Three floating casinos, packed with thousands of crap-shooting, roulette-playing Midwesterners, plied the Iowa side of the river in a grand attempt to revive Iowa's river cities, an experiment that is being closely watched by officials in Mississippi, Missouri and Illinois, where moves are under way to emulate it. 
 But instead of the career rogues of Mark Twain's day, the gamblers aboard these vessels are farmers and factory workers and great-grandmothers like Helen Callahan of Dubuque, Iowa.
 
More Than Plain Farmers
 "People think Iowans just grow corn and raise pigs," the 76-year-old retired school teacher said. "But we have a lot of good, intelligent people. We know a little bit about gambling."
She then joined the crowd in the shiny new Dubuque Casino Belle and headed for the slot machines, where she said she could hold her own.
Del Hildebrand, a factory worker, got up at 2 this morning to drive from just outside Milwaukee to Dubuque to make it in time for the maiden voyage of the Casino Belle.
"I figured the slot machines would be loose," he said. For him, they were. He won $150 in his first few minutes on board before the river boat had even left the dock.
The millions spent on gussying up the side-wheeler, a model of a 19th-century riverboat, with faux marble columns and waitresses in bustles and feathers, mattered little to people like Mr. Hildebrand. "I didn't come for the scenery," he said. "I don't care about the decor. They could stay at the dock and people wouldn't care."
The view from the three casino decks aboard the Casino Belle is mostly trees and brown water, and the hourlong cruise is essentially a journey to nowhere in particular, just eight or 10 miles south of Dubuque and back. So when the riverboat began to edge away from its dock, no one at the boat's 500 slot machines, 21 blackjack tables, two dice tables and the roulette wheel appeared to even look up.
"I didn't know we were moving," said Bob Gates, a Wisconsin logger in a red-checked flannel shirt and baseball cap, sitting at a blackjack table, neither losing nor winning, when told that the boat was in the middle of the Mississippi.
For all the intensity and slightly desperate hoping-against-hope that is typical of gamblers, state officials have sought to insure that gambling here is under control and that Dubuque and Davenport and Bettendorf, cities with casino gambling, do not turn seedy.
 
Strict Limits Are Set
 For one, gamblers are permitted to wager no more than $5 a bet and can lose no more than $200 a trip. Not-for-profit companies run the casinos, contracting out the management of hiring and maintenance of the boats to local private river boat operators. The managing companies determine how the casino profits will be divided between the city in which the license is held and charity. The state expects to reap about $50 million from the gambling.
State officials insist that Iowa will still be wholesome and clean. They say that compulsive gamblers will not like the Disneyland feel of Iowa gaming.
"This gives people a chance to take a cruise on the river," said Representative Jim Nussle, a Republican. "This is more than just sitting in a dark room playing cards."
This is also a chance for Iowa's river cities to blossom, as they did during the boom times of a century ago, when the Mississippi was their lifeblood and as many as 800 paddle wheelers visited their landings.
 
Hard Economic Times
 The last few decades have been particularly tough for cities like Dubuque, a city of 65,000 that saw its farm and construction equipment industry collapse with the state's farm economy in the 1980's and unemployment rise to nearly 25 percent.
"Industries held on to the riverfront land figuring someday it would be worth something to somebody," Mayor James E. Brady of Dubuque said. "Now we have a whole new industry. Our future is the Mississippi River.
Cranes now rise at the foot of Dubuque's steep bluffs and a new hotel and office building are going up. The city hopes that riverboat gambling will attract 2 million visitors a year to the three cities and that this will mean improved highways and more business, as well as money for its coffers. The city is hoping that people like Jim Fuegen, a corn and dairy farmer from Springbrook, just keep coming to take their chances on the riverboat.
Mr. Fuegen, for one, knows he will be doing well if he breaks even. But, he says, "The way prices are going, I'm gambling anyway, so I might as well have fun losing." He then pulled the lever on the slot machine and watched the green and yellow and pink symbols sort themselves out.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hellen Neuman-Weindruch of Bettendorf, Iowa, shooting craps aboard the Diamond Lady. The boat was one of three floating casinos that returned legal gambling to the Mississippi River yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Realtors' Ads To Protest Rise in Taxes

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Led by major realtors and landlords, an unusual coalition of New York City property owners is about to start a million-dollar advertising and direct-mail campaign urging taxpayers to write Mayor David N. Dinkins and other officials to oppose the Mayor's proposal for higher real-estate taxes.
The campaign, the first by one of the city's most significant and depressed industries, amounts to a declaration of war on the municipal government and an attempt to ignite a tax revolt from the top down by tapping the grass-roots anger of homeowners and small businesses. 
 "Don't be fooled into thinking the city has no choice," reads an advertisement prepared for newspapers. "While you worried about your job, the city added 5,000 people to the public payroll last year. So the tough talk about budget cuts is just that . . . talk."
 
Ads Raise Fears for Home and Job
 The ads, to be printed in newspapers and broadcast on radio, warn that the Dinkins administration's plan for nearly $1 billion in higher property taxes to balance its budget and finance its anti-crime plan would mean increases of more than 20 percent in some taxpayers' bills and would force businesses and residents out of the city.
"This tax hike will cost you hundreds of dollars a year, lower the value of your home and maybe even cost you your job!" one ad reads. The tag line is "Don't take a hike. Say 'NO!' to higher taxes."
"The magnitude of these taxes is literally like throwing gasoline on a fire trying to put it out," said John J. Gilbert 3d, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a major landlord group. He is helping to lead the campaign with Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. Both said it was the first such broad campaign the industry had sponsored.
The organizers plan to begin the campaign on April 15, re-enacting the Boston Tea Party by dumping "an environmentally acceptable equivalent of tea" some place along the Manhattan waterfront, Mr. Gilbert said.
Mr. Dinkins's acting press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said the administration was striving to balance the pain of budget cutbacks and new taxes fairly as it faced a projected gap of more than $3 billion for the fiscal year that starts on July 1. "Everyone has First Amendment rights, and we understand that everyone is feeling the pain," he said. "Those voices are coming at us from all sides."
In the past, large landlords and apartment owners complained that the City Council, which has the power to fix property tax rates, shielded small homeowners from higher taxes. But this year, the effects of a state law that requires a redistribution of the tax burden among different types of property, and the sheer size of the proposed increases, have drawn big and small owners into a new alliance.
 
30 Groups Allied, Organizer Says
 Mr. Spinola said he had sought to organize the group, which calls itself Taxpayers for an Affordable New York, because he did not believe most New Yorkers realized the real size of the proposed increases, which are embedded in a complex mix of proposals. So far he said, more than 30 groups have been signed up, from the Harlem Taxpayers and Property Owners Association to the Queens Chamber of Commerce.
To put pressure on politicians, a direct-mail packet to 750,000 property owners and co-op dwellers will include three prepared postcards addressed to Mr. Dinkins, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the local Council members, saying, "If you want to keep New York affordable, keep essential services and cut the waste."
Mr. Spinola said the campaign had resulted from dissatisfaction with the city's response to its complaints. "We were talking logic to the administration, and no matter how good our arguments, they were getting a lot of pressure from other interests," including labor unions, to raise taxes instead of cutting jobs or services, he said.
The state Public Employees Federation, one of the largest state workers' unions, is currently spending at least $1 million on television ads. They urge the Legislature to pass higher state income and sales taxes to maintain services and restore some of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget cuts.
Mr. Spinola said the coalition wanted the city to work harder to save money by reducing the work force, trimming fringe benefits for workers, cutting unnecessary programs and generally making do with less, something he said the recession had forced private industry to do. He said the Council leadership's proposal to raise only about one-third of the property taxes Mr. Dinkins was seeking was "a dramatic statement, but it doesn't go far enough."

HEADLINE: From Journey's End to a Commuter Stop

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
It's enough to throw the New Yorker magazine's made-up railroad maven, E. M. Frimbo, into a tizzy. When the Rip Van Winkle chugs out of Grand Central Terminal on Saturday night, the Beaux-Arts landmark -- which once billed itself as the gateway to a continent -- will turn into just another commuter station: the gateway to Pelham and Poughkeepsie.
In the name of efficiency, Amtrak is switching all its long-distance trains from Grand Central to Pennsylvania Station. Amtrak says that will let passengers from Washington and points south who want to go on to Albany and points north do so by merely going across a train-station platform, not an entire town. 
 Amtrak has spent $100 million to make this possible. It has built a new tunnel under Penn Station and has renovated a century-old bridge at Spuyten Duyvil. It has rebuilt miles of tracks beneath Riverside Park, which run past a squatters' colony of old cinder-block bunkers.
 
'A Thousand Dramas Daily'
 Rail buffs insist that things will not be the same in majestic Grand Central, where the cameras rolled as they rolled out the red carpet for stars like Fred Astaire and Carole Lombard and John Barrymore. "Crossroads of a million private lives! Gigantic stage on which are played a thousand dramas daily!" boomed a deep-voiced announcer on an NBC radio soap opera in the 1930's titled -- what else? -- "Grand Central Station."
A generation later, network television news shows originated right there in Grand Central and quiz-show hosts told viewers to send away for studio-audience tickets to Madison Avenue addresses that sounded quite fancy to out-of-towners.
But now Alex Trebek presides over "Jeopardy," "Concentration" and "To Tell the Truth" from Burbank, Calif., asking contestants when they moved west as if they were a bit dim for not having done so sooner.
"The world won't end over this," Kent S. Barwick, the executive director of the Municipal Art Society and a leader in the fight to save the terminal in the 1970's, said of the switch to Penn Station, "but who would have thought that in one fell swoop they could saw off Grand Central Terminal from the rest of America?"
Well, not exactly. Metro-North trains will continue to come and go from Grand Central. But they will be short-haul commuter runs: the 5:03, not the big-name long-distance trains like the 20th Century Limited or the Lake Shore Limited.
Train buffs have already reserved spots along the right-of-way from which to photograph what they consider a mournful bit of history: the final Amtrak trains to and from Grand Central. And redcaps who have worked there for years don't want to follow their passengers to Penn Station.
"I don't like it," Phil Williams, an Amtrak redcap who has worked in Grand Central for 23 years, said of Penn Station. "It's just generally depressing and claustrophobic." He said he had applied for a job with Metro-North rather than risk being assigned to Penn Station.
Thomas Henry, after six years at Grand Central, slandered Penn Station with the ultimate redcap epithets: "congested and hard to get around in."
Beyond the old iron gates, out on the concrete platforms where huffing-and-puffing locomotives once came to a halt with an ear-splitting blast of steam, there is already a certain nostalgia, though Amtrak is not gone yet.
 
The End of an Era
 "Personally speaking," said Tom Campbell, an Amtrak conductor who lives in Half Moon, N.Y., "I'm going to miss it. This is the station."
Frederick Palmer went a step farther, calling the end of Amtrak service at Grand Central nothing less than the end of an era. He is the superintendent of Grand Central. His father and grandfather worked there. And he remembers riding in as a youngster and seeing the New York Central trains, shined up and lined up and ready to head west.
"It was really something to see," he said, "the crispness of it, the fact that the crowd was headed someplace or arriving in a great terminal in a great city. You don't feel that way in airports."
Airports do not have eavesdropper's delights like the Oyster Bar, where a whisper comes in loud and clear all the way across the room. And airports do not have the grandeur of Grand Central -- something that 4 1/2-year-old Sasha MacDonald noticed the moment she set foot in the place on her way to visit her grandmother.
 
No More Slumbercoaches
 "She thought it was a church," said her father, Robert MacDonald, a Manhattan photographer.
No more Amtrak service from Grand Central means no more slumbercoaches on the trains that are making the change. Slumbercoaches are Amtrak's economy sleeping cars. For reasons that even Mr. Black described as complicated, there is no way to operate them on the new route. So slumbercoach passengers will have to ride to Albany in regular upright seats and wait for the slumbercoaches to be tacked onto the train before they can be tucked into their fold-down beds.
For passengers, the change to Penn Station will be a double whammy. The first train to Albany, on Sunday, will roll out of Penn Station on the very morning that Eastern Standard Time gives way to Daylight Savings. Hardly anything could be more confusing than remembering to reset one's watch and go to Penn Station instead of Grand Central.
"Wonder how many people will show up at Grand Central next Monday morning wondering where the train to Albany is," said Philip A. Lentz, the press secretary to Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, who lives in Manhattan and commutes to the State Capitol on Mondays. "It might delay the budget for another week."

HEADLINE: LOW MEDICAID FEES SEEN AS DEPRIVING THE POOR OF CARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Medicaid, the health program for poor people, pays doctors much less than either Medicare or private health insurers for the same services, and as a result many doctors are refusing to take Medicaid patients, a Federal advisory commission said today.
In a report to Congress, the panel, the Physician Payment Review Commission, said Medicaid paid doctors 69 percent of what Medicare paid, and an even smaller proportion of what private insurers paid. 
 Forty-four states have problems getting doctors to participate in Medicaid, and "low fees were cited as the most common factor in discouraging participation," the commission said.
 
Political Power a Factor
 Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 33 million elderly and disabled people, has a much stronger political constituency than Medicaid, a Federal-state program for 27 million low-income Americans, including 13 million children.
While doctors have often complained informally about the level of Medicaid payments, the study by the nonpartisan commission is the most systematic attempt to date to measure the disparities. The study, conducted with the help of the National Governors Association, was based in part on a survey of state Medicaid programs, which reported data on actual fees for services commonly used by Medicaid beneficiaries.
Another reason for the disparities in doctors' fees under the programs is the way the programs are financed. Medicare has its own trust funds, composed of payroll taxes, premiums and general revenues. Medicaid, by contrast, depends almost entirely on general Federal and state revenues.
 
Close to Market Rates
 The Federal Government decides how much to pay doctors under Medicare and has normally guaranteed that physicians receive fees close to market rates. But states have wide discretion in deciding how much to pay in doctors' fees under Medicaid. State Medicaid agencies set the fees, often in consultation with the legislatures.
States often fail to increase doctors' fees to take account of inflation. In some states, Medicaid pays less than it costs to perform certain services.
The commission found "very large differences" in physician payments. New Jersey and New York were among the lowest-paying states. New Jersey's Medicaid fees were 50 percent of average Medicaid fees for all states, and New York's payments were 53 percent, the commission said.
In 1989, New York's Medicaid program typically paid doctors $240 for a total hysterectomy, or 17 percent of what Medicare paid ($1,448), the commission said. New Jersey paid $257 for that procedure, or 22 percent of what Medicare paid ($1,163). For a typical visit to a doctor office's, Medicaid paid $11 in New York, or 35 percent of what Medicare paid ($31.68).
 
Effects on Patients
 In West Virginia, Medicaid paid $330 for normal delivery of a baby, or 38 percent of the average claim submitted to private insurers for that service ($860).
Missouri and Rhode Island were other low-paying states. The highest-paying states included Alaska, Arkansas, Georgia and Indiana, where Medicaid payments to doctors slightly exceeded Medicare payments.
The low Medicaid fees affect patients in several ways, the commission said: Medicaid recipients are less likely than other people to have a continuing relationship with a doctor, less likely to receive care in a private office and more likely to receive basic care in a hospital emergency room or clinic.
In addition, the panel said, doctors who choose to treat Medicaid beneficiaries may be at a "substantial economic disadvantage relative to their peers."
Doctors are not required to take patients under either Medicaid or Medicare, but many find it profitable to take Medicare patients.
The commission plans to make recommendations later this year for changes in how Medicaid pays doctors.
 
Action From Congress
 The 13-member commission, made up of doctors and other health-care experts, was created five years ago to advise Congress on paying doctors under Medicare, and Congress has enacted most of its recommendations. Its mandate was expanded last year to include Medicaid.
Dr. Philip R. Lee, chairman of the commission, said there appeared to be a trade-off in some states between the level of Medicaid fees to doctors and the generosity of Medicaid programs to beneficiaries.
Thus, he said in an interview, while Medicaid payments to doctors are relatively low in New York, the state's program has liberal eligiblity rules, offers a wide range of optional benefits and pays for large amounts of longterm care.
By contrast, the Indiana Medicaid program pays higher fees to doctors, but eligibility for benefits is stricter.
"Poor people have limited access to private physicians in New York City because Medicaid payments are often less than what it costs the physician to provide the service," said Dr. Lee, who is director of the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California at San Francisco. "But New York City has a well-developed system of public hospitals and outpatient clinics that assure access to health care for Medicaid beneficiaries and other poor people."
 
Inner City vs. Rural
 The commission said that fee increases might improve access to health care for some poor people by drawing more doctors into the program. If Medicaid increases payments to doctors, beneficiaries would be more likely to receive care in doctors' offices than in hospital emergency rooms, the panel said.
But James W. Fossett, a political scientist at the State University of New York in Albany, who has analyzed Medicaid claims data, said: "An increase in Medicaid physician fees would probably not improve access to health care for poor people in inner-city neighborhoods because there is a severe shortage of doctors in such areas. Higher fees could improve access to some types of care for residents of rural areas."
Dr. Lee warned that if the Federal Government required a substantial increase in Medicaid payments to doctors, states might try to offset the cost by restricting eligibility or limiting the scope of Medicaid benefits.
Medicaid is one of the fastest-growing items in state budgets, primarily because health-care costs are rising, but also because Congress has repeatedly required states to expand benefits and eligibility.
 
Trouble Finding Doctors
 Rather than simply mandating that all Medicaid doctors' fees be raised to a certain level, it might make more sense for the Government to require increases for selected services, like obstetrics and pediatrics, or increases for doctors in underserved areas, the commission said.
The commission estimated that it would cost $1.3 billion in Federal and state money a year to raise Medicaid doctors' fees to the level of those for Medicare. Federal and state agencies spent a total of $3.4 billion for doctors' services to Medicaid patients in 1989.
Twenty-six states said they had difficulty recruiting doctors to serve Medicaid patients in rural areas. New Jersey, Maine, Nebraska and Washington State said they had problems finding doctors for urban areas.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
A survey of the nation's purchasing managers showed that U.S. economic activity picked up in March but that the economy remained in a recession. The monthly survey showed a modest improvement in new orders, but many economists interpreted the report as a sign that the economy remained sluggish. [Page D1.] Construction spending dipped 0.1 percent in February. [D6.] 
 Medicaid pays doctors much less than either Medicare or private health insurers, a Federal advisory commission said, and as a result many doctors are refusing to take poor patients. [A1.]
The U.S. identified 52 companies and 37 individuals as fronts or agents for Iraq. [D6.]
The Supreme Court ruled that local governments enjoy broad immunity from antitrust liability for actions that would amount to illegal conspiracies if they took place in private contexts. [D6.]
A coalition of New York City property owners plans a million-dollar campaign against a proposal to raise property taxes. [B1.]
 
Companies
