HEADLINE: Higher Fees for Doctors May Not Help Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
When Medicaid was established, many members of Congress assumed it would supplant charity care provided by doctors at no charge. But now 26 years later, Medicaid fees lag so far behind the costs of providing care that some doctors offer free care without bothering to file Medicaid claims and others do not serve Medicaid patients at all.
Medicaid, which finances health care for poor people, and Medicare, for the elderly, were created by the same law. But Congress views the two constituencies in completely different ways, and so do doctors. 
 A report this week by a Federal advisory panel, the Physician Payment Review Commission, documented huge disparities between Medicaid and Medicare payments to doctors. The report helps lay a foundation for Congressional efforts to increase reimbursements to doctors, especially for basic health services like maternity and child care.
But the solutions are not easy because the problems are deeply rooted in the history of the Medicaid program, which serves 27 million Americans at a cost of $51.5 billion for the Federal Government and more than $39 billion for the states this year.
 
A Rule Not Enforced
 From the beginning, the Federal Government stipulated that doctors should be paid their usual fees under Medicare, but there was no such requirement under Medicaid, which gives wide discretion to the states. Since 1979, the Federal Government has required that states pay doctors enough to assure that their services are available to Medicaid recipients to the same extent as to the general population. But the Government has not enforced this rule. The failure suggests that Federal and state officials do not see the disparity in payments as a serious problem and feel little pressure to resolve it.
Congress and doctors have always been ambivalent about Medicaid, unsure whether it is a health or welfare program, and this confusion about purposes and goals has hobbled the program.
"It's just not economically feasible" to see Medicaid patients, said Dr. Isaac Novick, a 44-year-old Brooklyn dermatologist, who reported that he gets $62 for an initial office visit with a patient under Medicare, as against only $12 under Medicaid. "The gap between the two programs has widened," he said.
Medicaid has always been a stepchild of the nation's health care system. Barbara D. Matula, director of the Medicaid program in North Carolina, said that even when a little extra Medicaid money is available, many states distribute it to hospitals and nursing homes, rather than to doctors.
Gary J. Clarke, director of the Medicaid program in Florida, said: "Doctors aren't really interested in seeing Medicaid patients. As a result, they don't lobby their state legislatures for fee increases. Hospitals and nursing homes do lobby to assure they have adequate payment."
In a strange way, it may make sense for some states to funnel money to hospitals or clinics without increasing Medicaid fees for doctors.
James R. Tallon Jr., leader of the Democratic majority in the New York State Assembly, said: "In many states, the privately practicing physician is not the central or most likely source of care for a Medicaid patient. The Medicaid patient more often gets his or her care through an institutional provider, a community health center, a hospital outpatient department or, regrettably, an emergency room."
Medicaid payments to doctors thus become "a secondary political question," said Mr. Tallon, who has devoted much of his legislative career to work on health care issues.
Gail R. Wilensky, who supervises both Medicaid and Medicare as head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, said the lower Medicaid payments to doctors were apparently not having an adverse effect on Medicaid recipients' access to care.
 
Politics of Health Care
 "Medicaid recipients use health care at rates comparable to the general population, or higher, but not always in the same place," she said, observing that poor people often go to a clinic or a hospital rather than to a private doctor's office for their care.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, a leading architect of Medicaid, said today that the commission report showed that "Medicaid is grossly underpaying doctors in many states." But Mr. Waxman, a California Democrat, said he was reluctant to mandate higher fees for doctors because he feared that states would "make up for that cost by cutting back on eligibility."
The politics of health care are tricky. Much as they may wish to improve health care for poor people, lawmakers see no need to increase doctors' income. Doctors' net earnings from the practice of medicine averaged $155,800 in 1989, the American Medical Association says.
Governors and other state officials who worry about the cost of Medicaid insist that higher payments to doctors would not necessarily improve access to health care for poor people. Sara Rosenbaum, a health policy specialist at the Children's Defense Fund, agreed. "Even with a dramatic increase in fees, private physicians will play a very limited role in care of the poor," she said.
The American Hospital Association says that nine out of 10 hospitals lose money caring for Medicaid patients. Medicaid paid about 90 percent of the cost of such care from 1980 to 1985, but payments now cover less than 78 percent of costs, the association says.
Dr. John M. Eisenberg, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, suggested that "if we cannot provide an across-the-board increase in Medicaid payments to doctors, it might be desirable to offer a bonus to those who have a large proportion of Medicaid patients in their practice." Medicare already pays extra to hospitals serving "a disproportionate share" of low-income patients.
But Dr. Eisenberg, a member of the Physician Payment Review Commission, said, "We should not be so naive as to think that if we raise Medicaid fees to the Medicare level, we will suddenly get a group of doctors going to practice in the inner city who are of the same caliber as doctors practicing in wealthier locations."

HEADLINE: On Connecticut Tax Plan, Town Mutters, What Next?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMDEN, Conn., April 2

 BODY:
Sandy Maloney's outrage at the idea of a state income tax is passionate and personal, aimed at the man she believes is nothing less than a turncoat: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
"Whatever day he wants to come and watch my kids, that will be fine with me," said Mrs. Maloney, who says she will have to give up staying home with her two small children and go back to work if Mr. Weicker's proposed income tax becomes law. The tax, she said, would cost her family $1,000 a year, money she says they do not have. 
 But like so many other voices in this town and others like it across Connecticut, Mrs. Maloney's mixes anger with anxiety and confusion. She has seen stores close, and one of her relatives was in the now moribund construction business. She does not know how much worse things might get, or what actions by the state would push things one way or another.
"As much as I'm concerned about the income tax," she said finally, "I'm more concerned about the economy."
Hamden, an older suburb of about 52,000 people just north of New Haven, has the economic jitters, a malady with its own implications as towns like it consider Mr. Weicker and his budget proposals.
In the last six months, Hamden has lost more than 35 businesses, mostly stores. Fifteen others are operating "month to month," Mayor John L. Carusone said.
Welfare cases have increased fivefold in the last year, to 130. More than 500 tax liens have been filed against homeowners who cannot meet their property taxes -- double the usual amount in a 12-month period.
Concern over jobs has been compounded by the proposed deep cuts in state aid to towns that are part of Mr. Weicker's budget package. Hamden would lose about $3 million, in a budget of $90 million, requiring higher property taxes or local budget cuts.
 
Worried About Layoffs
 On Monday, the picture darkened further when both New Haven and the state announced layoffs that are sure to be felt here; New Haven cut 220 workers, the state 2,600. More than 600 state and New Haven employees live in Hamden, according to the Greater New Haven Labor Council.
In such an environment, the income-tax proposal is just one more thing to worry about for many people here.
"There's so much confusion now, and that's what's bad," said Mayor Carusone, a Democrat who has served in Town Hall for the last four years. "Everybody's in the dark."
Some people believe that the Weicker strategy counted on diffusing anger over an income tax by cultivating anger and confusion in other parts of the budget package.
"What Lowell has done is cut all the emotional stuff," said State Senator Philip S. Robertson, a Republican who represents part of Hamden.
 
Complaint of the Moment
 In the last few weeks, he said, his mail has shifted away from tirades over the income tax -- though he still receives some -- to tirades over Mr. Weicker's plan to eliminate local subsidies that have helped towns pay bus transportation costs for parochial and other private schools.
"You get people to yell and scream and say, 'You can't cut that,' and you make an income tax even bigger than the one proposed," Mr. Robertson said.
At Town Hall -- where "The Impossible Dream" rang out from the bell tower at noon during the week before Easter -- Mr. Carusone said he wants everyone to blame Hartford, if not Mr. Weicker, for the problems in town.
But he tilts in the opposite direction of many residents: He thinks Mr. Weicker's income tax does not go far enough, and he has announced his support for a progressive income tax, similar to New York's, with a rate that would rise with income.
A progressive tax, he argues with any resident who will listen, would raise even more money for the state, thus allowing property-tax relief to towns like Hamden. Mr. Weicker's plan calls for a flat 6 percent tax on all income over $25,000 for a family or over $12,500 for an individual.
To a certain extent, business leaders and political leaders also seem to be at each other's throats over the implications of Mr. Weicker's plans. The Democratic majority on the 15-member legislative council in Hamden, for example, is "pretty well fractured," said one member, Pasquale Corso, a Democrat who opposes Mr. Weicker's income-tax plan, not to mention the Mayor's.
Some business executives have expressed tentative support for the Governor's income-tax plan, echoing the view of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce, which includes Hamden. That group has endorsed the Weicker plan on the condition that it carries through on its proposals to cut business taxes and spending.
 
Income Tax Called Inevitable
 "I think most of the business people here would support what Weicker is trying to do if the cuts are left alone," said Edward Fred Hirsch, a retired executive who is considered a sort of dean of Hamden's business community. "The people I deal with all feel that the income tax was inevitable."
Mr. Weicker, who was inaugurated in January as a third-party governor with no members of his own fledging Connecticut Party in the General Assembly, quickly proposed a plan to overhaul the state's fiscal system, erase a huge budget deficit and stimulate business in a single throw of the dice.
His program would lower the sales tax, the corporate profits tax and the taxes on income from dividends, interest and capital gains. An income tax would make up the difference. Mainly because of the lowered sales tax, which would be cut to 4.25 percent, from 8 percent, and because state income taxes are deductible from itemized Federal tax returns, state budget officials say that people earning $40,000 or less would be better off, at least initially.
"In my district, a middle-class district, the vast majority I feel would gain substantially," said Representative Ronald L. Smoko, a Democrat who represents the south end of Hamden.
But he acknowledged that many people here simply do not believe that. "They're telling me seven- and eight-to-one, 'Representative Smoko, I don't want it,' " he said.
Mr. Smoko, a member of the Assembly's joint Finance Revenue and Bonding Committee, which will have to vote on some sort of budget plan this month, said he had not decided which side he would take. Intellectually, he said, he favors some tax-reform measure, though not necessarily the Governor's. Does he vote his conscience or do what his constituents tell him?
Fatalists here say it does not much matter. "Once they start talking about something like that, you know eventually it's going to happen," said Yvon Theriault, owner of the Sandwich Board, a breakfast and lunch restaurant. But he said that if the General Assembly were to lower the sales tax "and keep it there," people would put up with an income tax.
Others say that the surge of activity in Hartford is in itself a signal of hope, and that almost any direction is better than the feeling of drift that persisted here before Mr. Weicker's bombshell.
"Everyone has gone on with the feeling of, 'Well, what will happen?' " said Richard M. Nemergut, owner of The Bike Rack. "It's almost better to see it happen than to get ready for it."

HEADLINE: Woman Cleared After Drug Use in Pregnancy

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 2

 BODY:
A Michigan appeals court today ruled that a women should not stand trial on charges of delivering cocaine to her newborn son through the umbilical cord in a case that civil libertarians said could set the tone for future cases involving pregnant women who abuse drugs.
In a unanimous decision, the Michigan Court of Appeals rejected the state's argument that Kimberly Hardy, a 24-year-old unemployed factory worker from Muskegon, passed cocaine to her son Areanis in a way that constituted criminal delivery of drugs. The charge arose from Ms. Hardy's use of crack just hours before her son's birth. 
 The court decision overturned a lower court ruling that had ordered Ms. Hardy to stand trial. It was the highest level ruling yet on the question of whether a mother's drug use during pregnancy and it's effect on a child should be criminal matter, according to the American Civil Liberties Union.
"Today's decision should effectively put an end to a vicious and counterproductive prosecutorial tactic," said Howard Simon, executive director of the Civil Liberties Union in Michigan. "The practical effect of this kind of prosecution is to drive pregnant women from prenatal care. That is a horrible consequence."
 
'Health Care Crisis'
 Tony Tague, the Muskegon County Prosecutor, stood by his 1989 decision to charge Ms. Hardy in the autumn of 1989, and said he would appeal to the Michigan Supreme Court.
"This is a major health care crisis, and we must use whatever means we can to reach a solution," said Mr. Tague. "When the drug war is making casualties out of newborn children, it requires action."
Drug abuse by pregnant women has become a volatile reproductive rights issue. Since 1987, about 60 criminal cases have been set in motion in 19 states and the District of Columbia against women for abusing drugs during pregnancy. The charges include criminal child abuse, assault with a deadly weapon and manslaughter.
Ms. Hardy was charged with criminal delivery of drugs, which is normally applied to drug traffickers. Walter Connolly Jr., the lead defense lawyer, argued that the law was wrongly applied to Ms. Hardy.
"People were not put on notice that pregnant women could be prosecuted," Mr. Connolly said. "The legislature never intended it to be applied to pregnant women."
Civil libertarians argue that the main problem with such cases is that pregnant women are often ineligible for the very drug treatment programs that would prevent the abuse prosecutors are aiming at.
 
'Pregnancy Police'
 "This is an attempt to punish and make examples of women who can't get help for their addiction problems," said Lynn Paltrow, a senior staff counsel on the A.C.L.U.'s Reproductive Freedom Project. "Prosecutors say they are protecting babies and are tough on drug abuse, when all they're doing is harassing women, punishing them for not getting treatment that is not available to them in the first place. We're creating pregancy police."
Last year, Jennifer Johnson, a Florida woman, became the first woman charged and convicted on a drug-delivery charge involving a baby. She was sentenced to a year in a drug treatment program and 14 years of probation, including court-supervised prenatal care if she ever becomes pregnant again. Her case is now being appealed.
Ms. Hardy, who entered a drug treatment program shortly after her son's birth, says she has been drug-free for 18 months and her son and two other children have been returned to her after months of foster care. She expressed relief at the decision, but also misgivings.
"If I'd had known things would have turned out this way I would have taken the easier, softer way out and not told anybody," said Ms. Hardy, who admitted crack use to her doctor. "What woman wouldn't be afraid to tell her doctor if she had the threat of prosecution hanging over her?"

HEADLINE: Grumman Will Cut 1,900 Jobs, and L.I. Will Be Hit Hardest

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, about three-fourths of them on Long Island, because of cuts in defense spending and a need to trim expenses to become more competitive.
The aerospace and transportation manufacturer, based in Bethpage, L.I., said the reductions amounted to 7.4 percent of its work force of 25,600. The development dealt another blow to the metropolitan area's economy, since Grumman is Long Island's largest private employer, with 14,600 workers there. 
 The company, which builds the Navy's F-14 Tomcat fighter and A-6 bombers, said that 1,200 to 1,300 employees would be laid off in an action affecting virtually all of its manufacturing groups. The remaining 600 to 700 jobs will be eliminated through attrition.
 
Layoffs Start This Month
 Several hundred layoffs will take effect this month, Grumman said, and the rest will be spread throughout the year. It is the first major job reduction by Grumman since December 1988, when it moved to eliminate 3,100 jobs.
In a letter to all of Grumman's employees, Renso L. Caporali, the company's chairman, said that Pentagon spending cuts had led to fewer orders for its aircraft and other products. Among other things, he said, there are no new orders for the F-14 in the Federal budgets for fiscal 1991 or 1992.
At the same time Mr. Caporali said that Grumman needed to lower the prices of its products to remain competitive. The company had revenues of some $4 billion last year.

HEADLINE: Rights Movement in Struggle For an Image as Well as a Bill

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 2

 BODY:
As Congress prepares to reconsider civil rights legislation vetoed last fall by President Bush, groups pressing for passage of the bill find themselves facing a second and ultimately more crucial battle: one to define the image, agenda and relevance of the civil rights movement itself.
Heads of traditional civil rights organizations like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference are increasingly concerned that for many whites, "civil rights" now means preferential treatment for minorities rather than equality under the law. Even some supporters of the movement worry that to focus on the civil rights bill, with its legalistic tangles, is to distract attention from the more urgent issues of poverty and despair afflicting minorities and the poor. 
 Supporters of the measure bitterly dispute that it is a "quota bill," as President Bush said when he vetoed a nearly identical bill last year. The current bill, meant to overturn six Supreme Court rulings that made it harder for workers to win employment discrimination suits, expressly outlaws quotas. But critics say the only way for employers to avoid lawsuits would be to use de facto race and sex quotas.
The current argument over the civil rights bill -- and the defensive posture of its supporters -- symbolizes the difficulties the civil rights movement has faced since the 1970's in enunciating a clear, compelling moral message able to mobilize minorities without alienating whites.
"The power of the civil rights movement under Martin Luther King was its universalism," said Cornel West, head of the African-American studies program at Princeton University. "Now, instead of the civil rights movement being viewed as a moral crusade for freedom, it's become an expression of a particular interest group. Once you lose that moral high ground, all you have is a power struggle, and that has never been a persuasive means for the weaker to deal with the stronger."
There is ample evidence that quotas have become less popular with Americans.
Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, said polling for his group indicates strong support for the traditional civil rights agenda, including affirmative action, as long as it does not include quotas.
New York Times polls indicate that support for any preferential employment practices has slipped significantly. When respondents were asked in May 1985 if they favored preference in hiring or promotion for blacks in areas where there had been discrimination in the past, 42 percent said "yes" and 46 percent said "no." Asked the same question in December 1990, 32 percent said "yes" and 52 percent said "no."
 
'At a Crucial Juncture'
 As many civil rights veterans prepare to meet here on Thursday to mark the 23d anniversary of the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and to plot strategy for the future, there is widespread recognition that the movement has image problems, particularly among whites.
"I think we're at a crucial juncture in terms of how we think about civil rights as a country," said Geoffrey Garin, a Washington poll-taker who recently did research for the leadership conference. "If civil rights is defined as quotas, it's a losing hand. It it's defined as protection against discrimination and efforts to promote opportunity, then it will remain a mainstream value in American life."
The question has received increasing attention over the past year because of Mr. Bush's veto and the prominence of quotas and racial preferences as issues in the political races of State Representative David Duke in Louisiana and United States Senator Jesse Helms in North Carolina.
Some civil rights figures say the current environment is in keeping with the nation's historical attitudes.
"I don't think America was ready to end segregation," said Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P. "I don't think it has ever been ready to extend full equality. I can't think of anything we've gained as black people that has not come without a struggle."
But many in the movement acknowledge it now faces daunting obstacles. It faces a White House and a Supreme Court hostile to much of its agenda. It faces a tough economic climate in which many whites feel gains by minorities may come at their expense.
Perhaps most important, it faces problems that are national, not regional. They are problems that lack the clear solutions and obvious villains of the civil rights movement 30 or 35 years ago in the South.
"The issues in the 1950's were very simple -- whether you sit in a restaurant or whether you can vote," said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which spearheaded the civil rights movement under the leadership of Dr. King. "And the opposition was defending the indefensible and doing it by very offensive means. Now we have to find a way to simplify very complicated issues, and we haven't been able to do it yet."
Mr. Neas said many of the current problems of the civil rights movement reflect the degree to which its critics are trying to shape perceptions of the movement.
"The right wing has not been able to defeat civil rights bills on their merits, so they have always attempted to convert the debate to a debate over quotas when all these issues have nothing to do with quotas," Mr. Neas said.
He pointed to a broad array of bills passed over the past decade and by the most recent Congress, including legislation for the handicapped and bills on child care, the minimum wage and family leaves for workers as evidence of a broad-based movement whose agenda goes far beyond concern about discrimination. Supporters of the current civil rights bill are emphasizing its protection for women and other potential discrimination victims.
But he said its message has been distorted by opponents to the point that a bill that forbids quotas is labeled a quota bill; a far-ranging agenda of social, legal and economic programs is invariably debated in terms of affirmative action and racial preferences, and the considerable gains in civil rights legislative over the past decade are often ignored.
But critics, including conservative blacks, say the movement has lost touch with the most important issues affecting blacks and minorities. They say it was civil rights groups, not their critics, who made the civil rights bill their main legislative priority for this session of Congress.
"Mark Twain once said that if the only tool you have is a hammer then all problems look like nails," said Robert Woodson, a black conservative who heads the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise. "They are confronting a massive deterioration of the moral interior of the black community and instead of addressing the issue, they're assuming all the problems result from a retreat on civil rights. The civil rights agenda has nothing to do with the deterioration of life for low-income black people."
And others say the perceptions of civil rights stem from the degree to which the movement has come to rely on race-based remedies that in practice, if not in theory, often result in preferential programs.
"The insistence on quota-type remedies by the civil rights lobby is what keeps that issue alive," said Clint Bolick, the white director of the Landmark Center for Civil Rights, a conservative legal group in Washington. "Ben Hooks created David Duke, and we're going to see a lot more David Dukes until we finally move away from that issue."
 
Main Agenda Appears the Same
 There are few signs that the traditional civil rights groups are rethinking their main agenda. In pushing for the bill, many say racism is so deeply imbedded in American life that aggressive measures in the workplace to overcome both its legacy and continuing aspects of discrimination are essential. They say the movement cannot afford to sit back and allow the Supreme Court to take back hard-fought gains that affect millions of workers.
"Racial fairness in this country is essentially counter-cultural," said Roger Wilkins, the longtime commentator on racial issues, who teaches history and American culture at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. "Because of the weight of our history, for institutions and individuals to be racist is kind of like water flowing downhill. And in order to make water not flow downhill you have to make a dam. You have to do something counter-cultural to stop people from doing something that is not the normal, easy thing to do."
Many in the movement say it is the degree of resistance from conservatives in the White House and elsewhere that is draining attention and resources from the most pressing problems now afflicting minorities and the poor.
"The principal tragedy of the past 10 years has been that we've had to spend so much time on rear-guard actions, refighting battles won in the 1960's and 1970's, we haven't been able to fully address the economic justice issues that are the ones we need to address today," Mr. Neas said.
And many in the civil rights movement accuse the critics and the news media of unfairly focusing the debate on the concerns of aggrieved whites.
"We have had preference programs in this country, and we still have them, and the preferred are white men," Mr. Wilkins said. "But somehow in the debate all the victims are white men worried that black people are going to take their jobs. The only place in America where blacks have taken jobs in a major way from whites is the National Basketball Association."
 
Change in Focus Is Sought
 But some publicly and privately lament the degree to which the movement has failed to dramatize the most pressing problems of the poorest of the poor.
"I would want to focus more on the plight of children, more on the plight of the elderly, more on the plight of workers experiencing downward mobility," said Professor West of Princeton, who said he supports the civil rights bill but thinks it is not the most effective focus for the movement. "I would want to know what Bush says about the fact that one of two black children are poor and one of five in America. Those are fundamental issues that lend themselves to a moral force far beyond that of the black middle class trying to get into the mainstream."
Still, even bitter critics of the civil rights organizations, like Mr. Woodson, say opposition to the civil rights agenda rings hollow unless the opponents can offer other ideas to address the continuing inequities in American life.
"Conservatives don't have a legitimate right to complain unless they come up with an alternative," Mr. Woodson said. "Many of them opposed a lot of the civil rights legislation in its infancy, and now suddenly they're for a color-blind society. That doesn't hold much water."

HEADLINE: Dow Rises To 2,945.05, Up by 63.86

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
The prospect of lower interest rates plus rising hopes for an economic recovery helped to push stocks sharply higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 63.86 points and many broader averages reached record highs.
There were reports of heavy buying by American and foreign institutional investors. 
 Increasing speculation that the Federal Reserve Board may act to reduce interest rates drove bond prices higher and carried over into stocks. Traders also said that new confidence in the economy, bolstered by the recent surge in the dollar, was a big factor in the gains.
The jump in the bellwether Dow average, the top-30 blue chips, represented a 2.2 percent increase and was its biggest rise, in both point and percentage terms, since mid-February. The average closed at 2,945.05, which is less than 55 points from the magical 3,000. Many people on Wall Street view that level as something akin to the peak of Mount Everest.
 
Other Gauges Soaring
 Although the Dow came up well short of its record 2,999.75, reached last July, all-time highs were set by the New York Stock Exchange composite index, the New York Stock Exchange industrial index, the Nasdaq composite, the Nasdaq industrial index, the Standard & Poor's 500 and the S.& P. industrial index.
Except for the American Stock Exchange, where the advance was much less than 1 percent, prices were strong almost everywhere.
The Russell 2,000, basically a small-stock index, did not break its record of 180.78, established in October 1989, but did set a 1991 high of 172.64.
Trading volume jumped to a strong 189.5 million shares from 144 million the day before. Advancing stocks led declining ones by more than 2.5 to 1.
"The market's alive with speculation and gossip about a Fed easing," said Robert T. Falconer, senior vice president and economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, the government-bond house.
The speculation was prompted, he said, by the expectation that new employment figures due Friday would be disappointing. Some have said the report could show job losses of 200,000 to 250,000.
"Frankly, I disagree with it; I don't see the same decline in payroll," Mr. Falconer said.
About the flood of milestones, William M. LeFevre, market strategist for Tucker, Anthony Inc., the brokerage, said: "This is an important event. People who track this stuff are more cheered when the broader indexes set records than when it's just the Dow."
"Historically," he said, "April is the cruelest month for the stock market, but it isn't going to be this time."
 
Strong European Buying
 He attributed yesterday's strong gains in part to the fact that many European traders who had been on holiday on Easter Monday were back at work yesterday.
Other European houses in New York said they had not seen particularly heavy foreign buying. But Mr. Lefevre, noting that Tucker, Anthony has its own overseas offices, pointed out that Philip Morris had jumped 2 7/8, to 69 1/2 in heavy trading, that General Electric had climbed 2 3/8, to 72 1/8, again in heavy trading and that Merck had moved ahead 3 1/4, to 108 3/4 -- and that "these are the kinds of stocks Europeans like to own."
"I think there was European buying," he said.
Bonds, he said, no longer offer competition "and literally hundreds of billions of dollars in short-term parking places are looking for some place to go."
 
Changing Attitudes
 Asked about foreign buying, Edwin Walczak, chief investment officer for Vontobel U.S.A., the American arm of Swiss banking interests, said that while he had not seen strong buying, the economic slowdown in Germany was strong enough to raise investor interest in the United States.
"The main thing that's changed," Mr. Walczak said, "is their attitude. They see the U.S. now as a place they can play. They think the economy is going to recover, and that makes them more confident on the dollar." 
John A. Conlon Jr., head of stock trading for Rothschild Inc., the American arm of the British investment firm, remarked, "You had the whole world looking for a decline, based on yesterday's decline."
 
Competing Influences
 But at the same time, he said: "You've got a strong seasonal consideration -- new pension money coming in at the start of the quarter. When you have bearish expectations combined with new cash, you've got an explosive combination that takes the market up."
Birinyi Associates, which tracks such trading, said that in spite of two selling spurts, eight waves of program buying lifted the Dow blue chips a cumulative 23 points throughout the day. The heaviest wave came just after noon.
The tenor of the market seemed to gain almost from the start. By 9:45 the Dow was ahead 15 points; by 10:30 it had climbed 25 and by 1 P.M., 35 points. At 3:31, the New York Stock Exchange invoked its 50-point rule, preventing program traders from buying whenever the previous price was higher than the one just before that, a strategy to prevent their dealings from exaggerating the advance. In a declining market, the rule works in the opposite direction.
The Dow continued, nevertheless, to move ahead for the rest of the day.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Down In February

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Orders received by factories in the United States fell for the fourth straight month in February, the Commerce Department said today.
The department said orders fell five-tenths of 1 percent, which was steeper than most economists expected. The consensus forecast was for a three-tenths of 1 percent decline from January levels. The drop followed a revised 1.6 percent decrease in January, which had originally been reported as 1.7 percent, and declines of four-tenths of 1 percent in December and 5.8 percent in November. 
 Despite the overall decline in orders, several analysts said interest had now shifted to the prospects for an economic rebound, however weak it might be, once the full extent of the first-quarter decline in economic output was finally known.
"We're all now becoming very impatient for the first sign recession is coming to an end, and the evidence so far is very, very, very fragmentary," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Mr. Robertson said that at the least the rate of decline in orders for some goods was easing, raising some hope that the economy's slide was beginning to stabilize.
 
Deep Recession Still Seen
 However, Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "The decline in manufactured goods orders, although somewhat less serious than the previous month's figures, confirms that the economy is still deep in recession."
The Labor Department will issue March employment figures on Friday. Unemployment is expected to rise to 6.7 percent, from 6.5 percent in February, when it hit a four-year high.
The National Association of Manufacturers, which represents most of the big companies surveyed in today'ss report, said the recession might be prolonged because orders kept slowing, but stocks of unsold goods were not shrinking.
"The failure of inventories to decline under these circumstances raises the possibility that the economy will be caught with an inventory overhang in the coming months," Mr. Richards said.
Manufacturers' inventories of all types of goods were unchanged in February after falling one-tenth of 1 percent in January.
Producers have been holding down stocks of unsold goods, which economists say should speed recovery when consumer spending eventually picks up.
A key component of factory orders, durable goods, fell three-tenths of 1 percent in February after skidding 2 percent in January. Durable goods are big-ticket items like refrigerators and automobiles expected to last at least three years.
Military orders, a volatile category made more so by the Persian Gulf war, rose 2.5 percent in February after gaining 12.3 percent in January. Excluding military items, factory orders fell six-tenths of 1 percent in both months.
The main area of manufacturing strength has been in industries that sell most of their goods overseas, like commercial aircraft makers.
Transportation orders overall fell one-tenth of 1 percent in February after a 6.1 percent fall in January, but orders for aircraft, missiles and parts for commercial and military planes were up 13.8 percent after a 28.3 percent fall in January.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The High Cost Of Low Savings

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT'S morning in America, say two economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- the morning after. Since the mid-1980's analysts have been quarreling over the consequences of the free-spending ways of Americans. Now, Ethan Harris and Charles Steindel have produced what may be the definitive study of low savings and its impact.
Their article in the latest issue of the bank's Quarterly Review acknowledges the joys of eight years unbroken by recession, but they nevertheless believe that the 1980's consumption boom cost the economy dearly. If America had merely maintained the rate of capital accumulation of the earlier postwar decades, the two economists estimate, national output would have been $250 billion larger in 1990. Should the low savings rate of the 1980's persist through the 1990's, they project that the annual loss will reach $750 million. 
 The study's computer simulations suggest that getting back on the old growth track would not require onerous sacrifice: A five percentage point shift from consumption to savings would do the trick. But like many economists, Mr. Harris and Mr. Steindel find it improbable that tax breaks or exhortations from Washington could convert the shop-till-you-drop generation to the gospel of savings. Their own fix, huge Federal budget surpluses that would free hundreds of billions of dollars for private investment, seems only slightly more plausible.
One reason economists disagree about what happened to the savings rate in the 1980's is that they cannot quite pin down what savings is. For example, should capital gains from the run-up in stock prices in the late 1980's count as savings? The wow in the Dow certainly made a lot of people richer. However, if the gain merely reflected shareholders' expectations of what the next sucker would pay, it had no direct effect on productive capacity.
Mr. Harris and Mr. Steindel prefer a clean (if conceptually imperfect) definition that goes to the crux of the growth issue: savings available to augment productive capital. This, they reckon, is the inflation-adjusted change in household wealth, excluding holdings of government bonds and residential real estate. Corporate net worth, rather than stock prices, is used to value stocks.
Measured this way, the savings rate is worrisomely feeble. From 1953 through 1973, it averaged 8.7 percent of gross national product. But from 1980 through 1989, the rate slipped to just 4 percent. And in the last half of the 1980's, it averaged a still more meager 3.4 percent.
Foreign savers did make up part of the difference, in the process transforming America from the world's largest creditor to the largest debtor. Part, but not much: Savings from foreign and domestic sources fell to 5 percent of G.N.P. from 8.4.
The economists estimate that by 1989, this cumulative dip in savings had reduced the nation's stock of capital by 15 percent, and cut the G.N.P. by 5 percent. Extrapolating to the year 2000, the G.N.P. gap reaches 10 percent -- more than Washington currently spends on defense and Social Security.
A five percentage point shift from domestic consumption to savings would narrow the current G.N.P. gap in short order. It would also restore America's status as an exporter of capital, gradually paring foreign claims against future output. And while there would be no gain without some pain, consumption would approach the pre-1980's growth path within a decade.
Conceivably, households could make the transition with only a little help from Uncle Sam. But not likely: Tax carrots that increased private savings would also add to government deficits, partly offsetting the savings gain. In any case, even the truest believers in expanded individual retirement accounts and tax preferences for capital gains would have trouble conjuring a $100 billion-plus increase in private savings.
A more likely source for part or all of the extra savings is the Federal budget itself. The deficit, which reduced savings by 2.5 percent of the G.N.P. in the 1980's, is already slated under last year's budget accord to fall to just eight-tenths of 1 percent of the G.N.P. by 1995. If Washington had the will to push the budget two or three percentage points into surplus, the national savings drought would be history.
That, unfortunately, is a lot to ask from politicians who scatter like quail at the sound of the T-word. Raising government savings (or reducing dissavings) by a single percentage point of G.N.P. would require tax increases or spending cuts of $60 billion. But as the economists' simulation makes all too clear, the meter is running: Every year of delay makes the recovery more expensive.

HEADLINE: Plan to Create Jobs to Cut New York Welfare Rolls

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 2

 BODY:
In reaction to growing political pressure to trim New York's welfare rolls, the state's Social Services Commissioner proposed a program today that would pay private employers to create long-term jobs for welfare recipients.
National experts on welfare said the program would be the first in the country to use tax dollars to subsidize the creation of private-sector jobs for recipients of home relief, which pays benefits to low-income people who are not caring for children. It would extend a national trend that has seen welfare recipients increasingly required to earn their benefits by seeking either work or job training. 
 Under the plan, which was proposed to the Legislature by Cesar A. Perales, the Commissioner of Social Services, the state would pay up to 90 percent of the home-relief grant to an employer who agrees to hire a home-relief recipient for one year and who makes "a good-faith commitment" to continue employment after that. The employer would be required to pay the difference between the subsidy amount and the prevailing wage for the job, which would be at least half of the worker's total salary.
The new employees, Mr. Perales said, would receive a paycheck rather than a welfare check.
The plan would be mandatory for all employable home-relief recipients who have stayed on the welfare rolls for six months without finding work. Those who refused the offer of a job at that point would be removed from the welfare rolls for 75 days.
Mr. Perales acknowledged that the proposal was controversial, but said it would send a strong message about the direction of New York's much-maligned welfare program. "We literally want to take the taxpayers' money and give it to employers," he said. "A lot of people are going to look askance at this idea. But we want to communicate the idea that if you are able-bodied, home relief is transitional. We've never communicated that, and that's why home relief has such a bad name in some quarters."
Some legislators and advocates for the poor expressed concern that employers would take advantage of the state's subsidy for a year but then might dismiss the worker when the subsidy ended.
In New York City, where the home-relief grant is $353 a month, this is how the subsidy would work: An employer would have to pay the difference between the prevailing wage and $318, which is 90 percent of $353. The minimum four-week wage for a 40-hour-a-week job is now $680, meaning that an employer would pay $362.
After starting employment, the worker would be removed from the home-relief rolls. The employer also would be required to pay for the worker's health benefits if the job normally carried them. That would save the state the cost of insuring the home-relief recipient under Medicaid.
 
Training and Experience
 Mr. Perales said he believed that the plan would allow home-relief recipients to receive the job training and experience they needed to escape the welfare rolls permanently while also making it easier for businesses to expand employment during the recession.
Under Mr. Perales's proposal, local governments would have the option of participating in the program. If they did, it would be up to local social services departments to recruit potential employers and match home-relief recipients with jobs.
Of the Perales plan, Barbara J. Sabol, the Commissioner of New York City's Human Resources Administration, said, "We haven't received any written proposals, but we think it has some promise,"
The plan would require legislative approval, and Mr. Perales spent much of the day trying to persuade legislative leaders to support it. After speaking individually with Mr. Perales, the heads of the social services committees in the Assembly and the State Senate both said they agreed with the philosophy behind the plan but had reservations about its structure.
 
Cuomo Hasn't Seen Plan
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has not yet seen the proposal. But his deputy secretary for human services, Michael J. Dowling, said it would build on existing state programs that divert parts of the welfare grant for job training.
Home relief is the welfare program for poor people who do not qualify for aid to families with depedent children. It is the fastest-growing component of the state's welfare system, largely because the home-relief caseload is highly sensitive to downturns in the economy. Although home relief constitutes only one-fourth of the state's welfare caseload, it accounted for nearly three-fourths of the growth in the caseload last year.
Because it has grown so quickly, the home-relief program has come under harsh political attack, particularly from the Republican-led Senate. The Senate has proposed placing strict limits on eligibility for home relief and on the duration that benefits can be received.
Unlike aid to families with dependent children, which is financed jointly by the Federal, state and local governments, home relief is subsidized solely by the state and local governments.
Most of the state's 315,000 home-relief recipients have physical or psychological disabilities, are dependent on drugs or alcohol, or are otherwise deemed unemployable. But 115,000 are categorized as employable, and they are the focus of Mr. Perales's proposal.
Some officials with business and social-services groups found fault with what they said was the plan's underlying proposition -- that home-relief recipients seeking self-sufficiency only need a job and not training in both social and employment skills.
 
Preconceived Notions
 And some managers of the types of businesses that might be asked to employ home-relief recipients expressed ambivalence about the proposal, suggesting that it might be difficult for employers to abandon preconceived notions about welfare recipients.
"My first feeling would be it would never work out," said Danny Varracato, manager of the Jefferson Market at 455 Avenue of the Americas, between 10th and 11th Streets, in Manhattan. "You'd think that just as soon as some of these people get some money in their pocket, they'd just go back to drugs.
"But if somebody shows they could do a good job, then why not help them out? It's kind of like the state would be paying you to take a chance on them, and I guess that's fair."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Panama Agree On Access to Bank Data

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
United States and Panamanian negotiators have reached an accord that will open bank records in Panama for American criminal investigators to develop evidence on money laundering and drug crimes, Administration officials said today.
The officials said the agreement, reached on Saturday in Panama City, appeared to end a bitter dispute that moved Congress to freeze $84 million in economic assistance to Panama since early last year. 
 They expressed satisfaction that the treaty, the Mutual Legal Assistance Agreement, would help Federal and state efforts prosecute those involved in a broad range of crimes.
 
'An Excellent Arrangement'
 "Finally, the United States will realize we want to cooperate," said a senior Panamanian official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Still, American officials cautioned that the accord was not a panacea that would completely cleanse Panama's banks or eliminate illicit drug trading involving Panama. One official said the agreement would "be useful, though not decisive" in the war on South American cocaine traffickers. The treaty requires the approval of the Senate and the Panamanian National Assembly.
Some American law enforcement officials have said that opening a window into bank accounts may provide only limited assistance in tracking down money launderers, because Panama's corporation laws act as a virtually impenetrable shield that prevents the identification of the true owners and managers of companies.
Money laundering is a process by which illegally earned money is deposited in bank accounts or in other legitimate businesses, and is then withdrawn as "clean money." A 1989 Senate report listed Panama as one of the six nations most widely used to launder illegal profits.
Negotiations on the agreement began almost immediately after the invasion of Panama by United States forces in December 1989 and the replacement of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's military dictatorship with President Guillermo Endara's civilian Government. A preliminary draft was initialed in August, but Mr. Endara rescinded his support for the accord under intense pressure from Panamanian bankers.
Executives of Panama's 120 banks then argued that the treaty would neutralize the benefits of secrecy laws that give them a competitive advantage over other regional banking centers like the Cayman Islands and the Bahamas. Panamanian banks contain deposits of more than $15 billion and play a pervasive role in Panamanian society, forming the glassy skyline of Panama City and employing 10,000 workers.
United States and Panamanian officials noted that several influential bankers had reversed their position on the accord in recent weeks and had encouraged Mr. Endara's negotiators to sign a draft almost identical to the August version.
The final details were worked out when the chief United States negotiator, Michael Kozak, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, made a visit to Panama City last week.
Senior Panamanian officials have said that they expect a formal signing of the treaty by April 11.

HEADLINE: California's Fiscal Crisis Tests Government's Role

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 2

 BODY:
Facing a budget shortfall wider than ever before encountered by a state, the government of California has been plunged into a deep crisis that many lawmakers say could force a fundamental restructuring of government in the nation's most populous state.
Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, huddled with legislative leaders of both parties today at the Capitol in Sacramento to confront a gap of $12.6 billion between spending and expected revenue in the state's budgets for this fiscal year and the next. 
 The deficit is larger than the general funds of all but four other states: New York, Massachusetts, Illinois and Texas. It is 23 percent of the Governor's proposed $55.7 billion budget for 1991-1992.
 
In Dire Straits
 California could not balance its budget, Mr. Wilson said last week, even if all state universities and prisons were closed and all state employees were laid off.
"It's catastrophic," said Assemblyman John Vasconcellos, Democrat of San Jose. Mr. Vasconcellos is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and is one of several lawmakers trying to put together a combination of additional taxes and spending cuts to balance the budget, as required by law.
Senator Kenneth L. Maddy, a Fresno Republican who is the Senate minority leader and one of the lawmakers in today's meeting with the Governor, called for a thorough restructuring of the way services are delivered. "There is not enough political support to raise taxes to a level anywhere near $12.6 billion," he said in an interview.
Sacramento was awash this week with competing proposals, among them raising income tax rates in upper brackets, freezing the salaries of state workers, consolidating school districts and giving responsibility for some health programs to the counties.
The fiscal crisis, which began when Mr. Wilson announced the new deficit estimate on Friday, has stirred a bitter statewide battle over whether the Legislature should suspend a constitutional amendment that, in effect, guarantees public schools and community colleges about 41 percent of the state's general fund. Schools were fearing deep cuts, and the powerful California Teachers Association, a union, was organizing a rally for Wednesday at the Capitol.
 
30 States Struggling With Gaps
 In all, 30 states are grappling with budget shortfalls this year. While California's is by far the largest in amount, it is not the largest in percentage terms. Connecticut is trying to bridge a gap of $2.4 billion, about 37 percent of its general fund expenditures. New York has a potential shortage of $3 billion, or 10 percent.
For California, the situation represents a dramatic reversal of fortune in a state that returned a surplus to taxpayers as recently as 1987. Lawmakers attribute the current problem to a dozen years in which taxing and spending authority was limited and tax rates were cut while the state experienced huge growth in several areas, including population, prisons, immigration and AIDS cases.
Just after he took office in January, Mr. Wilson estimated the shortfall at $7 billion and called for cuts in welfare grants and school spending and for some additional taxes.
But by last Friday, he said, "a marked decline in economic activity" had raised the projected gap to $12.6 billion, $1.9 billion of which is for the current budget year and the remainder for the new budget year that begins July 1. Bank and corporation tax collections are running 14 percent behind last year's; schools have had to enroll 235,000 more pupils than last year in an increase of about 5 percent; the prisons have had to absorb 12,000 more convicts, or about 13 percent, and 47,000 clients have been added to the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, for a rise of 7.3 percent.
"So while the demand for services grows, our ability to pay for them shrinks," Mr. Wilson said. He cited a drop in housing starts, a slump in the state's once-prosperous military-contracting industry and the effects of a recent freeze and a drought.
The Governor offered no new plan, but asked the Legislature to come forward with proposals and to pass a new budget by May 1. He met today with Willie L. Brown Jr., Speaker of the Assembly; David A. Roberti, President Pro Tempore of the State Senate; Ross Johnson, Republican leader in the Assembly, and Mr. Maddy.
"There will have to be something that combines revenue increases and expenditure reductions," said Thomas J. Dooley, the chief deputy legislative analyst. "It is impossible to solve this just by cutting expenditures."
Because spending on the public schools and on health and welfare accounts for 70 percent of the state's general fund, the people who would cut spending were scrutinizing those programs. In particular, Republicans and even some Democrats were pressing to suspend the constitutional amendment passed in 1988 that guaranteed a minimum financing level for the schools.
Many lawmakers say the amendment, Proposition 98, has hobbled them, tying up 41 percent of the money available for programs, or about $17 billion this year. Because of the 1978 measure limiting local property taxes, Proposition 13, schools here depend mainly on the state for their money.
The provision can be suspended by a two-thirds vote of both houses in an emergency. Mr. Wilson favors such a suspension. But Proposition 98 has some powerful backers, including Speaker Brown; Bill Honig, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, and the influential 232,000-member California Teachers Association.
Pressure also built this week for an increase in state income tax rates. Democrats were talking about undoing a reduction, passed in 1986, that cut rates for taxpayers in the highest bracket, to 9.3 percent from 11 percent. The bracket includes single taxpayers earning more than $100,000 and couples earning more than $200,000. It is estimated that the change could raise more than $1 billion a year.
Assemblyman Vasconcellos said he could not live with a solution by which half the shortfall is made up with spending cuts.
 
Veto Is Threatened
 But today, Governor Wilson, reflecting views expressed by many Republicans that increases in taxes would drive away business and thus worsen the state's fiscal condition, threatened to veto such a bill.
Amid all this, many lawmakers of both parties have begun to question the very basis on which California government operates. The huge growth in population, with its attendant demand for services, conflicts with the the 1979 measure that imposes ceilings on increases in government spending.
Senator Maddy said he was considering steps like eliminating county school superintendents, imposing a statewide teacher salary scale and freezing the salaries of state employees at last year's levels.
The state Constitution sets a June 15 deadline for passing a budget for the next fiscal year.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Deficit in California" shows the 1992 spending plan announced in Januray, figures in millions. (Source: Governor's office)

HEADLINE: The Bolshoi Summer Tour Rescued From Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The financially threatened summer season of the Bolshoi Opera and the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House and a planned 31-city tour of "Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet" were rescued by legal maneuvers in bankruptcy court yesterday.
Judge Francis Conrad of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan approved the sale of contracts from the defunct Entertainment Corporation USA, the British-owned production company that had originally arranged for the tours, to Satra Entertainment Corporation, an American branch of Satra Ltd., another British corporation. 
 "We are very grateful to Ara Oztemel, Satra's owner, for believing in us in providing the necessary investment to assure that these companies will appear as scheduled," said Charles Dillingham, former president of the Entertainment Corporation USA, which declared bankruptcy on March 20.
Mr. Dillingham will serve as producer for Satra Entertainment.
Mr. Oztemel, who lives in Greenwich, Conn., has been engaged in industrial trade with the Soviet Union for 40 years through his corporation.
 
The Summer Schedule
 The Bolshoi Opera is to make its first appearances in the United States since 1975, at the Metropolitan from June 25 to July 6 and at Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va., from July 11 to 15. The "Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet" tour is to open on April 11 in West Palm Beach, Fla.
In an earlier effort to save the tours, the Entertainment Corporation USA conducted negotiations with James L. Nederlander, the Broadway theater owner and producer, in the hope that Mr. Nederlander might become a production partner at the Metropolitan and at Wolf Trap Farm Park. But last month Mr. Nederlander dropped out of the negotiations.
Peter Brightman, who will serve as executive producer of Satra Entertainment Corporation, said the financial problems arose because of the recession in both Britain and the United States, and because of the recent cancellation of tours by the Red Army Chorus in Britain and the Georgian State Dancers in the United States.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Looking at History With a Military Slant

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
The Lessons of History
By Michael Howard
217 pages. Yale University Press. $27.50.
 Reading "The Lessons of History," by Michael Howard, against the backdrop of the war in the Persian Gulf, it becomes all too evident that any study of modern history is inseparable from military history. That is one of the main points emerging from Mr. Howard's eloquent book of essays on the nature of armed conflict. Much as we might prefer to read about the forward march of civilization on the eve of the 21st century, the author forces us to ponder whether a world without war is possible in the near future. 
 Mr. Howard, professor of military and naval history at Yale and president of the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London, is sympathetic to the aspirations of people everywhere. But he says that aspirations can lead to convulsive reactions in the streets and, eventually, on the barricades and battlefields. He admires some heroic revolutionary leaders, as well as pragmatic technocrats from Moscow to Beijing, who are struggling to make their societies work. He finds it quite possible that war, in the sense of armed conflict between highly developed societies, may not recur. He even foresees that a stable framework for international order could become firmly established.
Still, looking down the shell-pocked road of history, the author cautions: "Nevertheless violence will continue to erupt within developed societies as well as undeveloped, creating situations of local armed conflict often indistinguishable from traditional war and requiring the continuing exercise of military skills. We have, for better or worse, not yet reached a state of social development when the soldier will find no opportunity to exercise his profession and warrior values have become obsolete."
Professor Howard wrote this two years before camouflaged American warriors fought in an alien desert and Scuds and Patriots began flying over the Middle East, but the picture he draws is all too familiar. After two World Wars, it's hard to distinguish local wars from large-scale wars, particularly when major powers find themselves engaged in ancient feuds between tribal nations that pump oil instead of growing rice or bananas.
So the reader hopes for lessons from this distinguished military historian who knows of war from personal experience. He fought with the Coldstream Guards in the mountains of Italy during World War II when Fascism was crumbling and the dream of a more peaceful world was in the air. It's something of a disappointment not to find ready answers in the book, a disappointment not necessarily in the author but in the brutal realities of the world he describes:
"We are left with a West whose wealth provides no relief from anxiety and turbulence; a socialist world which has now recognized with astonishing unanimity that its God has failed; and a third world which nothing can spare the strains and conflicts inherent in modernization. These are not exactly the 'broad, sunlit uplands' of which Winston Churchill once spoke, but the least that historians can do is to remind the world that there are no such uplands -- or rather that when we do find them, we will find also deeply shadowed valleys full of misery and despair. Each new generation is presented with new problems and new challenges, and analogies drawn from the past are likely to be more of a hindrance than a help in solving them. If the past has anything to teach us it is humility -- and suspicion of glib formulae for improving the lot of mankind."
Well, then, what comfort is there in reading "The Lessons of History"? Nothing less than the pleasures of encountering a challenging mind, supported by a great store of information, delivered in graceful language. The essays in the book cover Prussia in European history; empire, race and war in pre-1914 Britain; the Edwardian arms race; Europe on the eve of World War I; the finest hours of Prime Minister Churchill and why he did not keep up with the changing times; the era that ended after the nightmare of Hitlerism and the Holocaust of World War II, and social change and some of the root causes of war.
Rather diffidently, Professor Howard says, "History is what historians write, and historians are part of the process they are writing about." Still, he shows that a historian can indeed draw upon the past to foreshadow the design of coming events. In an essay written in 1988, which made the point that territory still remained a factor that could lead to war, he was prescient: "The one place in the world today where a global conflict might still conceivably originate is the Persian Gulf, without whose oil resources the West would be economically crippled."
In "The Lessons of History," Professor Howard does hold out some hope for those who envision progress without warfare. He writes that there is a continuing obligation to insure that "nowhere in the world should poverty, illiteracy and grinding hardship" deprive people of opportunities for physical improvement and moral growth. And, in the end, he says that history can count: "The historical process, through the very challenges it poses and the responses it evokes, itself creates the morality of mankind. That seems to me a very good reason for studying it."

HEADLINE: Where Old Havana Plays, Exiles Fear Another Revolution

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
FOR Liliam Martinez, the impulse to sing is overwhelming as she listens to musicians playing sultry Latin tunes in the darkened lounge of the Big Five Club. She rises from her table near the bar, takes a microphone from one of the professional singers and slips into an old Cuban torch song accompanied by a single guitar player. For 15 minutes, her dusky voice seems to peel away the years and transports her husband and other middle-aged club members back to old Havana.
She ends with the mournful ballad "La Gloria Era Tu (You Were Heaven)" and the words flood the interior of the Miami area's most prestigious Cuban-American social club with a powerful longing, not only for lost lovers but also for a homeland abandoned more than three decades ago after Fidel Castro seized power. 
 Sentiment for a touch of pre-Castro Havana and a desire to perpetuate the old social order were the motivating forces and glue behind the creation of the Big Five Club back in the 1960's, when the exile community reluctantly confronted the harsh reality that Castro could not be easily dislodged. After the failed Bay of Pigs invasion and the standoff of the Cuban missile crisis, the exiles came to see that they would not be going home any time soon -- if ever.
In sinking new roots, former members of five of Havana's elite yacht and golf clubs bought a piece of palmetto scrubland in what was then the unincorporated boondocks west of Miami and established the Big Five Club. At first the club was little more than a rustic retreat for family barbecues and picnics. But over the years, it grew into a 30-acre compound of clubhouses with ballrooms, an Olympic-sized swimming pool and athletic fields. New housing occupied almost completely by Spanish-speaking families now fills the surrounding area on the edge of the Everglades.
Like the land, the club and its membership have been transformed by the remarkable prosperity of Cuban-Americans, now numbering 625,000 in the Miami area and perhaps America's most successful immigrant group in rising within a generation to economic, political and social power.
Given this panorama of flourishing suburban life and Cuba's stagnant economy, it may seem that the real Cuban revolution took place in Miami, not Havana. But success and the Americanization of the Cuban community have spelled trouble for the Big Five Club, which with its membership list of 1,600 families, including hundreds of lawyers, physicians and bankers, has no peer among Spanish-speaking social clubs in the continental United States.
"Our young people, teen-agers and those in their 20's, are not too interested in a club," said Juan Torres, the 52-year-old president of Big Five, who owns a commercial printing company. "The ones born in this country feel they are more American than Cuban."
The Big Five is experiencing what other elite clubs in this nation have already learned. When people under the age of 35 mention clubs, they mean health clubs or discotheques. Traditional exclusive clubs, with high initiation fees and dues, don't hold the appeal they once did, especially in a high-voltage city like Miami with its outstanding restaurants, beaches and other attractions. Young Cuban-Americans, like their non-Cuban counterparts, tire easily of too much reminiscing about the old days, so part of the Big Five's problem is embedded in its strengths.
From the beginning, the Big Five was an exile's club with the exile's sense of loss and tragedy. Bar and dinner conversations, in the speeded-up tempo of the Cuban idiom, cover a variety of topics and are full of wit and friendly insults. Yet inevitably they turn to the latest rumor on Castro, like the one that he was ready to grant haven to Saddam Hussein.
And the spell of a glass of whisky or intoxicating nostalgia ignites a special memory of the ever-distancing days of "la gloria" of Havana, a land of childhood dreams, schoolboy triumphs and romantic conquests. It is a memory fiction-encrusted by age but kept alive by a passion for the land left behind and still denied.
If clubs are a home away from home, then the Big Five sheltered its wards by preserving their culture in a timeless context that could never be truly shared by those who had not experienced the old ways. "This is Cuba before Castro took over," said Angel Soler, 55, with a sweep of his hand around the club's restaurant.
In the lounge, Mrs. Martinez, the president of a Spanish foods company who came to Miami in 1960 at the age of 17, offered another view. "We come here to forget all the tensions of American life," she said, and one way she does it is by singing old Cuban love songs long into the night. "No other place in the world would I feel comfortable doing it."
From the start, young children and their grandparents were as much a part of the club as the dues-paying generation. "It's a place where you can drop children off at 10 in the morning and pick them up at 6 in the evening without worrying about them," said Manny Morales Jr., 37, whose father was instrumental in the club's formation. Children have access to organized athletic activities, games and a playground with the Disneyesque name "Big Five Land."
In a spacious card room in the clubhouse, older women play canasta, a rage in Cuba as well as the United States in the 1950's. In the time-capsule ambiance of Big Five, it is still the game of choice. Members over 65 pay greatly reduced monthly dues of $13 and those over 75 pay none, compared to about $75 for most.
The club has a 22-team softball league and four green-coated concrete courts, each with three high walls on which men play Cuban squash, which resembles jai alai with tennis racquets and balls.
Over the years the club has become more democratized, a condition of exile and intermarriage, opening membership to a few non-Cubans, though not to those who cannot speak Spanish. Like many private clubs in the Miami area, it has an official policy of nondiscrimination on basis of race. But longtime members cannot recall ever seeing blacks there, though the Cuban community includes sizable numbers of blacks.
Where originally a family was considered for membership only if there was a connection to the five old clubs in Havana -- the Biltmore Yacht and Country Club, Havana Yacht Club, Miramar Yacht Club, Vedado Tennis Club and Casino Espanol -- time and a new class of Cubans who made their wealth here ended that policy. But some former members of the Havana clubs express disdain for those who recently joined the Big Five.
A former member of the Havana Yacht Club who lives on Key Biscayne groused that the newcomers were O.K. to hang out with but that they were "not really one of us." He insisted on anonymity to protect his livelihood; he works as a business consultant.
The old guard is dying out, however, and since there is only a trickle of older people coming in from Cuba and elsewhere, the Cuban-American community's net growth since Mariel, when 125,000 people arrived, has been slow. Half of Greater Miami's population of 2 million is Hispanic, according to the 1990 census, but the major gains in the 1980's came in immigration from countries like Nicaragua and Colombia, creating the most ethnically diverse Hispanic community in the nation.
Besides having the highest household income of any major Hispanic group, Cuban-Americans whose families arrived before 1980 are much closer to non-Hispanic whites in terms of education, time of marriage and birth rate than they are to other Hispanic Americans.
"Our hope is that when our young do marry and raise families they will come back to the club to place their children in a wholesome atsmosphere free from drugs and other problems," said Fausto Diaz Oliver, 56, a former Big Five president who is a plastic-container manufacturer.
To encourage the process, the club will reduce its usual $4,000 initiation fee to $1,500 for any new member with children under 24, and it plans to add racquetball courts and a disco.
But like Castro's eventual fate, few dare predict the future course of the club in a land that has always looked to tomorrow, not yesterday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Deal Looks Doubtful to Viola

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., April 2

 BODY:
Unique. Innovative. Special.
Officials for the Mets used the words over and over again on Monday during their news conference announcing Dwight Gooden's $15.45 million contract extension. 
 Frank Viola heard those words, and he expects to hear them again and again. Indeed, the accomplished left-hander for the Mets said today he was all but certain the words would haunt his dealings with the Mets on a contract extension. It was Viola's opinion that while the words reflected the organization's affection for Gooden, they also amounted to a strategic groundwork for negotiations with him.
"Dwight's different from me in their eyes," Viola said.
 
Viola Perceives Limits
 And so the offered terms of endearment, Viola suspects, will not be nearly as lavish as the $5.15 million the Mets are now obligated to pay Gooden for the 1992, 1993 and 1994 seasons. In that light, Viola perceived the team's structuring of Gooden's deal -- $750,000 of the guaranteed money comes under an agreement for rights to make promotional videos featuring Gooden -- and the club's underlining of its "unique" aspects as tactics designed to limit Viola's asking price for a base salary.
"I don't see it happening," Viola, the 30-year-old left-hander who won 20 games for the Mets last season, said of a satisfactory deal with the Mets. "I don't know why that is. I am actually lost as to what they are thinking.
"But in the final analysis, it doesn't matter one way or the other. All of it -- Roger Clemens's contract, Dwight Gooden's contract -- is going to help in the long run. Now or later. Here or elsewhere."
The Mets have made only one formal offer to Viola, a three-year proposal for $12.5 million. Viola promptly rejected it, and Craig Fenech, his agent, countered last week with a deal for four years and roughly $20 million.
"Our position is that one judges the Mets by what they do and not what they say," Fenech said when asked about the organization's portrayal of the Gooden package. "From my point of view, the deal with Gooden means the Mets have recognized what fair market value is. They have de facto accepted the market place."
 Certainly, the Mets, who had long termed Clemens's average annual salary of $5.38 million as "incomprehensible" and a threat to the financial health of the industry, wound up making huge compromises in their negotiations with Gooden. That deal was a leap of more than a million dollars from their proposal of two weeks before.
"From their standpoint, they had to sign Dwight, and I understood that from the start," Viola said. "They couldn't have lost Darryl Strawberry and then Dwight Gooden. They would have been dead in New York. But I'm not considered New York."
Gooden said the Mets ought to consider Viola a vital part of the future success of the franchise, although he declined to say whether Viola was worth the money the Mets will now have to pay him.
"It's important they get a deal done with him," Gooden said. "He's a big part of this staff."
Fenech, meanwhile, would have no part of the organization's previous claims that affording both Gooden and Viola would be financially problematic.
"There is no doubt in my mind that the Mets have the wherewithal," Fenech said. "And anyone who doubts that hasn't taken a look at the economics of baseball.
"As for whether Frank is worth what Dwight got, I think it's unfair to the athletes to make the comparison and it's irrelevant to our negotiations. This is not an arbitration case. We don't have to go in there with reams of computer data comparing Frank to Dwight. The Mets will pay us what we consider to be fair market value or we will take our case to the rest of baseball at the end of the season."
As of late this afternoon, the Mets and Fenech had not spoken since Gooden signed, although there were still plans for several conversations. On Monday, Al Harazin, the executive vice president of the Mets, who handles contracts, attempted to avoid addressing the Viola situation.
"We want badly to sign him," Harazin said. "And we will offer him a handsome amount of money."
