HEADLINE: Not Too Late for Albanian Democracy

 BODY:
The contested election that took place Sunday in Albania, Europe's last Communist tyranny, was more than a historical curiosity. Not long ago, everything seemed to be forbidden in Stalinist Albania -- attending church, owning a car or murmuring a single critical syllable about Enver Hoxha, the cheerless party boss from 1945 until his death in 1985. So the mere fact of what appears to have been a free vote is more striking than the outcome -- a Communist victory over the newly formed opposition party, the Democrats.
President Ramiz Alia did not embrace democracy; it was forced upon him by bursting discontent, underscored by Mr. Alia's loss of his own seat in Parliament. Albania is Europe's poorest country; if Albanians are denied any form of democratic expression, popular anger and frustration could burst into widespread violence. Protests that began in Shkoder, in northern Albania, yesterday have already claimed 3 lives and wounded 30 people. 
 Desperation has caused 80,000 mostly young Albanians to flee the country since last June. Following an ancient exit route, thousands of refugees have packed ships bound for Brindisi, on Italy's heel. Even this comparative trickle provoked a Cabinet crisis in Rome, where politicians fear newcomers will flood the job market and otherwise burden Italy's economy.
Albania's other neighbors, Greece and Yugoslavia, have political reasons to fear a huge exodus across hard-to-police frontiers. Both worry that an influx of Albanians will heighten ethnic rivalries rooted in ancient quarrels. Promoting democratic values and stable politics in Tirana is thus in Europe's interest, and America's too.
Albania has for the first time endorsed the Helsinki Accords, which commit all signers to freedom of worship and travel. And it is seeking full membership in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which would end decades of total isolation.
These are important tokens of change, and now that elections have actually been held, Albania deserves encouragement from Western democracies -- conditioned, that is, on Mr. Alia's fidelity to his liberalizing promises.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Iraq: Drawing the Line

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
An Iraqi Shiite who has devoted his life to opposing Saddam Hussein visited me on Monday. "I know what you would not do," he said over bagels and coffee. "You would not intervene with military force in my country's civil war. I disagree, yet I understand. But what do you think the United States should do" to stop the killing of Shiites and Kurds, short of such intervention?
 His distinction is important. I still believe that the worst thing for Americans and Iraqis is for the U.S. to be drawn into the tribal and religious warfare there. But the second-worst thing would be to do nothing at all. 
 President Bush, in his zeal to avoid the prime sin of military intervention, is committing the second sin of almost total passivity.
 Passivity dangerously and erroneously signals a willingness to live with Saddam Hussein. It also suggests a cynical indifference toward Kurds and others after having incited their rebellion.
 At a minimum, Mr. Bush should enforce the strictest interpretation of the cease-fire agreement with Baghdad. That means shooting down Iraqi aircraft and helicopters. The loophole that allows the use of helicopters for administrative purposes has become a general license. Mr. Bush promised to destroy armed helicopters, and he should keep that promise.
 As for destroying Iraqi tanks and artillery, that leads into the civil war quagmire. It goes well beyond the U.N. mandate and would embroil American forces directly in ground combat.
 There should be no illusion, however, that firing on Iraqi helicopters will level the battlefield between Baghdad and the rebels. Iraq's forces vastly outnumber and outgun the rebels. But strong action in the air would send a critical signal to the Iraqi military.
 It would remind them that everything will be harder if Saddam stays in power. That signal has grown far too faint. Iraqi military leaders could read faintness as a change in Washington's course, as a new policy that only Saddam can keep Iraq whole.
 The nightmare of Lebanonization has to be avoided. But Mr. Bush and his coalition partners have carried this credo too far -- to the point of almost dropping the anti-Saddam ball. The Arab League compounded the signaling error last weekend by letting Saddam's Government participate in its Cairo meeting.
 There is another allied signal to Iraqi military leaders that needs strengthening: You will be held responsible for your brutality. Let them worry about what that may mean in personal accountability and future economic hardships.
 The Administration's failure to warn Iraq is shocking. The State Department practically achieves rhetorical orgasms of condemnation every time Israel deports Palestinian terrorists. It rarely condemns the killings of Kurds and Shiites.
 Silence fills the halls of the U.N. The Security Council surprised itself by authorizing war against Iraq. It surprises few today by returning to form and scampering away from all responsibility for postwar Iraqi turmoil.
 The U.N. does not mix into the internal affairs of its members. To be sure, such intervention would open a vault of troubles.
 Yet the U.N. has intervened with peacekeeping forces in the Congo and Cyprus and proposes to do so now in Cambodia. True, it always has been at the invitation of the host government. But regional organizations have been known to act without an invitation. Several West African states sent forces recently to impose a cease-fire on warring Liberians.
 My Iraqi visitor wants no similar involvement from Iraq's neighbors, whom he rightly fears. He knows well the U.N.'s reluctance to intervene. Still, he asks for some help from the U.N., some notice, some aid for refugees, some words of warning to the butchers. The U.N. can and should provide all. Maybe yesterday's French and Turkish initiative, though stalled, can produce some action.
 Above all, he prays for U.S. military intervention. But unlike the Savonarolas of intervention who preach that American guns are the easy answer to civil war, he also realizes the magnitude of what he asks of Washington.
 He smiles and offers one last story about a Kurd who said to a Palestinian: "I envy you. When you die, at least the Arabs, the United States and the United Nations complain."

HEADLINE: Brooklyn's Boulevard of Broken Promises

 BODY:
Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, Eastern Parkway was once the Champs Elysees of Brooklyn, a grand, tree-lined thoroughfare and a model for urban boulevards throughout the nation. Now, four years after New York City awarded a $59 million contract to restore the parkway's faded 19th-century elegance, the avenue and its once parklike pedestrian malls are in shambles -- a trash-strewn symbol of the failure of city government.
How did it happen? The Bronx-based company the city hired for the restoration was supposed to complete the work by last August. Then in December 1989 the business, Naclerio Contracting Company, was barred from bidding on new city contracts for three years as punishment for filing false invoices on other city jobs. Its cash flow problem greatly aggravated, Naclerio filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; construction, already behind schedule, slowed nearly to a halt. 
 Instead of taking swift action to void the contract and replace Naclerio with a responsible business, as newly streamlined contracting procedures permit, the city's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius Riccio, is trying to coax the bankrupt company along by spoon-feeding it with frequent installment payments. It's a losing strategy. The project is still moving at a slow pace. And Mr. Riccio's effort to prop up a plainly inadequate business sends a message of bureaucratic weakness to taxpayers and other city contractors.
Mr. Riccio argued that the job could be done quicker by avoiding legal entanglement in Naclerio's bankruptcy proceeding. He also feared that hiring a new contractor would lead to higher costs. But coddling Naclerio isn't getting the job done. Furthermore, it shouldn't be all that difficult, given the present recession, to find a contractor eager to complete it at a reasonable price. Mr. Riccio has ample reason to revoke the contract.

HEADLINE: Albany Republicans Seek Fairness to Suburbs in School Cuts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Lessons From a Budget Crisis" (editorial, March 23) neglects to acknowledge my position on the New York State budget and many of the alternatives State Senate Republicans have advocated. 
 I agree with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that $51.9 billion is sufficient to meet the immediate needs of this state. This does not represent a budget cut, but a slower growth rate more in line with inflation. There is more than $3 billion in new spending in the Governor's budget, much of it for interest on the state debt and matching costs for social service programs.
A 10 percent cut in state aid to education, as suggested by the Governor, does not sound unfair until you examine the lopsided distribution of those cuts. Suburban communities are being asked to bear a higher share, with the proposed reduction for some school districts as high as 67 percent, or 20 percent of their total budget. This cut needs to be minimized by shifting money in the budget or restructured to provide greater fairness and equity statewide.
Senate Republicans are also concerned about the magnitude of local aid reductions, and we support lifting costly mandates on local government. We propose lowering matching costs for Medicaid; limits on home relief benefits for people who are employable; prompt payment for local government and not-for-profits; relieving counties of costs associated with mental health patients held in state facilities, and reducing unnecessary maintenance standards for low-volume roads.
We agree with your call for a restructuring of Medicaid. Restructuring all social welfare programs should be a major focus of government because of the explosive cost of these programs, with little progress in reducing client dependence.
State Senate Republicans have proposed greater use of health maintenance organizations to deliver medical services to the needy. Our alternative Medicaid proposal and other related reforms can save taxpayers about $450 million more than has been suggested by the Governor.
Senate Republicans do not like the Governor's 10-cent increase in the gas tax. We are opposed to using the gas tax as a way to bail out the state treasury. But we recognize the need to provide a steady stream of funds to finance road and bridge repairs and ordinary maintenance.
Senate Republicans are opposed to increasing the state income tax. We believe that any effort to hold the budget hostage to an income tax increase is a waste of time and a disservice to the people we represent.
The way to avoid revenue increases is to spend no more than $51.9 billion. We do not favor gimmicks that allow for the appearance of holding the line on spending only to delay payment into the next fiscal year.
 
(State Senator) RALPH J. MARINO
Majority Leader
Albany, March 26, 1991

HEADLINE: Business, Not Bombs, Will Unite Ireland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Bullet and the Ballot Box" by Padraig O'Malley (Op-Ed, March 2), I would like to ask Irish-Americans who support Noraid and indirectly the Irish Republican Army: What must happen before Britain will consider serious negotiations on home rule? 
 Doesn't the I.R.A. realize its power base lies in the Irish Republic and in the millions of Americans, Canadians, Australians and British of Irish descent? These people are conservatives who are embarrassed to support so-called terrorist activities. But they would support peace initiatives and territorial discussions if the I.R.A. changed its tactics.
The Irish Republic has wisely cast its vote with the European Community. By encouraging its population to study engineering and computer science, Ireland is attracting outside investment. Ireland doesn't suffer from pompous delusions that are the underlying cause of labor unrest. Ireland's friendly business environment will attract increased investment. Manufacturing will transform Ireland from an agrarian economic colony of Britain to an industrial power able to compete in the new world order. The future will bring the day when British officials arrive in Dublin begging for investments. That day will also be the first day serious home rule negotiations take place.
If Irish-Americans really want a united Ireland they should invest in Ireland and encourage their companies to do so.
 
GERARD O'HALLORAN
Pompton Lakes, N.J., March 15, 1991

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The High Cost Of Low Savings

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT'S morning in America, say two economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- the morning after. Since the mid-1980's analysts have been quarreling over the consequences of the free-spending ways of Americans. Now, Ethan Harris and Charles Steindel have produced what may be the definitive study of low savings and its impact.
Their article in the latest issue of the bank's Quarterly Review acknowledges the joys of eight years unbroken by recession, but they nevertheless believe that the 1980's consumption boom cost the economy dearly. If America had merely maintained the rate of capital accumulation of the earlier postwar decades, the two economists estimate, national output would have been $250 billion larger in 1990. Should the low savings rate of the 1980's persist through the 1990's, they project that the annual loss will reach $750 million. 
 The study's computer simulations suggest that getting back on the old growth track would not require onerous sacrifice: A five percentage point shift from consumption to savings would do the trick. But like many economists, Mr. Harris and Mr. Steindel find it improbable that tax breaks or exhortations from Washington could convert the shop-till-you-drop generation to the gospel of savings. Their own fix, huge Federal budget surpluses that would free hundreds of billions of dollars for private investment, seems only slightly more plausible.
One reason economists disagree about what happened to the savings rate in the 1980's is that they cannot quite pin down what savings is. For example, should capital gains from the run-up in stock prices in the late 1980's count as savings? The wow in the Dow certainly made a lot of people richer. However, if the gain merely reflected shareholders' expectations of what the next sucker would pay, it had no direct effect on productive capacity.
Mr. Harris and Mr. Steindel prefer a clean (if conceptually imperfect) definition that goes to the crux of the growth issue: savings available to augment productive capital. This, they reckon, is the inflation-adjusted change in household wealth, excluding holdings of government bonds and residential real estate. Corporate net worth, rather than stock prices, is used to value stocks.
Measured this way, the savings rate is worrisomely feeble. From 1953 through 1973, it averaged 8.7 percent of gross national product. But from 1980 through 1989, the rate slipped to just 4 percent. And in the last half of the 1980's, it averaged a still more meager 3.4 percent.
Foreign savers did make up part of the difference, in the process transforming America from the world's largest creditor to the largest debtor. Part, but not much: Savings from foreign and domestic sources fell to 5 percent of G.N.P. from 8.4.
The economists estimate that by 1989, this cumulative dip in savings had reduced the nation's stock of capital by 15 percent, and cut the G.N.P. by 5 percent. Extrapolating to the year 2000, the G.N.P. gap reaches 10 percent -- more than Washington currently spends on defense and Social Security.
A five percentage point shift from domestic consumption to savings would narrow the current G.N.P. gap in short order. It would also restore America's status as an exporter of capital, gradually paring foreign claims against future output. And while there would be no gain without some pain, consumption would approach the pre-1980's growth path within a decade.
Conceivably, households could make the transition with only a little help from Uncle Sam. But not likely: Tax carrots that increased private savings would also add to government deficits, partly offsetting the savings gain. In any case, even the truest believers in expanded individual retirement accounts and tax preferences for capital gains would have trouble conjuring a $100 billion-plus increase in private savings.
A more likely source for part or all of the extra savings is the Federal budget itself. The deficit, which reduced savings by 2.5 percent of the G.N.P. in the 1980's, is already slated under last year's budget accord to fall to just eight-tenths of 1 percent of the G.N.P. by 1995. If Washington had the will to push the budget two or three percentage points into surplus, the national savings drought would be history.
That, unfortunately, is a lot to ask from politicians who scatter like quail at the sound of the T-word. Raising government savings (or reducing dissavings) by a single percentage point of G.N.P. would require tax increases or spending cuts of $60 billion. But as the economists' simulation makes all too clear, the meter is running: Every year of delay makes the recovery more expensive.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column in Business Day yesterday misstated a projection by two economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the annual loss in national output if the low savings rate of the 1980's persists through the 1990's. It is $750 billion, not $750 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman of Polaroid Plans to Retire May 7

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
William J. McCune Jr. plans to retire as chairman of the Polaroid Corporation on May 7 after the company's annual meeting, the company has announced. Polaroid said I. MacAllister Booth, its president and chief executive, is expected to be given the additional post of chairman.
Mr. McCune, who is 75, has been associated with Polaroid for 52 years and succeeded the company's founder, Edwin H. Land, as chairman. A 1937 graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, he joined Polaroid in 1939, two years after the company was founded by Dr. Land, who died on March 1 at the age of 81. Mr. McCune's first job was to establish the company's quality-control program. 
 During World War II, Mr. McCune worked with Dr. Land on Polaroid's guided-missile project. After the war, he worked with Dr. Land on the development of the original Polaroid Land camera and film.
Mr. McCune was appointed president and chief operating officer in 1975, and was elected to the board. He was named president and chief executive in 1980 and became chairman in 1982. Mr. McCune continued to serve as chairman when Mr. Booth assumed the position of chief executive in 1986. Mr. McCune has not been actively involved in the company's management since then.
As the first chairman after Dr. Land, Mr. McCune was a transitional leader at Polaroid, which is based in Cambridge, Mass. Analysts said Mr. McCune performed a tough balancing act, moving the company away from the paternalistic approach of Dr. Land to a more business-like approach. Still, some analysts asserted that Mr. McCune did not go far enough to instill a bottom line focus at Polaroid.
In 1976, there was a kidnapping attempt made against Mr. McCune on a street a few blocks from his Cambridge office. Mr. McCune foiled the abduction by fighting off an armed attacker, taking away his shotgun and chasing the assailant away.
In 1991, Polaroid's operating profit is expected to be constrained because of the weak economy and costs associated with product introductions. Analysts estimate that the company will earn about $2.10 a share, compared with $2.20 a share in 1990.
Polaroid's stock closed yesterday at $25, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Panel Confirms Stangl As Chief of the M.T.A.

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
When a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train arrived at Grand Central Terminal after skipping the 125th Street Station, Peter E. Stangl, the railroad's president, ordered the train's crew to return to Harlem and apologize to passengers.
"That was just Peter being Peter," said Thomas M. Downs, New Jersey's Commissioner of Public Transportation and a longtime friend of Mr. Stangl's. For Mr. Stangl, the incident in 1989 was "no big deal." 
 The State Senate yesterday confirmed Mr. Stangl as the new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the umbrella agency that oversees the largest and oldest public transportation system in the country.
The appointment came after the committee, in an odd confirmation process, had first approved his nomination and then had withdrawn its approval. The flip-flop came when members found out that Mr. Stangl was in the cab of a Metro-North train while a friend, Myron Schuster, operated the throttle and brakes during a ride in October between the Croton-Harmon station and Beacon, N.Y.
 
Reprimand and Regret
 Federal and state investigations into the incident cleared Mr. Stangl of any wrongdoing and of jeopardizing the safety of passengers. After reprimanding him, committee members decided his lapse of judgment was an aberration, a conclusion that many friends, colleagues and Mr. Stangl support.
"I wish it had never happened obviously, and as I've said, it was a mistake," he said. "It was not an easy thing to go through, that's certainly true, but on a very personal level, it probably strengthened me."
Mr. Stangl will need that additional fortitude to contend with the problems facing the M.T.A.: a loss of riders, deficits in operating budgets, labor negotiations and uncertainty over whether the Legislature will help the agency finance its $11.7 billion, five-year capital program scheduled to begin next year.
"It's the worst possible time to take on this job, because of the economic situation," said Richard Ravitch, who raised money for the authority's first capital program when he was chairman of the M.T.A. from 1979 to 1983.
 
A 'Brass Ring' Job
 Friends, family and colleagues deny that Mr. Stangl has a masochistic streak but nonetheless wonder why he wants the job.
"It's the brass ring in public transportation in this country, I guess," said Thomas Glynn, general manager of Boston's transit system, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. "But you couldn't call it a plum, because that connotes it's some kind of reward, which it isn't."
"Maybe because it's an enormous challenge, and Peter likes a challenge," said Richard C. Leone, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a friend of Mr. Stangl's.
Mr. Stangl said he wanted the job for both reasons.
"This is an institution that serves millions of people every day," he said. "I like the idea of knowing that on a daily basis, how we deliver a service affects millions of lives."
The job will cap a career spent rescuing many of the region's faltering public transit systems from years of abuse, neglect and political stalemates.
As assistant commissioner for public transportation in New Jersey, Peter Eugene Stangl helped integrate the state's transportation system, which eventually became N.J. Transit. He later helped to increase riders and improve on-time service at Metro-North.
Although he has weighty credentials for administering the country's largest public transit system, Mr. Stangl insists that his career is an accident.
"I never grew up wanting to be a lawyer or a doctor or a reporter or an electrician," he said. "I was just basically looking to do something that was interesting and that I would feel good about when I got home at the end of the day."
In fact, after he left New Jersey state government in 1978, he took 10 months to contemplate his future from behind an eight ball. "I just shot pool for 10 hours a day," he said. "I've played a little golf, and I like tennis, but no other game I've played requires the mental discipline of pool."
Mr. Stangl, who was born on July 14, 1941, spends his leisure time with his wife, Barbara, at their house on the Moses Taylor estate in Westchester County. The house was built in 1792 and once served as a chauffeur's home. The Stangls have no children. Mr. Stangl has pretty much given up pool, but he continues to play poker and tennis.
"He has an awful fast, cannon-ball hard serve that I sometimes don't even try to return, lest it kill me," said Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, the regional administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, who met Mr. Stangl when they both held office in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay in the early 1970's. "He's just like that serve: energetic, almost kinetic, driven and tough to beat back."
The odds were against Mr. Stangl when Mr. Ravitch appointed him to head Metro-North in 1981. The railroad was losing riders, only 81 percent of its trains were on time, and many of them were famous for running their heaters in the summer and air-conditioners in the winter.
"Metro-North was a real big mess, but Peter brought in new ideas and energy and made it a success story in New York and gave people in the mass-transit business around the country hope," Mr. Glynn said. "Peter is really seen as the single individual who led the charge, and he won."
The economy worked with him during that battle, but the recession has made Albany, where his major campaign to get financing for the capital program will be fought, more thrifty. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who nominated Mr. Stangl for the chairman's job, has proposed cutting state spending on mass transportation by $6 million, a decrease that the city would match.
Legislators point to the $16 billion already spent overhauling the M.T.A. network and ask why they should allocate $11 billion more. The network is made up of Metro-North, the Long Island Rail Road and the New York City Transit Authority.
Mr. Stangl must "build a coalition of legislators, M.T.A. board members and the body politic that can get the money together to fund that capital program at a time when everyone is counting every penny," Mr. Sidamon-Eristoff noted.
 
In Touch With Riders
 During Metro-North's metamorphosis, his candor and accessibility disarmed critical politicians and their constituents.
He often startled irate riders by inviting them to his office for coffee and a chat about the railroad's problems and how he might solve them. He became a familiar fixture at town meetings and public hearings in the counties served by Metro-North, listening to passenger complaints and explaining how he planned to address them.
But as president of Metro-North, Mr. Stangl also established a reputation for independence, running the railroad relatively free of interference from the M.T.A. chairman and board. He said he intended to run the M.T.A. in a collegial fashion, consulting with board members to plan long- and short-term goals.
"We will have differences, we will have debates, that's what boards do," Mr. Stangl said. "But we need to be together on the big items, and part of my job is to get us together so we can agree on what our goals are."

HEADLINE: In the Right Hands, The Lowly Meatloaf Finds It's a Star

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
THE way Sharon Moore talks about meatloaf, one would think she was describing the latest creation from the kitchen of the Four Seasons in New York.
"The first thing you need to know about meatloaf is that it can be served to the finest of company," Mrs. Moore said. Her recipe for blue-ribbon loaf blends ground pork and veal with crumbled blue cheese. "Can you imagine anything more beautiful, anything more elegant?" said Mrs. Moore, a food and wine writer and editor. 
 If she seems passionate about meatloaf, there is good reason. Mrs. Moore has just written a cookbook devoted to the subject, and not just to the blobs of oven-baked ground beef that have been the nemesis of children all over America.
Her book, "Meatloaf" (Clarkson Potter, $10.95), includes recipes for wild-game meatloaf made from venison, rabbit and pheasant; ethnic meatloaf, like a meatloaf stroganoff with mushrooms and sour cream; company meatloaf made primarily with smoked ham, and regional meatloaf, like Tex-Mex loaf with chili powder and kidney beans or Corn Belt loaf with ground beef, pork, sausage and crumbled cornbread. There is even a recipe for a California sushi loaf that relies on shrimp and crabmeat rather than red meat.
All this is a far cry from the bulbuous ground-beef loaves most Americans envision. If a cookbook devoted to meatloaf seems at first blush silly, nearly 10,000 copies of "Meatloaf" have been sold across the country since the book was published in January, and not just in the Midwest, where meatloaf has long been a staple. The publisher says "Meatloaf" is selling especially well in the Northeast and in California; so much for the two coasts as great spawning grounds for new ideas in cooking.
Yet to Mrs. Moore, "Meatloaf" was an idea whose time had come. In the current recession, she said, with families watching their pennies, meatloaf is a less costly alternative to other meatdishes. Fewer households have someone at home all day to cook, she added, and meatloaf freezes beautifully. Then there is the growing interest in "comfort food" -- pot roast with mashed potatoes, for instance -- as an occasional departure from low-fat, low-sodium, low-cholesterol, low-calorie cuisine.
"More and more, people are looking for easy-to-make foods that remind them of childhood," Mrs. Moore said. "Meatloaf fits that bill."
Dorothy Rosenbaum of Evanston, Ill., often ate meatloaf as a girl in the Pennsylvania Dutch country. "Meatloaf is earthy and basic," she said. "It may not have a gourmet element, but it conveys a sense of warmth and of family. And it is always served in generous portions. I love it."
Not everyone is.
A cartoon in a recent food magazine showed a flight attendant serving meatloaf to her passengers. "In case of a water landing," the flight attendant said in the caption, "your meatloaf can be used as a flotation device."
In "The Sting," Robert Redford nearly is sickened after ordering the blue-plate special. "I should have ordered the meatloaf," Mr. Redford tells the waitress behind the counter.
"It's not any better," the waitress responds.
Even to some purveyors of comfort food, meatloaf is simply too plebian. "We considered putting it on the menu but concluded that it was too borderline," said Linda Terczak, an owner of Terczak's , a comfort-food restaurant in Chicago. "People associate meatloaf with diners."
But Mrs. Moore holds that meatloaf approaches gastronomic nirvana -- and not just because it evokes childhood. Purists would maintain that meatloaf has to be made from red meat and some kind of filler like oatmeal and bread crumbs. Mrs. Moore takes a more expansive view: "Anything that has meat in it and is shaped into a loaf can be called meatloaf."
Indeed, her book "has 42 different recipes, only about one-third of which include ground beef," she said. She went on: "Most of the recipes use chicken, turkey, lamb or some other meat besides beef. The California sushi loaf is mostly shrimp and crabmeat, but it also includes fillers like brown rice and avocado.
In writing "Meatloaf," Sharon Moore's daily routine consisted of rushing home to her kitchen in Forest Hills, Queens, to prepare a different meatloaf recipe almost every night. All told, it tooks six weeks to try out the different meatloaves. The joke around the Moore household is that in writing "Meatloaf," she gave her husband, David, a coronary.
"My poor husband; he loves meatloaf and he ate all 42 loaves gladly, but two years ago he developed high cholesterol and needed a bypass operation," she said.
Basic meatloaf made from hamburger and filler is hard to ruin, but more advanced varieties require more care. So Mrs. Moore offers this advice for first-time meatloaf cooks:
First, use your hands and mix the ingredients well to avoid clumps.
Second, don't overcook your meatloaf. It can get as dry as sawdust.
Finally, allow the meatloaf to cool slightly before cutting it. Longtime meatloaf lovers call this allowing the meatloaf to "rest" so the flavors can blend.
 
Veal, Pork And Chicken
 
Granny's Meatloaf
Total time: 1 hour and 45 minutes
 
1 pound ground beef
 1/2 pound ground veal
 1/2 pound ground pork
2 eggs
 1/2 cup fine bread crumbs
 3/4 cup chopped parsley
 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
 1/2 teaspoon dried basil
 1/4 cup chopped green pepper (optional)
1 1/2 teaspoons salt
 1/2 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper
3 or 4 strips bacon.
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.
2. Place all the ingredients except the bacon in a bowl. Briefly blend well and form into a loaf. Place the loaf on a rack in a 10-inch baking pan and cover with the bacon slices.
3. Bake for 1 1/2 hours until the meatloaf is firm and the bacon browned. Let the meatloaf rest for 10 to 15 minutes.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Creole Chicken Loaf
Total time: 1 hour and 15 minutes
 
1 1/2 cups finely chopped onions
1 garlic clove, minced
1 cup finely diced celery
1 tablespoon unsalted butter plus 1/4 teaspoon butter for greasing pan
1 large egg
 1/2 cup heavy cream
 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper, or to taste
1 teaspoon file powder (optional)
1 teaspoon dried oregano
 Salt to taste
1 1/2 pounds chicken breast, deboned, skinned, trimmed of fat and ground
1 1/2 cups fine dry bread crumbs
 1/2 cup finely chopped sweet red pepper
 1/2 cup finely chopped green pepper
1 small carrot, grated
1 1/2 cups finely chopped fresh tomatoes, seeds removed.
1. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.
2. Saute the onions, garlic and celery briefly in the butter, just until the onions are translucent and the celery is bright green. Cool slightly.
3. Beat the egg; blend in the cream and seasonings. Add the chicken and bread crumbs and mix thoroughly. Add the sauteed onion mixture and the peppers, carrot and tomatoes, and blend gently but thoroughly. Place in a greased 9-by-5-by-3-inch loaf pan.
4. Bake for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until firm and browned. Let the meatloaf rest for 10 to 15 minutes.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

HEADLINE: 6% of U.S. Teen-Agers Report Trying Suicide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Six percent of American teen-agers say they have tried to commit suicide and 15 percent say they have "come very close to trying," according to a poll conducted for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield by the Gallup organization.
Three out of five of those surveyed said they knew a teen-ager who had attempted suicide and 15 percent said they knew one who had succeeded. But when asked to identify the "single greatest problem you face," suicide did not rank among the top 22 problems the teen-agers listed. The list was headed by grades in school, career uncertainties and problems in growing up, said George Gallup Jr., president of the Gallup organization. 
 Of the teen-agers who said they had tried or come close to trying suicide, nearly half cited family problems or problems at home. Other reasons included depression, problems with friends, feelings of worthlessness, and boy-girl relationships. Some gave more than one reason.
The poll, conducted nationwide from November to January among 1,152 people 13 to 19 years old, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Forty-one percent of the teen-agers polled said their school was providing counseling or seminars on suicide prevention. And a fifth of them said their communities offered a suicide telephone line, counseling or seminars. Twenty-eight percent said their church or synagogue had suicide prevention programs.
But more than 80 percent felt that communities, schools and religious institutions should offer programs to help teen-agers handle their problems.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Up in U.S. After Declining Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher yesterday against most major currencies in domestic trading after falling overseas as traders awaited the release of United States employment figures.
Gold closed higher, with the April contract on the Commodity Exchange in New York rising $1.80 an ounce to close at $360.30. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $359.20, up $2 from late Tuesday. 
 Analysts described foreign exchange trading as quiet in advance of the March employment report, which is scheduled to be released tomorrow.
 
Weak Data Expected
 Earl I. Johnson, a foreign exchange analyst with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the job data were expected to show a further weakening in the economy, forcing the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. The dollar tends to fall with interest rates because it, like all currencies, is supported by higher rates.
Mr. Johnson said the Fed might delay any action until after the release of the inflation figures next week. If inflation appears to be accelerating, the Fed might decide against any interest rate moves.
The dollar surged higher last week, partly on the belief that the economy was beginning to strengthen and that interest rates would remain stable. Now, Mr. Johnson said, "there's a feeling that some of the euphoria about the economy rebounding is not coming true and that says the dollar probably overshot itself last week."
He predicted the dollar would trade in a narrow range until the employment figures were released.
The British pound lost ground to the dollar in New York, falling to $1.7735, from $1.7780 late Tuesday. In earlier trading in London, sterling was higher, rising to $1.7805, from $1.7675 late Tuesday.
But the dollar fell against the Japanese yen in New York, falling to 137.30 yen, from 137.85 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.35 yen, to 137.78, and it was quoted later in London at 137.35.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, were: 1.6750 German marks, up from 1.6705; 1.4205 Swiss francs, up from 1.4185; 5.6795 French francs, up from 5.6615; 1,247.00 Italian lire, up from 1,245.50, and 1.15565 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15515.

HEADLINE: For Now, Pride Is Enough for These Ohio Voters

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, March 29

 BODY:
Flags are still flying along the neat blocks of bungalows on the border of Cleveland and Euclid. Shops still carry signs urging all who pass to "support our troops."
And for the moment, at least, George Bush seems to be a part of the patriotic tableau, an ominous sign for the Democrats. Even some who yearn for a stiff challenge to President Bush are hard put to name the Democrats who could provide it. 
 "He stood up for what I would have done," said Michael Brewer, a 48-year-old technician in Euclid who did not vote for Mr. Bush in the 1988 Presidential election. Cary Wayne, a 42-year-old executive recruiter, a Democrat who voted for both Ronald Reagan and Mr. Bush, said the President "made me very proud to be an American, not that I wasn't before."
 
Postwar Glow Lingers
 Interviews with about 20 people in this working-class area found an edginess about the faltering economy, but also the expectation that Mr. Bush would now turn his attention to problems at hoe.
Richard Stegh, 33, who was laid off from his job at a fiberglass products factory, said he understood that the war in the Persian Gulf "had to take a front burner."
But Mr. Stegh, whose house was decorated with one of the larger flags in the neighborhood, said he hoped that now "things are stable enough in the Middle East that he can start in on unemployment and education." And the father of two children -- "I'm playing Mr. Mom," he said, watching the children while his wife was at work -- had nothing but praise for Mr. Bush.
A great unknown in politics these days is how long Mr. Bush's postwar glow will last, how long he is seen as part and parcel of yellow ribbons and national pride. Democrats note that Presidential approval ratings can be extraordinarily volatile, that the 20 months between now and the 1992 election is a lifetime in politics and that domestic worries will only grow. Republicans contend that the war has brought lasting benefits to Mr. Bush.
"The message that working-class people in Ohio had was, This is not going to be another Vietnam, that we're going to do it right this time," said Brian Berry, executive director of the Ohio Republican Party. "It was a very clear message."
 
Behind Bush '100 Percent'
 Indeed, in Muldoon's Saloon and Eatery and Buettner's Bakery, on street corners and stoops, people often responded with patriotic fervor when asked about the President. "I have two brothers in the service, and when he decided to do this I was behind him 100 percent," said Laura Barry, a 30-year-old homemaker with two children and a husband who is a fireman. "You can't let somebody like that take over a country," she said, referring to Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein.
The Democrats, Mrs. Barry said, seemed "passive.'
Mike Lynch, a 22-year-old employee of an appliance service shop who voted for Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988, said of Mr. Bush: "I think he's shown his ability to lead in the gulf. Everything else, I really haven't thought that much about."
This is an area where many people are accustomed to voting Democratic in state and local races and Republican for the President. Tim Hagan, a Democrat who is a Cuyahoga County Commissioner, said, "These people are very, very patriotic and would rally to the flag and to the President." The glow from the war, he said, "has not diminished dramatically."
Still, there is some concern here that the war may not be completely over, or that the allied forces may have stopped too soon. "They should be going after Saddam," said Mary Szasz, behind the counter of Northshore Video. "What I thought they should have done is gone all the way to Baghdad."
And many people here voiced the discontent with conditions on the the home front.
Ed Savol, a 40-year-old manager of a Sunoco service station who voted for Mr. Bush, said the allied success left a lot of good feelings here. But he was quick to respond when asked what Mr. Bush should be doing now.
"Take care of his own," Mr. Savol said. "Take care of his own people. Come up with an educational program, a job program. Take care of the people here."
 
A 'Forgotten Party'
 The Democrats hope to capitalize on Mr. Bush's domestic shortcomings. But their weakness was apparent here.
For instance, Glynn Douglas, the vice president of United Auto Workers Local 2262 and a fierce critic of Mr. Bush, nevertheless had some difficulty listing the Democrats who could beat him next year. "I hate to say this, but in all honesty, I don't see anybody on the horizon right now," he said, adding that he still had hopes.
Nelson Whales, a 51-year-old machinist, said: "It seems like the Democrats are turning into a forgotten party, almost a joke. Like, 'Who are they going to come up with this time?' "
Mr. Whales, who considers himself a Democrat, said with a trace of sadness: "Democrats have always been blue-collar worker, gung-ho. And it seems like nobody's there anymore."
And Ann Shaughnessy, a 39-year-old sewing machine operator, said she worried about jobs' going to foreign workers; the trade issue was probably where Mr. Bush would lose her vote, she said.
But Mrs. Shaughnessy, an 18-year employee of the General Motors Corporation, added that the Democrats "haven't offered me anybody yet."
"Give me somebody who shows me they're going to help people who want to work," she said.

(Roger Mastroianni for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wringing More Costs Out of Wall St. Firms

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The falling ax on Wall Street has become as commonplace as the rising Dow. But now, with the most obvious cuts of employees and expenses out of the way, investment houses are picking up the scalpel in hopes of completing a historic and complex reorganization of the back office, one of the least understood aspects of their business.
Some major firms are considering merging their underused back offices, through which stocks, bonds and other financial instruments are moved to the account that purchased them and cash is moved to the seller. Some plan to sell part or all of the operations to outside contractors and then lease them back, or move pieces of the back offices out of Manhattan -- even to third-world countries -- to reduce overhead and labor costs.
 
Accompanying Layoffs
 "The cost pressure on Wall Street generally is encouraging people to look at lowering costs through changes in their back office and support systems," said Rick Adam, the partner in charge of global operations and technology at Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 If any of the mergers come to pass, analysts predict there will be yet another wave of dismissals on top of the 60,000 jobs lost since the October 1987 market crash. "If joint ventures do occur, the number of people laid off in the back office will go up substantially," said A. Michael Lipper, president of the Lipper Analytical Securities Corporation. "An additional 25,000 dismissals would not surprise me."
Too many people and too much capacity highlight the back office difficulties. "As a general matter, cost cutting is a No. 1 priority throughout the service economy," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist with Bear, Stearns & Company. "If you need any convincing, you just need to look at employment numbers in recent months, which are hemorrhaging badly in that area."
The back office is the nerve center of a Wall Street firm. Most back offices are huge operations with whirring computers in climate-controlled rooms and few paper shufflers. While some paper still flows through back offices -- monthly statements, dividend checks and the like -- an enormous amount of the work has been turned over to computers, which match the buyers and sellers of securities electronically.
The potential for savings in merged back offices is between 20 percent and 40 percent of fixed costs, securities industry consultants said. "The beauty of merging the back offices of two major firms is that the economies of scale are phenomenal," said Stephen G. Racioppo, a managing partner with Andersen Consulting.
After years of being criticized for short-term thinking, Wall Street tried the long view in the giddy 1980's, by laying out billions of dollars for more back office computers and employees in a bet that customer orders would keep climbing.
They were wrong. Now, Wall Street is paying dearly for its failed fling with long-term planning.
The buildup was rapid. Lipper Analytical said that by early 1985, Wall Street firms had 118,522 employees who did not produce income, most of them in back offices. By December, there were 140,951, and by late 1987, 168,226.
 
Still More Than 1985
 Since the 1987 crash, back office staffs have been cut, to 138,763 employees now, although that is still more than in 1985.
In the last year, virtually every major firm has looked hard at its back office. And the discussions are "creating interesting bedfellows," said DuWayne J. Peterson, executive vice president of operations systems and telecommunications at Merrill Lynch & Company.
"These changes are not only a capacity issue, but an investment issue," Mr. Lipper said. The firms "are looking at significant increases they feel are required for investing in new equipment, and so are considering ways to decrease their existing fixed costs."
One of the more aggressive planners is Salomon Brothers Inc., several Wall Street executives said. Over the last two years, Salomon has negotiated -- albeit unsuccessfully -- to merge its back office with Goldman, Sachs's; hired an outside company, Andersen Consulting, to maintain and operate computer programming, and agreed to move its back office to Tampa, Fla., from Manhattan. Recently, Salomon has also reportedly been considering providing back office services for other Wall Street firms. Thomas W. Strauss, Salomon's president, declined to comment on its back office plans.
"The time is becoming ripe for collaborative ventures and other moves to make fixed costs lower." said Jean Louis Lelogeais, who specializes in capital markets at Booz Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm. "That is the name of the game."
Wall Street executives say efforts to cut back on the costs are being hampered by the egos of some executives, as each investment house tries to make sure that no matter what savings are made, it will stay in control.
Part of that desire for control is driven by bitter experience. Until the 1960's, no one paid much attention to the operations until the 1968 stock market boom surpassed the capacity of back offices to keep up with trades, resulting in one of the most dramatic technical failures in the history of financial services.
As a result, trading in the stock markets was suspended one day a week, which had not happened since the crash of 1929. And a number of firms, unable to match buy and sell orders, teetered on insolvency or failed.
After that experience, Wall Street firms developed extensive back office abilities, which they are still wary of surrendering. "If you share the back office, you lose absolute control," said Samuel Hayes 3d, a professor of investment banking at Harvard University. "And the investment banks remember well the late 1960's, when the back offices got out of control."
But the pressures on Wall Street profits are forcing new thinking at a number of firms. The First Boston Corporation, for example, is in separate talks with Morgan Stanley & Company, Shearson Lehman Brothers, and Goldman about possible mergers, Wall Street executives said. Similar talks between Shearson and Prudential Securities Inc. broke off last month after the resignation of George L. Ball, Prudential Securities' chairman, who was driving the effort.
Shearson's data-processing operations have since been combined with the Information Services Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Express Company.
 
Talks Break Down
 Wall Street executives said a number of other firms had also been talking seriously about merging their back offices. Goldman and Morgan Stanley began talks in 1989 but the negotiations stalled when neither firm was willing to cede control. Securities industry executives said that each firm essentially wanted to run the operation and keep the other as a customer.
When the talks with Morgan collapsed, Goldman began new talks with Salomon Brothers. But these talks also broke down over differences, people involved in the discussions said.
Andersen Consulting has already taken over the maintenance of computer programs at Salomon Brothers while working on a long-range plan to build new systems. And First Boston recently asked for bids in a deal to sell its data-processing operation and lease it back.
Wall Street executives added that some firms, including Wall Street's largest investment houses, are looking into using technology to move their back offices to countries like Thailand and India, where salaries are significantly lower than in the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shearson Lehman, whose Manhattan back office is shown above, is one of several firms considering merging their support operations. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Mixed for 5th Straight Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week, ending yesterday.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's point to the current flatness in money market yields, which they say is a result of the market finally dropping to the level of the last easing by the Federal Reserve Board. Fund managers continue to hold securities with longer maturities in their portfolios without fear of interest rates rising. 
 "The markets, which are usually ahead of any Fed action, are not anticipating any further moves by the central bank," the analysts said. Even if tomorrow's employment report shows a sizable loss of jobs, there is no guarantee that the Fed will act, they added.
Tax-exempt money funds for the seven-day period that ended yesterday were higher for the fourth consecutive week. The average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios was unchanged at 50 days. Assets declined by $645 million, to a total of $90.2 billion.
 
New Issues Outpace Demand
 The average seven-day compounded yield for the period that ended yesterday was 4.47 percent, up 3 basis points, while the 30-day compounded average yield rose 7 basis points, to 4.33 percent. Analysts said yields were up because the supply of new issues outpaced demand.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield is 6.20 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 6.67 percent for those in the 33 percent bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, which are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund produced the best return on investment for the second straight week. It had a yield of 5.38 percent, or about 91 basis points more than the seven-day compounded yield. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. in Milwaukee.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $4.3 billion, to $458.4 billion. Institutional assets fell $2.5 billion, to $110.8 billion, while consumer assets declined by $1.8 billion, to $347.6 billion. The declines are the result of investors finding more attractive returns in stocks and bonds as taxable money market yields slip.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by a basis point, to 6.21 percent, while the 30-day yield fell 5 basis points, to 6.26 percent. The fund with the best return on investment for the second consecutive week was the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market fund, with a yield of 7.14 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds, fell 2 basis points, to 5.51 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Iran Will Accept Iraqi Kurds, and It Asks for Aid

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, April 3

 BODY:
Iran said today that it would welcome Kurdish refugees seeking shelter from Saddam Hussein's troops and made a rare request for international aid to help it house and feed the influx it now expects.
The announcement was made by Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati at a news conference tonight in the capital with the Foreign Ministers of Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, as the past, present and future presidents of the European Community. 
 "Our doors are open to all these refugees," Mr. Velayati said.
He declined to say how many Kurds were expected to cross the border into Iran or how much assistance Teheran was requesting from the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and the Red Cross.
 
Trade-Off on Hostages?
 At the news conference, Jacques Poos, Luxembourg's Foreign Minister and the current president of the European Community, said the release of the 12 Western hostages being held in Lebanon had been discussed with Iranian officials. The hostages are believed to include six Americans, three Britons, two Germans and an Italian. The longest-held is Terry A. Anderson, a correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped six years ago.
"I've made it very clear on behalf of the E.C.," Mr. Poos said, "that we are against hostage-taking. It is a criminal act."
Asked whether the three officials had coordinated their hostage discussions with the Swiss Foreign Minister, who was also in Teheran today, Mr. Poos said they had not, that the two visits were coincidental.
Teheran radio said that the Swiss official, Rene Felber, met today with President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and discussed refugee problems.
Although Mr. Felber's three-day visit here was long planned, his arrival in the capital set off speculation that hostage release might be imminent. Switzerland has represented American interests in Teheran since the United States and Iran broke diplomatic relations in 1979 after the takeover of the American Embassy here and the seizing of the American diplomats as hostages.
 
Pressure on Israel
 Iranian officials have consistently linked the release of Western hostages to that of six Iranians, Palestinians and Lebanese being held by Israel. The Western hostages are believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Muslim factions, including the Party of God, which is said to have particularly close ties to Teheran.
In Beirut, the newspaper Al Diyar reported today that the United States and Iran had reached an agreement on the release of hostages before April 15, according to reports reaching here.
Quoting unidentified informants in Christian East Beirut, the paper said the settlement would involve American aid to Teheran and was reached "in direct contacts" carried out by an American diplomat "who paid secret visits to Teheran last week." However, the paper has been inaccurate on hostage-release reports in the past.
Envoys in Damascus, the Syrian capital, and in Teheran have maintained near-complete silence about the hostages' situation. A longtime diplomat said only that the talks were "enormously complex, involving many parties," and that speculation and false reports would only complicate the effort to secure their freedom.
At tonight's news conference, Mr. Velayati said he would welcome United Nations relief teams and other international representatives to Iran so that they could better assess the needs of the refugees and the burden they would place on Iran's war-battered economy. He said that the aid organizations would be invited to work with the Red Crescent and other Iranian domestic relief organizations.
 
Already Carrying Big Burden
 Until today, Iran had seemed intent on feeding and sheltering refugees on its own. Mr. Velayati said his country had already provided food, shelter and other necessities for more than two and a half million refugees, most of them Afghans.
The Kurds would be the third wave of refugees Iran has absorbed since the Persian Gulf crisis began on Aug. 2. Soon after Iraq invaded Kuwait, thousands of Kuwaitis sought and received refuge here. Next came Iraqi Shiites Muslims, at least 40,000 of them, as well as Asians who were fleeing gulf states or Iraq.
An Iranian official conceded today that the continuous influx of refugees has placed a severe economic burden on his country, which only three years ago agreed to a cease-fire with Iraq after a highly destructive eight-year war.
The decision to seek international help reflects the size of the influx expected in northern Iran, which the Iranian authorities say could not possibly be managed for long. And the request for help is yet another indicator of Iran's desire to end its diplomatic isolation.
Earlier today, President Rafsanjani accused the American-led coalition against Iraq of showing indifference to the plight of the fleeing Kurdish refugees. And he suggested that Iran would let them cross the Iranian border if foreign nations addressed the underlying cause of their flight.
During his meeting with Mr. Felber, President Rafsanjani called on the International Committee of the Red Cross to aid an estimated 500,000 refugees seeking safe havens. But more important, he said, were efforts to eliminate "the causes of the flight."

HEADLINE: Banks Say Stiff Credit Is Easing

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The credit drought that some worry will cause the recession to drag on may not be over but there are signs that it is easing. "The risk that credit problems would prevent a recovery appear to have declined," William Brown, chief economist at J. P. Morgan & Company, said.
The number of banks tightening credit is declining, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of senior bank loan officers shows. The survey of 58 American and 18 foreign-owned banks, taken in mid-March, was issued yesterday. 
 Just over a fifth of the banks surveyed said that they had imposed stiffer terms on business loans in the last six weeks, compared with a third in January and half last November.
 
Caution on Results
 Stiffer terms might be anything from lower credit limits and wider margins to higher collateral requirements. "If there was a credit crunch, it looks like it has flattened out," said Anatole Balbach, director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.
The Federal Reserve's March survey was taken just six weeks after the previous survey, half the usual interval. "That makes the results harder to interpret," cautioned Thomas F. Brady, who directed the poll.
But there are other straws in the wind. After stagnating for months, the nation's money supply -- an indicator, if an imperfect one, of banks' ability to lend -- has been climbing rapidly again. Nearly every source of bank funds -- from large time deposits to money market deposits -- has been expanding this year. Indeed, the money supply has been growing at a 9.5 percent annual rate since early February, putting it in the Federal Reserve's upper target range.
 
Slide in Loans Slows
 "That's presumably because the Federal Reserve lowered the Federal funds rate starting late last fall," Mr. Brown of J.P. Morgan said. "If M-2 had continued to languish, one would have been increasingly concerned that credit problems were having a broad effect on the economy." M-2 consists of cash, savings and checking accounts, and small certificates of deposit.
The slide in actual business lending has slowed. Commercial and industrial loans, which fell sharply in January, merely edged down in February. "That typically signals the end of a recession," said Herbert L. Baer, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
T. Waite Rawls, vice chairman at the Continental Bank, said, "Not a whole lot has changed, but if we get signs in the next couple of months that the recession ended with the war, things will loosen up some."
Indeed, in the first quarter, many corporations took advantage of lower interest rates to refinance debt. They retired short-term bank debt and issued long-term bonds. Some economists interpreted the surge as a sign that plenty of money was available for business.
Banks are not clamping down so much on consumers, either. According to the Federal Reserve's loan officer survey, half as many banks as in January reported that they were imposing stricter conditions on residential mortgages, and two reported that they were easing up.
Separately, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported that applications for mortgages had tripled since December and that more than a third of all mortgage applications were from homeowners who were refinancing existing mortgages. With mortgage rates lower than last year, many borrowers with adjustable-rate mortgages are trying to switch to fixed-rate mortgages.
Consider the recent experience of Banc One, the large regional bank with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio. Business lending is still off, as it has been since last year. But consumer loans have jumped 15 percent since the start of the year. "The consumer is coming back," said John B. McCoy, the bank's chairman. "That's a precursor of industry coming back. We can't do anything for G.M. unless somebody wants to buy cars."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Higher for 4th Day As Hopes Rise on Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of silver futures rose for the fourth straight day yesterday as hopes for an economic recovery helped lift the metal's value to its highest level in nearly three weeks on New York's Commmodity Exchange.
On other commodity markets, cocoa futures tumbled; oil futures fell; grain and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Silver futures settled 7.2 cents to 7.8 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in April at $4.063 an ounce, the highest settlement for a spot silver contract since March 15. Silver has now risen by 24.9 cents, or 6.5 percent, in four days.
Analysts attributed the gains in silver and platinum to perceptions that an economic recovery -- with an attendant increase in industrial demand for those metals -- is near.
 
Sharp Decline in Cocoa
 Cocoa futures plummeted on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, largely in reaction to rumors that the Soviet Union sold 20,000 to 30,000 metric tons of cocoa that it bought about a month ago. The implication that the Soviet Union could not afford the cocoa dashed hopes for larger-scale Soviet buying.
Cocoa production has outstripped demand for seven consecutive years, and reports of good growing weather in West Africa have stirred fears of another surplus season. Cocoa settled $21 to $43 lower, with May at $1,100 a metric ton.
Gasoline futures led a decline in the petroleum complex on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil settled 17 cents to 28 cents lower, with May at $19.47 a barrel; heating oil was 0.31 cent to 0.95 cent lower, with May at 53.28 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.35 cent to 1.75 cents lower, with May at 65.97 cents a gallon, and natural gas was 0.5 cent lower to 0.1 cent higher, with May at $1.417 a thousand cubic feet.
Prices for most soybean and wheat futures fell while corn futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat settled 1 1/2 cents lower to 1 1/2 cents higher, with May at $2.89 1/4 a bushel; corn was 1/2 cent to 2 1/2 cents higher, with May at $2.57 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1 1/4 cents lower, with May at $1.30 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 4 1/2 cent to 7 1/2 cents lower, with May at $5.87 a bushel.
Cattle futures ended slightly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after traders failed to bid the April contract above Tuesday's record intraday high of 82.70 cents a pound. Weaker cash prices weighed on pork futures, which ended lower.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers took profits following Tuesday's mini-rally.
Despite the decline, market participants said there was no pattern to the trading. Dealers and investors remain focused on the release of March employment data tomorrow, they said. 
 The report is almost universally expected to show that the economy remained weak last month. But traders said they did not expect a weak report to lead the Federal Reserve Board to move immediately to ease monetary policy. The Fed did exactly that in January and again in early February.
Although short-term interest rates fell after the Fed's last move, bond traders, fearful of the inflationary implications, pushed up long-term bond yields.
"I think the Fed very much wants the market to lead, not the other way around," one government-bond trader said.
James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, said, "If the employment number is really weak and the Fed doesn't react to it, the market would be very happy."
Mr. Capra and other market participants said that in the eyes of the bond market a further cut in short-term rates by the Fed would not be viewed as appropriate until evidence of moderating inflation appeared. Producer and consumer price data for March are expected to be released on Thursday and Friday of next week.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 95 31/32, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.23 percent, compared with 8.21 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 1/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.04 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes dipped by 1/32, to 100 9/32, to yield 6.97 percent.
Late yesterday the Treasury announced it will sell $8.5 billion of new seven-year notes next Wednesday.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the securities were offered at a price to yield 7.94 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.76 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.77 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.88 percent.
A number of new issues were offered in the investment-grade corporate bond market. The second quarter is only three days old, but issuance so far this week suggests there has been little slowdown from the near-record pace recorded in the first three months of 1991.
New issues of convertible and non-convertible corporate debt totaled $44.6 billion, according to statistics compiled by the Securities Data Company Inc., as 288 issuers decided to take advantage of a highly favorable interest rate environment. The figure is the highest since the record posted in the second quarter of 1986, when just under 400 issues totalling $45.9 billion were sold.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were narrowly mixed. Prices of short-term securities rose slightly, while most long-term bonds eased by about 1/8 point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in fairly active trading. Dealers said investors, acting on the hunch that a weak employment report would push down bond yields, were buying up lots of longer-dated securities.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New York to Lose 4,000 MetLife Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would transfer or eliminate 4,000 jobs from its New York headquarters.
About 3,000 workers will be relocated in other cities during the next two years as the company prepares for a $150 million renovation of one of the three Manhattan buildings that house its offices. 
 Another 1,000 who are expected to refuse transfers will be offered early retirement or severance pay, said Charles Sahner, a spokesman.
Although MetLife based the decision on its need to renovate its headquarters, transferring operations to less-expensive cities would also reduce costs, Mr. Sahner said.
"Competitive considerations played a part in picking the new sites," he said. "There are advantages to having a headquarters in New York City, such as being at the center of the financial community, but there are other operations that can function as well in other places."
MetLife will transfer workers to Denver, Indianapolis and Atlanta, and to Tampa, Fla.; Rensselaer, N.Y., and several cities in New Jersey.
Most will work in MetLife offices in those cities. But about 1,200 will go to a new administration center planned for Bridgewater, N.J., and others will be assigned to a new computer center in Rensselaer, near Albany.
The renovation is expected to be completed by 1996, when MetLife will decide whether to bring workers back to New York, Mr. Sahner said.
Eliminating 1,000 jobs, a small fraction of MetLife's 54,000-member work force, will have less effect on costs, Mr. Sahner said. Nearly 5,000 employees, including corporate executives, will remain in the city.
New York City has lost 100,000 jobs, out of a total work force of 3.6 million, since the stock market crash in October 1987, said John L. Wieting, an economist with the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HEADLINE: New York Pension Funds Buy Israel Bonds

 BODY:
New York City pension funds have purchased $12 million in Israeli bonds, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman announced yesterday.
"This is a rock solid investment with a 100 percent Federal guarantee and no risk to the pension fund," said Ms. Holtzman, who is a trustee and chief investment adviser for the pension fund. For the first time since the 1970's, the United States agreed to guarantee some Israeli bonds as part of an aid package, her office said. 
 The bonds will yield 8.5 percent -- a high rate of return -- and will mature in 15 years.
Mayor David N. Dinkins commended the pension funds.
"By purchasing these bonds, New York City, which has the largest Jewish community of any city in the world, is again demonstrating its solidarity with the people of Israel," he said.
Ms. Holtzman said the bonds are designated to finance construction of housing for Jewish immigrants to Israel, such as Soviets and Ethiopians.
New York City pension funds have more than $38 billion in investments, Ms. Holtzman's office said.
