HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.N. VOTES STERN CONDITIONS FOR FORMALLY ENDING WAR; IRAQI RESPONSE IS UNCERTAIN

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 3

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council overwhelmingly approved a resolution today that offers to end the gulf war and progressively lift most sanctions against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein accepts a series of tough military and financial conditions.
But there was no immediate indication whether the Iraqi leader would agree to the Council's terms, which require him to renounce terrorism, pay billions of dollars in compensation for damage caused by the invasion of Kuwait, and accept borders that Iraq negotiated with Kuwait in 1963 but rejected just before invading and annexing Kuwait last August.
 
Kurdish Situation Addressed
 The resolution also requires Mr. Hussein to allow the destruction of all his chemical and biological weapons as well as his Scud and other ballistic missiles, and to pledge never to acquire such armaments again. 
 In an action separate from the adoption of the resolution, Britain and Belgium called today for the Security Council to take further action on the plight of the Kurds, some of whom have fled to Turkey, Iran and border regions after being defeated in fierce fighting against Government troops in northern Iraq. France and Turkey asked for similar considerations for the Kurds on Tuesday.
Thomas R. Pickering, the American representative at the United Nations, said the fate of the Kurds was under discussion, and he would make no comment on the American position.
 
Further Talks Planned
 No formal action was taken on the Kurdish measure, although the five permanent members of the Council -- the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China -- discussed the issue privately tonight. They issued no statement, and diplomats here said the full Council would hold further informal talks on the Kurdish question Thursday.
As soon as Baghdad accepts all the resolution's terms, a cease-fire will automatically come into effect with the allies, formally ending the war to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
But if Baghdad refuses to cooperate, it will remain barred from exporting its oil or importing anything other than the bare necessities of life for an indefinite time.
Iraq's representative to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, addressed the Council today but failed to give a clear indication on whether his nation's leadership would cooperate with the terms of the resolution.
He was critical of the resolution, though, arguing that disarming Iraq alone would increase instability in the Middle East and strengthen Israel. He said the Security Council has no right to fix Iraq's boundary with Kuwait. And he accused the United States of manipulating the Council to create "a new colonial period."
Mr. Anbari also called Mohammed A. Abulhassan, the Kuwaiti representative here, "a man with no identity or nationality," and he described his remarks to the Council today, in which he recounted the events of Iraq's aggression against his country, as "obscene."
Twelve of the Security Council's 15 members voted in favor of the measure. Only Cuba voted against it, while Yemen, the only Arab member, and Ecuador abstained. All previous resolutions adopted by the Council on the gulf crisis have also been supported by at least 12 members.
Mr. Pickering, the American delegate, called the resolution "tough but fair" and said it contained trade-offs that would gradually produce a return to normal conditions in the region. But he warned that Iraq's active cooperation with the Council would be essential.
 
Soviet Remarks
 The Soviet representative, Yuli M. Vorontsov, called the measure "a serious warning to all those who might be tempted to commit agression," adding that the "the international community has finally learned the lessons of the 30's."
On the Kurdish issue, Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, cited the civil warfare in Iraq and said, "My Government believes it will be impossible for Iraq to rejoin the family of civilized nations while Saddam Hussein remains in power." He said the Security Council must see what action it can take to aid those fleeing, but that the Secretary General and individual agencies must provide humanitarian relief, as well.
Diplomats say the Security Council can address the issue of the Kurds only if it believes that Iraq's repression of them has become a threat to international peace and security rather than an internal Iraqi matter.
The Soviet Union, which faces severe internal disorders of its own, is being cautious, not wishing to set a precedent that would allow the Council to review its handling of the Baltic republics and other pro-separatist areas, diplomats say. China, moreover, is always sensitive about United Nations interference in its affairs.
On Tuesday, France circulated proposals for a possible Council resolution, or a statement by its President, condemning Iraq's repression of the Kurds and calling for a dialogue between the Baghdad Government and Iraqi ethnic groups. It also asked the Secretary General to continue his humanitarian mission in Iraq and report to the Council on the condition of the Kurdish people.
In Paris today, President Francois Mitterrand told the French Cabinet that "the political and moral authority of the United Nations" would be badly damaged if the Security Council failed to condemn Iraq's onslaught against the Kurds.
 
Observer Force to Be Sent
 The resolution adopted today would send a force of United Nations military observers to keep watch over the Iraq-Kuwait frontier, and it commits the United States and its allies to withdraw their troops from southern Iraq once these United Nations soldiers are in place.
The resolution bans the sale of all weapons to Iraq for at least four months and links a lifting of this prohibition to Iraq's conduct, as well as progress toward regional disarmament. And it continues the ban on the sale of nonessential civilian goods like television sets and cars until the Security Council is satisfied with Iraqi Government policies and practices.
But the mammoth, 4,000-word document, by far the longest the Council has ever adopted, does not address the repression of the Kurdish uprising or the fate of the thousands of Shiite refugees now being cared for by allied forces in the south.
Although Iraq has accepted all previous Security Council demands on the war, agreeing for example to return stolen Kuwaiti property and accept financial liability for the damage the invasion caused, it may have done so only to secure an end to the fighting.
The new resolution binds the Iraqi leader in a complex web of humiliating new restrictions, designed to prevent him from ever terrorizing his neighbors again. In exchange, it offers a gradual easing of the United Nations trade embargo as well as a formal end to the war and withdrawal of foreign forces from the region.
 
Stage-by-Stage Compliance
 The Security Council frames this offer in the form of a 120-day timetable, setting dates for Iraq to accept its conditions and for the Council to ease various restrictions in return.
As soon as Iraq unambiguously accepts all the provisions of the resolution, a formal cease-fire will come into effect between the United States and its allies, and Iraq.
In addition, the resolution imposes other, more general obligations on Iraq outside the the 120-day timetable.
For instance, the Iraqis will not be allowed to sue foreign companies that failed to fulfill obligations because of sanctions or the war. Iraq must return stolen Kuwaiti property. And it must cooperate with the Red Cross on the repatriation of Kuwaitis and other missing foreigners.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mohammed Abulhassan of Kuwait, left, conferring with Salim al- Khussaiby of Oman, center, and Hussein al-Shaali of the United Arab Emirates yesterday before the Security Council vote. (Chester Higgins/The New York Times) (pg. A10)
 
Table: 'The U.N.'s Timetable
 
The schedule set forth in United Nations Security Council resolution 667 that would govern a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. The cease-fire would take effect when Iraq accepts the resolution
 
IMMEDIATELY Sanctions on food imports are lifted and restrictions on imports of other emergency civilian goods are eased.
 
By Friday - Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar submits plans for a U.N. observer force to monitor a buffer zone extending six miles into Iraq and three miles into Kuwait.
 
By April 17 - Iraq must provide lists of locations, amounts and types of its chemical and biological weapons, material that could be used in nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles with a range greater than 90 miles.
 
By May 2 - The Security Council must approve a fund to pay compensation for war damages that would be fed by an unspecified percentage of Iraq's oil revenues. A commission would administer the fund and take into account Iraq's needs and its foreign debt.
 
By May 17 - The Secretary-General and the International Atomic Energy Agency are to submit plans to the Council for a special commission to conduct inspections of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and within another 45 days destroy them.
 
May 17 Or Later - The Security Council will lift its ban on Iraqi exports, including oil, if Baghdad has handed over its dangerous weapons and nuclear materials for destruction or removal and the council has accepted the reparations payment plan.
 
By June 1 - The Secretary-General must submit guidelines to the Security Council for the implementation of a new arms embargo against Iraq.
 
June 1 And Every 60 Days Thereafter - The Security Council must review restrictions on non-military goods imported to Iraq and decide whether to modify them "in light of the policies and practices."
 
By August - The Security Council reviews its ban on some conventional weapons to Iraq "taking into account Iraq's compliance with this resolution and general progress toward the control of armaments in the region." (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Japan, the Trade Gap And America's 2 Minds

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
As consumers, Americans are happy enough to buy cars, television sets, videocassette recorders and all kinds of other things from Japan. As producers, they live in constant fear of the threat to themselves that their own appetites present. And after a decade in which Americans bought $350 billion more from Japan than Japan bought from them, these conflicting impulses are fully reflected in seemingly contradictory Administration policies.
On Thursday, President Bush meets Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan in Newport Beach, Calif. 
 Mr. Bush is expected to press for Japan to open its markets to American rice, construction materials, computer chips and other goods. Implicit in the pressure is a threat of trade retaliation if Mr. Kaifu doesn't oblige.
Closing American markets to Japanese goods would protect producers. Mr. Bush is also expected to reassert his commitment to free trade, which means no trade curbs, to protect consumers.
The President's chief trade negotiator, Carla A. Hills, who deals with these issues every day, is especially practiced in leaps across the seemingly unbridgeable consumer-producer gulf.
The barriers to the Japanese market have been "substantially diminished in the past 26 months," she observed recently. She "wouldn't want to ban our exports or put artificial inhibitors on our trade," she said. Implicit: no retaliation.
Yet almost in the same breath, Mrs. Hills pointed with feeling to the "enormous irritation in this country to have the second largest industrialized market in the world enjoy such access and remuneration in our market and for us not to have parity of opportunity." Implicit: retaliation.
But the toughest talk recently has come not from the Janus-faced negotiator but the new Agriculture Secretary, Edward R. Madigan, fresh from a seat in the Illinois Congressional delegation, which has strong agricultural and commodities interests.
Here is how he expressed his outrage after American rice producers, trying to display bags of rice at a trade exposition in Tokyo last month, were threatened with arrest because they were violating a rice import ban. He reminded the Japanese Minister of Agriculture, Motoji Kondo, that many American farmers "drive pickup trucks made by Isuzu and Toyota which were shipped from Japan." Did Mr. Kondo want two million American farmers to "band together against buying Japanese products?" he asked.
There is still some distance between Washington's talk and Government action. But Congress has been working to narrow the gap. Responding to lobbying from producers who see markets contracting from Japanese competition, the lawmakers have made it more difficult for the President not to take retaliatory steps.
Nothing illustrates America's state of mind about Japan more than the split between Congress and state governments.
Even as Congress is threatening curbs on Japanese investment, all 50 states are fighting each other all the way to their promotion offices in Tokyo for pieces of the Japanese purse.
When Gov. James J. Florio of New Jersey was a Democratic Representative in Congress, he joined in writing the Exon-Florio law that helps the President check Japanese investment. Today New Jersey is among the most aggressive seekers of Japanese investment to generate more jobs in the state.
Detroit presents another manifestation of the same phenomenon. Chrysler's president, Lee A. Iacocca, wants the United States to cut Japanese car imports. This may be good for Chrysler, but the benefits for the Chrysler-Mitsubishi joint venture in Normal, Ill., are less clear -- and even less so for buyers of Japanese cars and dealers selling those cars.
At the root of the growing sense of frustration about Japan, experts in psychology as well as trade say, is that its success here often reflects American failures. It still takes six years to develop an American car, 42 months for a Japanese car.
Nathaniel B. Thayer, director of Asian studies at the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies, puts it another way. The Japanese, he says, are now so entrenched in the United States economy that "by fighting the Japanese, we are really fighting ourselves."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Decision Not to Help Iraqi Rebels Puts U.S. in an Awkward Position

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Having decided not to intervene further in Iraq, the Bush Administration found itself today in the awkward position at the United Nations of seeming reluctant to back appeals for strong action to halt the repression of the Kurds.
Many political figures and foreign policy experts argue that the position taken by the Administration in recent weeks is morally indefensible, and in the long run may not produce the stability in Iraq or the Persian Gulf region that the White House says its policy is designed to encourage. 
 But the Administration, which based its gulf military operation in part on upholding the principle of self-determination for Kuwait, appears determined now to put other considerations ahead of self-determination for Iraqi religious and ethnic communities.
 
Bush Deplores Slaughter
 "I feel frustrated any time innocent civilians are being slaughtered," President Bush said today. "But the United States and these other countries with us in this coalition did not go there to settle all the internal affairs of Iraq."
Administration officials say their priority is to prevent Iraq from fragmenting and to speed the withdrawal of American troops from the region. They believe those ends can best be realized by not intervening in the Iraqi civil conflict.
Nevertheless, the apparent crushing of the Kurdish and Shiite rebellions this week by the Iraqi Army, and the stream of refugees produced by the fighting, have left the Administration on the defensive. Some Democrats and conservative Republicans are calling the Bush policy a betrayal of American principles, and the issue is likely to generate more political heat when Congress returns to work next week after its Easter recess.
"It's not just a tough call, it is a perfect dilemma," said Robert W. Tucker, a historian of international relations. "The Administration's policy has its own logic, but there is an equally strong sense that by doing nothing it will be viewed as a betrayal of values that we have always seen ourselves as championing."
Foreign-policy experts say the Administration is understandably hesitant about using American troops to back the Shiite and Kurdish uprisings in Iraq, considering that these rebellions could lead to Iraq's disintegration.
But many contend that the long-term moral and diplomatic implications for the United States of doing nothing, particularly after Mr. Bush made the gulf war a test case for a new world order, are great. They say the Administration must find some way to handle the outcry in some quarters for the United States to support the forces challenging Saddam Hussein, who were inspired in part by America's own appeal to topple the Iraqi leader.
Publicly, neither President Bush nor Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has given the American public any detailed explanation of why staying out of Iraq's civil war is in the best interests of the United States and how it is consistent with the principles upon which America's gulf policy originally rested.
 
Principles in Conflict
 Administration officials explain, however, that they found themselves torn between two principles of American foreign policy. Both principles were used to justify the effort to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait, the officials said, but they had to choose between the two when it came to dealing with Iraq after the war.
One principle is that the territorial integrity of nations must be respected for the sake of world stability, no matter what kind of Governments happen to rule within those borders. This justification was cited by the Bush Administration for rescuing the Kuwaiti monarchy, and American officials now find themselves using it to justify nonintervention in Iraq.
The other principle is America's longstanding commitment to human rights and self-determination. In the Iraqi civil war, this principle would seemingly dictate support for the Kurds and Shiites.
 
Preserving Iraq, Ousting Hussein
 The Administration is telling reporters that it can have it both ways. Administration officials say their policy is to allow President Hussein to restore the central Government's control over Iraq in the short run. Afterward, they say, the United States can use an arms embargo and economic pressures built into the United Nations cease-fire resolution to encourage Iraqis to replace Mr. Hussein with a more mainstream figure.
Many experts argue that such an approach is flawed. Laurie Mylroie, a visiting Iraq expert at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy Studies, said that if Washington does nothing about the situation in Iraq, "Why should it protest when the Soviet Union suppresses dissent in the Baltics or within Russia? And how can the Israelis take seriously American criticism of the expulsion of four Palestinians when America -- the dominant military power in the region -- tacitly accepts the annihilation of tens of thousands?"
A political theorist at Harvard University, Michael J. Sandel, said that a broader moral issue exists. In trying to assemble international support to oust Iraq from Kuwait, President Bush used both the argument about upholding international borders and the argument about the right of all peoples to self-determination. But he never really sorted out which took precedence -- and because of the nature of the war over Kuwait, he never had to.
The Administration's ultimate response to the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war will greatly influence how the United States' intervention in the region is perceived and remembered.
 
'Maintaining the Status Quo'
 "If, as it appears, we decide that the most important thing is to uphold Iraq's territorial integrity, even at the price of maintaining Saddam's dictatorship, then what we are really saying is that the gulf war was about maintaining the status quo and nothing more; but then its moral authority will be diminished," said Mr. Sandel. "If we decide that we cannot simply stand by and watch while the Kurds are brutally suppressed, but must help them, then we are saying that the principle of self-determination is the value we hold most dear."
Many experts have argued that the Administration's approach is based on the seemingly contradictory assumption that President Hussein can be allowed to remain in power for now to hold Iraq together, but can be toppled in the long run when his domestic iron fist is no longer needed.
"It is rather anomalous to say that Saddam is going to fall in the long run, even if he is allowed to crush his opposition in the short run," said Peter W. Rodman, a fellow of the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute and former member of the Bush Administration's National Security Council staff.
 
'A New Lease on Life'
 Assuming Mr. Hussein "beats back this challenge, it speeds his political recovery," Mr. Rodman added. "He will have defied the odds, and the American occupation. He will have a new lease on life."
Many experts also dispute the Administration's assumption that it can calibrate the diplomatic and economic pressures on Mr. Hussein to make them harsh enough to encourage his ouster, but soft enough not to break Iraq apart. This, say veteran Middle East observers, is like trying to fine-tune a volcano.
If Mr. Hussein is left with a free hand to suppress his domestic opponents, said Elie Kedourie, an Iraqi-born Middle East historian, "sooner or later he will be able to reestablish himself as a power in the area and we will again be on the same merry-go-round."
"I think that it is very foolish to think that an arms embargo can be maintained for months on end," he added.
 
Obstacle to Mideast Talks
 One reason that the Administration's efforts at following up the Persian Gulf war with Arab-Israeli peacemaking have gotten nowhere so far is that all of the important nations involved are waiting to see what happens to Mr. Hussein before they make any committments. The Arab nations are worried that Mr. Hussein will denounce them for any concessions they make to Israel, while the Israelis, still smarting from Iraqi missile attacks, are unlikely to consider serious concessions while Mr. Hussein remains in Baghdad.
"We can't generate any momentum for the Arab-Israel question while everyone is waiting to see how the gulf situation shakes out," said William Quandt, the Middle East expert at the Brookings Institution.
Finally, many experts argue that the United States could have taken steps short of an American occupation of Baghdad to show greater support for those seeking to topple Mr. Hussein. For instance, even if the United States does not want to shoot down Iraqi helicopters, it could easily adopt a more ambiguous public posture on this subject so that Mr. Hussein would not feel that he has a green light.
Others advocate meetings with the Iraqi opposition. After initially spurning any contacts, the State Department today invited in a few Iraqi dissidents for talks with the Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs, John Kelly. But officials quietly emphasized that this did not mean any change in its hands-off policy on Iraq.
"I would say that at this point we could still be more forceful about what we will or will not tolerate," Mr. Quandt said. "We don't want to feed the illusions of the Iraqi people but we simply cannot appear to be neutral toward a regime that has no respect for the human rights of its own people. The thing I find least appealing is that we have shifted from a rhetorical stance that Saddam is Hitler to one that says what happens inside Iraq doesn't really matter to us."

HEADLINE: Ravaged City on Mississippi Floundering at Rock Bottom

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill.

 BODY:
A river and a world away from the glass towers and preoccupied hum of St. Louis lies a charred skeleton of a town that is perhaps the starkest example of a near-total collapse of an American city and the forces that are supposed to keep it afloat.
East St. Louis, with its acre upon acre of burned-out hulks that were once houses, its sad tales of backed-up sewers and of police cars that run out of gas, of garbage piled so deep that entire streets are rendered impassable and of books so poorly kept that no one can calculate its debt, has become a textbook case of everything that can go wrong in an American city. 
 "Take any urban ill in any city in this country and you will find all of it in East St. Louis, and you will find it compounded because it is concentrated and isolated," said Ronald Bean, executive director of the Illinois Development Finance Authority and a member of a board appointed by the state last fall to oversee the city's finances. "There is a serious question as to whether you can turn a community like this around. It's a tragic situation."
The city chose a new Mayor in an uncontested election on Tuesday, but few expect him to reverse a decline that has reached crisis proportions in the last two years. The city's slide into a kind of economic quicksand has confounded state officials, who in the last few months have been assigned to save it and who are only now beginning to quantify its desperation.
They are working without a road map or much precedent. While there has been no comparative research on East St. Louis and cities like it, economists can think of few if any places outside perhaps rural Appalachia or the Deep South where the problems are so pervasive and extreme.
The decline of East St. Louis has been so rapid that virtually anyone who could afford to leave has moved away. The city has gone from a peak of about 82,000 residents, mainly white, in 1960 to about 41,000 residents in 1990, nearly all of them black and poor. Fully half the city's residents are unemployed and 75 percent of them receive some form of public assistance.
Around the country there are several small, predominantly black towns that stand in the shadow of major cities -- Camden, N.J., and Gary, Ind., for instance -- all struggling with high unemployment and a host of urban ills. But most are much larger towns with a broader tax base and have managed to keep some of the industry that once made them great cities.
But East St. Louis is a city at rock bottom, a partly inhabited ghost town whose factories and theaters and hotels and auto dealerships and gas stations and half its schools are mostly burned-out shells.
The city was once a prosperous and brawling blue-collar town of stockyards and meat-packing plants, railroads and speakeasies and neat frame houses along the Mississippi River. Residents fondly remember when there were flowers in Jones Park, and when, as Willie Reese, an Alderwoman said, "you didn't mind for your relatives to come and visit you."
 
Tax Base Slips Away
 But advances in technology made the old meat-packing plants outdated; most of them closed by the 1970's, taking with them other industries and the city's tax base.
"I can't think of any city of its size that has as little to work with," said Charles L. Leven, a professor of urban economics at Washington University in St. Louis.
"It's a ghetto neighborhood that by historical accident is a town unto itself," he said. "That very separateness means that nothing good can spill over the boundary from St. Louis."
The result has been fiscal chaos of such proportions that the city cannot provide the most basic of services. The city has not collected trash for four years, forcing people to pay for private collection services, to burn garbage in their backyards or to dump it wherever they can. The city's decaying sewer system has spewed raw sewage into homes and schools. City police officers must sometimes patrol the city in their own cars because the city's police cars have broken down.
 
Giving Away City Hall
 Last year, unable to satisfy a court judgment against it, the city had to give away City Hall as part of a settlement that made East St. Louis a national symbol of municipal hard luck.
"You don't see anything like that in America in 1991," Mr. Bean said. "You could take pictures of Kuwait or Beirut or Baghdad and hold them up to a picture of East St. Louis and you could not tell the difference."
For the past 12 years, East St. Louis has was run by Mayor Carl E. Officer, a brusque and flamboyant third-generation funeral director who inherited a city weakened by corrupt administrations, most of them white-led machines influenced by organized crime.
But conditions only worsened during his administration as the city suffered embarrassment after embarrassment and the Mayor attributed the problems to white state and county officials who he said had abandoned the city, trying to take control rather than to help.
It was under his watch that the city had to give away City Hall, one of the few buildings not a shambles, to a prisoner who who was beaten by a fellow inmate in the city jail. In the last year or two, the city has had many of its basic powers -- like running the local housing authority or putting together a city budget -- taken over by the state or Federal Government.
And in perhaps the biggest debacle of the Officer administration, a grand scheme to turn the flood plains on the East St. Louis side of the Mississippi into luxury condominiums, ended in court rather than in the riverfront revival Mr. Officer had promised. The city was awarded $7 million to be paid by the Wall Street investment firm of Matthews & Wright for defrauding the city out of millions of dollars.
 
Judge Doesn't Trust City
 But the Federal judge who made the ruling did not trust the city with the money and set up a foundation to control it. Meanwhile, the riverfront remains a weed-filled wasteland, and Mr. Officer is under investigation for his role. Mr. Officer declined to comment on the case or the city.
In February, residents voted Mayor Officer out of the City Hall he gave away and chose Gordon Bush, a former City Treasurer who has a master's degree in urban planning, as their nominee in the Democratic primary. The 48-year-old Mayor-elect, who will take office May 1, had no opponents in the April 2 general election.
His election is being seen as a turning point for a city on the brink. In the campaign, voters walked up to Mr. Bush with desperation in their eyes. One told him, "If you don't pull it off this time, I'm selling my house and leaving."
While mayoral candidates in other cities may debate such things as zoning laws or corporate tax incentives, Mr. Bush won by just promising regular trash pickup. That is perhaps the most glaring problem in a city, whose trash-fueled fires make it look as if it has been bombed.
Carlos Harris, 16, stood outside his house the other day and watched yet another fire raging virtually in his backyard. This time someone set some tires on fire. "It doesn't scare me anymore," he said. "I'm used to it now."
Not far away, Mario Johnson, an Army veteran, surveyed the rubble that has accumulated in the charred and gutted house next to his. The old frame house has become his block's dumpsite. Its roof is in the front yard, collapsed and burnt, along with umbrellas, milk cartons, tires, old radios and television sets, mounds of debris and a lipstick-red sofa, which a man dumped there not too long ago in broad daylight.
 
'The Prettiest House'
 "That used to be the prettiest house on the block," Mr. Johnson said. "I get tired of cleaning it up. I saw the man when he dumped this couch here and told him to stop. He pulled a gun and did it anyway. There was nothing I could do. You have to go four or five miles before you see cleanness, and that's another city."
Just about the only sign of life is along Collinsville Avenue, the city's faded main street. There, wig shops and a Woolworth's compete for customers and a check-cashing business attracts so many welfare recipients on check day that vendors set up shop inside the office doors to sell cheap jewelry and incense to a ready market.
The problems are so severe that many people are wondering what difference a new Mayor can make.
Unlike Mr. Officer, who was considered abrasive and suspicious of outsiders, Mr. Bush is seen as a bridge builder. Still the city will need more than good will to climb out of the hole it is in. "They've got about the same resources as the South Bronx," Professor Leven said. "It's like going to Roxbury in Boston and saying, "You're on your own."
But East St. Louis has few places to turn for help. The state has its own problems. Jim Edgar, the new Governor of Illinois, a Republican, has already ordered $500 million in cuts from this year's state budget and will probably not have much to give East St. Louis.
Last year, the state lent the city $4 million to get it through the current fiscal year. A state-appointed financial board is now trying to restructure a debt that members can only guess at because the city has not been audited since 1985. Current estimates put the debt at $50 million.
Many local residents are looking to Mr. Bush as a possible savior, but some economists envision spotty improvements at best. Others see hope in the 40,000 people left in the city. "You can go down a block that is devastated and find one family hanging on," said Craig Howard, an urban planner who is a consultant to the city's court-appointed foundation. "We have to find a way of rebuilding on those people."
Residents suggest that there may be a lesson in one of the city's few success stories -- the hometown football team, which has led the state since 1983, with almost nothing to work with. The Flyers are considered so formidable that many teams refuse to play them.
"We know we don't have the money or the equipment that the people we compete against have," Bob Shannon, the coach said. "We don't taunt or talk on the field. We don't say we got cheated, because nobody wants to hear that. We win with class and lose with class."
There have been times when the Flyers did not have the money to launder their uniforms and team members showed up for championship games with holes in the seats of their pants. But they play anyway and usually win. They have a gut-deep incentive.
"They know if they play football well and do their lesson," the coach said, "they have a chance to get out."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexico Pact Faces Hurdle on Tuna Fishing

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 3

 BODY:
With the North American free-trade agreement at a critical stage, the United States and Mexico are locked in a dispute over the environmental damage caused by Mexico's tuna-fishing fleet.
The fishing disagreement, which has already provoked a United States embargo on imports of Mexican tuna, pits American environmentalists with wide public support against one of Mexico's largest and most powerful export industries, which traps and kills tens of thousands of dolphins in its tuna nets each year. 
 With international support growing to halt the killing of 80,000 dolphins each year by foreign fishing fleets like those from Japan, Taiwan and South Korea, the dispute threatens to force President Bush into an emotional trade battle with the Mexican Government at the very moment he is courting and defending Mexico as a major trading partner.
 
Mexico Turns to GATT
 Faced with further losses or potential sanctions for its $450 million export fishing sector, Mexico has begun proceedings against the United States at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva.
But the presentation of arguments in the GATT complaint, scheduled for May, are expected to coincide with a Congressional fight over the renewal of Presidential authority to negotiate a continentwide free-trade accord.
Mexican critics of the free-trade accord have already seized upon the conflict as an example of what they say will be American domination under any such pact. American conservation groups have cited the behavior of the Mexican tuna fleet to emphasize what they say is the need for tough environmental scrutiny of all aspects of a free-trade accord.
"In terms of sheer numbers, Mexico kills the most dolphins of any country by far," said David Phillips, executive director of the Earth Island Institute, an American conservation group that has played a leading role in forcing a ban on Mexican tuna.
At the heart of the dispute, experts say, is an unexplained natural affinity that causes dolphins and the yellowfin tuna to swim together in large schools. The air-breathing dolphins remain near the surface, breaking out of the water in spectacular jumps that help fishermen locate tuna schools from boats or helicopters.
Although the dolphins have no commercial value, they are often captured with the tuna in milelong nets that are used to encircle the schooling fish. The nets are drawn together with winches, crushing or drowning tens or even hundreds of dolphins in the course of a single tuna catch.
The United States Marine Mammal Protection Act and other environmental laws have sought to reduce the number of dolphins killed each year by imposing increasingly tough commercial sanctions on fleets that use the so-called dolphin encirclement technique.
 
Provoking Challenges
 But foreign fleets, including those from Mexico, Venezuela and other Latin American countries, continue to use the encirclement method, provoking challenges from environmentalists.
Last August the groups won a court-ordered embargo on all Mexican tuna imports under provisions of the Marine Mammal Protection Act. The embargo was upheld on appeal in February, and then broadened March 26 to include Venezuela and the tiny island republic of Vanuatu.
The embargo has been enforced reluctantly by the Bush Administration, which has insisted that Mexico is trying to reduce the number of dolphins killed by its fleet. The measure has also provoked bitter denunciations in Mexico as an example of American economic coercion.
But Government and environmental experts say that for offending countries like Mexico, which exported $56 million in tuna last year, the costs of the tuna conflict will grow dramatically if no attempt is made to abide by the American restrictions.
Since the largest American tuna canners, as a result of public pressure, have refused for a year to buy any but "dolphin safe" tuna, the embargo has thus far had only a limited effect on American tuna imports.
Under the provisions of the law, the embargo will automatically be extended after 90 days to tuna imports from all intermediary countries that buy and process tuna from the offending fishing fleets. After six months, experts say, it may be extended to cover other fish products from the violating countries, potentially affecting some $400 million in other Mexican fish exports.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The credit drought may be easing as fewer banks are tightening lending practices. A Federal Reserve survey shows just over a fifth of the banks imposed stiffer terms on business loans in the last six weeks, compared with one-half in November. [D1.]
Wall Street firms are searching for ways to finish a complex reorganization of back-office operations. Some firms are considering various strategies including moving operations out of Manhattan -- even to third-world countries -- to cut costs. [D1.] 
 States are requiring reviews of insurance companies each year to determine whether the insurers have enough money to pay claims and meet other financial obligations. [D1.]
Savings industry regulators say in a suit that law firms contributed to the $2.6 billion collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan. [D20.]
 
COMPANIES
NBC is a big step closer to buying Financial News Network, the financially troubled cable channel, after a series of maneuvers in Federal bankruptcy court. A bankruptcy court judge ruled that a competing bid by Dow Jones and Group W was not satisfactory and approved a new NBC bid of $115 million. [D1.]

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
LOSING a job tests the mettle of a family. The emotional effects, felt by children and spouse alike, can be as severe as the economic problems that result.
One of the challenges faced by parents is to tell their children what has happened. It is a task many parents dread. Yet psychologists and others who work with families in this situation say that parents' concerns about their children's reactions are often overblown. 
 "This sort of stressful situation can actually improve the relationship and communication between parents and children," said Dr. Bruce Roselle, a counseling psychologist at Personnel Decisions Inc. in Minneapolis, who works with middle- and senior-level managers who have lost jobs.
"The key is communication," Dr. Roselle said. "If you let your children know that you're sad, angry or afraid, they'll see you more as a real person instead of a white shirt and tie who heads off to work every morning. They'll see your feelings, but they'll also see that you're not overwhelmed by those feelings."
When Tom Vande Hei lost his job a year ago, among his first concerns were his children: one adult son, a boy and girl in college and a 12-year-old daughter at home. The issue was compounded two months later when his wife, Mary, was laid off as well.
"I wanted to protect them from having to worry," said Mr. Vande Hei, whose job as director of communications at a health maintenance organization in Minneapolis had been eliminated. "Yet I found that it was only creating more worry for the children because they didn't know the emotions I was experiencing. Once I started sharing that with them, there was a degree of insight and cooperation from them that I hadn't experienced before."
Once children feel confident that they are not in any immediate danger and you will not abandon them, they will try to understand what losing a job means. A child who is in preschool or early elementary school, for example, might ask if you lost your job because you were bad. "To them, it's as if you were sent to the principal's office," Dr. Roselle said.
They might also ask about ways they can help. "For older children, taking a cut in allowance, even if it's only a few dollars a week, makes them feel they're contributing to the family instead of being a burden," said Dr. William Roiter, a counseling psychologist at Hurst Associates in Boston, which runs employee assistance programs for corporations.
Not sharing information with children does not always mean blissful ignorance. Children tend to let their imaginations run wild. They interpret their parents' silence as confirmation of their fear that the situation is so disastrous that it cannot even be whispered about.
"I hear parents say that they don't want to tell their children they lost a job because they want to protect them," Dr. Roselle said. "But that usually means that the parents are trying to protect themselves from their children viewing them as failures."
Dr. Roiter described a banker who consulted him out of concern over changes in his 14-year-old daughter's behavior. The father had recently lost his job. He told the child little about the incident. He did not mention that because he worked at the bank for 20 years, he received a year's salary as severance and the family was in no immediate financial danger.
The girl assumed that she would no longer be able to attend college. Without telling her parents, she reluctantly changed her track in high school from precollege to secretarial. She also started avoiding her old friends because she was embarrassed about what she perceived as her family's plight.
"She became depressed because she was concerned about her parents and didn't want to burden them," Dr. Roiter said. "They became concerned about her because of her depression."
Remember that children will take cues from their parents as to how confident or upset they should be. "Children are resilient and adaptable," said Dr. Jerry M. Wiener, the chairman of the department of psychiatry at George Washington University in Washington. "They do enormously well when they feel their resources and contributions to the family are respected."
 
IN TELLING THE FACTS, IT'S TIMING THAT COUNTS
PARENTS who have lost a job can help their children come to grips with the situation.
Tell your children, but not necessarily immediately.
The first reactions to being dismissed are often shock and distress. It may take the better part of a week before you gain a realistic perspective. "Get your act together before you talk to your children," said Dr. William Roiter, a counseling psychologist in Boston.
Don't overwhelm children with information.
Tell them enough to reassure them and satisfy their curiosity, but not so much that they become confused and worried.
"With a preschooler, you simply reassure the child that things have changed, but that disaster has not struck," said Dr. Jerry M. Wiener, the chairman of the psychiatry department at George Washington University. "Children that age need reassurance that things are going to be O.K."
Older children might need some idea of what you will be doing to find a new job, and roughly how long you think it might take.
Let your children help plan the changes ahead.
This is especially important if your life style and finances will change dramatically. Suddenly telling children that you won't be able to go the movies or eat dinner out, if the family is used to doing those things, will leave them angry and perhaps worried. But those feelings can be eased if they feel they have even a small say.
"By involving your children in coming up with such things as a new family budget, they'll feel empowered," said Dr. Bruce Roselle, a psychologist in Minneapolis.
Don't allow children to feel a sense of shame.
Young children may feel that you are out of work because you, or they, did something bad. "It's very important to talk to your children about what they can tell their friends, so they don't feel they have to hide a family secret," Dr. Roiter said. "Encourage them to talk to one or two close friends about it so they don't feel isolated. Let them see and hear you talking to your close friends."
Allow your children to help.
Teen-agers may want to cut allowances or get after-school jobs. Younger children need to know they can help by cleaning their rooms or setting the table, so you can focus on your job search.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Social Conscience

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
The nuns who run The Nurturing Place here will never forget what Freddie said at the seashore. Almost none of the kids had ever seen the ocean before; their faces, when they came over the dunes and saw the water spread before them in all its fractious glory, were something to see. But Freddie captured the undercurrent of all their little lives after they went out to dinner and came back to the beach. The first one over the crest of sand, he turned to say triumphantly, "It's still there."
There are 52 kids at The Nurturing Place, an early childhood education program that is part of the York Street Project. Some of them are the children of the women who attend Kenmare, the project's high school for female dropouts. Some are the children who live in St. Joseph's Home, its residence for homeless women and their children. And many are children who suspect that if you find something wonderful, it will disappear if you turn your back. 
 All are 5 and under.
There are other children at the York Street Project. They are the teen-age children of the middle class, who come here to work with kids who may never in their lives have had a permanent address. In the soft glow of the aquarium they rock the little ones at nap time, or sit at tiny tables and spoon macaroni and cheese into tiny mouths. The little kids feel loved. And the teen-agers, who in middle-class America risk thinking that a bad perm is a personal tragedy, gain a social conscience.
Any adult who attended Catholic school remembers pagan babies. The name makes me cringe. We scraped together nickels in an intramural rivalry to see which class could send more money to children in Africa and South America, children we named Bernadette and Thomas.
We are no longer so ham-handed, but the chance of our children believing that the world is composed largely of people like them remains great. Many of us raise our families in communities that are homogeneous economically and racially, gazing in a mirror. "South Bronx, South Africa" I saw spray-painted on a wall in the South Bronx, and it would have seemed hyperbolic had I not just ridden on a subway train whose passengers were all African-American once north of Manhattan.
The girls from Mount St. Mary or Immaculate Heart Academy are crossing some lines at The Nurturing Place. At 17, many of them know more about the homeless than most adults. They know that the bundle of rags in a doorway is only one part of the problem, and that thousands of homeless Americans are children.
They know that when those kids first arrive at The Nurturing Place they never stop eating, because they have known hunger so profound. They know that by the last week of every month, those whose mothers rely on welfare will be ravenous at breakfast. And so they know what most of America does not: that the welfare allotment is woefully inadequate.
They also know that the homeless are lovable.
The students who come to The Nurturing Place are kids a parent could be proud of. Some are fulfilling school requirements in Christian Service, and some just like working with toddlers. During spring vacation they could have been hanging out at the mall, scoping out potential romance.
Instead they rise at 5 A.M. in pleasant homes on pleasant streets to serve juice to children who believe the ocean will disappear because no good things last. "I usually feel guilty when I get home," says one young woman. "I go into my room and I look at all my stuff."
This is a terrific thing, this acknowledgment of blessings. It is why The Nurturing Place is benefiting the big kids as well as the little ones. It is why more arrangements like this could benefit us all. While we work to give our children Reeboks and ski trips and concert tickets, sometimes what gets lost is social responsibility and an understanding of the humanity of people who have less.
It's hard work to raise the kids at The Nurturing Place. But it's hard work to raise kids in other places, too. And if they grow into adulthood bright and healthy and selfish, blind to the dark places right next door to their sunny suburbs, then they are half-people and those of us who are their parents are failures.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: A Fast -- and Prosperous -- Track

 BODY:
Congress confronts two chances, one monumental, to boost prosperity through freer trade:
*The five-year Uruguay Round of international trade talks is, barring catastrophe, about to produce a reverberating agreement slashing trade barriers and thereby adding trillions to the world's economies by the year 2000. 
 *Mexico and the U.S. have vowed to negotiate a free-trade pact, which should provide modest advantages to both countries' economies.
But before any of this happens, Congress must first approve an extension of fast-track legislation that requires it to vote on trade agreements promptly and without amendments. Otherwise each agreement will be prey to killer amendments pressed by special interests. Freer trade is one way Congress can spur the sluggish economy. Fast-track is the necessary first step.
The Uruguay Round is designed to cut tariffs and open foreign markets to exports of agriculture, services and intellectual property -- all vital to the U.S. economy. Negotiations are bogged down over protectionist farm policies of the European Community, but it has recently indicated some flexibility. The stakes are huge, especially for underdeveloped food-exporting nations.
The case for a Mexican free-trade pact is less compelling. For starters, bilateral agreements are inherently discriminatory: favored access to the U.S. market for Mexican textiles means unfavored access for Brazilian textiles. But in this instance, trade diversion will be small.
More troubling is opposition by organized labor, which says the pact would cost millions of U.S. jobs. This fear is exaggerated. Freer trade will bring more jobs and cheaper consumer goods. As Mexico has dismantled protective rules, U.S. exports of high-tech products have doubled.
Mexican manufacturing workers earn one-seventh the going U.S. rate, but much of the difference is due to higher U.S. productivity. Yet some of the wage disparity results from bloated costs hiding behind protective trade barriers. With a free-trade pact, workers in textiles and steel will be laid off.
The compassionate remedy is not to impose billions in higher prices on all Americans. It is to provide generous assistance and retraining for the few thousand affected workers.
Labor has a stronger case when it says Mexican employers must provide safe, humane working conditions. Mexico has already adopted international standards, but enforcement is weak.
Environmentalists fear that U.S. companies will flee to take advantage of Mexico's lax enforcement of pollution regulations. As The Times recently reported, pollution routinely leaks into rivers that carry it to the U.S. But the trade pact wouldn't worsen the problem.
Mexico is special; the common border and its program of economic reforms warrant President Bush's commitment. The Administration has addressed legitimate criticism by promising to negotiate working conditions and environmental protection separately.
The upcoming fast-track vote will cover both agreements. This raises the danger that opposition to the Mexican pact will scuttle the Uruguay Round. If that peril develops, prudence dictates separating the two votes; the Mexican pact isn't important enough to risk losing the Uruguay Round. But otherwise the best outcome for Americans is for Congress to give fast-track authority to both pacts.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Save Libraries, and New York's Future

 BODY:
When Andrew Carnegie gave New York City the money for its branch library system, his intent was "to help those who will help themselves; to provide part of the means by which those who desire to improve may do so."
Carnegie suspected that access to books could reshape lives dramatically, particularly among the city's impoverished new immigrants. Millions who grew up in these libraries know how right he was. 
 The library system is now on the verge of collapse, reeling from budget cuts forced by the city's mounting fiscal problems. A few private citizens and philanthropists have come forward. But more help is needed, lest the libraries wither and die, taking part of the city's future with them.
The public library system is actually three systems. The New York Public Library covers Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx. The Brooklyn Public Library covers its own borough, as does the Queens Borough Public Library, which has the busiest circulation desks in the nation.
When Carnegie's last branch library opened its doors in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx in 1929, hungry readers immediately swept its shelves clean of books. The appetite for libraries is equally voracious today. The immigrants still stream in and expect to be taught everything: how to read English, get a driver's license, take a college entrance exam, run a small business.
The budget cuts have taken a toll. Children's services are being eliminated. The literacy programs that last year taught reading to 5,000 adults are being shut down. Entire branches are shut for parts of several days each week. And book collections that never recovered from the last fiscal crisis are once again dying.
On average, only about 1 percent of the money for branch libraries comes from private sources. The three library systems are struggling to improve on that. The New York Library, for example, has developed the Adopt-a-Branch program, a public-private partnership to which two donors have pledged $500,000 each to renovate two needy branches in the Bronx. This effort merits further support -- and replication.
New York's fiscal crisis will ease one day. Neglected roads and bridges will be repaired and deferred projects revived. But to wait for full economic recovery to help the libraries is to risk incalculable damage to New York's human capital. Government cannot escape its responsibility. But the spirit of philanthropy that created the libraries is urgently needed to keep them alive.

HEADLINE: Padding the Gulf War Bill

BYLINE: By Lawrence Korb; Lawrence Korb, a Pentagon official in the Reagan Administration, is a fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When the U.S. decided on military action against Iraq, it made two decisions about financing. First, the costs of the operation would be off- budget, and thus not counted in the deficit. And second, our allies would be asked to pay 80 percent of the costs.
When our generals expected the war to last months and result in tens of thousands of casualties, the Pentagon projected the cost of deploying and redeploying the forces and waging war at about $70 billion. And the Administration sought and received $56 billion in pledges, primarily from Germany and Japan. 
 Fortunately, the military's estimates of the casualties and the war's duration proved to be highly inflated. This circumstance, however, has not led the Pentagon to revise its estimates accordingly. Gen. Colin L. Powell and senior Administration officials still argue that the war costs will be around $70 billion.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates the cost at $40 billion -- some $15 billion less than the pledges already made. When an economist for the opposition Social Democratic Party in Germany cited the lower Congressional estimate and urged Bonn to pay less than it had pledged, Senator John Warner lambasted the party and the Germans for talking about money when there were 329 gulf-related U.S. deaths. The German Finance Ministry promptly paid in full. Congress, meanwhile, threatened retaliation against any nation not fulfilling its pledge.
The 1990 Omnibus Reconciliation Act, which put the war off-budget, specified that the supplemental budget should not be used to finance costs the Pentagon would normally experience. The Pentagon has violated the spirit of this act in several ways.
First, it has switched funding for the war's glamour missiles from its regular budget to the supplemental budget. The baseline budget for fiscal 1992 was supposed to buy about 6,500 Patriot, Tomahawk, Hellfire and Harm missiles. When that budget was presented to Congress in February, the Pentagon requested funds for only 1,500 of these four types of missiles. But it sought to purchase almost 6,000 with the supplemental budget, even though we used fewer than that number in the gulf and would have bought them anyway.
Second, the military wants the allies to pay for normal wear and tear of equipment. From 1986 through 1990, the Navy lost more than 230 planes to accidents -- about four a month. Replacing planes lost at this rate is factored into the normal military budget. In the nearly two months of combat, the Navy lost seven planes to enemy fire -- about four a month. Seeking to replace these planes is really double counting.
Similarly, the Navy and Marine Corps deployed 190 F/A-18 Hornets in the gulf. They flew an average of about 67 hours a month from August through February -- only slightly more than they normally fly on routine peacetime deployments. Yet the Pentagon estimates that the operations and maintenance costs will increase by more than 50 percent.
The supplemental request also ignores that by 1995 the structure of the armed forces will be 25 percent below that of 1990. Instead of 36 tactical air wings in the Air Force, there will be only 26. Since there are about 100 planes in each wing, the Air Force will have 1,000 fewer planes in its inventory by the middle of the decade. Does it make sense to seek special funding for the 18 aircraft the Air Force lost in the gulf war?
In the ground war, the Army used up equipment stocks placed in Europe for the six Army divisions that were to have been deployed in the event of a Warsaw Pact attack. With no more Warsaw Pact, why replace all this equipment?
From the beginning of the conflict, the Pentagon tried to use this off-budget and foreign-funded account to offset the reductions mandated by last fall's budget agreement. If we want our allies to fund the war in full or pay us for spilling our blood, we ought to say so.

HEADLINE: Poland's Plans to Use Debt Relief

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I appreciate your support of the idea of a significant debt write-off for Poland in "Eleventh Hour for Polish Capitalism" (editorial, March 5) and would like to follow up on it.
There are at least two approaches to debt repayment. In the first, the lender attempts to collect his debt by any means, including annihilation of the debtor. In the other, a more imaginative banker has interests that span beyond the initial loan to larger investments, greater profits and longer term commitments to the client. With the perspective of the second, more creative money lender, Poland is asking for a program in which the portion of the debt forgiven would not be consumed by society in general, but be invested in programs to improve environmental quality and the Polish infrastructure, creating more attractive and secure conditions for further investment. 
 The Polish Ministry of Environment has recently drafted a proposal, "Redirecting Debt Service for Environmental Recovery Purposes," in which it proposes using money from a major debt write-off to finance programs for environmental recovery. This idea developed from Polish-American projects on environmental protection and sustainable development at the University of Minnesota's Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs in 1988-90.
The Polish Government has established and prioritized domestic environmental policies for the most urgent problems, related mainly to (1) the supply of safe drinking water; (2) air quality, through promotion of technologies that reduce environmentally damaging emissions from coal burning; (3) hazardous waste management, to reduce the health risks, and (4) safe food production, through conversion of contaminated lands to nonfood crop production.
The Polish Government has also established activities to reduce its contribution to global environmental degradation, including (1) abatement of long-range transboundary air pollution by means of reducing sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions; (2) reduction of contamination and eutrophication of the Baltic Sea; (3) reduction in release of greenhouse gases by improving energy efficiency, increasing carbon retention and reducing nonpoint methane emissions, and (4) preservation of biological diversity through environmentally sensitive development in those regions that contain some of the most valuable natural assets in Europe. The proposal calls for a trust fund -- fed by money redirected from a portion of foreign debt service -- to be allocated to specific projects of international importance.
As American society has shown strong support for the political and economic reforms that Poland is pioneering among former Communist regimes in Central and Eastern Europe, it is important to point out the critical link between the environment and these reforms. Poland cannot
sustain political changes and improve economic conditions in the face of dropping life expectancy, growing morbidity and mortality, increasing poisoning of air, soils and waters.
For that very reason, Poland, deteriorated but liberated from Communism, needs to be treated at least as well as the United States treated its former enemies at the end of World War II. Debt forgiveness for Poland should also be regarded as an investment in further democratization and political stability in Eastern Europe, as well as in a healthier global environment.
 
ZBIGNIEW BOCHNIARZ
Visiting Professor
University of Minnesota
Minneapolis, March 14, 1991

HEADLINE: Soviet TV Viewers Want Public Affairs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You provide a good overview of some of the changes taking place in Soviet television programming in "Soviet TV Reflects the Kremlin's Grimmer Picture" (front page, Feb. 8). You write that the official rationale for cutting back on public affairs programming and increasing entertainment programming is public opinion, conveyed through polls.
Certainly, Soviet television has neglected entertainment shows, for economic and political reasons, and that imbalance is likely to be righted in the future. However, if public opinion is to be taken account of, then the most overwhelming and decisive judgment of the public should also be noted. 
 In a national survey in the Soviet Union, in which I participated, it was the program "Vzglyad" ("Viewpoint") that was the clear favorite. This contentious and bold investigative reporting showcase -- now suspended -- was put among the top five favorite programs by 67 percent of the Soviet citizens in seven republics (where 88 percent of the population lives).
The next most popular show gained 40 percent.
Moreover, "Vzglyad" was the favorite for 71 percent of those younger than 60, 73 percent of the college educated (and 71 percent of those with high school diplomas) and 62 percent of the members of the Communist Party. These are impressive figures, and they should be used if ratings are to drive programming.
In addition, you note that parliamentary debates have now been relegated to late-night hours.
Actually, that practice was initiated much earlier: after the 1989 live coverage of these lively and often searing sessions, there was a 20 percent drop in Soviet production, as the viewers were glued to their television sets. It was then that the change took place.
 
ELLEN MICKIEWICZ
Director, Soviet Media and
Intl. Communications Program
Carter Center, Emory University
Atlanta, March 15, 1991
 
The writer is the author of "Split Signals: Television and Politics in the Soviet Union."
