HEADLINE: Graham Greene, 86, Dies; Novelist of the Soul

 BODY:
Graham Greene, the British author whose novels of suspense and moral ambiguity plumbed the sordid politics of the modern world and the inner torments of mankind, died yesterday at La Providence Hospital in Vevey, near Lake Geneva in Switzerland. He was 86 years old.
The official cause of death was not immediately known, but his daughter, Caroline Bourget, told Reuters that her father died of a blood disease. Mr. Greene lived in an apartment in Antibes, France, but had traveled all over the world in search of subject matter during his 60-year writing career. 
 Among Mr. Greene's 24 novels, many of which were adapted into films, were "The Power and the Glory," "The Heart of the Matter," "The Third Man," "The Quiet American," "Our Man in Havana," "The Comedians," "The Honorary Consul" and "The Human Factor."
 
27 Languages, 20 Million Copies
 His plays included "The Living Room," "The Potting Shed" and "The Complaisant Lover," and he wrote dozens of short stories. His work was translated into 27 languages and sold more than 20 million copies in hard-cover and paperback editions.
He also wrote travel books, essays and children's stories, and two autobiographies, "A Sort of Life" and "Ways of Escape." An occasional contributor to newspapers and magazines, he even found time to write strong letters to the editor on political and literary matters.
That Mr. Greene never received the Nobel Prize in Literature was a source of regret and astonishment to many readers and publishing professionals.
In his outspoken comments on world affairs in fiction and in fact -- including criticism of American military intervention in Vietnam and in Central America -- Mr. Greene felt an obligation to express his views first and foremost as a moralist. He was a convert to Catholicism but not, he asserted, a Catholic writer.
"I think a writer ought to be a bit of grit in the state machine," he once said. "That applies to a democratic state machine, a socialist state machine or a Communist state machine."
Mr. Greene was a superb storyteller with a gift for provoking controversy by writing topical novels in political settings. But many of his deepest concerns were spiritual: a soul working out its salvation or damnation amid the paradoxes and anomalies of 20th-century existence.
Spiritual problems, however, were frequently overshadowed, especially for readers in this country, by Mr. Greene's distaste for what he regarded as American hypocrisy and materialism. "The Quiet American" (1956) and "The Comedians" (1966), for example, offended some readers because of their criticism of United States policies in Vietnam and Haiti.
Besides serious fiction, Mr. Greene also wrote what he described as "entertainments." These -- "Orient Express," "This Gun for Hire," "Brighton Rock" and "Our Man in Havana," for instance -- were first-rate novels of crime and intrigue. But they, too, showed a profound interest in the interplay of morality and abnormal behavior. "Brighton Rock," he wrote in his 1980 autobiography, "Ways of Escape," was "perhaps one of the best I ever wrote."
In addition, Mr. Greene was often labeled a Roman Catholic writer, a description that annoyed him but that nevertheless colored understanding of his work. He was indeed a convert to Catholicism and he did deal with doctrinal issues, but he insisted that he was not a church publicist.
 
Roman Catholic Ideas But Church Objections
 "Only a few of my books have a religious emphasis -- 'Brighton Rock,' 'The Power and the Glory,' 'The End of the Affair' and 'The Heart of the Matter' -- but I don't consider myself a Catholic writer, but a writer who took characters with Catholic ideas as his material," Mr. Greene said in an interview with Alden Whitman of The New York Times in Paris in 1967. "After all, one of my novels, 'The Power and the Glory,' was condemned by the Holy Office in 1951."
That book, in which the cult of the spiritual holds back the people, whose true enemies are the priests, shocked many Catholics. "I was not upset," Mr. Greene said in 1967. "In a private audience, Pope Paul told me he had read the novel and liked it. 'Parts of your novels will always offend some Catholics, but you should not bother,' the Pope said."
Later, in a 1978 interview, Mr. Greene acknowledged a lingering skepticism about religion, and particularly Catholicism:
"I don't like many English Catholics," he said. "I don't like conventional religious piety. I'm more at ease with the Catholicism of Catholic countries. I've always found it difficult to believe in God. I suppose I'd now call myself a Catholic atheist."
The Catholic-writer label was first affixed when "Brighton Rock" was published, and then more firmly after the publication of "The Heart of the Matter," one of his most popular books with both critics and public, though Mr. Greene said he thought it flawed. After the book came out, he wrote in 1980, "at a stroke I found myself regarded as a Catholic author in England, Europe and America -- the last title to which I had ever aspired."
 
At His Works' Center, A Sense of Evil
 Yet Mr. Greene did not deny that he viewed the world through a moralist's eyes. This was also the conclusion of many critics. One critic, Richard Church, a Briton, summed up the prevailing attitude:
"He sees his characters, and the scenes in which they make their penance, with an eye that elongates them and draws them into gestures made in a garish light. He delights to expose the raw nerves of evil, showing it as a force in the world, a skeletonlike figure working visible mischief in the ordinary everyday affairs of men and women and children."
Mr. Greene's writer's appeal, however, extended beyond readers concerned with good and evil to encompass those who liked a good story. He had some of the narrative flair of Robert Louis Stevenson, to whom he was related. He had, moreover, a talent for depicting local color, which he gathered at first hand; a keen sense of the dramatic; an ear for dialogue, and skill in pacing his prose.
Mr. Greene's backgrounds and situations often grew out of his own wanderings. In the late 1930's, he wrote, "a restlessness set in then which has never quite been allayed; a desire to be a spectator of history, history in which I was concerned myself."
Again and again in his autobiography, Mr. Greene stressed this desire to be on the edge of danger; writing of his visits to Indochina, he mentions being attracted by the women, the evening light and, "above all, by the feeling of exhilaration which a measure of danger brings to a visitor with a return ticket."
 
Prose That Traveled Too Swiftly to Stall
 "The average Greene novel," wrote the critic Adam de Hegedus, "seems to be based on a theory which is not unlike that principle of aerodynamics according to which the aircraft must maintain a specific speed or else it would tumble down. This speed Greene achieves by a masterly selection of detail, by a splendid economy of language and by swift and frequent changes of scene."
Mr. Greene had a somewhat puffy face and eyes that looked down warily from his 6-foot 2-inch height. His manner was generally affable but shy. In talking, he had a tendency to skip over his R's.
He had an obvious fondness for order and quiet that contrasted with his adventurous life. Born Oct. 2, 1904, in Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, England, he was one of four sons of Canon Charles Henry Greene and the former Marion Raymond Greene, who were cousins. Graham attended Berkhamsted School, of which his father was headmaster, and then Balliol College, Oxford. His childhood, he said, was unhappy.
 
The Deadliest of Games Becomes a Habit
 The biographer Norman Sherry, in "The Life of Graham Greene, Volume I: 1904-1939" (Viking, 1989), described a crisis that the future author went through in his second-to-last year at Berkhamsted: two classmates persecuted him -- among other things, for being bad at games -- and he suffered a nervous collapse.
His family then sent him to a psychoanalyst in London, prompting an experience that in the long run, Mr. Sherry wrote, "may well have established his life's pattern of escaping from the impossible or the boring into unknown and dangerous environments which would stimulate, offer fresh experiences and also provide copy for his novels."
Mr. Greene himself wrote later that "the psychoanalysis fixed the boredom as hypo fixes the image on a negative." So he took to playing Russian roulette with an elder brother's revolver.
"I slipped the bullet into a chamber and, holding the revolver behind my back, spun the chambers round," he recalled. "I put the muzzle of the revolver to my right ear and pulled the trigger. There was a minute click, and looking down the chamber I could see that the charge had moved into place. I was out by one."
Mr. Greene took the revolver with him to Balliol and continued to play Russian roulette until he found that "I was beginning to pull the trigger about as casually as I might take an aspirin tablet."
Later on, Mr. Greene experimented with opium, marched across Liberia and went, in wartime, into Malaya, Kenya and Indochina.
Out of Oxford, where he had briefly been a member of the Communist Party, Mr. Greene worked as a copy editor on The Times of London from 1926 to 1930. "I am journalistically minded," he once said. And he fiercely took issue with those who questioned the journalistic accuracy of his fiction, especially in "The Quiet American."
"Some critics have referred to a strange violent 'seedy' region of the mind (why did I ever popularize that last adjective?) which they call Greeneland, and I have sometimes wondered whether they go round the world blinkered," he wrote later. " 'This is Indochina,' I want to exclaim, 'this is Mexico, this is Sierra Leone carefully and accurately described. I have been a newspaper correspondent as well as a novelist. I assure you that the dead child lay in the ditch in just that attitude. In the canal of Phat Diem the bodies stuck out of the water. But I know that argument is useless. They won't believe the world they haven't noticed is like that."
 
His Fiancee's Religion Becomes His Own
 It was just before he joined The Times that he became a convert to Catholicism from Anglicanism. Summarizing the experience, the psychiatrist and author Robert Coles wrote in 1989, in The New York Times Book Review, that it came about through Mr. Greene's relationship with his future wife, Vivien Dayrell-Browning, herself a convert to Catholicism. Her "moral and religious preoccupations became very much his," Dr. Coles wrote, and "at the age of 22, he was received into the Roman Catholic Church."
In an interview published in 1983, Mr. Greene said a first step in the process was the day when, while attending a Catholic service, "I slipped a note into a collection box, asking for instruction because my fiancee was Catholic.
"I wanted a better grasp of the nature of her faith. I had no thought of becoming a convert myself."
His subsequent conversion, he said, "was purely intellectual," because of the arguments of a priest, a Father Trollope, "which persuaded me that God's existence was a probability."
On another occasion, Mr. Greene wrote that it was not until years later, when he had first traveled to Mexico, that he found "emotional belief" as opposed to intellectual acceptance of his religion.
A year after his conversion, Mr. Greene married Miss Dayrell-Browning. The couple had a son and a daughter and then separated in the 1960's. His daughter, Caroline Bourget, lives in Jongny, Switzerland. His son, Francis, lives in Devon, England.
Mr. Greene's first two novels, "The Man Within" and "The Name of Action," were written while he was on The Times. He left that newspaper in 1930 to become a movie critic, first for the periodical Night and Day and then for The Spectator, for the next 10 years. Early in this period he began his entertainments ("The difference between an entertainment and a novel is about 20,000 words") with "Orient Express," which was titled "Stamboul Train" in Britain.
This thriller almost immediately became popular, as were most of his in that genre. His reputation as a novelist soared with "Brighton Rock," published in 1938, which deals with homicide in the British resort town of Brighton. International renown came in the years after the war, especially with "The Heart of the Matter" in 1948.
The scene of this novel, considered among his best, is in West Africa, where Mr. Greene did intelligence work for the British Government during World War II. The protagonist is Maj. Henry Scobie, an essentially commonplace man capable of pity to the point of obsession. It is pity that does the major in. Although a Roman Catholic, his sympathy for, and understanding of, his wife and his mistress lead him to commit suicide to keep from hurting their feelings. The burden of love proves too much for him.
 
'The Quiet American' Is an American Success
 Among Mr. Greene's big successes in this country was "The Quiet American," published in 1956. The novel is a tart study of an American Government do-gooder in Saigon during the anti-French uprisings of the mid-1950's. The writer insisted that he was not anti-American and that his novel recorded only what he saw in Saigon, where he was the correspondent, in 1954, for The New Republic.
Mr. Greene was especially fond of "The Power and the Glory," a novel published in 1940. It is the story of a manhunt in the jungles and mountains of Mexico. The hunted is the last priest in a state where religion is outlawed: an imperfect priest, prey to alcohol and lust, yet a humble man who loves God.
Many of Mr. Greene's books were made into movies, but he said he felt the movies did not serve him well. "I hate the adaptations of my books, except when I do them myself, and then I don't always like them," he said.
Once he had attained success, Mr. Greene spent much of his time traveling. But he worked during these journeys, too, dictating and revising. "I like writing after breakfast," he explained, "and revising after a good dinner, when I have Dutch courage."
He was a steady writer who was not afraid to discard projects, even when they were well advanced, if they failed to satisfy him. "I hope I'm an artist," he told a visitor in 1967; on another occasion, in a bleaker mood, he remarked, "I have no talent; it's just a question of working, of being willing to put in the time."
 
The Effects of Place And of Henry James
 Mr. Greene was often asked what other writers had influenced him, and for this he had a ready reply:
"What one reads doesn't influence one as much as where one is. Still, a great many writers have had their effect on me. The serious ones, I guess, were Ford Madox Ford, Joseph Conrad and Henry James. He was my idol, but to say he influenced me is a bit absurd -- like saying a mountain influenced a mouse."
Mr. Greene's structuring of his novels seemed ideally suited to the camera and the stage. "I have a theatrical mind," he once said. But his own plays -- including "The Living Room," "The Potting Shed," "The Complaisant Lover," "Carving a Statue" and "The Return of A. J. Raffles" -- were not outstandingly successful.
Mr. Greene's long writing career made him wealthy as well as famous. He was little affected, because he preferred privacy to basking in adulation. He enjoyed his income, nonetheless, for it permitted him to live in considerable comfort and to eat well.
Of his many works, "The Honorary Consul," he said, was especially hard to write, and "perhaps the novel I prefer to all the others," while "Travels With My Aunt" was "the only book I have written for the fun of it." "Travels With My Aunt," which came out in 1969, is a lighthearted novel about a retired bank employee traveling around the world with 75-year-old dowager who has a black lover named Wordsworth.
Mr. Greene's literary fame was recognized formally in 1966, when he was named by Queen Elizabeth II as a Companion of Honor. In 1986, he received one of the highest British honors, the Order of Merit.
Critical enthusiasm waned for Mr. Greene's later works. "The Honorary Consul" (1973), "The Human Factor" (1978) and "The Captain and the Enemy" (1988) all received uneven reviews.
Mr. Greene himself had long since taken a detached view of questions of literary success or failure. Striking the understated note of guilt and gloom that was catnip to his loyal readers, he told an interviewer in 1971: "One fails in all sorts of ways in life, doesn't one, which are much more important than writing books. In human relations and that sort of thing."
But another estimation of his feelings about his work came in "Ways of Escape," when he wrote, "Writing is a form of therapy; sometimes I wonder how all those who do not write, compose or paint can manage to escape the madness, the melancholia, the panic fear which is inherent in the human situation."
 
Opening Words on the Moral Anxieties of an Anguished Century
In the course of a career that spanned more than six decades, Graham Greene wrote 24 novels, along with many short stories, essays and plays and two volumes of autobiography. Here is a sampling from the opening chapters of some of his novels and a list of some major works.
 Mr. Tench went out to look for his ether cylinder: out into the blazing Mexican sun and the bleaching dust. A few buzzards looked down from the roof with shabby indifference: he wasn't carrion yet. A faint feeling of rebellion stirred in Mr. Tench's heart, and he wrenched up a piece of the road with splintering fingernails and tossed it feebly up at them. One of them rose and flapped across the town: over the tiny plaza, over the bust of an ex-president, ex-general, ex-human being, over the two stalls which sold mineral water, towards the river and the sea. It wouldn't find anything there: the sharks looked after the carrion on that side. Mr. Tench went on across the plaza.
He said "Buenos dias" to a man with a gun who sat in a small patch of shade against a wall. But it wasn't like England: the man said nothing at all, just stared malevolently up at Mr. Tench, as if he had never had any dealings with the foreigner, as if Mr. Tench were not responsible for his two gold bicuspid teeth.
 -- From "The Power and the Glory" (1940, Viking)
Wilson sat on the balcony of the Bedford Hotel with his bald pink knees thrust against the ironwork. It was Sunday and the Cathedral bell clanged for matins. On the other side of Bond Street, in the windows of the High School, sat the young negresses in dark-blue gym smocks engaged on the interminable task of trying to wave their wirespring hair. Wilson stroked his very young moustache and dreamed, waiting for his gin-and-bitters.
Sitting there, facing Bond Street, he had his face turned to the sea. His pallor showed how recently he had emerged from it into the port: so did his lack of interest in the schoolgirls opposite.
 -- From "The Heart of the Matter" (1948, Viking)
One never knows when the blow may fall. When I saw Rollo Martins first I made this note on him for my security police files: "In normal circumstances a cheerful fool. Drinks too much and may cause a little trouble. Whenever a woman passes raises his eyes and makes some comment, but I get the impression that really he'd rather not be bothered. Has never really grown up and perhaps that accounts for the way he worshiped Lime." I wrote there that phrase "in normal circumstances" because I met him first at Harry Lime's funeral. It was February, and the gravediggers had been forced to use electric drills to open the frozen ground in Vienna's Central Cemetery. It was as if even nature were doing its best to reject Lime, but we got him in at last and laid the earth back on him like bricks.
 -- From "The Third Man" (1950, Viking)
 After dinner I sat and waited for Pyle in my room over the rue Catinat: he had said, "I'll be with you at latest by 10," and when midnight had struck I couldn't stay quiet any longer and went down into the street. A lot of old women in black trousers squatted on the landing; it was February and I suppose too hot for them in bed. One trishaw driver pedaled slowly by towards the river front, and I could see lamps burning where they had disembarked the new American planes. There was no sign of Pyle anywhere in the long street.
Of course, I told myself, he might have been detained for some reason at the American Legation, but surely in that case he would have telephoned to the restaurant -- he was very meticulous about small courtesies. I turned to go indoors when I saw a girl waiting in the next doorway. I couldn't see her face, only the white silk trousers and the long flowered robe, but I knew her for all that.
 -- From "The Quiet American" (1956, Viking)

HEADLINE: 'Tough' Year No Reason to Quit, Myers Says

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
New York City's Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., yesterday expressed frustration over his first year with city government, but said his mother-in-law's illness would determine whether he stayed on the job.
In an interview, Dr. Myers denied news reports quoting department officials who said he had been offered another job and was considering quitting out of dissatisfaction. But he described his first year in the city as "tough" and acknowledged frustration with the city's bureaucracy and fiscal problems that have limited the Health Department's work in the three areas he considers priorities -- child health, drug abuse and AIDS.
 
 Appearing with Mayor David N. Dinkins at a news conference earlier yesterday, Dr. Myers said he had not decided whether the time and financial obligations imposed by his mother-in-law's condition, which he did not identify, would force him to resign. He said Mayor Dinkins had given him time to consider the question.
 
'Incredibly Interesting'
 "I am trying the best I can to come to grips with some tough issues," he said. "I have liked the opportunities that have been afforded to me in the City of New York. It is one incredibly interesting place to be."
Yesterday was another mixed day for Dr. Myers. The Mayor publicly praised him for helping to secure an additional $17.6 million in Federal money to be spent on 20 New York City areas that account for 75 percent of its reported AIDS cases. But the Commissioner was required to submit a plan showing which programs would bear the cuts ordered by the Mayor -- $28 million, or 17 percent, of his budget.
Dr. Myers declined to give details about what he proposed. "I'll resist cuts that I believe will damage the quality of care that we provide," he said in the interview.
The budget crunch comes as the city is experiencing troubling rates of infant mortality and communicable diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis, measles and syphilis. "We're seeing a resurgence of a number of diseases that have no business growing and are directly attributable to poverty, drugs and the economic circumstances of government," Dr. Myers said.
But he also said his department was doing well under the circumstances and spoke enthusiastically about its accomplishments under his tenure. He described his upper-level management team -- 98 percent of whom are his own recruits -- as a "top-flight group of people." He said the department had created programs aimed at approaching health problems more creatively. For instance, he said, drug use in pregnant women has quadruped since 1985; the department responded by offering both substance-abuse treatment and prenatal care at one site.
Dr. Myers, 37 years old, came to New York City last year after serving as health commissioner for his native Indiana. There, he had backed a law requiring the recording of names of people infected with AIDS and tracing their sex and drug partners -- an approach that produced scathing criticism from AIDS groups here.
 Although he has not advocated those policies here, he soon upset AIDS groups again by abolishing a program that taught intravenous drug users how to disinfect needles with bleach to avoid the virus. These organizations and others in the health care community also faulted him for not being forceful enough in speaking out on health issues.
 Dr. Myers said he had overcome the ill feelings from AIDS organizations, but added, "There are a lot of people who don't want to believe that this commissioner can be successful."
Dr. Myers' wife, Debra, is a physician specializing in pulmonary diseases and sleep disorders. They live with their two children, a 12-year-old daughter and a 9-year-old-son, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The Commissioner also teaches at Cornell Medical School in Manhattan.
Department officials who declined to be named said on Tuesday that Dr. Myers had become dissatisfied over a number of issues, including his access to the Mayor, and had been seeking other employment.
Health Department officials confirmed Tuesday that he was considering resigning, but said the reason was his mother-in-law's illness.
Intensely private, Dr. Myers refused yesterday to discuss the details of his mother-in-law's illness or his own personal financial problems, which Mayor Dinkins alluded to during yesterday's news conference. The Mayor said Dr. Myers took a pay cut when he accepted his current post, which pays $110,000 a year.
Dr. Myers has no deadline for his decision. He said it would take "as short as I possibly can."
"At this point there are too many variables," he said. "I don't have enough information yet."
Of his tenure, he said: "It's been very tough, exceptionally challenging. I've had to think more on my feet and push myself to meet the challenge."
But he professed to have not been disappointed. "I came to this city over a year ago to have what I thought would be the most exciting challenge in my life, and it's been all of that."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
White Sox Decide to Gamble on Bo Jackson

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
With questions about his health and athletic future still unanswered, Bo Jackson made a rapid return to baseball employment yesterday, signing a contract with the Chicago White Sox in which both sides will share the economic risk of the unknown.
Jackson, whose dual stardom in baseball and football is unprecedented, could earn $8.15 million over three years (not counting potential bonuses for various awards), but the White Sox have guaranteed only $700,000 as his salary for this season.
 
 Jackson, whom the Kansas City Royals released 16 days ago because of a football injury to his hip, chose the White Sox, expressing his preference for the team, its new stadium, its medical staff and the city of Chicago. Among other teams said to have expressed interest were the Atlanta Braves and the Toronto Blue Jays.
 
Michael Expresses Surprise
 General Manager Gene Michael of the Yankees, the team that turned down the first chance to sign Jackson after he was placed on waivers, said he was somewhat surprised by the White Sox's decision to sign Jackson. He would still not second-guess the decision of the Yankees not to claim Jackson on waivers, which would have required the club to pay him the $2,375,000 salary from his Royals contract.
"No way," Michael said at the Yankees' camp in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "How could I second-guess the doctors?"
Of the White Sox, he added, "It's their business."
The White Sox contract does not prohibit Jackson from playing football, but a Jackson associate, who insisted on anonymity, said that Jackson knows that even if he plays baseball again, he will not be able to continue his National Football League career with the Los Angeles Raiders.
"Bo is well aware of the fact that he won't play football again," the associate said. "He has been told that's a risk he can't take. They'll deny it, but he knows it. He knows baseball is his life now."
 Jackson, 28 years old, has become a worldwide celebrity through his two-sport feats and the resulting television commercials and endorsements that bring him more money than he earns in his sports salaries. Some estimates have put his off-field income at about $5 million a year.
 The White Sox contract calls for a guaranteed salary of $700,000 this year, whether or not Jackson plays, and two option years. The $700,000 is the minimum Jackson could earn from the agreement. By earning bonuses of $10,000 a game -- with a different maximum number of games each year -- Jackson could earn as much as $1.5 million this year, $2.9 million next year and $3.75 million in 1993. Those totals do not include bonuses he could earn (a maximum of $500,000 each year) for a variety of awards.
 The contract, with the option years, would take Jackson one year past the time he would be eligible to become a free agent. He will be on the disabled list until he is able to play.
Explaining his decision to sign Jackson, Jerry Reinsdorf, White Sox co-owner, said it was not "a marketing thing because we're going to have an enormous ticket sale this year with the new stadium."
 "In making the business decision," Reinsdorf continued, "I assume he will not play this year. If he does, it will be a big bonus. But considering the total dollars he could potentially earn, compared with what we have to pay if he never plays, 90 percent is based on his ability to play. Considering that the financial risk is one we can afford to take, when you look at the risk-reward ratio, it's tremendous. The potential upside is tremendous. We're risking what is a substantial amount of money; it's not chopped liver. But it's certainly a reasonable amount."
 Reinsdorf offered an analogy. "It's like life insurance," he said. "You pay the premium, the premium is gone. But if it turns out you die, your family is very happy you had the insurance. We can afford the premium. If he comes back, we'll be thrilled with the results."
 If Jackson comes back this year, he would earn $10,000 for each game he is available to play up to 80 games. If he is available for 40 games, including 30 after Aug. 31, the option for 1992 will be automatically exercised.
Then, next season his base salary would be the salary he earned in 1991 less $100,000, and he could earn $10,000 a game up to 150 games. If he is available for 125 games in 1992, the 1993 option will automatically vest. His 1993 base salary would be equal to the salary he earned in 1992, and he could again earn $10,000 a game. But his maximum salary would be $3.75 million.
 Speaking at a news conference at the club's spring training complex in Sarasota, Fla., Dr. James Boscardin, the White Sox orthopedist, said the club initially thought Jackson's hip injury was "worse than it actually is from the media reports and such."
"We believe there's a very good chance Bo can become a productive member of the White Sox," he said
 Ron Schueler, the White Sox general manager, said a reasonable expectation was that Jackson would return in 1992. If he doesn't play this year but the White Sox exercise the option for 1992, his base salary would be $600,000.
 
Injured in January
 The injury Jackson suffered to his left hip in an N.F.L. playoff game Jan. 13 jeopardized his dual sports career and his dynamic commercial career. The Royals concluded, based on a report by their orthopedist, Dr. Steve Joyce, that Jackson would most likely not be able to play this year and perhaps never again. Rather than pay him his entire 1991 salary of $2,375,000, they decided to release him and give him the required 30 days' termination pay, which amounts to $391,484.
 The other 25 teams could have claimed him on waivers for $1, but all passed, put off by the risk of paying his entire salary but not knowing if he could play. The Yankees, as the American League team with the worst record in 1990, had first crack at him but opted not to gamble, citing the recommendations of seven orthopedists they consulted.
The White Sox were among the clubs who decided to pursue the outfielder as a free agent, and Jackson quickly decided they were his first choice. Not long after Jackson cleared waivers, Schueler met with Jackson's agent, Richard Woods, in Tampa, Fla. Then the White Sox dispatched Boscardin to Birmingham, Ala., to study results of tests performed on Jackson's hip by Dr. James Andrews, the orthopedist who has been most optimistic about the chances for Jackson's return.
 Finally, on Tuesday afternoon, Reinsdorf said, he spent less than two hours on the telephone with Woods negotiating terms of the contract.
 "Right now, I feel like a caged animal," Jackson said at the news conference. "I can't wait for them to open the chutes and let me go and do what I've been doing my whole life, and that's running."

HEADLINE: Investment Abroad Easing

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
American companies plan to increase investments overseas by 6 percent this year, down from the 19 percent average increase posted during the previous three years, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said a survey conducted in December showed that majority-owned foreign affiliates of United States companies planned $61.2 billion in capital spending this year, up from $56 billion in planned spending in 1990. 
 But the increase in planned foreign investments would be far less than the 21 percent that was planned in 1990 and actual spending increases of 13 percent in 1989 and 24 percent in 1988.
The Bureau of Economic Analysis, which prepared the report, said the 1991 projected slowdown in spending growth reflected reduced need following high levels of capital spending in preceding years and parent companies' constrained ability to finance overseas projects because of sluggish domestic economic conditions and weakening economies in some host countries.
The survey showed that manufacturers plan to increase spending by 4 percent, to $29.8 billion. The largest increases in investments were planned in Germany, up 18 percent, to $6.7 billion; Japan, up 17 percent, to $2.3 billion, and Britain, up 13 percent, to $13.4 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in U.S. Trading, With Rate Drop Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined broadly in domestic trading yesterday, with traders expecting lower interest rates.
Gold prices were generally lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 80 cents an ounce to settle at $359.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $358.30 an ounce, off 90 cents. 
 The dollar was mixed overseas. In New York, the currency declined on negative news about the economy and the possibility that the unemployment report scheduled today would show a further decline.
 
Started a Selloff
 The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new unemployment claims jumped to the highest level in eight years last month. The report, which dampened hopes of a quick end to the recession, started a selloff in the dollar.
"The dollar was knocked down as people began reassessing the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will ease credit," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA. Weak data might encourage the Fed to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, and such a move typically is negative for the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 137.45 Japanese yen, from 137.78 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it fell to 136.25 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 135.95 yen, down from 137.3 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.785, from $1.7805 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.7845 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.7735.
 
Other Dollar Rates
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.668 German marks, down from 1.675; 1.4033 Swiss francs, down from 1.4205; 5.6495 French francs, down from 5.6795; 1,241 Italian lire, down from 1,247, and 1.1555 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1557.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.667 German marks, up from 1.6645; 1.4025 Swiss francs, down from 1.4140; 5.645 French francs, down from 5.6472; 1.8780 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8765; 1,239.75 Italian lire, down from 1,240, and 1.1553 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1548.

HEADLINE: United and Pilots in Accord as Heathrow Service Begins

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 4

 BODY:
United Airlines and its pilots said today that they had reached a tentative agreement after more than three years of bargaining and several attempts by the pilots to buy the carrier.
United called the deal "a new, comprehensive labor contract." 
 The parties released no details of the proposed accord that was reached late Wednesday, but the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, which was seeking large increases in wages and benefits, said the agreement covered most important economic issues.
"A few significant issues" remain to be resolved, union officials said, but they added that the agreement would still be presented to United's approximately 7,700 pilots.
 
Contract Lapsed in April 1988
 The pilots have been working under a contract that lapsed on April 1, 1988. Technically, airline and railroad labor contracts do not expire but "become amendable." United's flight attendants and mechanics are also working under such contracts.
The stock price of United's parent, the UAL Corporation in Chicago, rose after the announcement. It finished up $2.125 a share today, to $149.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
United's protracted labor problems have been "a cloud hanging over the company," said Robert J. Joedicke, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. "It's one down and two to go, but it's the important one," he added. "You cannot operate an airline without pilots or machinists."
 
Economic Realities
 Weakness in the airline industry and a possibility of layoffs may have made the pilots more cooperative at the bargaining table, he noted. United may be seeking to settle its labor problems as it expands its trans-Atlantic business, Mr. Joedicke said.
The agreement came the same night that United took over routes into Heathrow Airport in London that it had acquired from Pan American World Airways Inc.
"We're always encouraged when the collective-bargaining process works," said David Stack, a spokesman for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, whose United contract lapsed in November 1989. "We certainly feel we will be able to come to an agreement at some point."
But Ellon Jarvis, the chief negotiator for the Association of Flight Attendants, whose contract became amendable in November 1987, said, "I can't express any excitement or optimism."
The pilots suspended their talks with UAL through much of last year while trying to lead an employee buyout of United. Their last effort ended in October when they were unable to obtain financing for a $4.4 billion bid.

HEADLINE: Plan to Ease Bank Credit is Criticized

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The nation's senior auditor said today that the Bush Administration's proposals to ease credit conditions were misleading "accounting gimmicks."
In a letter to top banking regulators, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, said the regulators should now be tightening accounting rules instead of trying to entice banks to provide more credit by relaxing the way troubled loans are valued, as the Administration has suggested. 
 "The solution to current issues facing depository institutions is not accounting gimmicks," said Mr. Bowsher, a constant critic of the Administration's banking policies and the Government's supervision of the industry. "The purpose of accounting is to provide even-handed, neutral and unbiased information for making business and economic decisions, and not to determine what those decisions should be."
 
Administration Disagrees
 The Administration took issue with Mr. Bowsher's assessment. "Nothing in this package is regulatory forbearance, as the G.A.O. has implied," said Desiree Tucker-Sorini, a spokeswoman for the Treasury Department. "We don't feel this is a loosening of standards, but a common sense approach."
Last month, bank regulators from four agencies proposed the changes at the request of Administration officials, who have said the existing rules discourage banks and savings and loans from extending credit to financially sound customers.
But critics have said the measures will eventually haunt the industry and the Government because the changes dilute standards at a time when increasing numbers of large banks are failing or reporting lower earnings. They have compared the proposal to the decisions in the 1980's to relax standards for savings institutions and to refrain from closing weak institutions.
The most significant proposal is now in a comment period before the Securities and Exchange Commission and the agencies that regulate the banks and savings and loans. They are expected to decide late this month or next whether to permit the change, which would allow institutions to split their bad loans into performing and nonperforming parts rather than writing them off entirely.
The guidelines were issued jointly by the Federal Reserve, the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
"At this time, the implied loosening up on valuation of real estate loans will only serve to temporarily gloss over existing problems," said Mr. Bowsher, who heads the General Accounting Office, which conducts audits and investigations for Congress. "We believe stronger, not weaker, guidelines need to be provided by the regulators."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
After 2 Deaths, Now a School Grieves for Itself

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

DATELINE: MELVILLE, L.I.

 BODY:
News of a school closing affects different people in different ways. At Sunquam Elementary School, one second grader took all the Sunquam literature out of her mother's wastebasket and put it up in her bedroom. "If I hang it all up," she told her mother, "they won't close Sunquam."
Another second grader began acting up at home, throwing shoes and tantrums. When asked by a teacher to write an essay beginning "I am lucky because. . . .," he wrote, 50 times, "I am not lucky." 
 Sunquam is a meandering one-story school in a woodsy corner of Melville, a community bisected by central Long Island's busiest commercial corridor, where potato farms are slowly yielding to housing tracts. Melville has no downtown and no Main Street. But it has Sunquam, near the public library, the fire house and the Dunkin' Donuts. In a way this is Melville's village square.
"The community is so spread out," said Kathy Asta, a Sunquam parent, "that what we've tried to do in the school is bring the community together."
It has been a hard year, both for the school and for its extended family. In September, a third grader, Nicky DeNicola, died of leukemia. Last month, another tragedy struck, in the way these things so often seem to, with a well-worn routine gone horribly wrong.
As her class was leaving the gym on March 14, 9-year-old Deanna Moon was caught and crushed between a closing motorized partition and the gym wall as she tried to slip through. Parents ferrying in tomato sauce for the annual spaghetti dinner tried to calm the children; a police officer giving an anti-drug talk down the hall radioed for help, and the Fire Deparment arrived in moments.
 But it was too late. Deanna died from her injuries nine days later.
 People in the community offered support, praying with the Moon family and taking food to the gym teacher, who has been accused of mishandling the door controls and suspended. Then, three days after the accident, the school district, Half Hollow Hills, announced that because of proposed cuts in state aid, two schools would have to close. One is a junior high school. The other is Sunquam.
The district Superintendent, Kevin N. McGuire, said Sunquam was chosen because it is the oldest elementary school, because it needs the most repairs and because it is half empty. Closing it would save the district about $300,000 a year, he said.
"It would not be financially appropriate to keep this school open," Mr. McGuire said.
Parents and their children reacted as if they had been physically hurt. To them, Sunquam is more than just a building with a few classrooms; it is the glue that holds together the spread-out neighborhoods in the western half of the district. If Sunquam were closed, the children would have to go all the way to Dix Hills, several miles to the east. Dix Hills has six elementary schools clustered together.
Hundreds of people turned up at a school board meeting to shout at Mr. McGuire and the board. When Mr. McGuire showed charts and graphs to illustrate the district's dire financial state, the audience barely seemed to listen.
"People are already upset about Deanna, and now that they're going to close the school, they're much more upset," said Jordan Goldman, 10. "Why us?"
A group of parents is considering filing two lawsuits, one to block the closing of Sunquam and the other to have the western half secede from the district, bringing Melville's commercial strip and its huge tax base with it.
Though its circumstances are perhaps sadder, Half Hollow Hills is not the only district going through an upheaval over closings. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget would drastically cut school aid across the state, with about half the cuts coming from districts on Long Island.
The Island went through a round of school closings in the mid-1970's as much of the baby-boom generation graduated. In the last 20 years, five schools have closed in Half Hollow Hills, which once had 13,000 students and now has 7,400.
With an annual budget of $94 million and a reputation for getting students into Ivy League schools, Half Hollow Hills has found only $6 million of the $14 million it needs to cut.
People in other parts of the district say they are sorry it has to be this way. "I don't think anyone would have ever, ever thought we would be in this economic situation," said Judith Faber, president of the P.T.A. Association Council.
But to Phran Ginsberg, Sunquam's P.T.A. president, the issue goes far beyond money. "If they take the school away," she said, "they've completely destroyed our community."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up on Economic Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An unexpected rise in initial unemployment claims, an increase analysts say virtually assures that March employment data expected to be released today will be weak, pushed up prices of Treasury securities yesterday.
The claims report, which is released each week by the Labor Department, showed that initial claims rose by 33,000 in the week that ended on March 23, to 543,000. It is the third straight week that initial claims have risen by more than 500,000. 
 Reports showing that sales of American-made cars remained sluggish during the last 10 days of March also helped to bolster prices.
"We are now five weeks past the end of the war, and to me there is no discernible bounce in economic activity," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
"I don't think the economy is turning up," said Edward J. Hyman Jr., the president of ISI Group Inc., a New York investment firm. "I think it will take another drop in rates to get there."
 
Focus Turns to Fed
 The weak economic reports revived speculation that the Federal Reserve Board might move to lower short-term interest rates again this month.
The reports, as well as the Fed speculation, helped to increase demand at an auction yesterday of new one-year Treasury bills.
The new securities were sold at an average discount rate of 5.88 percent, well down from the average 6.06 percent at the last one-year bill sale on March 7.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 19/32 late yesterday, up by five-eighths of a point, to yield 8.18 percent, down from 8.23 percent late on Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 3/8, up by 10/32, to yield 7.98 percent. And the 7 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 100 11/32 in late trading, up by 3/32, to yield 6.93 percent.
 
Short-Term Bills Down
 Rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills fell slightly.
Late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.74 percent, down by 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a basis point, to a late-offered rate of 5.76 percent.
In other developments, a number of companies reacted to the decline in rates by pricing new debt securities.
Among the investment-grade issuers was the Dow Chemical Company, which offered $300 million in 9 percent bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The securities, which mature on April 1, 2021, were priced at $99.46 to yield 9.052 percent, or 88.5 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds at pricing. They are noncallable for life.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said prices of most issues rose a quarter of a point to half a point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted securities were up by about a quarter-point.
 
Money Supply Higher
 Elsewhere, the Fed said yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week that ended on March 25. The third, the largest measure, M-3, fell by $4.7 billion.
M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely watched by the Fed, rose by $6.2 billion. The increase, the 12th weekly rise in a row for M-2, was in line with market expectations.
The report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.
Wayne Smith, an economist at Reid Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn., said M-2 growth this month should begin to slow.
"The current pace cannot be sustained," Mr. Smith said. "But the pickup we have seen, after virtually no growth in the fourth quarter of last year, has been a welcome development."

HEADLINE: A Nonprofit Council Honors 7 Corporations as 'Models'

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit group whose shopping and investment guidebooks have made it the best known of the many self-appointed watchdogs of corporate behavior, honored seven companies last night as "models for other corporations."
The awards were made at the organization's Fifth Annual Corporate Conscience Awards ceremony at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel with George B. Harvey, the chief executive of Pitney Bowes Inc. as host. 
 Herman Miller Inc., a furniture maker based in Zeeland, Mich., won in the environmental category for large companies for its early decision to stop using wood from rain forests, its installation of a co-generation energy plant that burns wastes and its founding of a subsidiary to recycle office furniture.
Smith & Hawken, a mail-order company in Mill Valley, Calif., that specializes in gardening equipment was the small-company winner. It was cited for wide-ranging recycling and energy-saving efforts, its use of nuts from rain forest trees in buttons and for signing the Valdez Principles, a 10-point environmental program.
The Kellogg Company, the Battle Creek, Mich., cereal producer, was honored for its treatment of employees, including a range of benefits supporting family life. Hallmark won for equal employment efforts that have encouraged the involvement of women and minorities in top management and for increasing purchases from minority-owned businesses.
The H. B. Fuller Company, a St. Paul-based chemical company, and Foldcraft Inc., a small Kenyon, Minn., furniture maker, received awards for charitable giving.
Time Warner Inc. was honored for "community outreach," including literacy programs dating to 1935 and an "adopt-a-school" program in which each division singles out a public school for support.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Giving the Banks Greater Powers

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES of the big money center banks are the strongest supporters of the Administration proposals for overhauling the banking system -- especially freeing the banks to expand all over the country and giving them broader powers, like the sale of securities and insurance.
"The fundamental problem in banking is colossal overcapacity," said Thomas C. Theobold, the chairman of the Continental Bank of Illinois. Writing in the current issue of the Journal of Applied Finance, he added: "We don't have 10,000 independent banks because the market needs or will support 10,000 banks. We have them because banks have been too tightly regulated and almost completely insulated from normal market forces." 
 And, at a conference on deposit insurance at Pace University in New York this week, Thomas G. Labreque, the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, spoke of the regulatory restriction on commercial banks in the face of growing competition from the "non-bank banks" -- commercial and industrial companies that provide some financial services.
"We've lost market share to captive finance firms like General Credit Corporation and General Motors Acceptance Corporation, and to non-bank financial holding companies like American Express, investment firms and global combinations like Sumitomo-Goldman and Credit Suisse-First Boston," Mr. Labreque said. "Take American Express, for example. It owns a bank which offers F.D.I.C.-insured deposits. It has a thriving credit card business. It also owns Shearson Lehman Hutton investment bank and IDS Insurance Company." But such companies, he added, were not "saddled with the regulations to which bank holding companies are subjected."
Critics of the Administration proposals worry about letting the commercial banks, especially those with weak capital positions, acquire new powers. In its report on deposit insurance, called "A Strategy for Reform," the General Accounting Office, which reports to Congress, stresses the need to strengthen supervision of the banks and raise their capital reserve ratios before they should be permitted to expand into other areas.
The G.A.O. wants "trip wires" that would force regulators to take action when the banks let their capital ratios fall too low, issue excess credit or take unacceptable interest-rate risks. G.A.O. also calls for on-site annual examinations and more bank examiners, and it demands stricter accounting rules and early notification by auditors to insure better compliance. It favors risk-based premiums, which would reward scrupulous banks and penalize the careless.
Steven M. Swaim, who headed the team that prepared the G.A.O. report, told the Pace conference that "in our judgment the powers of the banks should not be expanded until after the reforms are made." Even then, and only for well-capitalized bank holding companies on a case-by-case basis, should Congress phase out restrictions on interstate banking and consider phasing in powers for the banks to engage in securities and insurance businesses, the G.A.O. said.
Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, says such new powers should be carried out only by separate affiliates, with "firewalls" to prevent conflicts of interest. Lowell Bryan of McKinsey & Company favors the use of bank holding companies that would be divided into a core bank along traditional lines, with loans limited to individuals and small and medium-sized businesses, plus a finance company and a wholesale bank.
The bankers still fear that the regulators will regulate them unwisely and excessively compared with the non-bank banks. John S. Rippey, senior vice president and legislative director of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, said the necessary reform should have two main ingredients: "market-driven regulation" combined with "better and more sophisticated supervision." He praised the G.A.O. report for making a valuable start on both.
For the present, G.A.O., like the Administration, supports the "too big to fail" doctrine to prevent collapses of major banks that would jeopardize the whole financial system and take down any deposit insurance arrangements with it. But the G.A.O. differs with the Administration on its proposal that commercial and industrial companies be encouraged to own banks. Congress is afraid of undue concentration of power and is likely to junk the Administration's proposal.
Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady has not defended the proposal strongly and, in the view of some, is using it as "bargaining material" to get what he really wants -- nationwide banking.
The savings and loan disaster struck fear into the hearts of the Federal Reserve and the other regulators -- not to mention millions of depositors and taxpayers. Banking reform legislation and economic recovery are needed to restore health to the banking system. Yet it may take years to repair all the damage to the system created by a decade of excess debt creation and careless lending, of which the inflationary real estate boom was only the latest example. And a strengthened banking system is crucial to stronger national economic growth and performance in the global economy.

HEADLINE: An 18.2% Gain Is Seen For Money Managers

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
With the stock market finally snapping back after months of uncertainty because of events in the Persian Gulf, the nation's money managers saw the estimated value of their equity portfolios shoot up 18.2 percent in the first quarter, according to CDA Investment Technologies, a Rockville, Md., firm that tracks their performance.
The managers' performance beat both the 14.5 percent gain shown by the Standard & Poor 500 Stock Index and the 11.6 percent rise in the Dow Jones industrial average, when adjusted for dividends to be comparable to the CDA estimates. In contrast, the managers finished last year, a difficult time for stocks, worse off than the Dow, and only slightly better than the S.&P. They could have fared better by putting the money to work in Treasury bills.
 
Late Result Uncounted
 To estimate performance and come up with individual rankings, CDA reviewed periodic filings that 540 money managers made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. CDA then computed the theoretical return that each money manager would have earned, assuming that each ended the quarter with the same basket of stocks that was held entering the quarter. 
 While CDA's estimates are a fair indicator of performance over time for many money managers, that method has some shortcomings for money managers who trade actively during the quarter.
For instance, Kenneth J. Gerbino & Company, a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that topped the list of all money managers for the third quarter of last year, was put dead last this time with a drop of 1.6 percent. It was the only manager surveyed that reportedly lost money in the quarter.
Kenneth J. Gerbino, the firm's president, said, "On Dec. 31, we were out of the stock market, except for gold-mining stocks and cash, and in January we took $7 million to $8 million of cash and bought industrial stocks." The purchases were too late to be picked up by CDA, but Mr. Gerbino said he would have finished the quarter up about 6 percent had those purchases been counted.
Also, CDA does not adjust performance for gains or losses that result from short positions, that is the sale of borrowed stock in expectation of a price drop that would enable the short-seller to replace the borrowed stock at a lower cost. CDA also tends to exaggerate the performance, for better or worse, of money managers whose portfolios are concentrated in a handful of stocks.
This quarter, with many managers feeling the benefits of a rising market, money managers were not strenuously disputing their rankings.
Fred Astman, the portfolio manager for First Wilshire Securities Management in Los Angeles, which topped the list, said that CDA had exaggerated his true performance only slightly. "It was the best quarter we've ever had," he said.
CDA reported that First Wilshire had seen its $4 million portfolio, comprising 14 stocks, grow by 51.2 percent for the quarter. In fact, Mr. Astman, said, his portfolio has 30 stocks counting some small, obscure companies that CDA tends to overlook in its survey. "It would be closer to 40 percent when you figure all 30 issues," he said.
Besides having a heavy concentration in small, over-the-counter stocks, one of the big beneficiaries of the current market rally, Mr. Astman holds several health-care issues, one of the quarter's best industry performers. Hospital Staffing Inc., a supplier of labor to the nursing home industry, rose from about $4 to $6, and Hosposable, Inc., a supplier of hospital products, doubled from $4 to $8 during the quarter, he said.
 
Out-of-Favor Stock Cited
 He is also invested in some select savings and loans, including CalFed Inc., on the theory that their profit margins will widen as interest rates drop. That is because mortgage rates tend not to drop as much as the institutions' cost of funds.
Cypress Capital Management, which turned in the fifth-best performance, had an estimated gain of 39.9 percent. Robert Masterson, the firm's director of research, said an out-of-favor stock, Fruit of the Loom, contributed most to its strong performance. Fruit of the Loom closed yesterday at $13.875, down 12.5 cents, but well above its Dec. 31 price.
"It's recession-resistant; it's got minimal capital requirements going forward, and it's throwing off a ton of cash," said Mr. Masterson, who is unfazed by the well-publicized cash problems of the company's chairman, William F. Farley. He feels that certain covenants give investors ample protection from any of Mr. Farley's own debt problems.
Like some of the other names clustered at the top of the list -- Froley and the Revy Investment Company -- Cypress also has a well-known specialty in convertible securities, which paid off handsomely in the quarter. Like bonds, convertible securities pay some fixed rate to their holders, often 5 to 9 percent these days, but also mimic equities, in that holders have the right to turn them into stock if the stock surges.
"Two things have helped the convertible market," Mr. Masterson said. "One is the underlying boost in the equities, and the other is the yield on the converts," he said. "So you've had a double whammy."

HEADLINE: Dow Off 2.23 Points at Closing, to 2,924.50

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks lost ground yesterday, but smaller stocks picked up speed as Wall Street weighed the evidence pointing to a further drop in interest rates -- the kind of news that should give the market a shot in the arm.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which shot ahead 22 points at 2 P.M., slid 2.23 by the close, to 2,924.50. 
 Showing that the weakness was largely in the big, high-profile stocks, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks edged ahead 0.83, to a record 379.77.
The Nasdaq composite, the small-stock index, also reached a high, 497.57, up 2.52.
Traders are waiting for signs today whether employment figures will show that the economy is weak enough for the Fed to ease monetary policy.
Trading volume stood at a strong 198.1 million shares, down only slightly from Wednesday's strong 213.7 million shares.
Birinyi Associates said repeated waves of computer-driven program buying lifted the Dow by fewer than 3 points. Part of the reason for the small gain was a 13-minute-long selling flurry an hour before the close. It chopped 11 points off the blue-chip index.
Still, advances led declines 9 to 6. Only three stocks dropped to new lows but 180 rose to new highs, including American Stores, the food and drug chain, which rose 2 1/8, to 90 3/4.
Morgan Stanley, the investment firm, rose 3/4, to 87 3/4, for another new high.
"The market's hanging fire," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers, "until it sees what tomorrow brings."
Traders estimate that the rate of unemployment could now be as high as 6.7 percent, possibly enough for the Fed to trim rates.
One unknown, though, is a reported dispute at the Fed between Alan Greenspan, its chairman, and individual Federal Reserve presidents and its effect on what happens. The presidents are said to be unhappy that Mr. Greenspan has taken unto himself actions they regard as something they should have a voice in.
 
New Jobless Claims Rise
 Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers, Harriman, noted that bonds rallied -- carrying stocks ahead -- after weekly employment numbers released yesterday were weaker than expected. They showed that new jobless claims rose 33,000, to 543,000, or enough to give traders the feeling that the Fed might ease rates after today's numbers come out.
"It increased the likelihood that tomorrow's unemployment report will be weaker than originally expected, which could likely move the Fed to ease rates," he said.
The prospect of lower interest rates gave new pep to the financial stocks, particularly insurers and banks.
Among the banks, Citicorp climbed 1 1/4, to 15 7/8, with two million shares changing hands. First Wachovia of North Carolina rose 1 1/4, to 55. Bankers Trust tacked on 1 1/8, to 44 5/8. U.S. Bancorp of Oregon added 1, to 29 1/4.
In insurance, Chubb rose 1 5/8, to 75; Fund American 1 1/4, to 62 3/4; Ohio Casualty 1 3/4, to 43 3/4; St. Paul 1, to 74 1/4; A.I.G. 1 1/8, to 100 7/8; General Re 1 1/4, to 101 3/4, and Lincoln National 1 7/8, to 51 1/8.
High-technology stocks, a long-standing market leader, continued strong yesterday.
Borland International tacked on 2 1/4, to 60; Hewlett-Packard 1 1/2, to 52; Apple Computer 1 1/2, to 71 1/2, and Commodore International 1 3/8, to 20 3/4.
Compaq Computer, another technology leader, slumped 1 7/8, to 62 1/2, in heavy trading after it announced widely known plans to buy 13 percent of Silicon Graphics, a maker of workstations. Silicon Graphics fell 1 1/8, to 36 7/8, also in heavy trading.
Health care stocks were also strong. Value Health, a provider of managed-care programs marketed yesterday at $12, ended on Nasdaq at 15 7/8, with 3.2 million shares traded. Bristol-Myers Squibb gained 1 1/8, to 79; Humana 1 3/4, to 51 3/4; Medtronic 1 3/4, to 121 3/4; SmithKline 1 3/8, to 70 1/8; Warner-Lambert 1 3/8, to 77 3/4, and Allergan 1 1/4, to 25 1/2.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims at 8-Year High

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for unemployment insurance jumped in late March to 543,000, the highest level since January 1983, the Labor Department said yesterday. The report suggested that the economy was still mired in recession.
After the figures were released, interest rates on Treasury securities fell, as they often do on publication of statistics that indicate weakness in the economy. The data also suggested that the unemployment rate for March, to be announced by the Labor Department today, will show a rise from February's 6.5 percent level. 
 But the sharp increase in initial unemployment claims for the week ended March 23 -- that is, applications for unemployment pay filed by newly laid-off workers -- ran counter to other recent data indicating that the recession was past its lowest point and that a recovery was beginning. Rising home sales and a rebound in consumer confidence with the end of the Persian Gulf war were among the recent optimistic reports.
The conflicting data produced conflicting assessments. David Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, for example, said the latest unemployment insurance claims simply confirmed what the nation already knew -- "employment is weak and will continue to be weak, even after we start an upturn." He added, "The figures were not unexpected."
Mr. Mullins's remarks seemed to suggest that even if the Labor Department's employment report was very negative, the Federal Reserve would not respond by lowering short-term interest rates another notch to stimulate economic activity. The Fed lowered rates on March 8, the same day the Labor Department announced that the unemployment rate rose to 6.5 percent in February from 6.3 percent in January and 208,000 private-sector jobs disappeared.
The Labor Department itself was pessimistic about the initial claims level that it announced yesterday. "If you look back over the figures for initial claims in recent weeks, you don't discover a lot of upturn in the economy," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner in the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The 543,000 initial claims, seasonally adjusted, represented a rise of 33,000 from the 516,000 claims in the week ended March 16. Although the norm is for claims to fall in the spring when construction and other activities increase, Mr. Plewes said, initial claims have been moving gradually upward instead.
The last time initial claims were this high was in the week ended Jan. 8, 1983, when they reached 546,000. The nation was then beginning a recovery, and the number of initial claims was moving downward, not upward as it is today.
"What happens in the spring is that claims decline, but this spring initial claims are growing," Mr. Plewes said.
Initial claims for most of March averaged 200,000 a year more than they did in March 1990, the Labor Department said, and the total number of people receiving unemployment insurance rose by one million over a one-year period to 3,475,000 in mid-March.
Still, the relationship between unemployment insurance figures and total unemployment is not as close as it once was because state regulations governing unemployment insurance have tightened, making fewer unemployed people eligible for jobless pay.
During the 1974-75 recession, for example, 67 percent of the nation's total unemployed people were eligible for unemployment insurance, compared with 45 percent in the 1981-82 recession and roughly the same percentage today.

HEADLINE: Japanese Improve Share as U.S. Car Sales Decline

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 4

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of sluggish sales in March, Japanese auto makers improved their share of the American automotive market at the expense of the Big Three domestic auto makers.
In late March, car sales in the United States were off 7.8 percent, to 232,240, compared with 279,996 a year earlier. Light-truck sales were off 8 percent to 130,213, from 157,185 last year. There were 9 sales days in the latest period compared with 10 last year; percentage changes are based on the average daily rate. 
 Ten-day total vehicle sales totaled 362,453, a decline of 8 percent from 437,181 a year earlier. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales from March 21 to March 31 was 6.3 million, compared with 7.2 million last year.
Although consumer confidence indicators have risen sharply since American troops in the Persian Gulf stopped fighting, "personal income levels are much more important to vehicle sales than consumer confidence," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco. Personal income levels in January and February were weak.
Domestic auto makers and automotive analysts have been predicting that the Honda Motor Company and the Toyota Motor Corporation will increase financial incentives to consumers to shrink growing inventories. Honda did increase incentives, as well as cut production, and Toyota was offering incentives on some models until Wednesday.
At the same time, the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation slashed production, which means that a bigger proportion of sales went to foreign companies in March.
 
Japanese Import Protection
 Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, in a March 6 letter to President Bush asking for protection from Japanese imports, had predicted that discounting by Japanese auto makers would result in lost market share for United States companies.
In the American car market, sales of American-built and imported models dropped 10.6 percent in March to 735,994, from 855,260 a year ago; totals were based on 26 sales days this year, compared with 27 last year. The percentage decline is based on the daily average.
G.M. car sales were off 12.3 percent for the month, to 255,236; Ford car sales were off 14.8 percent for the month, to 149,126, and Chrysler car sales were off 18.3 percent, to 55,713. Hence, G.M.'s share of the total United States car market declined to 34.7 percent for the month from 35.4 percent last year; Ford dropped to 20.3 percent, from 21.2 percent last year, and Chrysler dropped to a 7.6 percent share, from 8.3 percent last year.
Analysts noted that fewer sales by the Big Three to rental and leasing fleets in March caused bigger declines compared with last year. Conversely, some large foreign auto makers, whose fleet sales are proportionately smaller, experienced less of a decline in sales and, consequently, were able to gain share of the car market.
Car sales for the Honda Motor Company were up 9 percent in March to 74,961. The Toyota Motor Corporation sales were off 5 percent, to 66,494. But the Nissan Motor Company car sales were off 24 percent, to 32,473.

HEADLINE: For F.D.I.C.'s Top Law Firm, Fees Reaching $600 an Hour

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Government has agreed to pay lawyers at a prominent Manhattan firm as much as $600 an hour for their work in several cases involving some of the nation's largest failed savings and loan associations.
The fee arrangement with Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which has the unusual feature of promising a minimum fee plus a contingency, is potentially the most lucrative ever between the Government and a law firm. It is expected to be worth tens of millions of dollars over its life. 
 The fact that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation turned to one of America's most prestigious -- and most expensive -- Wall Street law firms to help it recoup some of the billions of dollars lost by failed financial institutions reflects the growing complexity of legal work surrounding the savings and loan bailout. It also signals the importance the Government places on the task. But some members of Congress criticized Cravath's fees today and accused regulators of wasting taxpayer money.
David Boies, a Cravath partner who is billing the Government as high as $600 an hour, said the fee agreement showed how Government litigation "is more and more resembling complex commercial litigation."
Mr. Boies compared the complexity of the assignment to two other highly celebrated Cravath victories, the I.B.M. antitrust case in which the Government ultimately dropped its charges and the Westmoreland libel suit, which his client, CBS, also won.
Terms of the agreement were negotiated last summer between Cravath's senior partners and Alfred J. T. Byrne, the F.D.I.C.'s general counsel, who came up with the idea of hiring a top-flight law firm to tackle the cases. He notified six firms and received bids from three, including Cravath.
Since the bailout began, the regulatory agency has become the nation's largest employer of lawyers. This represents a shift for many private law firms, which in this time of economic recession can no longer count on growing work from their stable of Wall Street and corporate clients. The agency has retained more than 1,000 law firms, including those that are doing work for the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is specifically charged with administering the savings bailout.
Last year bank regulators paid $615 million to law firms for services ranging from prosecuting savings and loan officials to collecting delinquent loans. Cravath's share of these fees was $1.6 million.
Cravath's work focuses on litigation against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., former senior executives at the firm including Michael R. Milken, the former financier whose "junk bonds" helped finance some of the largest takeovers in the 1980's, and other firms that peddled such bonds to savings institutions that later failed.
The Cravath fee arrangement came to light today when the Government released major parts of its contract between the firm and the F.D.I.C. The agreement was obtained through a legally enforceable request submitted by The New York Times in November under the Freedom of Information Act.
Already, Cravath lawyers have filed actions against Drexel, the Milkens and the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., seeking more than $20 billion. The suits contend that the defendants were culprits in the savings and loan debacle through their participation in a "fraudulent" junk bond market. Among the institutions that have been cited with Drexel are Centrust Savings of Miami, Gibraltar Savings also of Beverly Hills, and Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif.
Under a novel arrangement for the law firm and the Government that pegs Cravath's pay to performance, the firm's senior litigators -- Thomas D. Barr and Mr. Boies -- could bill the Government as much as $600 an hour, its other partners $425 and associates $270.
The firm's compensation is tied to its performance, but the arrangement is unlike the traditional all-or-nothing contingency fee, which typically is up to one-third of a judgment if the suit is successful and nothing if it fails. In this case, the lawyers are guaranteed a minimum discounted from their original rates. At a minimum, Cravath's senior litigators will bill $300 an hour, even if they fail to recoup a cent for taxpayers. If the firm manages to obtain more than $200 million for the Government in these cases, then its rate jumps to as high as $600 an hour.
But some authorities on compensation said that the deal was a fair one; a bargain for the Government and potentially lucrative arrangement for Cravath, whose senior lawyers typically are said to charge hourly rates of $375 to $400, excluding any premiums for satisfying clients.
"If things don't go well, the Government gets them at a discount," said Steven Brill, president and editor in chief of The American Lawyer, a monthly trade publication. "If they do well, then they get only a small percentage of the overall take."
The unusual agreement has drawn criticism from some lawmakers who say it will add to the already high cost of the bailout, as well as defendants in the cases filed by Cravath who see the lawyers as little more than bounty hunters.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, said the F.D.I.C.'s system of obtaining lawyers was "scandalous" because it was not subjected to the same kind of competitive bidding as other Government contractors.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The services of Thomas D. Barr, a senior litigator at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, could cost Government as much as $600 an hour. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times) (pg. B18)

Thomas D. Barr, David Boies and "partners
