Other partners 250 an hour
 
Associates 180 an hour
 
Paralegals 50 an hour
 
Word processors and others 22 an hour
 
ADJUSTMENTS AFTER JUDGMENTS OR SETTLEMENTS
 
When monetary judgments are entered or settlements reached in excess of $200 million, a 10 percent increase is applied retroactively on all hourly rates. This amount cannot exceed 5 percent of the aggregate amount of judgments entered and/or settlements reached.
 
FURTHER ADJUSTMENTS AFTER CASH IS COLLECTED
 
Once cash or equivalents are actually collected, the firm receives retroactively the following additional amounts, plus interest based on 90-day Treasury bills. The total amount to be paid from recoveries is not to exceed 25 percent of the aggregate cash or cash equivalent collections from the Government.
 
Thomas D. Barr and David Boies and "partners of
comparable seniority" $270 an hour
 
Other partners 150 an hour
 
All associates 72 an hour
 
Paralegals 30 an hour

"Different Mix at Law Schools"
At law schools approved by the American Bar Association.
 
For the third year in a row, students at dozens of law schools boycotted classes Thursday to protest what they say is the failure of their schools to hire enough minority and women faculty members.
 
At the University of California at Berkeley law school, where the protest was organized, about 80 percent of 900 law students boycotted classes and six professors canceled classes. Of the 55 faculty members, 5 are members of a minority group and 10 are women.
 
By contrast, students at the University of Texas at Austin held a rally after the school offered faculty appointments to four women, one of whom is Hispanic. If that professor accepts the offer, she will be the law school's first full-time Hispanic professor.
 
Graphs: Graphs shows statistics on minority groups of students and faculty members from '80-'90. (Sources: American Bar Association (students); Review of Legal Education in the United States (faculty members) (pg. B18)
 
"My judgment is that the Cravath fee is excessive," said the Democrat in a telephone interview from his home in San Antonio. "It's the equivalent of war profiteering."
Mr. Byrne, the F.D.I.C.'s general counsel, conceded that Cravath had been retained only after "an informal competitive bidding process" and that the agency did not have an objective written policy.
He said it was "a reasonable bargain in favor of the Government" and would result in a "substantial net recovery to the benefit of taxpayers."American Continental+ (Lincoln)

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 182 words

HEADLINE: Gap Between Rich And Poor Widens

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To show that Republican policies of the 1980's did not favor the rich, Senator Pete Domenici draws an inaccurate conclusion from his statistics -- that the income of the poorest gained almost the same as the income of the richest, 11.8 percent versus 12.2 percent (news article, March 7). 
 The same percentage change for a wealthy person and for a poor person will lead to significant differences in absolute terms. Let us assume that someone earning $10,000 a year and someone earning $1 million a year (an absolute gap of $990,000) both gain a 10 percent increase; the poorer has gained $1,000, whereas the richer has gained $100,000; the absolute gap has widened from $990,000 to $1,089,000 -- a $99,000 increase.
The gap itself between rich and poor has increased by 10 percent. And a poorer person spends a much larger percentage of income on necessities than a richer person (Engel's Law) -- that is, the rich man's gain is for luxuries.
 
SIMON RASKIN
Flushing, Queens, March 15, 1991
 
The writer teaches economics at Kingsborough Community College.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"When 'Fairness' Isn't Fair" (Op-Ed, March 24) by Clayton Yeutter, President Bush's counselor for domestic policy, makes me realize how desperate Mr. Bush's staff is to have him re-elected, and why his domestic policy failures are commonplace.
The Reagan-Bush boom Mr. Yeutter speaks of was a false economy created and perpetuated by turning a blind eye to the savings and loan network that pumped unsecured billions into the economy to ignite construction spending, which the White House viewed as the cornerstone of our economy (similarly, the recent cuts in the prime interest rates by the Federal Reserve). The other main economic tool was astronomically escalated military spending, which provided thousands of temporary jobs at inefficiently run oligopolistic companies that could furnish ludicrous bids but receive a contract by default. 
 Unlike Mr. Yeutter and the rest of the Bush Administration, most Americans deal with reality, economically and socially, and know this is the Reagan-Bush legacy:
(1) In 1980 we had a $1.1 billion trade surplus; by 1990 we had a $95 billion trade deficit. (2) In 1990 alone President Bush ran a deficit greater than the deficits of Presidents Carter, Johnson, Kennedy and Truman combined. Before Ronald Reagan all 40 Presidents ran up a combined national debt of $994.3 billion. The Reagan-Bush Administrations alone added $2.63 trillion. In fiscal year 1991 the interest on the debt was $197 billion.
These frightening figures, along with a decline in the manufacturing base, an unwillingness to educate the American public for a global future, to address AIDS, crime, health care, homelessness, to provide desperately needed funds for research and development, and to draft an overall industrial policy (such as both Japan and Germany have), lead the politically aware to believe the White House has only one domestic policy.
A study by the Trilateral Commission several years ago concluded that television creates excess democracy. I must argue the opposite. Since the corporate takeover of television (for example, the General Electric Company's ownership of NBC), democracy is severely restricted by corporate and Government self-interest. My argument is this:
The Reagan-Bush Administrations have brilliantly used television to lull the American mind to sleep. They have pejoratively neglected the American public, while forging the "new world order," which is another bubble waiting to burst (like our economy). Meanwhile they have created distraction after distraction (remember how conveniently the flag-burning issue grabbed the headlines daily during the savings and loan investigations?) and sound bite after sound bite to mask their covert, illegal and clandestine activities.
Wake up from your decadelong slumber, America; democracy is dying. Don't you remember when homelessness wasn't even in your vocabulary?
 
MICHAEL WILEY
New York, March 25, 1992

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Old Litmus Tests Are Abandoned In the New York Democratic Primary

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
The more raucous it gets, the more cozily familiar a New York Democratic Presidential primary can feel. After a couple of weeks of in-your-face protests, spats over Israel, splashy appearances by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, press harpoons and candidate snits, this uncharacteristically important race approaches its Tuesday climax in what at first blush appears to be the standard indigenous style.
But in fact the primary that pits Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas against former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California differs starkly from off-the-shelf New York primaries of yore, in which candidates fell over each other to express their concern for cities, social welfare programs and any number of issues that the state's traditional liberal and labor-oriented primary voters once valued. Many of the traditional litmus tests for Democratic candidates in New York have been all but abandoned, suggesting much about the status, and the troubles, of the national Democratic Party and the growing compromises forced on its New York branch. 
 "The note of liberalism has been complemented by a grace note of desperation on the part of Democrats," said Norman Adler, one of the state's droller political operatives.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown have not forgotten to profess their admiration for New York or the need for attention to cities, the poor and racial equality. But these issues have assumed a far less central place in either candidate's platform than they did in those of past candidates. The classic appeals to New York Democrats, usually revolving around aid targeted to cities and their poor, have been bypassed by national themes involving the general economy, a show of revulsion over insider politics and new demographic realities.
A couple of months ago, when a host of Democratic contenders addressed the United States Conference of Mayors, many sobered city executives left the session believing that the Presidential contender with the best program for cities was the second-tier aspirant, Larry Agran, former Mayor of Irvine, Calif. (who was arrested last week in the Bronx when he tried to participate in a Brown-Clinton debate).
Yet endorsements from liberals, unions and Democratic leaders have flowed to Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton despite their contrary positions on what used to be core issues. They include Mr. Clinton's approval of the death penalty and his leadership of a right-to-work state and Mr. Brown's advocacy of a flat tax, a levy so offensive to New Yorkers that when one was proposed in the Reagan era, the conservative Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato staged a mock Boston Tea Party.
"This hand-wringing of the cities, and the 'Why don't you love us?' is not in tune with the political mood or the demography of the 1990's," said Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York in Albany. The beginning of the change came in June 1978, he said, when California voters passed Proposition 13, cutting local property taxes in half. The rebellion started prairie fires across the country, and soon President Jimmy Carter pulled back on his recently announced multi-billion dollar urban initiative.
President Reagan's victory in the air traffic controllers' strike in the early 1980's helped push right-to-work laws into the background as unions focused on the more direct threat of striker replacement, an issue many union leaders view as their litmus issue of this campaign.
Locally, former Reppresentative Edward I. Koch was fashioning a successful run for Mayor of New York by breaking with his liberal colleagues over such issues as the death penalty, low-income housing in middle-income neighborhoods and racial quotas. He opposed them all.
Many political analysts believe the major issues of urban America increasingly began to be identified as those of the poor and minority groups at a time when middle-class whites living outside the cities, and hurting in the current recession, were becoming a larger part of the electorate. In their recent book, "Chain Reaction" (W. W. Norton, 1991), Thomas Byrne Edsall and Mary D. Edsall note that between 1970 and 1986 the nation's heavily white suburbs grew to 44.9 percent of the population, up from 40.8 percent, while the cities' proportion slipped from 35.2 to 31.6 percent.
"In a critical development in Presidential elections," they wrote, "the 1992 contest will mark the first time that suburban (and exurban) voters cast an absolute majority of ballots. This reflects the continuation of a trend that will have profound implications for the strategies of both parties, for the role of race in national elections and for the formulation of policy."
Although both candidates have been paying increasing homage to New York and the cities, Mr. Clinton's 10-page position paper clearly charts a policy that does not emphasize a return to massive aid targeted to beleaguered urban areas. Rather, it argues that the best way to help Americans in cities is to help Americans in general.
 
Unusual Developments
 Mr. Brown has raced to endorse a $30 billion aid plan being pushed by the Conference of Mayors, but his main message is that the overhaul of a "governing elite" will send more money and help to cities and to average Americans generally.
Meanwhile, in New York, these unusual developments have emerged: Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger and other liberals have endorsed Mr. Clinton despite his capital punishment position, and an execution in his state this year.
Many union leaders, including Jay Mazur of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, endorsed Mr. Clinton despite his state's right-to-work law. The garment workers have suffered probably more than any other union over the loss of jobs to Southern right-to-work states.
Barry Feinstein, whose Teamsters local represents thousands of city workers, and other labor leaders endorsed Mr. Brown, despite his flat tax proposal. When President Reagan proposed such a tax, New York state leaders said it would mean huge tax increases and devastating layoffs.
Invariably, the endorsers say nice things about their candidates and then say they were forced to choose from a highly limited field.
Ironically, as the local liberal political agenda diminishes in importance, the New York primary itself has catapulted in political significance. The Clinton camp says a win would all but clinch the nomination. A win or something close to it for Mr. Brown would boost his standing dramatically and also add to the possibility that some in the party would beat the drums for an entirely new candidate.
But in a conservative era, New York Democrats have extracted few promises. Speaking of local party and labor leaders, William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the City University Graduate Center, remarked, "They're so dying for a Democratic President that a lot of the other stuff, traditional issues and so forth, forget it."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Arabs Find A World in Which They Count Less

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
As they try to define their new relationship with the United States and the rest of the triumphant West, the Arabs are reaching the conclusion that they do not matter as much as they thought they did.
Throughout the Arab world, a realization has dawned that after the disappearance of the Soviet Union and the defeat of Iraq they are no longer feared; in addition, many Arabs say they are shocked to find that they are not respected either. 
 Their fears do not appear to be a delusion. The Bush Administration has been persistent in getting Arabs and Israelis to sit down at peace talks, but it has not made public any comprehensive vision for a policy toward the Middle East or Arab world. In private, American diplomats say the Administration has returned to dealing with the Arab lands country by country, an approach that assumes no urgent reason to do otherwise.
The sense in the Arab world that it has been marginalized was only intensified by the treatment accorded Libya last week by the United States, Britain and France. Acting through the United Nations Security Council, the Western powers obtained economic sanctions designed to compel Libya to turn over to Western justice six Libyans accused in two airplane bombings that killed 441 people in 1988.
While there is hardly any admiration for the Libyans in the Arab world, the episode was seen as a demonstration of how little the West cared about the way the Arabs think, or how they see themselves. In the Arab view, the Western allies paid only lip service to pleas from friends like Egypt, Morocco and Tunisia for more time to find a more conciliatory way out of the impasse. The 21-member Arab League tried in vain to take charge of the issue but was ignored.
 
Benign Neglect?
 "From our perspective this new world order translates into a combination of benign neglect for Arabs, punctuated with selective punishment as we see with Iraq and Libya," Sherif al-Shobashi, chief European correspondent for the Egyptian daily newspaper Al Ahram, commented in a recent conversation. "It is a vengeful new order," he said, summing up a view that has predominated in the Arab press in the last few weeks.
Though they look at things from a different perspective, United States policy makers in fact reach some of the same conclusions as the Arabs.
When asked for a cold-blooded assessment of American policy in the Middle East, one United States diplomat spoke at length, on condition that he remain anonymous, in an interview. His comments echoed those of senior American envoys in the field.
"I don't think Washington sees an Arab landscape out there any more," the diplomat said. "We see Egyptians, we see Saudis, we see Libyans and Algerians. While there is still some appreciation of the concept of Arab solidarity, it no longer plays a role in our calculations."
There were, he said, hardly any "shared values" for the West and the Arabs, and the West's one big interest in the region, oil, is more secure than ever in the absence of Soviet competition and the relative feebleness of opposition to the West, even from Islamic fundamentalism.
The diplomat said things have changed irrevocably since the tense period less than two years ago when the United States showed great deference to Arab sensitivities during the gulf crisis. Since then the United States has concluded, among other things, that the so-called "Arab street" -- the power of public opinion -- is more myth than potent threat to American interests, the diplomat said. It has also concluded that the individual interests of Arab states like Saudi Arabia, which needs American protection, and Egypt, which needs American money, transcend by far any notion of Arab solidarity. And finally, he said, America has concluded that Islamic fundamentalism simply "does not carry the kind of punch the Soviet threat did."
This American official says there is no new doctrine governing Middle East policy, only what he described as "ad hoc and gradual" new rules that appear to be governed by lack of concern about old dangers rather than a quest for a new direction.
Ahmad Khalidi, a Palestinian scholar and political consultant based in London, says the rules these days "single out the Arabs for punishment and disciplinary actions while letting Israel free to defy all United Nations resolutions and the concept of a new world order." Nevertheless, he and other Arab intellectuals acknowledge that things are changing for Israel too. A senior Egyptian diplomat in Europe noted that American military inspectors were sent to Israel two weeks ago to investigate a charge (for which, last week, they found no evidence) that Israel gave advanced Patriot missile technology to China, "just as inspection teams have been plowing Iraq" to destroy that country's ability to make nuclear or biological weapons.
The comparative coolness of current American policy toward Israel is acknowledged by American officials, who say the new American language in Middle East diplomacy revolves essentially around the willingness of the region as a whole, including Israel, to yield to Washington's views. "The American-Israeli relationship is receding in the sense that there is a growing willingness to ask whether what Israel does falls within the area of our shared values," the American official who described the Administration's policy said. "But it would be foolish for Arab governments to conclude that there are more shared values between us and them as a result."
Among Arabs it is not evident that any credible resistance has yet emerged to what Mr. Khalidi calls the "American era." Libya, Iraq, Iran, leftist Palestinian factions and militant fundamentalists attract almost no support and, if anything, are under Arab pressure to keep quiet. Meanwhile, influential countries like Egypt and Saudi Arabia maintain that the way to influence American policy is by remaining under the American umbrella.
 
Resentments
 It remains true, however, that large numbers of the estimated 300 million Arabs are deeply resentful of American policies in the Palestinian-Israeli dispute; even with relations between the United States and Israel having cooled, Arabs retain a belief that America applies a double standard when considering the rights of Israelis and the rights of Arabs. This is now also complicated by the growing perception that Arab views, policies and even cultural values are seen as worthless in Washington.
Gamil Matar, a widely respected leftist Egyptian writer, noted in an essay last week that the United States and the West are "not offering the Arabs a deal or even a prospect for a deal." The essence of the West's policies, Mr. Matar wrote, is a rejection, rooted in racial and cultural prejudice, of all fundamental Arab beliefs, including their legitimate grievances.
Last week there was, indeed, the first hint since the gulf crisis of a unified Arab protest, in the complaints over the treatment of Libya. This suggests that there may be some life left in what was thought to be the cadaver of pan-Arabism. But whether the outcry will evolve into a strong challenge to America's new vision remains to be seen.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Will More Guns for the Generals Aid or Threaten Democracy?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
AT first everyone fell into a hush, and then they gawked as the black, sharp-angled F-117 Stealth fighter built in the United States streaked over a desert airstrip on the outskirts of Santiago like a strange Andean bird. It was the kickoff last month of Chile's 1992 International Air and Space Show, the pride of the Chilean military.
Though the name may connote something less bellicose, the air show is the largest display in Latin America of technology and hardware to kill and wage war. Grenades, cluster bombs, Uzi submachine guns, artillery, radar systems, helicopter gunships and a host of fighter jets were on view. Generals, colonels and officers of indistinguishable rank mingled with arms vendors in a 10-day event that they hope will lead to multimillion dollar deals. 
 But the display of highly advanced weapons -- technology these countries neither need nor can afford -- struck an odd chord. Less than a month before, an attempted military coup in Venezuela had reminded political leaders that democracy is not guaranteed. Many people in Latin America are asking how to structure armies in the future so that they remain loyal to civilian authority while continuing to provide for the national defense.
Should governments keep military spending at an absolute minimum and try to limit the army's ability to disturb the democratic process? Or should they provide enough spending to give their armed forces a continued sense of mission and pride, in hopes of keeping the soldiers in their barracks and away from the political arena?
Analysts here and in other countries note that discontent among military establishments is fueled by several sources. If the civilian government is corrupt or ineffective, the military is often considered an option for change. And if the level of military spending, particularly wages, is low, that often aggravates the problem.
In Venezuela, for example, real wages for the military have fallen 30 percent in five years; in Bolivia they are down almost 50 percent. Argentine officers earn less than half what they did in the early 1980's, and Brazil has cut military pay more than 25 percent. "Because of wage cuts, militaries have seen their social standing go from that of the middle class to the lower middle class," said Rosendo Fraga, one of Argentina's top military analysts.
Much of this is a direct reflection of economic conditions in Latin America. Many countries, like Argentina, are straining to get their economies back on a pay-as-you-go basis and have found military spending a convenient area to neglect. Indeed, spending on weapons systems, warships and other military hardware is now less than $1 billion a year in South America, experts here say, compared with an annual rate of $3 billion during the 1970's, the heyday of military governments.
"It's either put a lid on the military and let it erupt as it has done before, or expose them to the democratic process of defending what they are doing and provide them with the level of spending they can justify to the public," said Patrice Franko-Jones, an assistant professor of economics and international studies at Colby College in Waterville, Me.
Why, then, were the United States and other countries so eager to show up at the air show? Though military spending is small in Latin America compared with the Middle East and Southeast Asia, contractors are now pursuing all markets, in part because spending in the United States and NATO is being slashed. Some hope that as Latin America's economies recover, so will military spending.
 
Buyers and Sellers
 Chile is by far the most sought-after target, mainly because the civilian Government does not control arms spending. By law, 10 percent of Chile's copper revenues, or about $300 million a year, goes to the military. This has made Chile the biggest spender on the continent in percentage of gross domestic product. Argentina, for example, spends 1.8 percent of its national product on its military, down from 4 percent in the early 1980's. Brazil spends 5 percent. Chile spends 5 percent to 6 percent.
For military contractors, that means about $300 million to $350 million a year. Indeed, the big excitement here was over which company would get the contract for a new generation of fighter jets for the Chilean Air Force to replace its 30-year-old British-made Hunter aircraft; the contract could be worth more than $200 million.
Besides Chile, few countries are now building up their armed forces. Argentina does not have the money to buy enough spare parts for its existing equipment, leaving half of its fighter aircraft, 20 helicopters, 250 armored personnel carriers and its one aircraft carrier out of commission. Peru, though facing a fight against Shining Path insurgents, will spend little more than what it gets from the United States in military aid.
Colombia was said to be only in the market for light weapons, vehicles to fight guerrillas and drug traffickers. And Venezuela, Paraguay, Uruguay and Bolivia are all considered modest buyers. On the other hand, Brazil is expected to spend about $200 million a year on new arms and Ecuador is said to be trying to buy $120 million worth of tanks, most likely from the French.
Who will emerge as the dominant supplier remains to be seen; certainly there is every prospect of a competition between the overstocked Western powers and the cash-strapped former allies of the Soviet Union. A lot of the weaponry from both sources, while conventional, is still more sophisticated than what Latin American countries now have.
"Everyone wants the most sophisticated weapon, whether they need it or not," Mr. Fraga said.

HEADLINE: BETTING ON BORIS;
With $24 Billion, Allies Hope to Buy Peaceful Transition

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In moments of national challenge, when the arguments President Bush must make to Congress and the public seem beyond his usual oratorical grasp, he often looks for help to the World War II era that formed his own world view.
Mr. Bush did that to gather the nation for war with Saddam Hussein. And last week, as he introduced a program of substantial aid for Russia, he seemed to borrow arguments that Harry Truman made for the Marshall Plan. 
 "The burden of our responsibility today is greater, even considering the size and resources of our expanded nation, than it was in the time of Jefferson and Monroe," President Truman said on April 5, 1947. Secretary of State George C. Marshall pleaded for "foresight and a willingness on the part of our people to face up to the vast responsibility which history has clearly placed upon our country."
On April 1, 1992, Mr. Bush said, "The stakes are as high for us now as any that we have faced in this century." He added, "Future generations of Americans will thank us for having had the foresight and the conviction to stand up for democracy and work for peace."
Like Truman's time, this is a moment when history unfolds with bewildering rapidity and forces choices that will reverberate for decades. Despite the political capital Mr. Bush obviously wanted from the announcement of the aid program in an election year, no one rolled their eyes when he spoke of a "defining moment in history."
Even the most reserved public figures talk of epochal changes nowadays, and the $24 billion aid program announced by the Group of Seven industrial nations seemed a fitting start. The program was a dramatic affirmation of President Boris N. Yeltsin's economic policies, the clearest break from the hesitation in American policy on Russia.
It is tempting to seek parallels between the proposals of aid to Europe in 1947 and assistance to Russia in 1992. But if the tattered Soviet Union is the modern equivalent of the battered post-war Continent, Mr. Bush's plan to aid Russia is clearly not the late 20th century version of the Marshall Plan.
Unlike the Marshall Plan, which provided material goods that the Europeans then sold for reconstruction funds, the current program is one of straight assistance: $6 billion to back the value of the ruble, $4.5 billion in loans, $2.5 billion in postponed loan payments.
To fill out the package, the United States toted up programs already under way among its allies and tossed them into the pot. The figures were extraordinarily jumbled -- the Japanese complained, in fact, that announcing anything about the program was premature -- but Mr. Bush insisted that they added up to $13 billion (or if they didn't, they would eventually). Most important, he said, no new taxpayer money would be required.
Mr. Bush hopes to use the money to prevent economic collapse in Russia from permitting the resurgence of dictatorship. The Marshall Plan, which began with $4 billion -- in today's terms, about $24 billion -- also aimed at preventing a rebirth of fascism. But its broader goal was to contain Soviet Communism.
Mr. Yeltsin may face a more daunting task to earn his aid and keep the peace than Europe's postwar leaders did. "The Marshall Plan very deliberately built on skills that were already there," said the historian Stephen E. Ambrose. "The Russians have some highly skilled people in weaponry of all types, but they don't know diddly about insurance or banking or risk capital."
So far, the aid plan that Mr. Bush has signed on to focuses only on Russia. Future aid is promised to the 11 other former Soviet republics, but some of these are already starting to question Mr. Bush's vision.
Truman and his aides were years ahead of public opinion and took extraordinary political heat. Mr. Bush, who took months to approve the aid program, does not have that problem. There is no talk of a Bush Doctrine, or even a Bush Plan. "Much less interested in emotion, much more interested in getting something positively done," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Bush was heavily criticized for clinging so long to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and some ask if the President, for whom personal relations are the key to foreign policy, is now relying too heavily on Mr. Yeltsin.
"In the past, we bet everything on Gorbachev and it was a mistake," said Jan Vanous, an expert on the former Communist economies. "Now we are betting everything on Russia."
With the International Monetary Fund conditioning loans in part on Russia's selling oil at market prices, Mr. Vanous said Moscow could get a windfall of billions and cripple Ukraine, Belarus and the Baltics, which have been buying Russian oil for decades at subsidized rates.
If the Marshall Plan pattern is the wrong precedent against which to measure the Bush program, Brent Scowcroft, the President's National Security Adviser, prefers another one: the Weimar Republic.
He has been arguing in the White House councils that the aftermath of World War I, when Britain and France stood astride a broken Germany, contains valuable lessons. While America gave Weimar Germany money, the brunt of postwar policy lay in the crippling war reparations that helped produce economic ruin and thus set the stage for Hitler's rise to power.
 
A Fear of Resentments
 Now, American officials fear the fringe nationalists in Russia who resent the victors in the cold war in a way that recalls the feelings of Germans toward their conquerors in 1918.
Mr. Bush does not push the Marshall Plan analogy too far, perhaps mindful that his domestic political problems may be even bigger than Truman's.
After World War II, the United States was in a relatively magnanimous victor's mood, and even then Marshall's State Department had to fight hard for the European aid program against right-wing Republicans led by Senator Robert Taft.
Truman succeeded in part because he gave Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, the Republican internationalist, plenty of notice and secured his support.
In 1992, Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican insurgent, is playing Taft to Mr. Bush's Truman, calling on Congress to stop the "Russian gravy train." Mr. Bush told the Democratic leadership about his aid plan 30 minutes before announcing it.
Still, on this subject also, Mr. Bush seemed to be hearing Truman's echoes, in his own fashion.
Asked what he would say to those who think $24 billion is too much, or not enough, Mr. Bush replied: "I will say that I think it is enough, and that it's what we ought to do right now and fight like heck for what we believe in here."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
If the G.N.P. Counted Housework, Would Women Count for More?

BYLINE: By MARIA ODUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Homemakers often feel their work is taken for granted, and advocates in the women's movement argue that the statistical invisibility of what used to be called women's work has policy implications that undermine a wide range of family issues. And so, there is an international movement to add housework to the gross national product as a way of elevating the work's status and, by extension, that of women.
The idea unsettles some economists and legislators, who say there is no sensible way to attach a price tag to unremunerated work, and that doing so would compromise the integrity of economic statistics by freighting them with political assumptions. 
 But proponents of the idea envision it as the magic wand that will force women's issues to the forefront of the American agenda.
"If you raise the status of women," said Representative Barbara-Rose Collins, Democrat of Michigan, "then there wouldn't be such a debate on subjects like the Family Leave Bill, which passed in Congress but the President vetoed. We would be more conscious of the family unit."
Carol A. M. Clark, an economist at Guilford College in Greensboro, N.C., agrees. "If we had been counting women's unwaged work 30 years ago when women began entering the work force," she said, "policy makers would have foreseen and prevented the current child-care and elder-care crises."
Opponents say the idea would only amount to empty symbolism and would create a convenient excuse for the tax collector to reach deeper into the family pocket.
"Once you establish it as a 'normal' part of income, then the Government can start to tax it," said Robert Rector, a policy analyst for family issues at the Heritage Foundation, "and I really think that's the bottom line here."
 
Pricing the Quality of Work

Furthermore, economists cannot easily grapple with the question of how to determine the value of particular jobs. The average cook, for example, earns $12,480 annually, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but what is the economic value of the homemaker who can prepare a coulibiac de saumon -- or the one who can't even boil eggs?
"There are questions of quality," said Larry Moran, a research economist with the Bureau of Economic Analysis. "I don't know about your quality of housework, but the quality of my housework would be in trouble."
In October, Ms. Collins introduced a bill to an Education and Labor subcommittee that would require the Bureau of Labor Statistics to determine a dollar value for unpaid services like housework, caring for children or the elderly, agricultural work, volunteer work and work in a family business so that the amount could be added to the G. N. P., the standard measure of all the goods and services produced in a country.
Because the monetary value would apply to the work itself, the legislation would count the efforts of men as well as women if they share or perform household or volunteer work. The legislation, endorsed by the Congressional Women's Caucus, has 31 co-sponsors, including a Republican, Representative Constance A. Morella of Maryland.
It's been seven years since the International Wages for Housework Campaign, founded 20 years ago, won its first major victory. At the United Nations Decade for Women World Conference in Nairobi, Kenya, a resolution was adopted calling on all nations to measure and include in their G. N. P.'s the unpaid contributions of women.
"It's important for policy concerns on women," said Dr. Joann Vanek, coordinator for programs on gender statistics in the United Nations statistical office. "The United Nations is particularly concerned about this in developing countries, because so much of what women do in those countries is not reflected in statistics."
 
The Economists' Ideas
 Several methods have been devised by economists to value housework.
One is market cost, which measures how much it would cost to take all the services performed inside the home into the market. For women in this country, this value would be about $16,000 per year in 1991 dollars, based on research by the Bureau of Economic Analysis in 1976. This value is comparable to the average salary of a kindergarten teacher, hotel clerk, receptionist or security guard, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Another is replacement cost, which measures how much it would cost to get someone to come in to perform all the household jobs. This conjures visions of a home crawling with babysitters, maids and cooks dashing in to perform a task and leaving soon afterward. This value turns out to be the same as the market cost.
And then there is the opportunity cost, which determines how much a person could earn in a job outside the home if he or she weren't doing housework full time. This figure, of course, could vary. If a woman had a law degree, for example, she could potentially earn in the six digits. However, based on a survey of women for a study by the Bureau of Economic Analysis in 1976, this figure was about $17,000 per year in 1991 dollars. This method has been used mostly by lawyers representing women in divorce proceedings.
Despite the United Nations' entreaty to have member nations include unpaid work in their G. N. P.'s -- which by some estimates is an additional $4 trillion worldwide -- countries have been sluggish, if not unresponsive, about embracing and carrying out the idea.
So far, no country has begun counting women's unpaid work in the G. N. P., but some countries, like France and Norway, have created "satellite" G. N. P. estimates that include it. Others, including Germany, Australia and Canada, have begun studies on the topic, said Dr. Vanek, the U.N. statistician.

HEADLINE: Wake Up From Your 80's Slumber, America;
Not Reagan's Heir

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Clayton Yeutter's "When 'Fairness' Isn't Fair," (Op-Ed, March 24) gets it half right. He exposes the bizarre methodology and statistical sleights-of-hand used by the Congressional Budget Office to denigrate the economy's tremendous performance during the Reagan expansion. Mr. Yeutter stretches credibility, however, by arguing that George Bush is continuing the conservative policies adopted by Ronald Reagan. 
 In constant 1987 dollars, domestic spending climbed by an average of $2.82 billion annually in the eight years Ronald Reagan was President. But under George Bush domestic spending has, on average, grown by an astounding $43.4 billion annually (even excluding deposit insurance and net interest). Even Jimmy Carter, with average annual domestic spending growth of $15.3 billion, seems conservative by comparison.
On taxes, Mr. Bush's reversal of Reaganomics hardly needs elaboration. Despite his campaign pledge, he capitulated to the largest single-year tax increase in our history. His regulatory record is equally dismal. Legal monstrosities like the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Clean Air Act have contributed to reregulation that chokes entrepreneurs with red tape and wipes out the limited deregulation gains of the 80's.
Big Government policies have not worked any better for Mr. Bush than they did for Jimmy Carter. Median family incomes are falling for the first time since the late 1970's-early 80's. Unemployment is climbing. Jobs are disappearing almost everywhere except the Federal Government payroll. National output is stagnant. Consumer confidence is low.
I sympathize with Mr. Yeutter for trying to make the best of a bad situation in the White House, having been given the near-impossible job of cleaning up the mess largely created by Richard Darman, the Budget Director. However, statistical manipulation is bad, no matter who controls the calculator.
Just as liberals should not try to make the 1980's look bad by holding President Reagan accountable for the economy's poor performance under President Carter, neither should Mr. Yeutter try to make President Bush's miserable record look good by giving him credit for the Reagan expansion.
 
DANIEL J. MITCHELL
John M. Olin Senior Fellow
The Heritage Foundation
Washington, March 24, 1992

HEADLINE: Your Money;
At Tax Deadline Without the Cash

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For thousands of reputable middle-class Americans, April 15 represents a guilty secret. They fail to file income tax returns, and there are indications that with layoffs rising their numbers may grow this year.
Failing to file is a serious mistake but can be rectified. Even people who owe taxes but lack the money should file returns, experts say, and work out payment plans to avoid or minimize penalties. 
 Robert G. Nath, a tax lawyer and contributing editor to Bender's Federal Tax Service, said: "Some traumatic event triggers the nonfiling. It could be a divorce, a business disaster, a personal crisis such as drugs, alcohol or other illness, or a combination." Most nonfilers he has met are male, he added, and "have an astounding capacity for denial, taking refuge in self-deluding excuses": " 'The Government owes me money,' or 'I didn't have the money to pay,' or 'I'm getting my records together.' "
Often they miss one year, he said, promising themselves to make it up in the future, but "one year leads inexorably into another and then to a third." By then, fearful of the I.R.S. and a jail sentence, they are too overwhelmed to file.
Julian Block, a tax lawyer and author in Larchmont, N.Y., who answers tax questions on the Prodigy home computer service, said he had received many inquiries this season from people who have been laid off and received unemployment insurance with no withholding. They are now low on cash, but owe taxes. Should they just delay filing until they have the wherewithal, instead of calling attention to themselves by filing without paying?
"There's a perception that if it's not debtor's prison, it's the gulag," Mr. Block said. "They are not aware that they can work out payment arrangements."
Sol J. Upbin, partner in charge of the New York tax practice for Arthur Andersen & Company, notes that the I.R.S. is constantly improving its document-matching procedures, identifying income recipients by the W-2 forms that employers must file and the 1099 forms that financial institutions and other payers must file.
"If you have been a consistent filer in the past, it is very certain you'll be picked up for not filing," he said. "At a minimum," he advises, "file your return and eliminate one set of penalties."
Penalties for not filing can reach 25 percent of the tax owed, as can penalties for nonpayment of taxes, although when both are assessed one partly offsets the other. The penalties are in addition to taxes and interest due. Willful failure to file is a misdemeanor punishable by a maximum fine of $25,000 and one year in prison, or both, plus the costs of prosecution, Mr. Nath noted, and willful failure to pay any tax is similarly punishable. In serious cases the Government can press felony charges of attempted evasion, which carries a maximum fine of $100,000, a five-year prison term, or both.
"Despite these penalties, when the I.R.S. catches a nonfiler, compliance is usually the most it seeks," said Mr. Nath, a shareholder in Odin, Feldman & Pittleman, a law firm in Fairfax, Va. But the agency's means of assuring compliance can be severe. He said the I.R.S. could prepare a return for the taxpayer "making all the assumptions against you," such as listing the taxpayer as single with no itemized deductions. The agency can then attach wages, bank accounts or other assets to get the tax, he said. It assessed taxes of $2.5 billion on 1.7 million nonfilers in 1988.
"When you array all your sources of credit, I would rank the I.R.S. last in terms of being responsive," Mr. Upbin said. If it is necessary to stretch out payments, he continued, "I would much rather work with a bank, regardless of the bank's rate." But it is necessary to negotiate frankly.
Taxpayers without alternative sources of credit should file Form 1127, applying for an extension of time to pay, by April 15, along with the return or a Form 4868 for a four-month extension.
"There are payment arrangements worked out all the time -- the best excuse in the world for not paying is being laid off," Mr. Nath said. "The I.R.S. as creditor wants as much as they can get. They will work with you to get it over time."
What's more, when there is reasonable cause, the service can waive the late filing and late payment penalties, he noted, and "in a surprising number of cases, there really does exist reasonable cause," like an illness, he said. People with a history of failing to file should consult a lawyer.
In one of Mr. Nath's cases the I.R.S. waived penalties for an alcoholic who had joined A.A. and quit drinking, in another for a young man who was supporting terminally ill parents and in another for a worker with a stressful, physically difficult job.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Industrial Metals Decline; Unemployment Rise Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Futures prices for silver and other industrial metals sank yesterday as a disheartening unemployment report shot down expectations for a rapid economic recovery.
Silver futures settled 10.7 cents to 12.7 cents lower on the New York Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in May at $3.95 a troy ounce and the spot price at $3.935 a troy ounce. 
 Among other industrial metals, April copper deliveries fell 1.1 cents,to $1.079 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange, April platinum deliveries fell $2.10, to $399.90 a troy ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and June palladium dropped $2.10, to $92.35 a troy ounce, on the New York Merc.
 
 Gold Moves Higher
 Gold, which is considered almost exclusively an investment metal, edged up on the Commodity Exchange, settling 30 cents to 40 cents higher, with April at $359.80 a troy ounce.
The drop in industrial metals marked a sharp turnaround for silver, which had risen more than 6 percent during the four trading sessions ending Wednesday on expectations that the recession was nearly over.
But hopes for a recovery were dimmed by the Government's monthly unemployment report, which showed the nation's jobless rate at 6.8 percent in March, up from 6.5 percent and the highest level in more than four years.
"That really kind of stalled any idea the economy is turning around," said James Steel, metals analyst with Refco Inc. in New York.
Analysts said silver's rally had been largely speculative and did not include significant buying by industrial users.
 
Cotton Futures Rise

"In a case like that, something has to happen on the fundamental side to prop up the rally," said Randolph Donney, director of commodities research with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. But there was nothing, he added, "to recommend buying it."
Cotton futures rose sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange. Heavy rains have delayed cotton planting in California and may require growers to replant cotton in Arizona and coastal Texas.
"In California, they should have started planting by the end of March," said Ernest Simon, cotton specialist with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
Cotton settled 0.60 cent to 1.85 cents higher, with May at 85.34 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures prices ended mostly higher after a choppy session on the Chicago Board of Trade, supporting theories among some traders that a seasonal upswing was under way.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Rose to 6.8% in March, Highest Since 1986

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Reflecting an increasingly grim labor market, the Government reported today that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in March, to 6.8 percent, the highest rate since late 1986.
With the ranks of the jobless swelling by another 414,000, there are 2.1 million more people looking for work now than there were last June. The total number of unemployed is nearly 8.6 million. 
 The figures released today, which provided the first broad view of the economy in March, were somewhat worse than expected and increased the pressure on the Federal Reserve for another round of interest-rate cuts to help pull the nation out of recession.
 
No Relief From the Negatives
 The report was almost unrelievedly negative. Besides fewer jobs and higher unemployment, it showed more discouraged and involuntarily part-time workers, longer spells without work and a shorter workweek.
Nonetheless, economists were divided as to whether expectations of a prompt economic recovery had been significantly set back. Stock prices sagged in reaction to the report, after the Federal Reserve did not act on the news to reduce interest rates, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,896.78, down 27.72 for the day. Prices of Treasury securities swung wildly and settled somewhat higher.
 
Data's Value as a Predictor
 Except for the length of the average workweek, which declined moderately last month, employment statistics are not considered predictors of business conditions. In fact, those that do not move in tandem with the economy tend to lag behind it, so that the unemployment rate, for example, may well continue to rise even after the economy has begun to expand again.
But while unemployment has often tended to keep rising after the economy starts to expand again -- people may resume looking for jobs before companies are confident enough in the recovery to hire them -- the jobless rate sometimes falls promptly. "We've had both kinds of experience," said Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
This time, in fact, prospects for a quick improvement in the jobless rate could be relatively good, because growth in the labor force has slowed substantially, largely for demographic reasons. Over the last year, for example, the labor force has expanded by 650,000, barely one-third of the average growth rate of 1.8 million during the last decade.
At the same time, however, this lack of labor force growth has helped keep the jobless rate from rising as high as it otherwise would have. The jobless rate now is four percentage points below the 10.8 percent peak reached during the 1981-82 recession, the worst since the 1930's.
 
 Confidence at White House
 At the White House, Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, stuck to his recovery forecast today even as it became increasingly likely that the economy's contraction in the first quarter of the year was greater than the 1.6 percent rate of contraction in the final quarter of 1990.
"We're going to see mixed signals for the next few months," Mr. Boskin said in an interview. But, he added, "The economy is likely to rebound by the middle of the year if the Fed makes sure to sustain growth in money and credit."
He cited currently favorable preconditions for recovery: relatively low oil prices, an expanding money supply, falling interest rates, lean inventories and resurgent consumer confidence.
But Geoffrey H. Moore, director of Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research, concluded that the recovery would probably be postponed.
 
 Outlook for the Recession
 "The recession is still with us -- and looks like it will be for several more months," he stated in publishing the index that the Columbia center designed to forecast the labor market. The index, which is derived from official figures, including the report issued on Thursday of another weekly jump in initial claims for state unemployment insurance, fell in March to a nine-year low.
Similarly, Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said that he found "no sign of an economic rebound" in the figures released today but that the report was probably not weak enough to compel the divided Federal Reserve policy makers to take quick action to cut rates. Two important inflation reports are to be released next Thursday and Friday.
The number of payroll jobs -- probably the best single indication in the report of the economy's present condition -- slumped another 206,000 in March, with job losses concentrated in manufacturing, construction and retail and wholesale trade.
 
 Revised February Figures
 This was in the upper range of expectations, but the fall was magnified by the fact that the February decline was revised to 291,000, from the 184,000 that was initially reported. Payroll employment for January, however, was revised to show moderate improvement.
"The large back-to-back declines in February and March suggest that no abatement has yet occurred in the rate of job loss," Dr. Norwood said at a news conference.
Factories shed jobs at a somewhat slower rate than in February -- 92,000 compared with 149,000 -- but this was partly offset by a 12-minute decline in the length of the average factory workweek.
The survey by the department of payrolls also showed that its index of aggregate weekly hours of production workers fell to 121.3. The drop of eight-tenths of a point more than offset an advance of three-tenths of a point in Februrary.
The jobs data, published by the Labor Department, are based on surveys conducted during the calendar and payroll weeks that include the 12th of each month.
The department's survey of households, from which the official jobless rates are calculated, showed a 164,000 decline in civilian jobs, combined with a 250,000 increase in the labor force, raised the jobless level to a total of 8,572,000.
The three-tenths of a percentage point increase in the jobless rate was the second straight rise of this size. At 6.8 percent, the rise now stands 1.5 points above the rate at which employment peaked last May and June.
Jobless rates continued their upward march for all of the main population groups last month, with the rate for adult women rising three-tenths of a point, to 5.7 percent, and the rate for adult men rising two-tenths, to 6.5 percent.
The following developments were also noted in the report:
*The jobless rate for teen-agers jumped 1.6 points, to 18.7 percent, with the rate for black teen-agers rising a similar amount, to 38.6 percent.
*The average time out of work increased to 13 weeks last month, while the median duration rose to 6.6 weeks.
*The number of part-time workers who would have liked to have worked full time climbed by 100,000 in March after a 500,000-plus surge in February.
*The department's quarterly tabulation of discouraged workers -- those who say they want jobs but have given up looking for them because they think the search would be fruitless -- rose to 997,000, from 941,000, about half as large as the increase in the fourth quarter.
Geographically, all 11 biggest industrial states had increases in their unemployment rates last month. The biggest jumps were 1.1 percentage points in Texas, to 6.6 percent, and nine-tenths of a point in Michigan and Illinois, to 10.7 percent and 6.8 percent, respectively.
 
 In New York and New Jersey
 The rates for New York and New Jersey both climbed to 6.8 percent, up about half a point and of marginal statistical significance. But the unemployment rates in New York State, New York City and New Jersey all rose to what were apparently the highest levels since the mid-1980's; no separate rate was measured for New York City in 1988 and 1989.
In New York State, unemployment was up from 6.2 percent in February and 6.6 percent in January. The rate was 5 percent a year earlier.
In New Jersey, unemployment rose from 6.3 percent in February. A year ago the rate was 4.7 percent.
The rate in New York City rose to 8.1 percent in March from 7.3 percent in February. The city rate was 7.9 percent in September 1990 and 6.8 percent in March 1990.
The overall national jobless rate, including domestically based military personnel, was 6.8 percent last month, the same as the civilian rate but four-tenths higher than in February.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Higher After Wild Swings

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury issues swung wildly yesterday before settling slightly higher.
At first, the fixed-income market responded enthusiastically to a Government report showing a sharp rise in unemployment last month. 
 Because negative economic news lessens inflationary pressures and tends to lower interest rates, the report that unemployment jumped three-tenths of a percentage point in March, to a four-year high of 6.8 percent, caused prices of existing Treasury bonds to rise as much as 18/32, or roughly $12.50 for each $1,000 of face value.
 
Gains Evaporate

But when the Federal Reserve did not respond to the job report by putting downward pressure on interest rates, as the market had expected, the gains began to evaporate.
Late in the session, for example, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were being offered at 96 24/32, after ranging from an intraday high of 97 2/32 to a low of 96 14/32. At 96 24/32, the long bond's yield was 8.17 percent, down from 8.18 percent the day before. A week ago, its yield was 8.24 percent.
On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $8.5 billion of new seven-year notes. The notes traded on a when-issued basis yesterday to yield 7.87 percent.
Among other representaive Treasury issues, the 7.75 percent notes of 2001 rose 2/32, to 98 15/32, to yield 7.97 percent; the 7.75's of 1996 rose 2/32, at 100 15/32, for a yield of 7.63 percent, and the 7 1/8's of 1993 rose 2/32, to 100 13/32, for a yield of 6.90 percent.
"There was a decided change of market sentiment after midday came and went and the Fed took no action," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Volume declined as many cashed in early profits and left for the weekend."
As for the relative strength of the Treasury bill market, Mr. Sullivan said it could be attributed to "the belief that sooner or later the Fed will have to ease." He added: "But the market acts more on fact than on hope. Furthermore, the supply of bills has shrunk because the Treasury has been reducing the size of its bill auctions for several weeks."
The discount rate on the 90-day bills fell six basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.70 percent; six-month bills dropped six basis points, to 5.72 percent, and the one-year bills declined three basis points, to 5.85 perent.
Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said the Fed's lack of action on interest rates meant the central bank was still preoccupied with inflation. "If so, the Fed would not favor increasing reserves in the banking system," he said.
 
Bid to Lower Expectations

"Actually, the Fed's main effort seems to be to lower inflation expectations," Mr. Sherman added. "It is the expectation or fear of inflation that causes investors to demand higher interest rates."
Despite the Fed's nonintervention, the Federal funds rate closed at 5.75 percent after trading at 6 percent most of the day. The funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, usually declines before a weekend.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 27.72 as Fed Fails to Act

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks sagged yesterday after the Federal Reserve failed to fulfill widespread Wall Street expectations that it would lower interest rates quickly to deal with the sluggish economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average -- the 30 blue chips that set the tone for the entire market -- dropped 27.72 points for the day, and 17.08 for the week, to 2,896.78. 
 Traders felt before the market opened yesterday that the combination of Thursday's report of a strong rise in new unemployment claims plus a sharp jump the March jobless rate would be enough evidence of economic weakness to prompt the Fed to cut interest rates. But when the Fed did not act after the jobless rate climbed to 6.8 percent for last month, its highest level in more than four years, stocks gave way.
 
 Drop in Turnover

Trading declined to 187.4 million shares, from 198.1 million on Thursday.
Declines led advances by 957 to 601, but in a sign that buying remained heavy in plenty of favorites, 127 stocks climbed to new highs.
One place to find them was among the stockbrokers: Salomon Inc. rose 7/8, to 30 1/8, after setting a new high of 30 3/8. Another was among the insurers: American International Group reached a high of 101 1/4 before dropping to 98 3/4, down 2 1/8.
The market's decline spread through the blue chips, the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the Nasdaq composite, the American Stock Exchange's market value index and the Russell 2,000.
Still, the smaller stocks, as represented in the Nasdaq, Amex and the Russell, held up better than the rest of the market. Several of the broader indexes, including the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq, reached all-time highs earlier this week.
"I think you'll need bullish news to pull the market out of a logjam," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers. "You need a further ease in interest rates to overcome apprehension about forthcoming first-quarter earnings."
"Even though we've had token new highs in several market averages and the secondary stocks have done extremely well," he added, "you need the leadership of the blue chips to renew the upturn."
Bond dealers are understood to have told the Fed yesterday that any rate cut now would not really solve anything because investors would instantly sell long-term bonds and push interest rates back up again. They reminded the Fed that in early March, when the Fed lowered rates, investors did just that and rates rose again.
Dealers argued that the Fed probably would still lower rates soon. Some bond market participants speculated the Fed might act just before or after Thursday's producer price figures or Friday's consumer price report. The Fed gets the data maybe a day before they are released and, consequently, could move as early as Wednesday, if the numbers show that inflation is not rising.
After the release of the March unemployment data yesterday, some market analysts said that as bad as the jobless rate was, they felt that the fact that the workweek, or number of hours worked, also fell was more pertinent in underscoring the economy's weakness. The length of the average workweek is considered a predictor of business conditions.
 
CBS and McGraw-Hill Up
 CBS rose 3 3/4, to 169 1/2. Traders said that though it reported first-quarter earnings of $1.21 a share against $3.31 the year before, the results were better than expected.
McGraw-Hill, the publishing house, long thought to be a takeover target, rose 2 3/4, to 62 1/4, on speculation it might be pursued by Paramount Communications. Paramount, which fell 1 1/2, to 38 1/2, told analysts Thursday that it was looking for entertainment or publishing companies and might spend up to $5 billion for one.

HEADLINE: Brick Maker's Upturn Spurs Hope

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., April 4

 BODY:
The mood has turned upbeat this week at the headquarters here of the Glen-Gery Corporation, the nation's third-largest brick maker, as the company posted its first two-million day for brick shipments since Nov. 21.
"It's boffo!" said Philip R. Mengel, the chief executive, as figures showed shipments in the first three days of April running at 96 percent of the comparable 1990 period. They were only at 74 percent during the final third of March and at 71 percent in early March. "We're quite encouraged," he said. 
 It is still too early to tell how much of the surge in the last week or so is normal seasonal pickup and how much represents recovery from the acute recession in the construction industry. A mid-December plunge sent Glen-Gery's business to levels 30 percent below those of a year earlier.
The slump, dating from mid-1990, had forced production curtailments or temporary closings at 11 of Glen-Gery's 13 brick plants since November, at various times idling 45 percent of the hourly paid factory work force of about 1,000, and prompting severe cost-cutting measures.
The new upturn in orders, if sustained, represents good news not only for Glen-Gery, which lost money last year, but also for the economy at large. Bricks and other basic construction materials have traditionally been a reliable indicator of general business trends, one of the first sectors to lapse into recession and one of the first to recover.
Glen-Gery's recent surge seems to confirm national reports late last month of a rebound in new-home sales and construction and in permits issued for future building. But the national economy apparently has not yet benefited from the rise. Applications for unemployment insurance jumped in late March.
No single company, of course, can fully reflect conditions in Reading and surrounding Berks County, which along with much of the rest of the country has succumbed to the nation's ninth post-World War II recession.
The unemployment rate in the county soared in January to 7.3 percent from 5.5 percent in December. The reasons for the large jump in January, the latest month for which figures are available, are unclear. But state and local jobless rates often have big swings because samples are smaller than national ones.
Although manufacturing now represents only 40 percent of national output, goods producers like Glen-Gery are still the big swing factor in business cycles, accounting for about 80 percent of changes in the gross national product, according to Lehrman, Bell, Mueller, Cannon Inc., an economic consulting firm in Virginia.
Brick is generally a high-bulk, low-value item, which limits shipping distances. But Glen-Gery executives have a rather large window through which to view the economic landscape. The company has thirteen plants -- seven in Pennsylvania, two in Ohio and one each in New Jersey, Virginia, Missouri and Iowa -- that send bricks throughout the Northeast, Midwest and near South.
Two of the plants are here in Berks County, one next to headquarters, the other the huge Shoemakersville plant 12 miles north of Reading. With an annual capacity of just over 90 million molded bricks a year, the Shoemakersville plant is one of the nation's largest. Six plants also make either concrete blocks or pipe.
About two-thirds of the company's bricks are used in residences, with the rest used in commercial, government and other buildings. Glen-Gery supplied the brick for the Worldwide Plaza skyscraper in Manhattan and the Trump Castle in Atlantic City. Last week it won the contract for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
While brick makers have developed a staggering variety of colors and shapes to differentiate their wares, brick is relatively easy to make -- ground-up shale is mixed with water, put into molds, dried and finally baked in a kiln for about 24 hours. That means orders can be filled quickly, either from production or inventory that can be stored on-site as long as necessary. "Glen-Gery brick, a hundred to a million quick," was once the company slogan.
Whether or not the current business surge is sustained through the spring's "prime time," as Mr. Mengel calls it, the company's responses to many months of depressed conditions have had a considerable, lingering impact.
Poor results prompted a sweeping management reorganization that has chopped the corporate staff by 15 percent and contributed to the ouster of Mr. Mengel's predecessor. Mr. Mengel, who helped shape the company while a mergers and acquisitions consultant in New York, was installed by Glen-Gery's British parent, Ibstock Johnsen P.L.C., last July. Over all, Glen-Gery has shed 23 percent of its salaried staff in the last year, leaving just under 400.
 
A Temporary Shutdown
 In late November, with demand withering, the company temporarily closed its Reading plant, laying off 60 hourly employees for two months. The plant was reopened on Feb. 1.
The company also shut one of the two kilns at its cavernous Shoemakersville plant, halving production between mid-November and March and idling 42 workers.
Both kilns are now operating again. And even though they are operating at only 70 percent of capacity, the imposing on-site stockpile has crept above 31 million bricks, a four-month supply at sales rates that prevailed until recently.
Standing amid huge stacks of 505-brick cubes, Ronald L. Smeal, the plant's manager, talked of the hard times. "The whole plant operation has been tightened up," he said. "If you can get along without it, you just don't buy it."
Another economy has been to juggle personnel, making sure crews are big enough to handle the available work in regular shifts, and thereby avoiding overtime pay. This, in turn, has cramped the spending of a work force still trying to pay off debts that mounted during winter layoffs.
Plant closings and permanent layoffs have also helped Glen-Gery pare costs, at the expense of the economy. It closed a plant in Ottumwa, Iowa, and cut 115 management positions.
Other cost-cutting measures made since last summer include switching long-distance telephone carriers at an annual savings of about $70,000 and renegotiating contracts with rental-car companies and with companies that supply chemical additives, stretch wrap and steel strapping.
"I was amazed to find out how much you can save," Mr. Mengel said, adding that pay increases had virtually disappeared and that first-class air travel had been banned as the company's break-even rate dropped by about 10 percentage points, to 70 percent of capacity.
Yet Glen-Gery finds it can do little to spur demand for its products. And without that, it cannot return to profitability, since bricks accounted for about 75 percent of its 1990 revenue of about $150 million.
And even with the reductions it has made, its fixed costs remain high. "We have reduced the break-even level substantially,' Mr. Mengel said. "But there's a lot of operating leverage in this business, a lot of fixed costs in those kilns."
For the moment, executives are hoping further cuts will be unnecessary. But if the current pickup fades, Mr. Mengel said, another round of closings and production cuts may be inevitable, a prospect he calls painful to think about.
"We are gaining optimism and we are gaining market share," Mr. Mengel said. "Nevertheless, we are directly linked to construction. And we expect that for demographic and other reasons, recovery will be slow and gradual."

HEADLINE: Boston Harbor Cleanup Haunts a New Governor

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 5

 BODY:
As the Republican Presidential candidate in 1988, George Bush used the pollution of Boston Harbor as one of his main campaign themes to defeat his Democratic rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
But now a Federal district judge has placed the new Republican Governor, William F. Weld, on the political hot seat because of his tardiness in the harbor cleanup. The judge, A. David Mazzone, has barred virtually all new sewer hookups in the Boston metropolitan area until Mr. Weld decides on a site for a landfill as part of an effort to clean up the harbor. The ban, imposed earlier this week, covers new costruction and renovations in existing buildings. 
 And Judge Mazzone refused today to grant a request by the Governor that the ban be delayed for 120 days to allow him to seek an alternative to a landfill site previously selected by the Dukakis Administration and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.
Last fall, in his campaign for governor, Mr. Weld pledged not to put the landfill in Walpole, the area that state and Federal officials had selected after a three-year search. His promise was seen at the time as an effort to win votes in Walpole.
 
Governor Plans to Appeal
 "There is nothing within the Governor's plan or the Commonwealth's plan that is going to help the situation," said Judge Mazzone, who was appointed to the Federal bench by President Jimmy Carter in 1978.
A spokesman for Mr. Weld said the Governor would appeal the judge's ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston. The spokesman said Mr. Weld had heard reports that some families were in a serious predicament after moving out of their apartments only to find they could not occupy new apartments because of the ban on sewer hookups.
The judge's order could have a serious effect on the economy of Massachusetts, which is already in a deep recession, and especially on Boston's metropolitan area, which has more than two million people.
Commenting on the decision not to delay the ban, John H. Spurr Jr., president of the Building Owners and Managers Association of Boston, said: "The real estate market is in tough enough shape as it is. Now what they are saying is that you cannot move."
 
43 Communities Are Affected
 Mr. Spurr estimated that 30 million square feet of space in industrial and commercial buildings in the 43 cities and towns affected by the ban cannot be occupied.
The 43 communities make up the area served by the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, a state agency created by Mr. Dukakis after state and Federal courts ordered him to clean up Boston Harbor. The $6 billion cleanup project has been beset by disputes from the start.
Judge Mazzone's order forces Governor Weld to choose between keeping his campaign pledge to the 20,000 people who live in Walpole, 20 miles southwest of Boston, and the economic health of eastern Massachusetts.
"He's trapped himself," Richard P. Kotelly, deputy director of water management at the Boston office of the E.P.A., said of the new Governor. There is no reason for the state not to transfer the land to the water authority "other than a political one," Mr. Kotelly added. "It's just the same not-in-my-backyard syndrome."
He said the landfill site in Walpole, on an overgrown pasture wedged between two state prisons, would not be environmentally harmful. If the cleanup of Boston Harbor goes according to plan, only three or four truckloads of branches and other debris will be dumped in the landfill each day.
Walpole is concerned that large quantities of sludge will also be brought to the landfill. But the water authority is building a $70 million plant to process the sludge into fertilizer. The Walpole site is intended to be a backup if the new plant breaks down.

The Economy
 The unemployment rate climbed to 6.8 percent in March, the highest since late 1986. The rise of 0.3 percentage point swelled the ranks of the jobless by another 414,000, to 8.6 million, and there are 2.1 million more people looking for work now than there were in June. The figures were somewhat worse than expected and increased the pressure on the Federal Reserve to begin another round of interest-rate cuts to help pull the nation out of recession. [Page 1.] 
 Consumer credit declined at a 3.7 percent annual rate in February, the first time in four years that installment debt has decreased for three straight months. [28.]
The mood has turned upbeat at the headquarters of Glen-Gery, the nation's third-largest brick maker, and that could mean good news for the economy. Bricks and other construction materials have been a reliable indicator of general business trends. [27.]

 Markets

Prices of long-term Treasury issues swung wildly before settling slightly higher. Large gains began to evaporate when the Fed did not put downward pressure on interest rates. [30.]
Futures prices for silver and other industrial metals sank as hopes faded for a rapid economic recovery. [36.] The dollar rose sharply against European currencies in choppy trading. [36.]

HEADLINE: At Grand Central, a Stop and a Start

 BODY:
In the pursuit of efficiency, Amtrak, the nation's long-distance passenger rail system, will begin tomorrow to run all its long-distance trains headed north of Poughkeepsie through Pennsylvania Station instead of starting them at Grand Central Terminal. That may or may not make good economic sense; what it does mean is that after the Albany-bound Rip Van Winkle leaves Grand Central tonight, the magnificent Beaux Arts landmark that once called itself the gateway to a continent will become just another commuter station.
That's sad news, in the sense that it marks the end of a glorious era of long-distance passenger traffic originating and ending in Grand Central -- an era of big-name trains like the 20th Century Limited and the Lake Shore Limited, of red caps and movie stars. But that era has been disappearing for some time, and besides, there's offsetting good news: Grand Central itself is getting a facelift. Its waiting room is being refurbished, and now at night it is bathed in spectacular light furnished by 135 lamps mounted on four nearby buildings and positioned to enhance the terminal's celestial elegance. 
 That's small consolation, of course, for passengers arriving from the north and west who will now be decanted at Pennsylvania Station -- many years removed from the glory days of the Broadway Limited and the Spirit of St. Louis and badly needing a facelift of its own.
But it's wonderful news for the thousands of commuters who use Grand Central Terminal. The Grand Central Partnership, which raised $3 million in private contributions to light up the old building, is to be commended for making the end of an era in rail travel the beginning of what could be a bright new chapter for the station itself.
