HEADLINE: The Council's Flawed Budget

 BODY:
To the surprise of its many critics, the New York City Council has proposed a plausible budget, a flawed but serious plan to close the enormous deficit. That may not sound like much, but for the city's legislature it represents a leap from a do-nothing past toward the responsible exercise of power under the new City Charter.
The Council would close most of the anticipated $3 billion deficit with service cuts and higher taxes, work force reductions, productivity savings and ways to streamline government. Some of the ideas for consolidating services and agencies make sense, like merging economic development offices. Other ideas are questionable, particularly reliance on $350 million in one-shot revenues from selling city-owned land and refinancing bonds. 
 Using one-time revenues is seldom a good idea because even after those revenues have been spent, the programs and services they paid for still require financing. The City Council says its proposed long-term service cuts would eliminate that need; it also proposes to contribute half of the one-time revenues to the general reserve fund.
Both proposals make the one-shot tactic more palatable, but it is still inadvisable. There is no guarantee that the long-term cuts will be made, and it is dubious whether the city could sell certain pieces of land for as much as the Council predicts.
The Council's plan, which Mayor David Dinkins derided yesterday, diverges most from his own on the matter of taxation. It wants to slash his proposed real estate tax increase from $755 million to $300 million. The Mayor's increase may be too high in a recession. To raise real estate taxes dramatically now could make the city less attractive to the middle class and to businesses. But the Council goes too far in protecting real estate, no doubt driven by parochial loyalties to constituents who are small-home owners.
Despite weaknesses, the Council plan is intelligent and substantive enough to serve as a useful alternative to the Mayor's proposal. That in itself is an accomplishment for a legislature just beginning to learn how to use its new responsibilities.

HEADLINE: Eastern Europe Is Out of Print

BYLINE: By Peter B. Kaufman; Peter B. Kaufman heads Pubwatch, a nonprofit organization that coordinates Western assistance to publishers in Eastern Europe.

 BODY:
More than a year after revolutions toppled Communism in Eastern and Central Europe, book publishing in the region remains in chains.
Forty years of totalitarian control combined with the rapidly changing economic landscape threaten the industry's future. The publishing houses that used to be supported by the state are collapsing, the heroic underground publishers are uncertain how to make money above ground, and state-owned booksellers, unable to become competitive, are closing in droves. 
 In the 1950's, Poland, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria tried to quash independent publishing. Book production equipment and paper mills were placed under state control. The state's monopoly on literary agencies, distribution networks, postal systems and import-export companies controlled the flow of printed information; nationalized finances made every publishing house dependent upon the state.
Today, old typesetting and printing equipment cannot meet new consumer demands. Worse, distribution networks and booksellers are paralyzed by millions of unsalable books. Laws regarding copyright, royalties and private profits have not yet been normalized.
Government subsidies for publishing houses in such fields as education, medicine and law have been slashed. In Czechoslovakia, the two state pedagogical publishing houses cannot afford to set type and print new textbooks in history and economics to replace the old ones that were filled with lies.
Moreover, economic and currency reforms meant to usher in market economies are bankrupting many publishers and booksellers. In Czechoslovakia, interest rates, foreign exchange rates and import duties have all risen. The price of paper and printing will soon go up by 100 to 200 percent, as will basic service costs.
Regional publishers admit that they do not know how to restructure their businesses. Last winter, at a conference in Prague on American publishing, more than 300 Czech and Slovak publishers, booksellers, literary agents and writers inundated the speakers with basic questions. "How are royalties paid?" "What should happen to books that are not sold?" "What is the importance of the Frankfurt Book Fair?"
The abolition of censorship, the goal of so many Western human rights activists, may mean little because of the barriers that face publishing in Eastern Europe.
But the West can change that. Western philanthropies, publishers, booksellers and government agencies should work together to help book trades in these countries weather the next two to three years. Western book publishers should supply free or discount copies to Eastern Europe's private distribution networks and retail stores. They should donate copyrights. They should share their business expertise. Publishing reference books, periodicals and catalogues are also needed.
Western companies should provide more publishing and computer equipment. In Romania, a publishing house that wants to release "The Federalist Papers" continues to produce its manuscripts on 40-year-old manual typewriters.
It is vital that Western support now be coordinated and focused on the entire publishing system -- from acquisition and production through distribution and bookselling -- in each country. In 1989, the pen won its main battle against the sword, but the war rages on.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Drops 3.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Consumer credit declined at a 3.7 percent annual rate in February, the first time in four years that installment debt has decreased for three straight months, the Government said today.
Analysts said the report was not surprising, considering the employment cuts and falling incomes accompanying the recession. 
 "It is consistent with retail sales being weak, with the decline in the employment numbers and personal incoes," said John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit dropped a seasonally adjusted $2.3 billion. It was the second consecutive month that installment debt decreased at a 3.7 percent rate. These decreases followed a six-tenths of 1 percent decline in December, the first drop since a two-tenths of 1 percent dip in February 1989.
The January plunge had been the steepest since a 5 percent decline in February 1987. And, the Fed said, the three-month drop was the first since installment debt fell from December 1986 through February 1987.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It is tracked closely because it helps finance much consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
There have been signs since the end of the Persian Gulf war that consumer confidence and willingness to spend might be picking up. Retail sales rose for the first time since October and both new and existing home sales were up.
Still, Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, expects consumer credit to be weak for months to come.
"I don't see consumers going back to buying big-ticket items until the recovery is well established," he said.
All major categories of consumer credit declined in February except for credit card debt, or revolving credit, which increased $1.38 billion, the equivalent of 7.5 percent a year. Revolving credit grew at a 6.8 percent pace in January after a 8.3 percent drop the previous month.
Auto loans fell at a sharp 13.1 percent rate, or $3.10 billion, after a 7.3 percent decline in January. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate fell a second straight month, down at a 1.9 percent rate, or $339 million. Still, the decline was not nearly as steep as the 14.7 percent plunge a month earlier.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on April 6 titled "Consumer Borrowing," about changes in outstanding consumer credit, misstated the annual rate of change for two months. It was down 3.5 percent in January and down 0.3 in February, according to the most recent revision. The error was disclosed last month when revised Government figures were issued, Because other discrepancies between Government figures and those in The Times's data bases were suspected, this correction was delayed so that the data could be reviewed. The latest version of the chart, with corrected data for the two affected months, appears today on page 36.

HEADLINE: John G. Tower, 65, Longtime Senator From Texas

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
In his 24 years in the United States Senate, John G. Tower, the first Republican Senator from Texas since Reconstruction, became one of the most influential and knowledgeable lawmakers on military and national security issues. But when he left Washington in 1989, he departed in virtual humiliation, as the Senate rejected a nominee of a new President for the first time.
Mr. Tower's repudiation by his former colleagues, who rejected him as President Bush's nominee for Secretary of Defense after public allegations of womanizing and heavy drinking, left a bitterness that could not be assuaged. In the normally clubby Senate, Mr. Tower was regarded by some colleagues as a gut fighter who did not suffer fools gladly, and some lawmakers indicated that they were only too pleased to rebuke him. 
 To have the institution that he had served turn on him was "deeply wounding," the 65-year-old Texan said in an interview last year. It was "something that stays with you and will stay with you for the rest of your life."
 
Four Terms in the Senate
 A dapper, diminutive figure who served four terms in the Senate, Mr. Tower was chairman of the Armed Services Committee when he retired in 1984. In the 1970's and early 80's he was a leading advocate of modernizing and expanding the military, and served as a central player in Congress in President Ronald Reagan's efforts to build up the nation's military arsenal.
But the job he craved for years, Secretary of Defense, was unattainable. And the rejection by his former colleagues shadowed the last two years of his life.
After his defeat he compared Capitol Hill unfavorably with Beirut. "They're pretty straightforward wha they do in Beirut," Mr. Tower said. "They hurl a grenade at someone or shoot a machine gun. Up here, it's a little more subtle, but just as ruthless, just as brutal. They kill you in a different way."
This year, in a book he wrote called "Consequences: A Personal and Political Memoir" that was published by Little, Brown & Company, Mr. Tower raged against his former colleagues. Senator John Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, is "not the brightest guy in Washington," Mr. Tower wrote, while Senator Jim Exon, a Democrat from Nebraska, "drinks, and drinks heavily." Senator Ernest F. Hollings is "the Senate bully, quick to attack with harsh and personal invective," Mr. Tower said of the South Carolina Democrat.
Mr. Tower reserved his most acid comments for Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who succeeded him as chairman of the Armed Services Committee and whose announcement against Mr. Tower's nomination was widely credited with sealing its defeat. Mr. Tower said the Senator suffered from blind ambition, timidity, inexperience and priggishness.
Only last month, shortly after the end of the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Tower sounded a melancholy note. He spoke of his long involvement with national security and foreign policy issues. "It's a little frustrating not to be involved," he told The Washington Post. "I think I could have made a very good job of it."
Mr. Tower's bitterness over his defeat was not assuaged by his access to Mr. Bush, with whom he occasionally lunched in private and who sought to ease the pain of defeat by naming him chairman of the Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, where he served until his death today in a commuter plane crash near Brunswick, Ga.
 
Son of a Minister
 John Goodwin Tower was born in Houston on Sept. 29, 1925, the son of a Methodist minister. He joined the Navy in World War II at the age of 17 and served for three years in the Pacific on a landing craft. After the war he graduated from Southwestern University in Georgetown, Tex., and earned a master's degree in political science from Southern Methodist University in Dallas before studying for a year at the London School of Economics.
Mr. Tower taught political science at Midwestern University in Wichita Falls, Tex., served as a Sunday school teacher and worked as an insurance salesman and a radio announcer.
He became a Republican in 1948 and ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the Texas Legislature in 1954. Texas Republicans chose him for a sacrificial run against Senator Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960, and he won 41 percent of the votes. The next year, when Mr. Johnson gave up his Senate seat to become Vice President under John F. Kennedy, Mr. Tower defeated William A. Blakeley, a conservative Democrat who had been appointed to replace Johnson.
 
An Unabashed Conservative
 Mr. Tower was an unabashed conservative from the moment he entered national politics. He was the first Senator to announce support for Barry Goldwater's 1964 Presidential campaign. In 1968, Mr. Tower helped to hold the Texas delegation for Richard M. Nixon, and he did not support Mr. Reagan until 1980. In 1988, Mr. Tower helped carry Texas for George Bush.
Mr. Tower sought the job of Secretary of Defense in 1981, but Mr. Reagan named Caspar W. Weinberger. After leaving the Senate in 1985, Mr. Tower served 14 months as the strategic arms negotiator in Geneva. Returning to Washington, he tried again for the Pentagon post in 1987 after Mr. Weinberger retired.
President Reagan turned to Mr. Tower at two critical junctures, as chairman of a panel that investigated the Iran-contra scandals and in lobbying Congress for ratification of a treaty with the Soviet Union banning medium-range nuclear weapons.
Mr. Tower also set up up his consulting company, John Tower & Associates, in Dallas. The company was consultant to some of the nation's largest weapons manufacturers, including LTV, Martin Marietta, Rockwell and Tetron. Mr. Tower did no lobbying, but had called a Congressional aide and former associate, James F. McGovern, who was Under Secretary of the Air Force, to check the progress of a contract for a client.
 
Bitter Divorce in 1987
 Twice divorced, Mr. Tower was the subject of rumors about womanizing, raised by his second wife, Lilla Burt Cummings, in a bitter divorce in 1987, and about excessive drinking. Mr. Tower denied his former wife's allegations. Associates said he was a moderate drinker but not a problem drinker. But Mr. Tower was close to his first wife, Lou Bullington, and dedicated his book to her.
It was these allegations that probably cost him the Pentagon post, but Mr. Tower also was criticized as being too close to the military industry.
In retrospect, he felt that he had been the victim of a virtual political mugging by his former colleagues. In an interview with The New York Times last year, Mr. Tower said: "Have I ever drunk to excess? Yes. Am I alcohol-dependent? No. Have I always been a good boy? Of course not. But I've never done anything disqualifying. That's the point."
He is survived by two daughters, Penny Tower Cook and Jeane Tower Cox, both of Dallas. A third daughter, Marian, was killed with him in the plane crash today.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John G. Tower in March 1989, with his daughters, from the left, Penny Tower Cooke, Marian, who was killed with him in the plane crash yesterday, and Jeane Tower Cox. (Marty Katz)

HEADLINE: The Sandinista Decade

BYLINE: By Linda Robinson; Linda Robinson is the Latin America correspondent for U.S. News & World Report.

 BODY:

BLOOD OF BROTHERS
Life and War in Nicaragua.
By Stephen Kinzer.
Illustrated. 450 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95. 
 If the decisive United States military action in the Middle East marks the end of America's "Vietnam syndrome," no conflict better illustrates that syndrome than the decade-long controversy over Nicaragua's Sandinista revolution. The American public readily believed that Saddam Hussein threatened United States interests, but during the 1980's it was deeply divided over the Reagan Administration's effort to force Nicaragua's Marxist Government from power through the limited means of funding the contras.
Even now that the Sandinistas are out of power, ousted in elections last year, no consensus exists on what danger they actually posed or what the United States should have done about them. No American reporter is better qualified than Stephen Kinzer, the author of "Blood Brothers," to conduct a post-mortem on United States policy and Sandinista rule. He opened The New York Times's bureau in Managua in 1983 after covering the 1979 Sandinista revolution for The Boston Globe, and stayed until 1989.
Mr. Kinzer, who now heads The Times's bureau in Bonn, believes that American policy makers wildly exaggerated the danger posed by the Sandinistas and failed to understand that they represented a genuine desire for change in Nicaragua. "Here," he writes, "was the living result of a foreign policy process in which factual assessments by professionals in the field had been systematically ignored, while lurid rumors were accepted as gospel."
The author's firsthand experience of the contra war convinced him that its main effect was to inflict suffering on civilians and harden Sandinista rule. For instance, in July 1987 he went to investigate what the contras claimed was a major military victory in the northern town of San Jose de Bocay. He found no evidence that the army command post or airstrip had even been damaged, and saw only the corpses of nine militiamen, three children and a pregnant woman. "Another trip in search of the 'new' contras had been in vain," he concludes.
Mr. Kinzer makes vividly clear that this was not a low-intensity war, as Pentagon strategists dubbed it. Six years of covering a conflict in which 30,000 Nicaraguans died took its toll on him: "Even my sleeping hours were filled with images of dead bodies and sobbing peasants." In the best tradition of reporters' books, "Blood of Brothers" takes us inside the lives of Nicaraguans humble and powerful, without the rhetoric that so often confounded efforts to understand what was really going on in that tiny country.
Mr. Kinzer was the first journalist to stumble on a contra camp in Honduras, and he defied the Sandinista authorities to travel to Nicaragua's remote Rio Coco region, where he witnessed the emotional homecoming of Miskito Indians displaced by the war. Most intriguing is his account of the power struggles among the top Sandinista comandantes, notably President Daniel Ortega Saavedra's outmaneuvering of his chief rival, the Interior Minister, Tomas Borge. Although the Sandinistas did send arms to their revolutionary brethren in neighboring El Salvador, Mr. Kinzer reports, they were far more occupied by internal conflict, which was fueled but not created by the United States.
"Blood of Brothers" is a graphic account of a country torn in half over the Sandinistas' efforts to build a new political and economic order. Early on, Mr. Kinzer saw that Sandinista policies were alienating ordinary Nicaraguans. "In 1983 most Nicaraguans had still not fallen to the depths of deprivation and despair which they would reach in later years, but many were already unhappy and restive. . . . When the Sandinistas decreed that foreign trade was to be a state monopoly, they effectively declared war on these small-scale entrepreneurs. . . . [And] by trying to transform [the existing system of food production] so completely and so suddenly, they were underestimating the deeply ingrained conservatism of Nicaraguan peasants."
While Mr. Kinzer in no way sees the Sandinistas' actions as justifying the United States intervention by proxy, he does recognize that they fed the contra resistance: "As years passed, the nature of the contra force changed. Most of its members were young Nicaraguan peasants and workers, driven by Sandinista policies to the point of rebellion."
Moreover, it was these policies that led to the Sandinistas' crushing electoral defeat in February 1990. Until the day after the elections, most Americans believed that Nicaraguans blamed the United States, not their own Government, for their misfortunes. "Blood of Brothers" raises the unanswerable question of whether the Sandinistas might have moderated their rule had the United States not sponsored a war against them. "No one will ever be able to say what the comandantes would have done with their historic opportunity in Nicaragua if they had not been confronted with civil war," the author writes.
Yet Mr. Kinzer's own critique of what he calls the regime's "colossal misjudgments" suggests that the Sandinistas' policies were not just tactical responses to outside aggression but reflections of their deep political convictions. His catalogue of their "errors" is long: their rejection of free-market economics, their militarism and arrogance, their antagonism toward the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy, the "suffocating social and political controls" they imposed, their embrace of an obsolete Communist political model and of "Fidel Castro's outlandish dream" of spreading revolution throughout the hemisphere.
Reflecting his penchant for steering clear of polemics, Mr. Kinzer balances that criticism by pointing out that the Sandinistas were willing to put their revolution to the test of the ballot box, and kept that bargain when to their great surprise they lost. Just as important, he notes, without the revolution the Somoza dictatorship would not have been dismantled.
"Blood of Brothers" might have ended with a more definitive judgment, but it is without doubt the best contemporary history of the Sandinista decade to appear. We finally have a welcome antidote to reams of literature about Nicaragua treating the Sandinistas and their country as nothing more than a cold war battleground.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra speaking at a rally in Managua, Nicaragua, 1989. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Alma Maters Court Their Daughters

BYLINE: BY ANNE MATTHEWS; Anne Matthews (Wisconsin '78) teaches nonfiction writing at Princeton University and writes frequently on higher education.

 BODY:
WEEKLY, MONTHLY, YEARLY, CAMPUS-GIVING PLEAS tumble into the mailboxes of America's college and university alumni, stirring memories and disturbing consciences. Each glossy full-color brochure, reunion invitation, nostalgia-inducing video and perky telefund call carries a single urgent subtext: send cash. But for many female college graduates, reactions to such appeals can be complex -- and getting more so.
Donna Guthrie (Rider College '68), a children's author in Colorado Springs, Colo., doesn't give to her alma mater. "As an older baby boomer, peace and justice issues concern me far more," she explains. With her husband, a physician turned businessman, and two children, Guthrie will spend much of April hauling lumber and mixing stucco at a Habitat for Humanity site in Key Largo, Fla. "I'm 44 now, and college seems lifetimes away. I'd rather underwrite my own community needs, from Laotian refugees to the soup kitchen." 
 Rachel Golden (Bryn Mawr '57; Ph.D. Columbia '70) has donated to both her schools, but, she says, "I can't get excited about the case for higher-education support because I'm so often made to feel like a number, or a faceless target, during fund drives." Golden is an Evanston, Ill., economist and consultant to nonprofit groups. "Ask me for my ideas, my advice, my participation, as well as for my money. Make me part of an ongoing community. If the schools had smarter marketing, my pocketbook would be wide open."
Regina Montoya (Wellesley '75; Harvard Law School '79), an attorney specializing in government relations at the Dallas firm of Godwin, Carlton & Maxwell, wants to build a history of women's giving to match the centuries of male philanthropy that have shaped institutions like the Harvard Law School. "I give to both my schools," she says. "Harvard taught me my profession. Wellesley helped me grow up. So I'm aiding another generation -- but on my terms. My Harvard contributions are earmarked for minority organizations or women's causes."
What, if anything, do women owe an alma mater? Gratitude and its cousins -- sentiment, duty, the yen to see one's name on a very large field house -- have paid many bills in American higher education. Since private giving now accounts for nearly a third of some college budgets, a school's survival, especially in economic hard times, can be decided by the unpredictable dance of donor and fund-raiser.
Many campus administrations have long assumed that "donor" primarily means "male donor." No more. As alumnae move into prominence and power in business and the professions (often becoming, in the process, major giving prospects), their views on college philanthropy are creating bewilderment, even alarm, on many campuses. The reasons why women give, or refuse to give, or give sporadically, or donate to one institution attended but not another are proving far more complex than previously believed -- and far different from the giving decisions of their male counterparts.
To meet operating budgets, four-year colleges and universities normally rely on six main sources: endowment earnings; Federal and state monies; corporate grants; foundation awards; private donations, and tuitions and fees (which often cover less than 40 percent of the educational price tag). With the baby boom over, campuses face soaring costs and severe cuts in Government money, even at rich institutions like Harvard or the University of Texas.
One response to the money crunch has been to undertake fund drives for staggering amounts. The size of such campaigns is often a function of prestige as well as an essential part of the annual budget. Stanford has nearly completed its drive for $1.1 billion. Columbia is campaigning for $1.15 billion; Cornell, $1.25 billion. Harvard and Yale have goals of $2.2 billion and $1.5 billion, respectively.
Commensurate with the huge amounts to be raised is a far more sophisticated approach to fund raising. Gone are the days of souvenir mugs and T-shirts; nowadays the focus is on detail, pressure and glitz. Stanford's centennial roadshow, for example, paired faculty panels on biomedical ethics with a singing-and-dancing extravaganza requiring a technical crew of 40 to set off lasers, fireworks and an on-stage bonfire. But the campus money push is colliding with other financial facts: an inconvenient recession, the rush to make college fund raising more professional and rising numbers of money-savvy alumnae.
Although American colleges and universities have extended higher education to nearly three generations of women since World War II, they have often failed to win women's fiscal allegiance. And until the last 10 years, fund-raising assumptions at many of the schools would have been familiar to Jane Austen: male graduates make money; female graduates marry into it. Development offices still schedule major solicitations of male graduates between the 25th and 50th class reunions, when earned income presumably crests. Fiscally speaking, college fund-raisers have traditionally found women most interesting after widowhood or inheritance gave them donatable goods -- stocks and bonds, office buildings, oil wells, Van Goghs.
Only recently have college fund-raisers realized that alumnae control record wealth, particularly asset wealth. Women are living longer, inheriting more and, despite persistent salary differentials and advancement cutoffs, the so-called glass ceiling, earning more, too.
Of the 3.3 million Americans whose gross assets of $500,000 or more qualified them as "top wealth holders" in 1986 (the most recent year for which the Internal Revenue Service has such figures), 41.2 percent (up substantially from only four years before) were women. On average, the women in the group were 6 percent wealthier than the men, held slightly more corporate stock and were considerably less in debt. The women had less insurance and personal property than the men but owned more cash, real estate and bonds.
And a recent Entrepreneur magazine survey found women starting small companies at three times the rate of men; by running their own franchises, women avoid the dual hurdles of the "glass ceiling" and the "mommy track" of much of corporate America.
In philanthropy, women are, at first glance, the generous gender: 78 percent of them contribute to causes like health research, youth care, religion, international or environmental issues, as opposed to 72 percent of men. But men give more in dollar terms: 3.1 percent of their income goes to charity; of women's income, only 1.8 percent. Male giving is up; women's, flat.
Women's donations to higher education are especially lackluster. For the past decade, more women than men have earned bachelor's degrees at the nation's 3,406 colleges and universities, but female donations bunch at the bottom and top ends of the giving scale. Women give more of the $10 to $250 donations ("nominal gifts," in the language of philanthropy), while more men occupy the crucial mid-range, supplying "major gifts" of five and six figures.
At the "ultimate gift" level, women reappear, but not in force. Of the roughly 140 private donations to higher education in 1990 exceeding $1 million, about 20 gifts came from individual women and about 60 came from individual men, the rest coming from couples or families. (Couples' gifts sometimes support women's institutions, as does Camille and Bill Cosby's $20 million donation to Spelman College, a black women's school in Atlanta.)
Fears about the scope and reliability of donations from women often lay behind objections to coeducation in the late 1960's and early 70's, especially at many formerly all-male Eastern schools, among them Colgate, Dartmouth, Bowdoin, Princeton and Amherst. " 'They won't give as well as men will,' was a frequent comment," recalls Sheila Tobias, who teaches gender and politics at the University of California at San Diego and who was an administrator at Wesleyan when coeducation was introduced. "To retain a constant number of male alumni, Dartmouth enlarged enrollments by up to 25 percent." However, a Dartmouth spokesman says increased enrollment had mostly to do with maintaining full quotas for male athletic teams.
But given the relentless scramble for alumni dollars, fund-raisers are being forced to come to grips with the question of why women will or will not give to their alma mater.
"It's true, women don't give like men," observes Willard F. Enteman, former president of Bowdoin and now a philosophy professor at Rhode Island College. "Asking the right questions, in the right way, has a lot to do with it. There are two ways to raise funds -- irrational and rational. With male alums, you often go out drinking till all hours to extract some whopping donation. I found that morally dubious -- and hard on my liver. Women don't respond to rah-rah. They want facts. They want accountability. I found this attitude refreshing, but many administrators resent it."
Men who want their children to attend their old schools often donate generously to their alma maters, hoping for preference. "Women don't use money that way," Sheila Tobias says, "maybe they don't see the power-money equation clearly yet. Or don't give enough. Five-hundred-dollar donations won't help a child get in, but a $700,000 endowed chair might. Once women earn that kind of money, we will see female philanthropy redefined -- and notions of female immortality, too."
At many coed schools, women are now approaching women for donations, contravening the venerable fund-raising principle of assigning male officers to potential male and female donors. Alumnae approached by fund-raisers of their own gender often voice approval, even relief, and use words like "condescending," "perfunctory," "over formal" and "too knee-jerk rah-rah" to describe previous solicitations by male campus representatives.
The next quarter-century will see the first wave of women to benefit from 60's and 70's coeducation move through the prime giving years. After that may come an even larger group of female graduates. Last fall, for the third straight year, over a million more women than men were enrolled in American colleges, consolidating a trend begun in 1979. Development offices may not learn the implications of this shift until well into the next century, but such new demographic realities are making the campus financial planner's life increasingly uncomfortable.
 BARBARA PAUL Robinson (Bryn Mawr '62; Yale Law School '65) is the first woman partner at Debevoise & Plimpton, a prominent Manhattan law firm. She is also the firm's specialist on charitable organizations and private philanthropy.
"This is a bad time to ask anyone, male or female, for donations," she says. "Everyone's retrenching, from the $10,000 givers who are philanthropy's mainstay to the heavy hitters, constantly pursued by this country's million or so nonprofit organizations. You know who sustains college fund raising today? Alumni volunteers. Many are exhausted, overscheduled professional women, who know that without alumni-funded scholarships, colleges could easily revert to preserves for the rich. But to sit in someone's living room these days and say 'Give!' takes much determination, and extremely thorough briefing."
At large colleges and universities, research staffs now create detailed financial and biographical files on select graduates, often with elaborate codings and rankings of giving potential. The data range from rumors about their financial assets to income estimates compiled from car registrations and zip-code analyses. Public-record information, such as divorce proceedings or property assessments, may appear in such files, though some deem the use of it morally objectionable.
Alumni have begun to return the favor, scrutinizing their old institutions with increasing care. From racial tensions to dormitory crimeto quarrels over course content, campus controversy makes donations from graduates far from automatic. Old-fashioned priorities can anger many alumnae, especially when schools tout a winning football team as reason enough to send a check. "I'm not putting my money in some sports sinkhole," says one Yale Ph.D.
Millions of American women, of course, do support their schools. The most loyal are alumnae of established Catholic women's colleges, like the College of St. Catherine in St. Paul, Minn. Next come graduates of nonreligious single-sex colleges, and last are women who attended coed schools.
Donors usually cite strong social or intellectual satisfaction with their school years, a sense of obligation to history or the desire to honor a family member with a named gift, from a sculpture to an endowed teaching chair. Where male patrons often want to support showier, big-ticket causes -- athletics, especially -- women are more willing to make anonymous gifts, often for practical uses, like new wiring or the refitting of buildings to ease access for the handicapped.
 FOR EVERY ALUMNA who gives, many don't. It is the naysayer that interests Martha Taylor (Wisconsin '71; West Virginia '75). Taylor is the sole female vice president at the University of Wisconsin Foundation and a specialist in upper-end alumni giving. In the mid-1980's, in the course of doing a four-year study on alumni giving, Taylor began to suspect that the University of Wisconsin -- which ranked (and still does) first in private support among American public universities -- could raise even more money by learning why female graduates rejected standard pleas.
In her office, Taylor paces before a plate-glass wall framing a 20-mile view of university buildings, the waters of Lake Mendota and the rolling countryside near Madison, and ticks off categories of refusal.
There is the Last to Die Mentality, whereby women donate only to a husband'scollege, in his name, for projects he would have approved, firmly declining to support her own college. Taylor sighs: "These are frustrating; they truly believe being humble is ladylike. 'No male ego here,' they tell me. Yesterday I went to see a widow, saying: 'Why not scholarships for the music school? You were a music major.' But she was horrified. 'Oh, no, I couldn't. Peter would have wanted everything to go to the business school. I didn't earn the money, so I can't have a say.' This despite the fact that now it was all her property."
Many alumnae, Taylor has discovered, have not made financial decisions beyond household budgets (which she dubs the Supermarket Mentality) or local volunteerism (the Bake Sale Mentality). These women see the future as alien or threatening, and so declare themselves unable to give. Characteristic evasions are "I've got to ask my husband and my son" or "I don't think my accountant will let me."
Among older women graduates who have worked, "Look out for yourself first" is a fiercely repeated motto, especially after years of earning 67 cents to the dollar. "Money insecurity, real or perceived, prevents them from giving," Taylor says. "Women still worry about money like first-generation immigrants or Depression-era Americans, obsessed with keeping bread on the table and the kids in shoes. There's little energy left for the noblesse oblige impulse or the nostalgic sentiment behind so many big male gifts."
Taylor notes that the Bastion of Males argument is motivating a growing number of women (many with self-made fortunes) who at midlife think twice about underwriting schools that patronized or discouraged them when they were young. Many regard donations as leverage for change and influence, whether gaining a trustee seat or a female name for a new physics lab.
"Money gives such women immunity to say things universities don't want to hear," Taylor explains. " 'Why are women not being groomed for power?' is a very tough question now, right up there with 'Why are there no women on your board?' " Statistics confirm those resentments: males now account for 89 percent of presidents and chancellors, 88 percent of full professors, 80 percent of trustees, between 75 and 90 percent of chief academic officers and 80 percent of upper-level fund-raisers.
These days, when schools bid for important gifts, a frequent reaction from alumni wives is what Taylor calls "But you'd better ask me, too" -- an attitude strongest among women who share a two-career marriage. Few in this group find it amusing to be ignored as prospects for major donations while their husbands are separately wooed.
For the Nurturing Mentality, other causes -- from the performing arts to children's services -- seem more compelling than supporting an alma mater. Nurturers are decisive, even stubborn, about their priorities. Frequent responses are: "The university is rich"; "It's taxpayer-supported"; "It doesn't need me."
The New Career Mentality, which Taylor finds prevalent among ambitious women under 40, has this argument: "It's my money and I deserve to keep it." Women in this category share the suspicion that college philanthropy remains at heart a boys-only game. And donations often rub hard on 70's and 80's graduates, who are grimly paying off $100,000 student loans. ("Give my school more money? Don't make me laugh" is a frequent retort.)
Taylor sees women's giving as both a complex marketing problem and a neglected research issue. "Coed schools have never made a concerted effort to encourage female donors; the system just doesn't work that way," she says. "I was surprised to find how very differently women and men think about college giving. Men often give to preserve. Women use their money for change, hoping to make things easier on those coming up, and often give to their children's colleges rather than their own for just that reason. Mostly, women crave the balanced life -- and are exhausting themselves in the process."
 CAUGHT BETWEEN Rising anger and rising costs, higher education's fund-raisers have begun to consider new ways to appeal to alienated alumnae. But fund-raisers hoping to study patterns in female (or minority) giving, then tailor appeals to female (or black or Asian) graduates, often fear accusations of discrimination. If a female or minority trustee requests such information or action, the way is clear. Otherwise, many development officers hesitate even to propose fund-raising ideas based on gender, especially on campuses already torn by harsh debates over what, how and why they teach, and for whom. Some schools are investigating new avenues for support -- through women's honor societies, as at Dartmouth, or female professional groups, as at Cornell. But methods of encouraging women's donations often remain tentative and experimental.
At the University of Wisconsin, major female donors and trustees, intrigued by Martha Taylor's findings, have established a women's council to seek gifts of $10,000 and up from women. Some projects featured by the council are of special interest to women, from a cooperative children's book center to the recruitment of female engineering students. And council members and other alumnae have begun serious networking, often giving old social formulas a vigorous philanthropic spin.
Trying to interest women donors means invoking powerful sexual politics, since anger, duty, nostalgia and realism work in unpredictable ways. Some female fund-raisers dub the impulse by women to give for women "the Carol Gilligan factor," in wry homage to the Harvard psychologist's notion that women and men often judge the world in separate styles. Others see women's giving as a way to channel growing fiscal power toward traditionally "female fields," the liberal arts, education and social studies. A few hope to change male-dominated disciplines, pointing to donors like Clare Boothe Luce, who had not shown a particular interest in science but who left $70 million in her will to establish professorships and grants for women in science and engineering.
There are those who call such single-sex approaches self-ghettoization. "I approach donors as donors, not as male or female," says Donna E. Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison and former president of Hunter College. "A woman owes an alma mater no more and no less than a man: to make sure that others have the chance to attend in their turn."
 WOMEN GIVING EVEN modest gifts often attend financial seminars or planning courses, such as the Ms. Foundation's annual conference on women managing wealth. Impatient with requests for donations that imply "Just trust us," many female donors argue for fuller disclosure of campus needs. Joan Hopf (Smith '43), who used to be an active alumna, observes: "Our schools should tell us precisely what's needed and how they're spending the cash -- this much to buy books for needy foreign students, that sum to endow a dorm. Then we can decide what to do. We're all reasonably bright."
This shopping-list approach is beginning to dominate college philanthropy. Although administrators much prefer checks for general funds, donors, male and female, increasingly prefer targeted-giving appeals or restricted-use bequests.
How a woman supports her school frequently reflects her vision of American higher education. Some see it as, at heart, a business. ("I attended a financial corporation with educational subsidiaries" is a joke often heard when female graduates talk about the large universities they attended.) Others view the campus as a microcosm of reality, inequities and all; still others, as a fragile model of what the world could be.
"Are women satisfied with their educations?" asks Janet Holmgren McKay, Princeton's vice provost. "Academically, yes; socially, not very." At 42, she is one of the highest female administrators at Princeton, tending a $400 million university budget. A linguistics Ph.D. from Princeton and former assistant to the chancellor of the University of Maryland at College Park, McKay will, in July, become president of Mills College in Oakland, Calif.
Standing by a deep-silled window in her 18th-century Nassau Hall office on a recent weekday, McKay looks down at the elm-edged campus green. Students pause to chat between classes, book bags in hand. Men stand mostly with men; women, with women. The peak donation years for all lie just ahead, commencing in 2016.
"Women's giving combines those two great mysteries, sex and power," McKay says quietly. "We're about to find out if women will use their fiscal and political clout to hold schools accountable, on many levels. Money not only talks in higher education, it also confers the right to question, to stipulate and to withhold, as well as to support."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 26; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1053 words

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
Is There Life After Marley and Juice Ads?

BYLINE: By MILO MILES; Milo Miles reviews world-beat music for "Fresh Air" on National Public Radio.

 BODY:
Once the quintessential outsiders' sound, reggae now appears to be safe in America's pop firmament. Its off-center beat has high name recognition among casual music fans and pervades commercials for fruit juice and tropical vacations. But reggae has a vitality problem: its revered past and sluggish present threaten to stifle its future.
Despite the outstanding, previously unreleased live performances on Bob Marley and the Wailers' recent "Talking Blues," the album points up the threat from the past. Marley's ghost seems to be the only reggae figure the mainstream considers worthy of attention. For the most part, current trends from Jamaica do not offer fierce competition. The popular dance-hall style, with its nimble electronic shimmy and groove-seeking arrangements, is potentially the reggae equivalent of hip-hop but in practice much more reactionary. Even with the resourceful producer Winston (Niney) Holness stretching beats, an anthology of contemporary reggae like "Turbo Charge" (Heartbeat CD HB 85; all three formats) settles for the same honorable, if shopworn, party pleasures as an old "Shindig" collection. 
 Likewise, solo performers are having trouble generating more than intermittent flickers. In 1989, the singer Foxy Brown burst in with a sinewy remake of Tracy Chapman's "Fast Car." But Ms. Brown's new "My Kind of Girl" (RAS RASCD 3070; all three formats) slides into servile love plaints, sparked briefly by a vigorous rhythm-and-blues oldie, "Piece of My Heart." Hers is exactly the sort of derivative, loose-ended album that plagued reggae before the music began to hammer out a vehement identity in the late 60's and early 70's.
Spurred by racial activists in the United States and the rising respectability of Rastafarians in Jamaica, reggae became the soundtrack for the most articulate and persistent center of black pride and pan-Africanism outside America. And this truculence has fired much of the enduring reggae for the past 20 years.
In the middle of reggae's confusion, the most acute vocal trio in the music soldiers on: Culture, led by Joseph Hill, with harmonies by Albert Walker and Roy Dayes that envelop his sandy tenor like a cozy cloak. Along with Winston (Burning Spear) Rodney, Mr. Hill, who launched Culture with the thunderous Two Sevens Clash in 1977, is the supreme exponent of "conscious" reggae -- music out to comfort and redeem the downtrodden.
Culture's only competition in reggae vocal drama is Toots Hibbert, now without his backup Maytals and recording infrequently. Both Mr. Hibbert and Mr. Hill are transformed gospel testifiers. But while Mr. Hibbert in his 70's heyday was a brash loverman-preacher in the mold of Otis Redding and Solomon Burke, Mr. Hill goes farther back for his church services. His passionate wails against despair and injustice have the power of a backwoods sermon. Oddly, the one overtly religious number on the new "Culture in Culture" (Heartbeat CD HB 67; all three formats) is the most perfunctory. Only the bemused rejection of gambling in "Five to One Strip Me" breaks new subject matter.
 The sly defiance of "Capture Rasta" rides on an undulant chorus with the inevitability of rolling hills. Long, languid horn lines in "Old Tattoo" convey the majestic rhythm progression long bumped aside by the clatter of dance hall. But the focus is always Mr. Hill, with his abrupt but well-timed shouts, gurgles and chuckles, and his insistent warnings and exhortations from the shadows of the mix. When he seems to peer through the barrier between rich and wretched souls and declares "too much different temperature here," you want to hear more. When he announces lightly that his faith in "Peace and Love" has nothing to fear from M-16's, you believe him.
The most provocative and quick-witted new reggae performer in several years has also evolved away from the spotlight, in England. Macka-B (Christopher McFarland) is a rapper -- or toaster, as they are known in Jamaica -- whose back catalogue of four records (available on all three formats) has been released in the United States by the Washington-based RAS Records.
 At least as verbally inventive as the celebrated Shabba Ranks and more touched by melody, Macka-B could soon equal acknowledged toastmasters like Big Youth, if his future material matches the high points of "Looks Are Deceiving" (RAS ARICD 038), "We've Had Enough!" (RAS ARICD 032), "Buppie Culture" (RAS ARICD 048) and "Natural Suntan" (RAS ARICD 058). His 1987 debut, "We've Had Enough!," is undernourished in both songwriting and sound. The rugged bass player Preacher and silky multi-instrumentalist Steel were not yet on hand, and the producer Mad Professor grows adventurous after their contributions are added. The accompaniment is spare, with slowly convoluting rhythms and just enough electronic chirps and synthesizd horns for a contemporary feel.
 Macka-B has unexceptional obsessions for a Rastaman: black pride, apartheid and Nelson Mandela and the ugly persistence of racism and classism. The difference is that his irrepressible personality consumes his causes and dilemmas, and makes them frightening, hilarious and vibrant. For a tribute to "Blackman," Macka-B appropriates the theme from "Batman."
This kind of disarming irreverence makes Macka-B the most tender-hearted militant imaginable, and he's by no means limited to standard activist themes. Occasionally he takes on peculiar calamities that even he can't do much with (salmonella-contaminated eggs, for example). More often, the unpredictable feints of wit and anger give his rhetoric a corrosive bite. On "Don't Beat Her," he asks how an abusive husband can claim to care more about his wife than the TV set, which he would never slap around.
Macka-B most sounds like an upstanding citizen of a newly ordered world when he turns to spirited morality in "Get Conscious" and "Badder Than Jah," both appeals of a religious man free of sanctimony. But his mortal spirit finally carries the day in the autobiographical tracks "Unemployment Blues" and "Drink Too Much." In a way, the songs are simple cautionary tales from a sensitive eccentric figuring out what work suits him and how to handle himself at Christmas parties. But at bottom, they are introductions to reggae's ruling boon companion.

HEADLINE: RECORD NOTES;
Small Labels, Eternal Hope

BYLINE: By GERALD GOLD

 BODY:
And still they come: new classical labels crowding into an already overcrowded field, each convinced it has something special to offer. The explosion of new labels in the compact-disk era has added welcome spice to a field increasingly dominated by huge companies.
The Cala label, which bows in May, comes to the fray after making its mark with a six-CD series commissioned for the mail-order catalogues of American Express and Neiman-Marcus. The series, as Cala put it, was designed to appeal to a "well educated but for the most part musically untrained public," and the recording of Holst's "Planets" with the London Symphony was a best-seller in Britain. Cala's artistic director is Geoffrey Simon, a 43-year-old Australian-born conductor who lives in England. Mr. Simon regularly conducts several London-based orchestras. 
 Cala's first release as an independently financed label, sold in stores as well as by mail order, will be two disks of music by Debussy with Mr. Simon conducting the Philharmonia. It will be available in May.
Cala's brave new manifesto talks of using top-flight artists, reinterpreting the standard repertory and exploring little-known works. In addition, the label says it hopes to fill an educational role, in the sense that the original mail-order disks appealed to general audiences. But Cala also hopes to win over specialists as well.
 The Debussy disks, which mix familar and unfamiliar works and arrangements, will be followed by releases featuring Ravel, Brahms compositions and Respighi.
A more traditional entry in the small new label sweepstakes is Cedille. It is basically a one-person operation, the person being James Ginsburg, a 25-year-old law student in Chicago.
Like many small labels, Cedille sticks to soloists for economic reasons. Two disks are by the pianist Dmitry Paperno, a Soviet emigre who is a professor at De Paul University in Chicago. Mr. Paperno has lived in the United States since 1977 and performs in the Chicago area and abroad. He is featured on two disks -- one of Russian piano music (CDR 90000 001), the other, works of Bach, Beethoven, Schubert and Brahms (CDR 90000 002).
Another pianist recorded by Cedille, Easley Blackwood, who is also noted as a composer, plays works by Alfredo Casella and Karol Szymanowski (CDR 90000 003).
The only other disk in the Cedille catalogue is a harpsichord recital by David Schrader playing the music of Padre Antonio Soler (CDR 90000 004).
 
Advance Notice
 In this age of electronics, careers are often made first by records. An example of one such career is that of the Soviet pianist Alexei Lubimov, who will make his North American debut at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, performing Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21, K. 467, with the Classical Band conducted by Andrew Parrott.
Mr. Lubimov comes to the United States preceded by a reputation built largely on the first two disks of a continuing cycle of Mozart's piano works, for the Erato label. Reviewing the disk containing Mozart's last four sonatas (Erato 2292-45510-2), Will Crutchfield, in The Times, praised Mr. Lubimov's ability to see "the Chopinesque side of Mozart . . . an example of the benefits of the 'early music' movement as it spreads and becomes more diverse."
 
Getting There First
 In May, Erato will release the first recordings of Daniel Barenboim conducting the Chicago Symphony in his new post as music director. (Mr. Barenboim and the Chicago have a five-year contract with the label.) The first releases will feature John Corigliano's new First Symphony and Richard Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel" and "Ein Heldenleben."

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
A Bedazzled Critic Finds Oz, in Paris

BYLINE: By John Rockwell

 BODY:
A recent trip to Europe brought visions of cultural grandeur and impoverishment. Unfortunately, the impoverishment was not so much in the eastern parts of Germany, where cultural pride remains high despite severe economic woes, but looking back cross the ocean, in the United States.
We may be the mightiest nation on earth. We may have the most enviable popular culture, and through the hard work of a few artists and their champions we may still produce new work in the traditional arts that commands international attention -- John Adams's "Death of Kling hoffer," for instance, which just had its premiere in Brussels. But we can't seem to afford basic cultural amenities, and that's galling when one is faced with the riches of Europe. 
 Riches first: The largesse the Germans lavish on their theaters and museums and concert halls is legendary, and even with the strains brought about by a perhaps too sudden effort to swallow the former East Germany whole, the largesse continues. The eastern Germans worry, with reason, that theaters may be closed, artistic personnel laid off and new productions postponed, at least until the nation's cultural budgets sort themselves out.
Still, the basic vigor of German culture is beyond question. Even the British, slashing lustily at arts budgets after years of Thatcherism, seem about to restore music education as a basic part of the curriculum for young children.
But what struck me on this trip was the splendors of Paris. Under the presidencies of Georges Pompidou and Francois Mitterrand, stretching back now more than 20 years, Paris has been enjoying what will surely be reckoned by future historians as a cultural golden age. With the Musee d'Orsay and I. M. Pei's perky pyramids in the Cour Napoleon of the Louvre, Beaubourg and Pierre Boulez's Ircam and the Bastille Opera, new film centers and the spiffy refurbishment of the Theatre des Champs-Elysees, Radio France's championing of every century of French music and the exquisite early-music movement led by William Christie, glowing monuments downtown and shining theatrical marvels in workers' suburbs led by brilliant directorial innovators like Patrice Chereau -- France is, for a bedazzled American straw man on holiday, an Oz-like cultural wonderland.
The country's artistic riches are not just vulgar excess, as in certain American cultural centers thrown up with much local boosterism but a lamentable lack of actual art. French cultural subvention represents a truly regal extension of the royal patronage of the Old Regime, a feeling that politicians win glory in the eyes of history for the artistic legacies they leave behind. Some politicians, like Mr. Mitterrand or Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, are artist-intellectuals themselves.
Europe's politicians, for all their pomposity and vainglory, care enough about culture to support it as a necessity of life. Ours defame the arts by paying earnest attention to laughable philistines concerned only about the publicity they may reap by attacking "obscenity."
On this same trip, I kept running into Harvey Lichtenstein and his problems. Mr. Lichtenstein, who is the president and chief producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has done noble work in bringing the best of European vanguard performing arts to New York. Yet now he is feeling the pinch -- of the recession and its impact on corporate and individual donations, and of cuts in the city, state and Federal arts budgets, which were minuscule to start with.
The latest problem was "The Black Rider," an amusingly kooky collaboration among the director Robert Wilson, the rock composer Tom Waits and the writer William S. Burroughs, produced at the Thalia Theater of Hamburg. It had been announced as a centerpiece of the New York International Festival of the Arts in June. But Mr. Lichtenstein, encountered first in Brussels and then in Hamburg and back in Brooklyn, reported that he was having trouble with the Thalia people, who, he said, kept raising the ante. The Thalia's administrative director, Ludwig von Otting, complained for his part that Mr. Lichtenstein had no money, that the Thalia had cut its fees to the bone and that the academy's Opera House was "unbelievably primitive, like some theater in Moscow."
What it all came down to was money, and the fact that Mr. Lichtenstein didn't have enough of it. He probably won't have enough to bring in Mr. Wilson's visionary production of Wagner's "Parsifal," either -- which after its current Hamburg State Opera performances will journey next winter to the Houston Grand Opera. Unless, of course, he can finagle a German grant.
Perhaps Mr. Lichtenstein is just being prudent, shedding commitments to preserve his overall operation. He still plans, he insists, on bringing in much valuable work, from "The Death of Klinghoffer" in September to, he hopes, projects by Peter Brook and Ariane Mnouchkine. He even talks about an academy-produced English-language tour of "The Black Rider." But at this point, that's pretty nebulous, and he knows it. Americans, when feeling flush, import large-scale art; by and large, we can't actually afford to create it.
Right now, Mr. Lichtenstein's academy is hurting financially, like so many other American institutions. And that means we're hurting artistically. After a renewed exposure to a European culture that gives the arts a higher priority than we seem to manage, that's a depressing realization.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURAL PLANS;
Visions Vs. Realities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Goldberger's article "Two Reasons for Dancing in the Streets of New York" [March 17] should have arranged for legions of relief dancers, generations of them, if the celebration of the March 1991 plan for the Penn Yards along the Hudson River is to commemorate anything more than what it truly is -- just another plan. Numerous designs and projects have preceded it and Trump City, its immediate predecessor; some even before the then far-advanced "Litho City" of about 50 years ago. A published history referred to the abandoned Penn Central rail yard as a "nursery for dreams."
Such long-vacillating architectural visions in New York are certainly not unusual -- they number in the hundreds and probably encompass a major portion of the city's architectural efforts. But cheering the current railroad yard proposal is unusual. Not just from the lack of any meaningful direction for its advancement, but because current movement is in the opposite direction. Instead of "relocating" the roadway, a major rebuilding of the existing structure is about to proceed, and the potential for a huge park land development is another pleasant dream when we consider that the dilemma for the future will be how to maintain existing parks.
Does anyone actually believe that the $70 million newly renovated structure will be removed and the roadway relocated this century? The coalition of community groups should be congratulated for their imaginative design, but will the design be appropriate at a time well into the future?
Other goals and needs may then be of a much higher priority for this very large railroad yard area. For instance, environmentalists, concerned about the greenhouse effect and global warming, warn about potential rising water levels at the shoreline. This might require that the development be placed on stilts. Not to worry. The planning department's Special Manhattan Landing District, covering almost as large an area and planned well over a decade ago, though likewise unrealized, was also to be partially placed on stilts.
As housing, economic and social conditions in the city continue to decline and their ills compound each other, perhaps rationality and reason will return. What if this very large, repetitiously planned area, which has nevertheless so long remained a wasteland, could meanwhile provide a good deal of badly needed housing through mobile home placement? When the long-abandoned railroad yards really reach a point in time for actual renewal, the mobile installation could be moved to some other long-established wasteland.
 
SEYMOUR B. DURST
New York City
 
 The writer is a partner in the Durst Organization, a New York real estate firm.

HEADLINE: Selective Passions

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber; Laurel Graeber is a New York writer specializing in the arts and design.

 BODY:
A LONG ISLAND couple, serious collectors of English ceramics, still have the first pieces they ever bought: two Wedgwood blue-and-white cups and saucers, purchased 30 years ago for $15. "I don't think they're worth more than $120 now," says one. "We've kept them for their sentimental value. But I think if we had to do it over again, we'd have started by being more selective."
Selectivity, always important in collecting, can have special meaning for the beginner: It may be a question of buying the most beautiful American quilt instead of the extraordinary -- and extraordinarily expensive -- piece of folk art, or the finest Victoriana as opposed to the rarest Chippendale. However the choice is made, building new collections in these leaner days calls for more time and study: visiting the most respected dealers, auction houses and museums for advice, and reading as much as possible. Also, in choosing an area of interest, perhaps the most important priority is not to become too obsessed with priorities. When means are limited, a little eclecticism and flexibility, combined with good judgment, can help the novice find something tasteful that is still within his budget. 
 "Don't be monomaniacally concentrated on something," advises Laurence N. Strenger, a longtime collector who is a partner at Ampton BCS Investments in Manhattan. "Rather than buying for the sake of buying, shift into another area. If you can't afford furniture, buy watercolors."
Most experts advise staying away from categories that are enormously popular -- and therefore expensive -- or those that have attracted an international audience. When the dollar is weak, pursuing objects coveted by foreign collectors is bound to be a losing proposition. "The best thing is to buy here, in this country, and buy things that aren't Japanese," says Herve Aaron, president of Didier Aaron, a New York business dealing in 18th- and 19th-century French, English and Continental antiques.
Setting realistic goals, however, does not mean giving up completely on a competitive area. If a new collector has found a sought-after style, period or artist that excites his passion, his first objective should be to determine whether there is an example he can afford. Although an original painting by Edward Hopper or Picasso is probably out of the question, a print or drawing by the same artist may be available at a reasonable price. And if fine 18th-century English or American furniture is beyond your means -- and if it isn't, you needn't read further -- there may be an area of the same period's decorative arts that will allow you to capture the look at lower cost.
"Everyday 18th-century tole objects can go for less than $1,000," points out Chris Jussel, owner of Vernay & Jussel, New York dealers in 18th- and 19th-century English furniture and clocks. "The same is true of textiles and costumes. And even some Old Master drawings are still available and within reach."
Another approach is to acquire pieces of a particular style that were made at a later date. This may involve investigating objects that were inspired by an earlier period, as 19th-century neo-classic was by 18th-century neo-classic, or investing in reproductions, now antiques themselves, that were made 100 years later. But keep in mind that this strategy won't assure a bargain -- Gothic Revival furniture, for example, is generally more expensive than Gothic -- and it may earn downright derision, depending on the level of purism in the field.
"Something like late Gothic Revival has a different approach and a style of its own," says Herve Aaron. "But to buy 19th-century copies of 18th-century French furniture is worth nothing -- there's no originality."
MUCH DEPENDS, however, on the priorities of the individual collector. Edward Munves Jr., president of James Robinson, Manhattan dealers in antique silver and jewelry, points out that there are many ways to admire an antique. While a reproduction cannot be valued for its originality, it can often hold its own on craftsmanship, beauty and condition. He offers as an example an egg-shaped silver jug, an 1865 reproduction made in the style of 1715. "Do we say the fellow who made the first created an original," he asks, "and all he made later, and all his colleagues made, were copies? You can carry the emphasis on originality to the nth degree. After all, you can say the 1715 egg-shaped jug isn't original, because the craftsman saw a chicken drop the thing, and all he did was put legs and a spout on it." Granted, the Victorian reproduction is worth $5,500 as opposed to about $35,000 for the original -- but that's not bad for a piece that probably brought only $100 a generation ago.
An even thornier question is whether the novice should settle for second-best. Again, he has to determine why he's really collecting. Whereas devoted scholars of the decorative arts take their collections as seriously as a museum's, others acquire merely to furnish their homes.
"If you decide that $1,200 is too much for an antique dining table in good condition, and you just want the look, you can pay half that for one whose legs have been replaced," says Karen Keane, managing director of Skinner, an auction house with offices in Boston and Bolton, Mass. "But," she cautions, "the ones in pristine condition are the only ones that will appreciate. It really depends on your motive."
If it's truly serious, some experts will advise purchasing at the absolute top level you can afford -- certainly a safe route in the midst of recession. "Buy the best even if it means eating creamed eggs for two months," asserts Letitia Roberts, senior vice president and director of Chinese export porcelain and European ceramics at Sotheby's. "The best things will always hold their own. And good things may bring even more money in hard times."
Others point out, however, that second-best doesn't have to mean second-rate. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the merely good, especially since it's usually more affordable than the great. And this may be the most enjoyable way for the beginner to gain experience.
"I think it's best to start small and build up," says William Iselin, vice president in charge of European furniture at Christie's. "You can get very discouraged if everything you look at is five times more than you can spend. And even if you have the means, you're not giving yourself a chance to learn."
Basically, any collector trying to buy affordable pieces can follow one of two routes: Look into the less important examples of an important art form or the exquisite examples of an area not yet in demand. Among the former, says Edward Munves, might be serving pieces in English silver, gold bar brooches, jewelry mounted with semiprecious stones and unmatched elements of a porcelain set. In the second category -- and often ignored -- are fine works by less recognizable artists and craftsmen. "A first-rate work by a lesser painter is better than a third-rate work by a top artist," says John L. Marion, chairman of Sotheby's and author, with Christopher Andersen, of "The Best of Everything: The Insider's Guide to Collecting -- for Every Taste and Every Budget" (Simon and Schuster, 1989). "As the first-ranked paintings get more expensive and go off the market, the law of supply and demand makes the others more important. If you've bought them, you win on two counts: quality and value."
Other areas that may appreciate in the future include well-made pieces that are not in the current taste or objects that have caught on in only one region of the country. For example, R. S. Prussia porcelain is not widely collected outside the Middle West, points out Letitia Roberts.
"The best prospects can be areas in which nobody has done much research," she adds. "In American ceramics, for instance, good pieces were made in small establishments that didn't keep a lot of records. And one way to increase the value of any collection is to do the detective work yourself in an uncharted area."
Whatever the approach, the critical criterion is quality. If an object is not top-tier, it should still be a worthy example. And if it's very good but not popular now, it's likely to become popular again. According to Roberts, "Fashion will accommodate whatever's worth accommodating." Areas some of these experts consider undervalued are 19th-century watercolors and drawings, American Empire furniture, early English oak furniture and pieces from the English Arts and Crafts movement. African and pre-Columbian art, as well as some antiquities, can be both affordable and fascinating, notes John Marion. "Antique coins are like miniature sculptures and may only cost in the hundreds of dollars," he says. And don't neglect the well-made objects of the 20th century. Already becoming collectible are items as recent as postwar architect-designed furniture and original posters from the 1960's.
"Salt and pepper shakers designed by Raymond Loewy or a Questar telescope made in the 1950's have all the qualities we prize in antiques," points out Donald Nathanson, a Philadelphia psychiatrist and lifelong collector. "Great workmanship will be passed on forever."
But even the finest piece of its kind can be a bad bet if you don't really like it. Collecting is inherently a passionate pursuit, and those who are serious invest their emotions as much as their incomes. Love for an object can be an added enhancement if its value increases, and a crucial consolation if it doesn't. As Nathanson puts it, "Anything that remains beautiful is a wonderful purchase."
