HEADLINE: Within Limits

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
ARCHITECTURE IS NOT free verse. It's more like a sonnet: It demands creativity within a highly structured framework. Designing buildings is a struggle to make art within limits, to soar without wings, to make magic without pretending that the world is supernatural. It is the ultimate exercise in accommodating to reality.
In this sense, architecture is ideally suited to respond to the facts of life in the 1990's. Now, more than ever, we seem to have not enough time, not enough room and, most of all, not enough money. Choices in architecture and design are increasingly becoming as much a matter of what to omit as what to include; the house that has everything is not going to be the house of the 90's. In this decade, less has got to be more, and not in the way Mies van der Rohe had in mind, either. 
 Of course, architecture has always been the result of a decision about priorities -- or, to put it another way, a response to constraints. They sometimes involve a building's site, sometimes the project's functional demands and, almost always, money. And they are just as likely to be a combination of the three.
What we almost never see is architecture unconstrained by any of these limits -- an instance where an architect is presented with unlimited money, time and design freedom. But isn't this the dream, the magic moment of creativity that all architects yearn for? Try again. If you look back at the architecture and design of the last couple of generations, architects who have been invited to work without limits, or given only moderate ones, have almost never yielded first-rate buildings. Indeed, the opposite is closer to the truth: Almost every time an architect has designed a house on a virtually unlimited budget, the result has been one of his or her weakest designs.
Does any student of residential architecture really think that Richard Meier did better when he created a sprawling, 11-bedroom villa in Old Westbury, L. I., in 1971, than he did several years earlier, in 1965, with his Smith House in Darien, Conn.? The Smith House, whatever its impracticalities, is a tight, crisp homage to Le Corbusier, bursting with a young architect's enthusiasm. It is elegant and fresh, a stunning composition of wood and glass. But a few years later, when success brought Meier a client with a much bigger budget, the object stretched -- but the architectural ideas did not. Indeed, the Old Westbury house is vast and more than a little bit banal, with the scale of a small institution more than a house. Everything got bigger except the architecture, which seems almost to have shrunk.
The same thing happened to Meier's longtime peer, Charles Gwathmey. In the same year that Meier designed the Smith House, Gwathmey designed a house and studio for his parents in Amagansett, L. I., that became an icon of beach-house architecture. The pair of small, spare wooden buildings is energized by tight geometries; as in the early Meier house, they convey a young architect's creative passion, brilliantly contained and controlled. There was very little money available for the Gwathmey project, but the tight budget, like the structure of a sonnet, only intensified the brilliance of what was made.
Yet, in content, the Gwathmey house and studio are really like a haiku: The architect made poetry with a minimum of material. Gwathmey and Robert Siegel, with whom he has worked for most of the years since, have gone on to design a great deal of distinguished work, but never again has there been that same sense of astonishing achievement within tight limits. Indeed, many of Gwathmey Siegel's houses, like the 1971 Cogan residence in East Hampton, L. I., or the original plans for the Gimelstob Residence, designed in 1982 for a site in New Vernon, N.J., suffer from the same problem as Meier's house in Old Westbury: They are vast, sprawling and institutional. The architects described the Gimelstob project by saying that "the design attempts to interpret 'house' through cubist transformations rather than traditional vernacular" -- which, once you get through the professional rhetoric, seems to be a way of admitting that the building would have looked like a 1960's school.
Now, it's not that Meier and Gwathmey were once young and lean, and then got fat and happy, though these houses could well lead one to such a conclusion. The point is not the progress of architectural careers so much as it is the particulars of individual jobs, and the fact that creative energies often flow best under certain kinds of pressure. Take away the limits, and you have not really let the bird fly free: Sometimes, you've only let it fly in bigger and bigger circles.
The same relationship between small budgets and brilliant houses and big budgets and much weaker work exists in many other architects' careers. Stanley Tigerman, for example, came to prominence in the mid-1970's for a series of modernist houses around Chicago that were quirky, slightly perverse, but undeniably potent as images: The Animal Crackers House, looking like the wagon on the box of cookies, and the Daisy House, with its suggestively erotic floor plan, are perhaps the best known. When the big-money clients came calling on Tigerman, however, his architecture got weaker. The design of a house in Northfield, Ill., completed in 1987, deteriorated into a glitzy parody of Palladio. The red-brick suburban villa, a sprawling house with an indoor pool decorated in trompe l'oeil, is to a traditional suburban tract house what a "pimpmobile" is to a station wagon. Perhaps there are some ideas in this melange of fantasies, but they're well hidden.
It's no more accurate, however, to dismiss Tigerman's career as a progression from lean and smart beginnings to fat and dull middle age than it would be to describe Meier's or Gwathmey's that way. Tigerman has done plenty of impressive work in recent years, not the least of which has been his own weekend residence, a witty, almost bouncy compound of barnlike buildings designed with his wife and partner, Margaret McCurry. But the success of this project only proves the point. Tigerman and McCurry had relatively little money to spend, and their economic constraints forced them to a series of creative solutions not unlike the early projects designed by all of these architects. It's the limits that gave the work its focus and definition, not the point in the architect's career in which it occurred.
This phenomenon extends beyond the architecture of houses. A few years ago, Kevin Roche, as gifted a commercial architect as any practicing today and perhaps the most celebrated designer of suburban corporate headquarters in the world, produced an overblown, high-tech version of Versailles outside Paris for Bouygues, the French construction company. It was another case of too much: too much land, too much money, too much desire to dazzle the world. And Philip Johnson's career has sometimes suffered from the same affliction. While the lavish architecture of Johnson's historicist period has often been convincing -- who could not admire skyscrapers like Transco Tower in Houston or the I.B.M. tower in Atlanta? -- it's hard not to think that a lot of the buildings Johnson and his partner, John Burgee, have designed in recent years would have been twice as good had they cost half as much.
Haiku, sonnets -- it's not a coincidence that one comes up with words like these as ideals for the decade, for they suggest limits and constraints at their most positive. The real challenge for the architecture of the 90's will be to use the limits of this time to make the right choices -- to design lean buildings that will be not overblown epics, but eloquent, simple poetry.

I., is big-budget but weaker. ( Ezra Stoller)

HEADLINE: Talking: Shortfalls;
If a Sale Fails to Pay The Loan

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE decline in home values in the last few years is forcing some sellers to accept buyers' offers that do not cover still-outstanding mortgage balances.
In the early years of a home loan, most of the borrower's monthly payments go for interest rather than principal. So when an owner has to sell at a low price, he not only may lose his down payment and the small amount of equity he has built up, but he also may wind up owing thousands of dollars to the lender. The same problem would arise in a foreclosure. 
 For example, a couple who bought a home in 1988 for $150,000 with a $120,000 mortgage might find that the house can now fetch only $110,000 and that the shortfall could leave them with almost $10,000 still due on the loan. Such problems crop up in only a small fraction of sales, but it happens often enough for bankers to have given the phenomenon a name -- "the short sale."
"There's no question we are seeing it happen more often," said Thomas Hylinski, first vice president at People's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn., an area where prices have fallen substantially.
Lenders report no hard and fast rules for handling such situations. "Deals are being worked out strictly on a case-by-case basis," said John Battaglia, vice president of residential lending at the Boston Five Cent Savings Bank in Boston.
Much will depend, lenders say, on the market in which the property is situated, the attitude of the company servicing the mortgage payments and the policy of the investors who bought the loan from the local lender and who have the final say over any deals.
Lawyers warn sellers that they are legally obligated for the full deficiency. Richard Liebman, a bankruptcy lawyer in Rockville Centre, L.I., said lenders are in a strong position to enforce this obligation because they can hold up sales of mortgaged properties until they have been paid in full. "Theoretically the debt has to be satisfied before a closing can take place," Mr. Liebman said.
In reality, however, all sorts of maneuvering takes place. In today's weaker market the lender is often eager for the home to be sold even at a lower price, especially if the owner is having trouble meeting mortgage payments.
The fear is that otherwise the owners might simply abandon the home. It then becomes extremely expensive and time-consuming for the lender to pursue all the legal steps to take back ownership through foreclosure. In the meantime, the home may deteriorate and be worth even less.
Short sales may also be more attractive to sellers than foreclosure because they can keep their credit ratings intact.
Tim Good, president of Mortgage Access Corporation of Morris Plains, N.J., said troubled sellers under pressure to move should try to work out deals whereby they agree to sell as quickly as possible for the best price they can get in exchange for some compromise on the anticipated shortfall -- either paying a lesser amount or paying the money back in installments.
Whether the lender accepts a compromise amount will depend on the strength of the local market, on how much more the lender is likely to lose if he does not compromise and the seller then refuses to sell voluntarily, and on the likelihood that the seller has the income or alternative resources to make good on the full sum eventually.
"We have done a few of these compromise deals," said Ken Herz, a spokesman for Chemical Bank in New York City. "But like everyone else we try to collect the whole thing whenever we feel we can."
What can help tip the balance toward a compromise, said Robert Engelstad, senior vice president of mortgage and lending standards for the Federal National Mortgage Association, is if a mortgage insurance company -- a company that guarantees repayment of the loan to the lender in the event of foreclosure -- is willing to help diminish the shortfall.
Any owner who took out a mortgage for more than 80 percent of a home's value may still have such a policy in place. And although the mortgage insurance company is legally obligated to pay the lender only if there is a foreclosure, a growing number are stepping in earlier voluntarily.
"WE are doing so as a way to control the extent of our own losses," said Jeanette Bernay, manager of corporate communications for General Electric Capital Mortgage Corporation of Raleigh, N.C., a mortgage insurance company.
Normally, however, the intervention occurs only when the seller has clearly exhausted all financial resources or in instances of genuine hardship "such as death, unemployment or illness," said John Hoff, vice president for claims at Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation of Milwaukee, another mortgage insurer.
The most likely option for anyone else is to arrange to pay off the deficiency over several years. "That's what's been happening with most of our short sales," said John Haggerty, director of operations for Citicorp Mortgage, one of the nation's largest residential lenders.
Typically, say bankers, the amount is spread over 5 to 10 years and interest is charged on the sum still outstanding. The Veterans Administration has started working this way, charging borrowers 4 percent and giving them up to 15 years to repay.
Consider, too, how People's, the Connecticut bank, decided to handle two recent short sales. One involved the sale of a home in Trumbull that had left the lenders with a $10,000 shortfall. The bank refused to compromise on the amount due because the husband still had a good income. Instead, it agreed that the $10,000 could be paid back over five years. An interest rate of 10 percent was charged. Payments came to $212 a month, which were tolerable, since the couple's monthly housing costs had dropped from $2,000 before they sold the house to $800 for a small rental apartment.
In the second case, the owner of a condominium in Bridgeport still owed the bank $15,000. He did not want to walk away from his debt or declare bankruptcy, but it was unlikely he could easily pay back so large an amount. So a deal was struck whereby the man's family co-signed a note for $15,000 payable over five years at $310 a month. It may appear at first like a troubling indenture. But it has enabled him to maintain good credit.
Usually a payment schedule is workable only when the amount is under $40,000 and the seller still has a good income. Otherwise bankers say the tendency is for the beleaguered owner to file for personal bankruptcy. Although this may generate future credit problems, it normally wipes out the debt entirely.

HEADLINE: 'Other Boroughs'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your article on March 10 entitled "Other Boroughs Strategy Bucks Difficult Times" you refer to several Brooklyn projects either completed or proposed that not only affect the economic well-being of the borough, but the long-term esthetic impact, too. 
 First, there is the Livingston Plaza complex, which is to become the new home of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Though not yet inhabited, the building, because of the use of gray and gray-black tile for its facade, already looks as dirty and dingy as if it had been ravaged by pollution for the last 30 to 40 years. And the copious use of those tiles, along with its high rounded corners, makes the building just another rotten piece of official architecture, very much in keeping with the dismal Landlord-Tenant Court building directly across the street.
You also refer to the proposed construction of Atlantic Center over the Long Island Rail Road station at Atlantic Avenue. According to the public plans presented at community meetings, it calls for two large office towers immediately adjacent to the Williamsburgh Savings Bank building. The singular beauty and striking esthetic of the bank would be significantly marred by two office towers alongside it. The wiser course would be to distribute the office complex to, literally, a wider base much smaller in height, rather than have these towers rise in esthetic competition to one of the finest pieces of architecture in all of New York City.
It seems that in these cases form becomes the slave of function (much to our regret), and we in the "outer" boroughs will have to suffer the outrage of Livingston Plaza for decades. But it may not be too late to save Atlantic Avenue.
 
ERNEST J. MORTUZANS
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:

Paying for Repairs
 
Question: We are senior citizens living in a rent-controlled apartment in a building converted to a cooperative under a noneviction plan. The owner of our apartment, the former building owner, refuses to pay for repairs, claiming that the co-op management should pay. Meanwhile, the superintendent says it's our responsibility. Who should pay and how does one get them to pay? . . . Herbert Stessin, Manhattan
 
Answer: Your dispute is probably with your shareholding landlord, and you have recourse to the courts and state regulators. Michael R. Finder, a Manhattan housing lawyer, said a co-op's lease usually provides that repairs within a unit, such as a leaky faucet, are the owner's responsibility and that structural repairs, such as a leaky roof, are management's.
If a written request fails to get action from your landlord, you can file a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal at its borough office, 240-6010. Mr. Finder said your other options are to sue the landlord in the housing division of City Civil Court or to withhold your rent and raise the repair issue when the landlord sues you for nonpayment. A lawyer is not required for housing court; call its borough office at 374-2212 for information.
 
Electrical Outlets
 
Question: Is the landlord required to provide grounded three-pronged electrical outlets in an older apartment building in New York City? Would the cost of converting the outlets be the tenant's responsibility? Is it lawful to use adapters on refrigerator and air-conditioner plugs to fit the older style electrical outlets? . . . J.Sussman, Manhattan
 
Answer: Landlords are not required to provide three-pronged outlets in pre-1967 buildings. That year the city's code was amended to require grounded outlets in new construction, according to Vahe Tiryakian, spokesman for New York City's Buildings Department. All post-1967 buildings should have the grounded outlets.
If a Buildings Department inspection found a code violation, Mr. Tiryakian said, the owner would be ordered to comply. Housing lawyers say the cost of compliance is the owner's, not the tenant's, responsibility.
Adapters are widely used for plugs on modern appliances in pre-1967 buildings lacking three-pronged outlets. But Mr. Tiryakian said such adapters are not approved by the city's code.
 
Late-Payment Penalties
 
Question: The landlord notified all tenants of our rent-stabilized apartment building as follows: Rent is due the first of each month. Rent received after the fifth day will be subject to a $20 late charge. If the rent is not paid within 10 days, the tenant will be served with eviction papers. Proceedings will not be discontinued unless legal fees are paid. Is this legal? . . . Herman Marak, Elmhurst, Queens
 
Answer: Maybe. The first issue is whether your lease provides for a late penalty, according to Michael B. Rosenblatt, chairman of the Enforcement Bureau's Co-operative and Condominium Committee in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. If the lease allows a penalty, the next question is whether the amount is reasonable. The $20 appears to meet that test.
As for the threatened eviction, Mr. Rosenblatt said that landlords are entitled to invoke such proceedings in cases of unpaid rent, but that imposing legal fees on the tenant is for a court, not the landlord, to decide.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
The Hartford Builds on Spec in Hometown

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FIFTY-FIVE Farmington, the first large office building to be completed in Hartford since 1989, and the last expected for another two to three years, opened two weeks ago after a troubled history.
 The general contractor went out of business midway through construction and apprehension over the economy and the city's stagnant real estate market gave the builder, the Hartford Insurance Group, some anxious moments. But the company completed the 272,000-square-foot structure at a cost of $40 million. 
 "It was discussed that we not do this building," said Kevin North, the insurance group's deputy director of real estate. "Undoubtedly it's going to be slower to lease than we projected, but we think it is poised for when the market comes back."
 The 12-story building, at the corner of Farmington Avenue and Flower Street, is the Hartford's first speculative venture in its home city, after developing more than 5.5 million square feet of office space in 20 other communities. The company will occupy 12,000 square feet and U.S. Travel Systems, a Hartford corporate-travel agency, has taken 20,000 square feet through the Farley Company, leasing agents. Rents will range from $14 to $17 a square foot for unfinished space.
 Michael Ezell, project manager for the designers, Thompson, Ventulett, Stainback & Associates of Atlanta, said the building "has a solid feeling of permanence and stability that lawyers and accounting firms like."
 Sitting on an oddly shaped lot of 1.2 acres across the street from the Hartford's headquarters, the triangular building is constructed of precast concrete, etched to simulate limestone, and green granite. The exterior focus is a rounded corner with bay windows.
 With 1.4 million of the 8.3 million square feet of office space downtown empty, Fifty-Five Farmington enters a fearsome market. Hartford's vacancy rate has risen from 6 percent in 1987, when it was the lowest in the nation, to about 17 percent downtown and 25 percent in the suburbs, according to Cushman & Wakefield Realtors.
 The central business district is pocked with craters left by demolition through the 80's, making way for ambitious new projects that never materialized for lack of funds.
 A $100 million World Trade Center lost its franchise and the new franchise was issued to Bridgeport. The planned 51-story $250 million Cutter Financial Center is believed to have been taken over by John W. Galbreath Company of Columbus, Ohio. Neither developer responded to phone calls.
 Plans for the Society for Savings' 1.2 million square feet of offices between Pratt and Asylum Streets are not expected to be resuscitated for three to five years. In the meantime, Robert A. Firger, senior vice-president of the bank, said the bank was talking to the city about creating a park or "other attractive street activity" that would not be permanent or affect its future building plans.
 The Oakleaf Development Corporation's site for a 1.2 million-square-foot building at 180 Allyn Street is under consideration as a state convention center site. "We may sell," said Daniel R. Friedman, chairman of Oakleaf, which has let 10 of its 18 employees go.
The city's Planning Department has not heard in over a year from I. D. C. Sari, a French developer, on its as yet unapproved proposal for a huge mixed-use project near the northern city limits. Calls to the developer's office in Hartford were not returned.
 "Hartford is in a horizontal mode," said Carl Traub, vice president at Cushman & Wakefield Realtors, who said a meager 26,188 square feet was leased downtown in 1990. This year, 53,000 square feet has been vacated, while 97,000 square feet has been leased downtown and 136,000 square feet in the suburbs.
 Fifty-Five Farmington was temporarily stalled last August when the E & F Construction Company of Bridgeport went out of business after real estate investments soured.
"FORTUNATELY, we had a contract stating that in the event the general contractor became insolvent we could terminate with a simple letter and take over the subcontractors ourselves," said David Holl, the Hartford Group's director of construction. "We'd never done it before. We did it without missing a beat, but I don't think we would do it again. It takes its toll."
 The two-story entrance rotunda, lined with green marble and mahogany, leads to a wide corridor flanked by banks of elevators. Straight ahead is a huge picture window through which can be seen the Capitol and Bushnell Park. "Nothing can ever be built to destroy that view," said Mr. Ezell, the project manager for the designers.
 Shops, banks, travel agencies and restaurants are sought as ground-floor tenants, with each unit having direct access to the street and the lobby. Ceiling heights are 9 feet, but the top floor has 14-foot ceilings and decorative balconies around the windows.
 The building and a park across the street have a total of 852 underground parking spaces. As a hedge against future needs, the garage under the park was built to become the basement of a future Hartford Group office building. Until that happens, the park's benches, walks and a court with sculpture commissioned by the insurance company will be open to the public.
 If the city is to emerge from the doldrums, Deputy Mayor I. Charles Matthews said, the revival of the Economic Development Commission, which disbanded in the booming early 80's, will be the catalyst. Last month the City Council reconstituted a commission of 15 members, 5 of whom must live in the city, while the rest may be suburbanites. Mr. Matthews said he hoped to have the commission seats filled by April 30.
 "We need a one-stop service which will help retain existing businesses and recruit new ones," he said, adding that the city is prepared to offer tax deferrals and abatements. Traditionally, Hartford's growth was generated from within, by expansion of the giant insurance and banking concerns that are now contracting.
 Lately, in the absence of a commission, Mr. Matthews has been meeting with the Chamber of Commerce, the Downtown Council, the Convention and Visitors Bureau and other business groups, "relaying information back and forth," he said. "They all have something to say, but not to each other."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Plans for a $100 million World Trade Center on this lot on Asylum Street have been dropped. Fifty-five Farmington, first new large office building in Hartford since 1989 and last expected for two or three years. (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Pressing to Save Jobs From Pentagon Cuts

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MOUNTING concern over the survival of some of the region's largest military installations has sparked a vigorous lobbying effort in New Jersey and on Capitol Hill.
As many as 15,000 New Jerseyans' jobs could be at stake if -- as some members of Congress fear -- Fort Monmouth, the Picatinny Arsenal and the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard appear on the cost-cutting "hit list" that the Pentagon will release by April 15. 
 Fueling those fears is an internal Army report, as well as meetings that New Jersey lawmakers have held with military officials.
"There is active concern that Fort Monmouth, Picatinny and the Philadelphia Naval Yard may go down," said Representative Robert E. Andrews, Democrat of Bellmawr, who has actively lobbied in defense of the bases. "New Jersey seems to have been disproportionately targeted."
The Pentagon's proposals would have to pass muster with President Bush and Congress before taking effect this fall.
At stake are 7,700 civilian jobs at Fort Monmouth in Red Bank and 5,200 at the Picatinny Arsenal in Dover, as well as 7,500 at the Philadelphia shipyard. About 3,000 of the shipyard workers live in New Jersey.
Mr. Andrews and his New Jersey colleagues, particularly Representatives Dean A. Gallo and Frank Pallone Jr., have begun an aggressive campaign to convince defense officials that the military installations should be spared. The measures have included letters to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, a meeting with Army Secretary Michael Stone, testimony before the House Armed Services Committee and tours of the bases.
Community groups have also sprung into action. The Save Our Fort Committee in Monmouth County and the Concerned Responsible Individuals to Save Picatinny have mounted letter-writing and petition drives.
At the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, a Joint Committee for Yard Development brought 500 workers to Washington last month for a rally in support of the shipyard.
By April 15 the Pentagon is to recommend which military installations should be closed or consolidated to meet cost-reduction targets set by the defense appropriation bill that Congress passed last autumn. In January Mr. Cheney outlined a 25 percent reduction in active-duty personnel by 1995.
That move will reduce funds for the military by about 20 percent over the next five years, said Robert M. Rauner, director of the Pentagon's Office of Economic Adjustment.
"The cold war is over," Mr. Rauner said. "We therefore have need for fewer things, because we will have fewer people -- meaning we don't need as many places to train them, house them, feed them, entertain them, medicate them."
An internal report by the Army Materiel Command, the Army's main procurement branch, cites Fort Monmouth and the Picatinny Arsenal as candidates for closing. The report, "A.M.C. Vision 2000," proposes to streamline Army command functions by consolidating several units, including Monmouth and Picatinny, into one operation in Huntsville, Ala., now the site of a smaller installation called the Redstone Arsenal.
The last time the Government initiated a round of military closings, in 1989, a New Jersey base, Fort Dix, lost its status as an Army basic-training operation. The phase-out, to be completed late next year, will result in the net loss of 800 civilian jobs and as many as 3,200 military jobs.
"Between Fort Dix and the other two bases we've discussed, that would be the end of the Army presence in the state," said Mr. Pallone, Democrat of Long Branch. "And I think that would be totally unfair."
New Jersey members of Congress and their constituents argue that the base closings proposed so far will not even save money. The Army Materiel Command report estimates that consolidating command units into one operation in Alabama will cost $2 billion initially and will not start saving money until 2008.
And supporters of Fort Monmouth, Picatinny and the naval shipyard argue that the military will lose valuable expertise and resources if they are moved.
"I feel that the Army can find much smarter ways to save money," said Martin Kane, chairman of the Save Picatinny Committee, a grass-roots organization representing the installation's 5,200 civilian workers.
"We all recognize that there are going to be necessary cutbacks that have to be implemented in order to cut costs," said Mr. Kane, a civilian lawyer at the Picatinny Arsenal. "But the 'Vision 2000' just doesn't make sense from a readiness standpoint, or from an economic standpoint."
Mr. Kane's committee has urged government officials of 132 municipalities in the area to write Secretary Cheney with their concerns and has invited members of Congress to visit the base. Nearly 100 lawmakers have toured Picatinny since January, spurred in part by interest in the technology that assisted in the Persian Gulf war. Picatinny researchers helped develop components of the Patriot missile and the Copperhead artillery projectile, a "smart" weapon.
The gulf war amply illustrated the strategic value of Delaware Valley installations, say supporters of the two bases and the shipyard. Fort Monmouth provided electronics equipment and served as a communications center. The shipyard sent two aircraft carriers refurbished at the yard -- the Independence and the Saratoga -- to the Persian Gulf.
 
'Importance of High Technology'
 "With Operation Desert Storm having shown the importance of high technology and battlefield communications, this is hardly the time to begin to make changes in Cecom," Mr. Pallone said, referring to the Communications-Electronics Command.
Mr. Pallone recently joined Mr. Gallo, Republican of Parsipanny, for a meeting at Fort Monmouth that drew more than 300 civilian workers.
At Picatinny, Mr. Gallo said, the staff's research and development expertise would be difficult to replace. Past attempts to relocate military bases have shown that few employees are willing to move, he said. He and other New Jersey lawmakers also stressed the state's strategic location as a mecca for universities and the advanced-technology industries.
"At a time when we are dealing with a shrinking military, I think a place like Picatinny becomes much more important," Mr. Gallo said. "Because you are looking to give those in the service the best capability in terms of new, hard-hitting weapons. And that is Picatinny's expertise."
 
County's Largest Employer
 Fort Monmouth, near Eatontown, is Monmouth County's largest employer. Picatinny is the second-largest employer in Morris County, after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Mr. Gallo said that closing Picatinny "would have a devastating effect on the economy of northern New Jersey and the region, frankly," because the impact would extend into parts of Pennsylvania and New York.
Transplanting Fort Monmouth to Alabama also would affect the entire community, said Frank Wyckoff, a spokesman for the Save Our Fort Committee and president of the Greater Eatontown Chamber of Commerce. With New Jersey in an economic slump, the region can little afford to lose close to 8,000 jobs, he said.
The ripple effect on businesses in Monmouth County and other regions, from retail stores to restaurants, could be severe, New Jersey lawmakers said. And the loss of military contracts could have dramatic consequences, they said. Picatinny awarded some $72 million in defense contracts to New Jersey companies last year. At Fort Monmouth, 1990 contracts totaled $63 million for New Jersey companies.
A 1990 study by the Pennsylvania Economy League estimated that closing the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard would cost the Delaware Valley region an estimated total of 35,000 jobs and $900 million in income.
 
Fight Led by Senators
 New Jersey members of Congress, led by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and his fellow Democratic Senator, Bill Bradley, fought to maintain Federal financing for the naval yard's Service Life Extension Program. The program allows the yard to rebuild 30-year-old aircraft carriers and extend their life for 15 to 20 years.
But the yard may well end up on the Pentagon's base closing list, said Mr. Andrews, who warned that "the signals were not good" during a recent meeting that he and other members of Congress from the region had with Susan Livingstone, Assistant Secretary of the Army.
New Jersey lawmakers are hoping for an ally in former Representative Jim Courter, a Republican from Montclair, who is chairman of President Bush's eight-member Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which will review the Pentagon list and offer its own recommendations to the President. Mr. Courter, at least, is familiar with the state's defense structure, his former colleagues said. During the last round of base closings, initiated in 1989, Mr. Courter strongly opposed cutbacks at Fort Dix.
But Mr. Courter told the Senate during his confirmation hearing in March that he and the commission would be "totally objective and nonpartisan." And Mr. Rauner, at the Pentagon's Office of Economic Adjustment, warned that with a 25 percent reduction in force, some bases would simply have to go.
 
Need for Cuts Acknowledged
 New Jersey lawmakers acknowledge that the defense budget needs paring. A freshman Representative, Dick Zimmer, Republican of Flemington, who ran on a "no new taxes" platform, said he would support the process as long as it is fair and objective and allows input from Congress.
Unlike some lawmakers, Mr. Zimmer said, he believes that forming a nonpartisan base closing commission was a good idea.
"Congress would not have had the will to close bases through the traditional process, and in fact hadn't been able to close a single one for 12 years," he said.
But many lawmakers are frustrated by the sense that New Jersey has been unfairly singled out. New Jersey already absorbed the loss of basic training at Fort Dix, they argue, and now faces more cutbacks while the South appears to gain.
Fort Dix also has been the target of lobbying efforts by New Jersey lawmakers who would like to see the fort's basic training mission restored. Mr. Lautenberg introduced legislation in February calling on the Defense Secretary and the Base Closing Commission to consider regional balance in deciding which bases should close.
 
Favoritism Is Seen
 "There clearly is favoritism to the South and the West, and some of that is Congressional politics," Mr. Andrews said, adding that the Defense Department had undoubtedly felt pressure from those regions' influential members of Congress. Economics may also play a role, speculated some New Jersey residents who cited high costs of living costs in the Northeast.
Mr. Rauner admitted that the nation's newer bases tended to be in the South and that older bases like those the Northeast tended to be more expensive to operate. But Army officials insisted that base closings and cutbacks would take place throughout the nation.
"Every post in the United States is being looked at," said the Army Secretary, Mr. Stone, in his recent meeting with New Jersey lawmakers. "New Jersey, I can assure you, has not been singled out."
Pentagon officials were also optimistic about the region's ability to recover. At the Office of Economic Adjustment, which advises communities on how to recover from base closings, Mr. Rauner said the vast majority of military towns came back even stronger than before, with more diversified economies.
But New Jersey members of Congress say they are as concerned about national defense as they are about the state's economy. And even if the region's bases appear on the April 15 closing list, New Jersey lawmakers said, they have vowed to continue lobbying.
"We really see the 15th of April as the beginning of the fight, not the end," Mr. Andrews said.

HEADLINE: Florio Plan to Sell Roads Is Criticized

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
GOV. JIM FLORIO's plan to to cut the projected $800 million state budget deficit in half by selling state highways to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority is drawing criticism from financial analysts, urban policy experts and a growing number of legislators, including some influential Democrats.
The proposal, critics say, is at best bad planning and at worst illegal because it would require the Turnpike Authority to spend bond money raised specifically for maintenance and widening of the superhighway and its feeder roads. 
 Critics also call the plan a thinly veiled tax increase that will ultimately result in even higher tolls for turnpike users and will perhaps necessitate tolls on previously free roadways. At the same time, they say, the state's credit rating will suffer as investors lose confidence in the Florio administration's ability to balance the budget without resorting to such drastic measures as mortgaging highways.
Administration officials acknowledge that the proposal is a one-time effort to help balance the state's budget deficit, rather than a long-term solution. But while the proposal may be unusual, they say, it is not illegal and is not expected to result in any new tolls. And they argue that the state's credit rating continues to be among the best in the nation and should remain strong as the result of decisions made by Mr. Florio in his first 15 months in office.
The Turnpike Authority, an organization that receives no state funds, operates and maintains the 118-mile toll road that stretches from Ridgefield Park in northern New Jersey to Pennsville in the south.
Critics predict that the authority will embrace the Governor's plan because the chairman, David Goldberg, and four of the five board members are Florio appointees. Officials of the authority have declined to comment on the proposal.
The controversy comes in the wake of increases of 70 to 100 percent in turnpike tolls that have forced commuters to dig deeper into their pockets and have sent truckers searching for alternative routes through or around New Jersey. At the same time, the proposal has provided yet another rallying point for Republican officeholders hoping to sustain voter unrest through 1992, when the entire Legislature is up for re-election.
"I think this is the dumbest scheme to hoodwink the taxpayers of the state of New Jersey that I ever heard of," said the Assembly minority leader, Garabed Haytaian, Republican of Hackettstown. "You don't close a budget gap for one year by using smoke and mirrors."
Mr. Haytaian, along with the Senate minority leader, John H. Dorsey, Republican of Boonton Township, and other Republican legislators recently held what they called a town meeting in the East Brunswick Public Library to air their views on the issue.
 In addition, some key Democratic legislators have expressed reservations with the plan.
The Senate president, John A. Lynch, Democrat of New Brunswick, said last week that he feared it was inevitable that tolls would be charged on roads taken over by the Turnpike Authority. He said the state budget should not be balanced by passing new tolls onto the public.
And in the State Assembly, George A. Spadoro, Democrat of Edison, along with several other Democratic Assembly members, recently questioned the legality of the sale. Mr. Spadoro, who is chairman of the Assembly Transportation Authorities, Telecommunications and Technology Committee, said his committee would hold hearings on the proposal this month.
 The proposal, which was first made public by Mr. Florio in his budget address in January, calls for the sale of a number of state-owned roads to the Turnpike Authority for $400 million. Officials have not yet specified which roads would be sold but expect to submit a formal proposal to the authority in the next few weeks.
A special report, written by Mr. Haytaian and Mr. Dorsey for the East Brunswick meeting, said that the highways under consideration included the full length of Interstate 295 and a stretch of Interstate 95 between the turnpike's northern terminus in Ridgefield Park and the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee.
Also being considered, the report said, are roads that are still on the drawing board, including Route 92 between Routes 1 and 130 in central New Jersey, and proposed access ramps from the turnpike to Liberty State Park in Jersey City.
The roads would be paid for with a portion of the $2 billion the Turnpike Authority raised in 1985 through the sale of bonds. All the money was originally earmarked for widening and improvement programs on the turnpike.
Since 1985, however, only $700 million has been spent, with $900 million held in reserve for continuation of that work. The remaining $400 million would be used for the purchase of the state roads.
Some financial experts, however, say the money should either be retained by the Turnpike Authority or used to retire part of the outstanding debt on the bonds.
"I don't see any fundamental economic justification for this proposal," said David O. Zenker Jr., senior vice president in the bond department of Oppenheimer & Company, a New York investment house. "From a political point of view, though, it's kind of clever."
 Mr. Zenker said money raised to improve services on the turnpike should be used specifically for that purpose. "They borrowed this money to allow for future growth of the turnpike," Mr. Zenker said. Recent toll increases, he said, reflect both increases in operating expenses and the continuing obligation to pay interest on the bonds.
If the $400 million is used as Governor Florio has proposed, Mr. Zenker said, the money would not improve turnpike services, but instead would increase the Turnpike Authority's liabilities by expanding maintenance responsibilities to the new roads.
"Transferring the cost of those roads to the Turnpike Authority is essentially a regressive tax on turnpike drivers," he said. "What you're doing is placing the burden on those who use the turnpike as opposed to spreading it across the state."
Moreover, Mr. Zenker said, changing the use of the bond proceeds could have a negative effect on the state's otherwise excellent credit rating.
 
Bond Outlook Changed
 "Using turnpike funds for transparent budget fixes jeopardizes the borrowing integrity of both the turnpike authority and the State of New Jersey," he said.
Indeed, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a credit-rating concern, while continuing the state's AAA rating, recently changed its outlook from "stable" to "negative."
"The outlook is an indication of where we think ratings are going over the next 18 to 36 months," said Arthur J. Grisi, senior vice president of Standard & Poor's municipal finance department.
The negative outlook, Mr. Grisi said, is the result of a number of factors, including the general downturn in the economy, the state's looming budget deficit and the Florio administration's proposal to sell state property to raise cash.
"Going forward with proposals like selling $400 million worth of roads is uncommon for the State of New Jersey," Mr. Grisi said. "This is clearly a shift from the conservative fiscal approach the state has had in the past."
 
Effect on Credit Rating
 Mr. Grisi said that Standard & Poor's was basing its rating and outlook on the presumption that the proposed sale is a one-time revenue item, meaning that any budgetary benefits would be short-lived.
"Indeed, the state will need to replenish the $400 million somewhere into the 1993 budget," he said.
Moreover, Mr. Grisi said, the proposal could have an impact on the Turnpike Authority's credit rating.
"We certainly need to review the current status of turnpike ratings if this $400 million proposal works the way the Governor is proposing," he said. "It certainly isn't going to impair their ability to finance, but they could come under some pressure."
State Treasurer Douglas C. Berman acknowledged that the proposal amounts to no more than a one-time infusion of revenue into the state treasury, but said that such measures must sometimes be used in difficult economic times.
"Real-world problems demand real solutions," he said.
 
Alternatives Are Welcomed
 The administration, he said, has done everything in its power to balance the budget by cutting spending to a point where there is nothing left to cut. Critics of the turnpike proposal, he said, are welcome to suggest other ways to make up the expected $800 million shortfall.
"What is the alternative?" he said. "Do they want more in layoffs? Do they want to not fund the Property Tax Relief Program this year?"
The fact that the state's credit rating has remained at AAA despite its fiscal difficulties, Mr. Berman said, is proof that the credit agencies believe that the administration is acting responsibly.
But beyond economics, critics are also questioning the legality of the administration's proposal.
"There are a number of troubling questions surrounding this issue," State Senator Dorsey said. The Turnpike Authority, he said, may be legally prohibited from taking money raised for capital improvements and using it for other purposes.
 
No Conclusion on Legality
 In a legal opinion prepared by the State Office of Legislative Services, Albert Porroni, the legislative counsel, said the legality of the proposed purchase could not be conclusively determined without knowing specifically which roads would be acquired.
Mr. Berman, however, said the administration was confident that the proposal would not violate any of the covenants contained in the bond prospectus.
"I think that people ought to wait to see how it's finally proposed to determine if it meets all of the legal and financial policy tests," Mr. Berman said. "We are confident that in the structure we are going to propose it, it will be perfectly legal."
And speculation regarding the imposition of tolls on whatever roads are ultimately sold is premature, he said. "Our expectation is that there will be no tolls."
 
A Responsibility to Help
 When asked what might motivate the Turnpike Authority to purchase non-toll roads that would cost money to maintain, Mr. Berman said the authority had a responsibility to help solve the state's fiscal difficulties.
"The turnpike is part of the state government," he said. "And helping the state out in this situation is part of an overall solution in which they will also gain a more rational road structure that makes sense."
 The Turnpike Authority recently hired a tax law firm to study the matter.
Critics, however, believe that the authority, will ultimately go along with the proposal.
"The Turnpike Authority has been captured by the Governor," said Dr. George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of city planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "The fact that the proposal makes no sense for the authority from a business perspective doesn't make any difference. It makes $400 million worth of sense to the Governor."

HEADLINE: Shifting Currents Affect Day Care in County

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
MORE parents are driving their young children to the office each morning as corporate-sponsored day-care programs proliferate in the county. At the same time, many day-care programs for the children of low-income workers are struggling as government subsidies are threatened. 
 "There are two currents in day care: one going out and one coming in," said Sally Ziegler, executive director of the Child Care Council of Westchester, an information and referral agency that also supervises home-based child-care programs in the county. "Going out is support for low-income families and coming in is corporate support. There is a whirlpool in the middle where a lot of parents are in trouble."
 
Corporate Efforts Grow
 Corporate-sponsored day care has been growing in Westchester since General Foods USA provided funds three years ago to help start the Phelps Child Care Center in North Tarrytown, an on-site day-care center for employees of the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center that was the first of its kind in the county.
General Foods has also joined the Nestle Foods Corporation, Gannett Westchester Rockland Newspapers and MONY Financial Services to renovate a wing of the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains as a child-care center for the companies' employees and the general public. The Avon Corporation has for the last year offered on-site day care for its employees in Rye.
The International Business Machines Corporation and Pepsico are jointly financing the $600,000 renovation of a newly purchased home for the Country Children's Center in Katonah, a few miles from their new corporate office buildings in Somers.
And at its South Westchester Executive Park in Yonkers, the Robert Martin Company is about to open another child-care center, the third in 18 months for the real estate-development company, which also operates centers in Hawthorne and Elmsford. In a program that is the first of its type in Westchester, the company operates the centers for use by the tenants of its corporate parks.
But the majority of working parents in Westchester have no access to corporate-sponsored day-care centers like these -- even if they could afford to use them. Weekly fees for infant care at the Robert Martin center in Elmsford, for example, are $182.
The high cost of living in Westchester, which often requires both parents to work, is responsible for the increased demand for day care, Mrs. Ziegler said. Despite the sluggish economy and the declining birthrate, the Child Care Council received 3,904 calls last year, 882 more than in 1989. Most were from parents with limited resources, and most were seeking infant day care.
 
Where Two Currents Meet
 "People have to work to live here," Mrs. Ziegler said. "If you are single and making $25,000 with three kids, in Westchester you are poor."
At the Country Children's Center, the two currents in day care come together. Forty-four preschool children attend the center, which until its new home is ready in September will continue using space in the Katonah United Methodist Church and nearby St. Luke's Episcopal Church. Most parents pay the full $130 weekly fee. But 16 families have been receiving government subsidies.
"There are not that many families in Katonah who need subsidies," said Polly C. Peace, director of the center. "But there are at least 20 percent more than we can even help."
 
Five Subsidies Eliminated
 Until the beginning of March, each of those 16 families received aid from Title XX, a Federal block-grant program that provides an array of social services to each state. Five weeks ago, the Country Children's Center was told that the income-eligibility requirements had been raised for the families. In 11 cases, the parents saw their subsidies reduced; in five cases, the state aid was eliminated altogether.
Unwilling to evict the families, the nonprofit Country Children's Center dipped into its reserve fund -- set aside to help pay the mortgage for the new property -- to provide scholarships for the five families who had lost their subsidies.
Last week, Annette Myers, the county's Assistant Commissioner of Social Services, said the county had made an error and the subsidies would be restored immediately.
Tuition was raised in January, Mrs. Peace said, and it may have to be raised again. The center is determined to provide room for families with limited resources, Mrs. Peace said, but "it makes it very expensive for other people."
 
'A Wonderful Blessing'
 "It was a wonderful blessing when we got this very large grant," Mrs. Peace said, discussing the financial contribution provided by I.B.M. and Pepsico for the center 's new site. "But ongoing, it doesn't do a thing for us. We have to pay the mortgage, and with these cuts at the government level, it's going to be difficult."
I.B.M. has provided $430,000 and Pepsico $170,000 to allow the Country Children's Center to convert a three-bedroom house into a center that will provide daytime care for 52 preschoolers, including infants. The house sits on a four-and-a-half-acre parcel that also has a pond and a barn, where the children and staff will be able to raise rabbits, incubate duck eggs and plant a garden, Mrs. Peace said.
Employees from I.B.M. and Pepsico will be given some priority for spaces, Mrs. Peace said, although details haven't been settled. The I.B.M. contribution to the center is part of a $22 million fund that the company established two years ago to to increase the availability of child-care services for its employees nationwide. The fund is the largest financial commitment made by any American corporation toward child care.
 
100 Years in Mt. Vernon
 Thirty miles south of Katonah, the Mount Vernon Daycare Center, a nonprofit operation, plans to celebrate its 100th anniversary this month. But its director is worried that this birthday may be the last.
Enrolled at the center are 100 children, 21 months to 5 years old, nearly all of whose parents receive state subsidies. Weekly care for children up to age 3 is $115, and $100 for the older children.
Government assistance to such centers is being jeopardized by state efforts to close an estimated $6.5 billion budget gap. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed that $50 million of the state's Title XX funds -- about a fourth of the total -- be shifted from discretionary uses to help pay for other, mandatory social services. Although the state is insisting that day-care services be maintained, county officials are not sure how they can comply without cutting other needed services.
"We are preparing for the worst scenario," said Linda Iglehart, director of the Mount Vernon center. Many of the parents are employed as bank tellers or home health aides, she said. "They are coming in and showing me their rents and leases and saying 'how do you expect me to pay?' "
 
A Push Toward Welfare?
 The paradox of the government cutbacks, she said, will be if the inability to pay for day care forces a parent to quit working and go on welfare.
"I'm going to help them, even if I have to go to corporate America and beg," Ms. Iglehart said. The center is now financed by parental fees, government subsidies and the United Way.
How county agencies will be able to maintain day-care programs with significantly less money is a question that perplexes the county's Social Services Commissioner, Mary E. Glass. The state, she said, "continues to mandate levels of service, and the money is simply not there."
The county is trying to get the state to clarify which day-care programs must be maintained despite expected fund reductions, the Commissioner said. But cuts must occur, she added, and so "it will be that much more difficult to assist the working poor."
 
Deeply Felt Consequences
 The consequences, she said, will be deeply felt. "These are the teachers and firemen who affect the fabric of Westchester," she said. "These are the people who make things tick."
One of them is Lisa M., a secretary at a Westchester hospital and the single parent of two preschool children. The young mother, who spoke only on the condition that her name not be published, takes home about $320 a week, of which she spends nearly half for child care.
Lisa said she has been grateful for the $30 weekly subsidy she received from Title XX, which helped her afford to send her son to the Mount Vernon Daycare Center.Last month, Lisa learned that she and 12 other parents at the center had lost their subsidies.
Last week the $30 was restored, when the county admitted it had made an error in ending the subsidy before a final agreement had been worked out with the state on what reductions would be permitted as the county responded to state budget cuts.

PUB-DATE: April 7, 1991

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1749 words

HEADLINE: St. Agnes Is Put on a Path To Self-Sufficiency

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
ST. AGNES HOSPITAL, an 85-year-old institution widely perceived to be at death's doorstep a few months ago, emerged last week from a series of consultations with a smaller staff, new medical roles and improved chances for a complete recovery.
John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, arrived here by helicopter on Monday to confirm his decision, taken against the advice, he said, of five independent financial assessments, that the 184-bed hospital remain open. 
 "This is one of the happiest days of my life, as last December was one of the saddest," Cardinal O'Connor said. On his earlier visit he had told the same gathering of doctors, nurses and staff members that the hospital would have to find a way to earn the $6 million it expected to get from the archdiocese this year or he would have to sell the institution.
 
250 Hours of Meetings
 "I didn't know which way to turn, except upward," the prelate said, recalling the 250 hours of meetings he said he had held in the four intervening months. Speaking slowly, with occasional flashes of wit and touches of emotion that had some staff members in tears, he described the difficulties he had faced before the "new affiliations" were completed.
Under the reorganization, St. Agnes will establish new links with the Westchester County Medical Center, referring tertiary, or specialized care, patients to the larger institution, which has a 95 percent occupancy rate, and getting the Medical Center's primary care cases in return.
St. Agnes will also become a teaching hospital, specializing in primary care, for New York Medical College, which is only four miles away on the county-owned Grasslands Reservation in Valhalla. The college will continue to use the Medical Center as its principal teaching hospital, providing medical students with experience in tertiary care.
 
A Bittersweet Taste
 The college, a "nonsectarian school in the Catholic tradition," as its dean, Dr. Karl Adler, describes it, will effectively take control of St. Agnes. The hospital's 17-member board is being replaced by a five-member board, three of whom are also college trustees. Both institutions are controlled by the Archdiocese of New York.
The Cardinal's visit, savored by doctors and staff members, had a bittersweet taste. His welcome message that the hospital would be given a chance to survive was coupled with a firm declaration that it would have to accomplish that goal on its own. "There will be no more archdiocesan money going into St. Agnes," he warned.
He had told the staff in his December visit that the hospital must find ways not only to earn the $6 million he estimated that it would need to break even this year, but also to show how it could repay at least part of the $9 million it owed the archdiocese and the $3 million it still owed suppliers.
"I hope that one thing has been learned," Cardinal O'Connor said to the assembled hospital employees: "That we do not have a bottomless well. The Archdiocese of New York is not a welfare state. We do not have any more money for St. Agnes, and consequently we have to do everything conceivable" to make the reorganization work.
Speaking to reporters after addressing the staff, he was even more direct, saying, "We no longer have any financial responsibility for St. Agnes under the new arrangement."
Asked how long he thought it would take for St. Agnes to become self- sustaining, Cardinal O'Connor said that Dean P. Gestal, the chairman of the new hospital board, "said he can do it in six months."
The Cardinal noted that "most of the financial estimates say if we could do it in 1992, it would be pretty fast work." Mr. Gestal, a private investor of Greenwich and a former general partner at Glickenhaus & Company, which he left in 1989, moved quickly and decisively in reducing expenditures, handing out some of the 60 to 80 termination notices planned before the day had ended.
He said he intended to reduce the staff of 600 by 10 to 12 percent. These included nurses, technicians, maintenance personnel and administrative employees -- every category except doctors, who are not considered employees.
The reorganization of St. Agnes, meanwhile, found welcome partners in the Medical Center and the college, each of which is involved in changes that complement the new affiliation.
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, introducing Cardinal O'Connor on Monday, said, "The county of Westchester, some time ago, offered to all hospitals in the region the ability to affiliate with our Medical Center, to assure that tertiary care would be available to everybody."
 
'Willing to Work With You'
 That effort has drawn some interest, but so far little enthusiasm. Edward A. Stolzenberg, the Acting County Commissioner of Hospitals, said the county had contacted the 42 hospitals of the Hudson Valley region -- Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Dutchess, Orange, Sullivan and Ulster Counties -- but that only 12, including St. Agnes, had responded.
"We said 'we're willing to work with you in planning services for your area,' services they might not have, such as handling trauma cases," he said. "We're overloaded and a lot of hospitals are nearly empty. We have to find ways to work with community hospitals to build up their services, so they can retain their patients and send us only those who need specialized care."
Mr. Stolzenberg noted that "hospitals are always nervous about other hospitals' involvement, wondering if a big teaching hospital will gobble them up."
The Medical Center's goal, he said, is to "use our space and St. Agnes's space more effectively."
"We'll be referring a lot of the primary patients who fill up our beds, and who come to us from a variety of sources -- emergency rooms, clinics, doctors -- to St. Agnes, and that will give us the room to take in the patients we really should be taking care of."
 
AIDS Center Designation
 Mr. Stolzenberg said that the County Medical Center is "an AIDS center and the only one licensed by the state as such in the Hudson Valley region that we serve." Now St. Agnes will also apply to the state to be designated an AIDS center, he said, "and will probably have a 20- to 25-bed clinic for that purpose." He said the Medical Center would take "tertiary-care AIDS patients, those requiring brain or heart surgery."
Mr. Stolzenberg said he expected that St. Agnes, working with the Medical Center "in areas of unmet community needs, would also be providing obstetrical care for Medicaid mothers, which is a crisis in Westchester because hospitals are turning poor women away."
Other areas that he said would be considered for St Agnes are pediatrics, geriatrics and drug-abuse treatment.
 
'Triage Based on Disease'
 Mr. Stolzenberg said the Medical Center was not seeking to increase its revenues by shedding primary-care patients for the more highly reimbursed medical procedures. "This is triage based on disease," he said. "We are a county facility, with 40 percent of our caseload Medicaid cases. For a hospital like ours, staffed and equipped to take care of very, very sick patients, it is not economical to treat patients who are not very sick."
The Medical Center budget for this year is $250 million, he said, "of which we raise $232 million."
The $18 million difference is made up through county taxes. "But it's been fairly steady in recent years," Mr. Stolzenberg said. "And it reflects services we provide the county, such as burn care, that a private hospital might not take on."
Dr. Adler, the dean of the medical college, said the new affiliation with St. Agnes was "timely" because "a major part of medical education throughout the country right now emphasizes primary care."
He said students would continue to get training in primary care at other hospitals, mostly in New York City, but the emphasis would now be on St. Agnes.
 
Convenient Training
 "It is much more convenient with a large class to have the hospital training nearby," Dr. Adler noted, as has been the case in tertiary care at the adjacent Medical Center, "as well as using community physicians."
Dr. Vincent Nicolais, president of the St. Agnes medical staff, said that the changes would provide an academic setting for the hospital's physicians.
"Previously, if you were a physician and wanted access to higher training or newer techniques," he said, "you would have to go to conferences. Now, affiliated with the medical college, you have the means for improvement at your fingertips."
 The reorganization follows a difficult four-month period as the hospital saw its occupancy rate dip below an already low 73 percent, in part a result of the decision by Kaiser Permanente, a health-maintenance organization with 32,000 members in Westchester, to cancel its contract with St. Agnes.
Paige Stetson, a spokeswoman for St. Agnes, said, "Kaiser represented 20 percent of our business. They said the prime reason for ending the contract was the uncertainty of St. Agnes's future."
 
Delays Hurt Reputation
 The uncertainty had been growing through the 1980's, with the hospital delaying the purchase of new equipment because of financial problems created by the cost of building a new medical services building.
The modern equipment has since been bought but the delay did not help the hospital's reputation. St. Agnes also suffered the loss through death or retirement of a dozen of the hospital's most active primary-care physicians in the 1980's. They had referred patients to the hospital's specialists, and without those referrals, the occupancy rate declined.
Only 60 to 80 of the 480 doctors on the staff admitted a majority of their patients to St. Agnes, a situation that Dr. Nicholai predicted would change dramatically now.
"We had physicians referring their patients to wherever they wanted to refer them; there was no structure," he said. "Doctors would rent office space at St. Agnes, seeing their outpatients on the grounds but referring them to White Plains Hospital or United in Port Chester or any of the other primary-care hospitals where they also had affiliations.
"With the medical college controlling St. Agnes through a new board of trustees, those doctors will now have a greater incentive to use St. Agnes for primary care or the medical center for tertiary care."
The incentive would be continuing to rent space at St. Agnes. Some doctors, anticipating the new referral patterns, have already left.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Princeton;
Senior Thesis Debated: Enrichment or Torture?

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Huddled over their computers and encirled by stacks of books in the Firestone Library, bleary-eyed Princeton University seniors are scrambling to complete within the next week or so the hallmark of their "Princeton experience": the thesis, a research paper on the order of a Ph.D. dissertation.
But if some professors and administrators have their way, this 66-year-old mandatory rite of passage will become optional, enabling both faculty members and students to put their time to better use, they say.
The subject has been debated by faculty members, especially in the larger departments, since the fall, when Sheldon M. Garon, last year's director of the senior seminar program, recommended expanding the seminar program at the expense of the thesis requirement.
 
A Trade-Off Is Suggested
 
 Lawrence Stone, an emeritus professor of English history, wrote in The Princeton Alumni Weekly on March 20 that the "only practicable way of offering more undergraduate-level seminars is to make a trade-off in which some existing forms of instruction are cut back."
"In my view," he asserted, "the prime target for such a trade-off is the compulsory senior thesis."
Richard G. Williams, associate dean of the college, said he would favor an optional senior thesis, since 10 to 30 students each year do not graduate on time because they have problems with their theses. But he expressed doubt that the thesis could be eliminated without a bitter controversy, especially considering that the university's president, Harold T. Shapiro, is among its staunchest supporters.
"The thesis can be an important experience, but on the other hand I know that for some people it defines that experience in a very painful way," Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Garon, a professor of Japanese history, said he believed the importance of the senior thesis had been greatly overemphasized. It should be a requirement only for students who wish to graduate with honors, the practice at most colleges, he said in an interview.
 
Results Called Dubious
 "The thesis demands enormous amounts of faculty and student time, and the results in many cases are not worth the effort," Mr. Garon said. He added that all too often theses did not involve primary research and failed to make an original contribution to their field.
Mr. Garon said that in his experience as departmental representative, the mandatory thesis had injured all attempts to make innovations in the curriculum, particularly at the senior level, because students were so consumed with their theses that they ignored their classes.
"I discovered, to my frustration, that very few seniors wanted to take the seminars, even though we have a highly motivated faculty," Mr. Garon said. "Probably they thought it would interfere with their theses, or worse, they wanted a degree without ever challenging themselves intellectually." The eight interdisciplinary seminars are now in their second year.
Mr. Garon, who has been informally sampling colleagues' opinions on the subject, said he believed the faculty "overwhelmingly supports" his position. But he is quick to add that it may take months, if not years, to make a change.
 
The Ultimate Challenge
 In the past, faculty members have viewed the thesis as the ultimate challenge to students to bring together the knowledge and skills they have gathered in the previous three years and make an original contribution to their field of study.
"I have always believed that the most important part of an education is to think deeply about a single issue," said President Shapiro, a professor of economics. "In that respect, the experience of the senior thesis is really an invaluable one."
Walter F. Murphy, a professor of politics for 32 years, put it more bluntly, "To give up the senior thesis would be somewhat like playing the Super Bowl and then, sometime in the fourth quarter, blowing the whistle and saying, 'Game over.' "
Gray Tuttle, a senior from Birmingham, Ala., who wrote a collection of poems as his thesis, said his senior independent work gave him an unusual opportunity to pursue his particular interests under the guidance of a thoughtful adviser.
But with classes and a job search to cope with, many other seniors find the pressure of the thesis aggravating, if not unbearable.
"It is a very valid exercise, but it would take much of the stress and strain off professors and students if it were optional," said Laura Fortner, a senior from Setauket, L.I., majoring in East Asian studies.

HEADLINE: Sunday Outing;
Chinatown: More Than Restaurants

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
Manhattan's Chinatown is for the adventurous shopper who delights in a treasure hunt and considers a babel of foreign dialects -- Shanghai-ese, Cantonese, Mandarin, Fukienese, Toisan and more -- music to the ear.
Chinatown is hustle: vendors hawking umbrellas, children's pajamas, pancakes filled with fried scallions. It is also bustle: people jostle one another in the streets and don't bother to excuse themselves in any dialect. 
 Some sights are predictable: the roasted ducks hanging in the windows, for example, or the cars double-and triple-parked for lack of spaces.
But Chinatown is mainly about flux. As new immigrants from China, Hong Kong, Vietnam and Thailand move in, each day brings change. For the shopper who prizes serendipity, the change is revealed in unfamiliar products: a porcelain fishbowl with painted carp inside, or oolong tea at more than $100 a pound.
The heart of Chinatown is Canal Street. The N, R, No. 6, J and M subway lines stop at Canal Street near Broadway. From there, walk east from Broadway toward the Bowery.
 
Delicious Finger Foods
 The sidewalks are lined with one of the area's prized resources: the vendors who sell delicious finger foods at recession prices. Fifty cents buys a plump steamed bun, three inches in diameter, filled with cabbage and ground pork; or a rolled wide rice noodle made with dried shrimp and scallions, or a scallion-filled pancake six inches across, fried to golden crispness.
"Many of the food vendors are from Wenzhu, an old seaport on the coast south of Shanghai where the people have a history of going overseas," said Peter Kwong, a professor of political science at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, L.I., and the author of "The New Chinatown" (Hill & Wang, 1987).
Armed with pushcart licenses, the vendors prepare their ingredients at home and cook them on the street. To find the best food, look for the carts with the largest crowds of eager, noisy customers.
For more substantial fare, there is Kam Man, one of the neighborhood's most popular supermarkets. In addition to addictively juicy strips of barbecued pork, soy-sauce squab and roasted duck, the two-floor market sells homemade joong, which are to the Chinese what tamales are to Mexicans. Inside the lotus-leaf wrapper is a mixture of glutinous rice, black beans, a Chinese sausage, black mushrooms and pork. There are also joss sticks, teas and dried plums. Kam Man is at 200 Canal Street, near Mulberry.
 
Tea and Ginseng
 Where there is Chinese food, there is also tea. Ocher-colored tins hold a dozen varieties of tea at Ten Ren Tea and Ginseng Company at 176 Canal Street, near Mott Street. A pound of oolong can cost $7.20 to $118.80. "The difference is bitterness and sweetness," said Alfred Liu, a salesman at the store.
Wood cabinets also hold ginseng from Korea, the United States, China and the Soviet Union. A teak table designed for serving tea has a hole through its top with a container underneath for discarding tea leaves.
To brew the tea and cook the food, there are Chinese utensils like bamboo brushes for scrubbing woks and a cleaver that, held sideways, flattens a clove of garlic in a split second. A wide assortment of utensils is at Hong Chong Imports, 14 Bowery near Doyers Street.
 
24-Karat Treasures
 A literal treasure, found more readily in Chinatown than in uptown jewelry stores, is 24-karat gold, the soft, deep-yellow gold like that buried with pharaohs, fought over by pirates, and sewn into the hems of robes when the Chinese had to flee from one place to another. A tiny horse charm sells for $90, and a rectangle with a raised Chinese character that translates to "long life" sells for $240 at May Cheong Jewelry, 175 Canal Street near Mott Street.
Two old stores in Chinatown specialize in porcelains. Quong Yuen Shing at 32 Mott Street, near Bayard Street, was founded in 1891 by Lee Lok, who came to the United States from Canton. Today, the store, which has its original wood cabinetry, still sells porcelains -- and also tickets to Yankee baseball games and other events from a Ticketmaster machine.
 Nearby, at 26 Mott Street, is Wing On Wo & Company, which first sold porcelains in 1901. Large porcelain urns painted on the outside with peonies and inside with gold-colored carp, were originally used by the Chinese as fishbowls. Nancy Seid, the store's owner, suggests a different use for the reproductions, which sell for $350 to $650. "Put glass on the top and use it as an end table," she said.
At Pearl River China Resources Products Inc., a child might find joy in a plastic pencil box ($4) with four buttons that, when pushed, open four different compartments. For an adult who wants a note of Chinese sybaritism in the bedroom, there are shocking-pink silk comforters filled with silk wadding ($230 for one 70 by 80 inches). The store is on the second and third floors at 277 Canal Street, near Broadway.
For a different glimpse of Chinatown life, look skyward. Walking along Elizabeth Street north of Canal recently, Peter Kwong noticed dozens of pairs of navy blue slacks flying like pennants on a line stretched from a rooftop to a truck parked on the street.
When clothes are finished in the Chinatown garment factories, which are often in tenements that don't have elevators, the workers string a nylon cord from the factory roof to a truck across the street. The clothes, wrapped in plastic and placed on wire hangers, are then hung on the nylon cord. A gentle push from the workers on the roof sends the clothes sailing down the cord.
Occasionally a few fall on the ground, where another worker casually picks up the garments and shakes them out. A little dirt never hurt a pair of navy blue slacks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Canisters, some holding teas costing more than $100 a pound, line shelves at Ten Ren Tea and Ginseng Company in Chinatown. The ginseng comes from the United States, Korea, China and the Soviet Union. (Photograph by Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)
 
Map: Chinatown is centered on Canal Street east of Broadway.
