HEADLINE: World Markets;
Top U.K. Index Hits Peaks, Thrice

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The leading British stock-market index reached record closing highs last week on three successive days, as the London market rode a crest of optimism about lower interest rates, falling inflation and a relatively early end to the recession.
With the new highs, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index has managed to outperform the Dow Jones industrial average, which has stumbled twice in trying to break through its all-time closing high of 2,999.75. Since the beginning of the year, the Financial Times index 100 is up 18.7 percent, and the Dow is up 10 percent. Since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the British index is up 8.8 percent, and the Dow is down about a tenth of a percent. 
 But while the blue chip stocks are lagging on Wall Street, smaller United States stocks have matched the London rally. Both the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index reached all-time highs last week.
With its performance, the London stock exchange has neared or exceeded the predictions of many European analysts for the full year. Michael Howell, the chief strategist for Salomon Brothers in London, has moved his year-end prediction of 2,750 for the Financial Times index to 3,000. UBS Phillips & Drew is leaving its year-end target at 2,500, but Mark Brown, the firm's chief British strategist, acknowledged that it might have to be raised soon. The index closed on Friday at 2,545.3.
The extra driving force that the British market seems to have over Wall Street comes from the prospect of greater cuts in interest rates. In addition, inflation in Britain is expected to decline more dramatically, with the "headline rate" -- the main inflation indicator -- projected to fall to 4 percent from its current 8.9 percent. And at least until recently, British stocks have had relatively low price-earnings ratios, and so the London market has been perceived to be a better value than many foreign stock exchanges.
In Britain, analysts seem to be regularly lowering their interest-rate estimates for the end of the year. At the end of 1990, S. G. Warburg was predicting the base rate, the key interest rate set by the Bank of England, would drop only as low as 12 percent by the end of 1991. A month ago the firm moved the prediction to 11 percent, and the estimates are now at 10 percent. The base rate itself was recently cut to 12.5 percent.
In the United States the key short-term interest rate, the Federal funds rate, is at 6 percent and is not expected to slip much further.
Most of the downward revisions in Britain have been prompted by the strong performance of the British pound in the European Monetary System. With the recent fall of the German mark, sterling has risen above the midpoint of its fixed trading range against the mark. This gives more leeway for lowering interest rates without pushing the pound through the bottom of the trading range.
But how much higher the stock market can go is an open question. George Hodgson, the chief equity strategist for Britain at S. G. Warburg in London, expects a consolidation soon but another surge in the second half of the year, when he believes data will show inflation falling and a recovery beginning. "We need decisive evidence not just that the economy is bottoming out but that it is turning up," he said, "and that is some time off."
And what can go wrong?
The decline in interest rates could be slower than is now expected. Merrill Lynch raised this warning in a recent analysis, suggesting that central banks may be willing to suffer a little more recession to squeeze out a bit more inflation. In addition, the relative attractiveness of the British market erodes as the rally persists. Mr. Brown of UBS said the overall earnings-per-share ratio is now around 13, "and the market no longer looks cheap."
In its survey of data through March 14, the Institutional Brokers Estimate System, a compilation of earnings expectations, concluded the British market was already overvalued. Since then the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index has jumped another 45 points, or 1.8 percent. The analysis also revealed considerable uncertaintyabout the outlook for earnings in the next 12 months. On balance, analysts are revising their earnings estimates downward for the next two years.
And then there is the political uncertainty. Prime Minister John Major must hold a general election by June 1992, but the timing is still in doubt. It could be as early as June of this year.
Mr. Howell of Salomon Brothers has done an analysis based on historical data that shows that the Financial Times index would be likely to fall 150 to 200 points when an election is called, or about 6 to 8 percent at current levels, if the leading parties are equal in the public opinion polls.
But he also argues that a lead by the Conservatives over Labor tends to temper the decline in the Financial Times index. If Mr. Major were to have an election this June, he figures, the market would drop 50 to 100 points because the Tories have been ahead in recent polls.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 31-April 5

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Compaq, MIPs and a Strategic Graphics Alliance 

When the Compaq Computer Corporation said last week it would form a strategic alliance with Silicon Graphics Inc., a manufacturer of computer work stations with powerful graphics capabilities, the numbers were small: only $185 million to be invested by Compaq. But at stake might be nothing less than the future of the $50 billion personal computer and work station market. A struggle is now emerging among six competing groups to set technical standards for the industry. Compaq and 20 other companies, including Digital Equipment, have formed a consortium based on a new family of microprocessors designed by MIPs Computer Systems in Sunnyvale, Calif. By choosing this standard, they are pitting themselves against International Business Machines, Intel, Motorola and other very big names. But Compaq's new alliance may give the MIPs group a technological edge. Further announcements are expected Tuesday.
 
Texans' Bid Kicks Up a Feud
 
It was pure Texas. Last year the Energy Services Company, a Dallas-based driller headed by Richard E. Rainwater, bought 58.6 percent of the Penrod Corporation. R.D Smith & Company, an investor group, owned the rest. Penrod is a drilling company once controlled by the Hunt family. Last week, Energy Services offered $8 a share to buy out its partner. But what started as negotiations turned into a feud. Energy Services, in a move most likely designed to sow dissension among the individual investors in the Smith group, offered to buy only 75 percent of their holdings. The offer "could be worth as much as double what they're offering for it," said James Rubin, an investor in the Smith group.

More Viewers, Fewer Ads
 
Even though viewership was up during the gulf war, the networks lost money. NBC said it lost $55 million on its war coverage, and last week CBS reported a $17 million loss in the first quarter of 1991. As a result, CBS will layoff 400 employees, about 4 percent of its work force. War and advertising, it appears, make strange bedfellows. "Advertisers didn't want to display their products between battle scenes," said Jib Fowles, a professor of media studies at the University of Houston, Clear Lake. But the losses to the networks are far from over. "People scan the television the way aborigines scan the horizon. They flip channels and never really watch anything. The advertisers know this and are backing away. They want more targeted media."
 
A Federal bankruptcy judge approved a $115 million offer last week from NBC's cable affiliate, Consumer News and Business Channel, for its rival, Financial News Network.
 
Dixon Draws Just Five
 
Don Dixon, the Texas real estate developer, led Vernon Savings Association, near Dallas, from obscurity into oblivion. When the regulators took control of the savings and loan in 1987, they found 96 percent of its loans past due. Losses to the association totaled $1.3 billion, which the taxpayers still must pay. Last December, Mr. Dixon was convicted of 23 counts of fraud, including defrauding regulators and illegally spending depositors' money to support his lavish life style, beach houses and companions. Mr. Dixon, who faced a sentence of 120 years and fines of $5.6 million, was sentenced last week by the United States District Court Judge A. Joe Fish to five years in prison. He could be out by 1992. He was also fined $600,000 and ordered to do 500 hours of community service. Judge Fish said that Mr. Dixon's misdeeds "were a far cry in my mind from the loss of a billion-dollar institution." He got off easy compared with Woody F. Lemons, Vernon's chairman, who received a 30-year term from a different judge a year ago.
 
Citibank: Shop, Shop, Shop
 
Citibank, the nation's largest bank, already has the world's biggest credit card operation. More than 30 million subscribers charge about $47 billion a year on their cards, adding about $1 billion a year to the bank's earnings. But once you have the customers, how do you get them to use their cards more frequently? Citibank has an answer. Buy something with a Citibank card and if you find it selling for less within 60 days, the bank will pay you the difference. With the Citibank card you do not have to shop around. There is a cap of $250 on each refund and a $1,000 cap for the year. The program boosted card use by 5 percent in tests. How much will the program cost? Experts think not much at all. With other refund programs, like extended warranties,less than 1 percent of all users ever file a claim.
 
Postwar Buyers Loyal to Honda
 
It was a terrible month for the automobile industry. For everyone except Honda, that is. Sales for the industry were down 10.6 percent for March, compared with last year. The big American makers did the worst: General Motors was down 12.3 percent, Ford was down 14.8 percent and Chrysler was off 18.3 percent. Sales of imports also declined but not by as much, and Japan's market share actually improved. The only bright spot for Detroit was Chrysler's better sales of minivans. And Honda? Its sales were up 10.2 percent for the month. "Obviously the idea that people would be buying American after the gulf war was a little off the mark," said Harvey Heinback, an automotive analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Hey Buddy, Spare a Little Loan?
 
The credit crunch is finally ending, according to the Federal Reserve last week. Only a fifth of the senior loan officers it surveyed at 58 American and 18 foreign-owned banks imposed tighter terms for business borrowers in the last six weeks. In January, a third had made it more difficult to borrow and last November, half the banks had hearts of stone. But some economists still question if there ever was a credit crunch. It all depends on how you read the data. "The decline in lending is not the disease, it's the symptom," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. And what is the disease? "A recession that varies from region to region and industry to industry." If you can't borrow in New York, try Chicago.
 
Jobs Get Scarcer Still
 
Another sign that the recovery is still more wish than reality: Unemployment jumped to 6.8 percent last month, from 6.5 percent in February. The gloomy news surprised many economists. "The numbers were about 50 percent worse than the consensus forecast," said Kermit Baker, chief economist at Chaners Economics. "It shows the path to recovery is not as smooth as some people hoped for." The service sector did better than manufacturing.
 
Gloom Lingers at the Factory . . .
 
Is the manufacturing economy starting to develop a little bounce? Not yet, if factory orders are any guide. They fell by 0.5 percent in February, according to the Commerce Department, following four straight months of even deeper declines. "The best you can say is that the sharp declines have faded out, but there's no sign of an upturn yet," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser to DRI Inc. "Indications are that the March numbers will be no better."
 
. . . And in Construction
 
Construction too remains mired in a slump. Last week, the Commerce Department announced that spending on new projects fell in February for the 11th straight month. New construction, one of the first sectors to go into recession, was down 0.1 percent following a decline of 2.8 percent in January.
 
 Where Doctors Fail to Tread
 
Not so long ago, doctors made house calls. Now many of them won't even treat the sick, at least if the sick are also poor. That is what the Physician Payment Review Commission told Congress last week. The advisory group said 44 states have trouble getting doctors to accept Medicaid patients. The reason: low fees. Medicaid, the joint Federal-state program for 27 million low-income Americans, pays physicians, on average, just 69 percent of what Medicare does. And Medicare pays less than most private insurers. Just raising Medicaid payments may not be enough to improve treatment. "Many patients come from areas where there are few if any physicians," said William B. Schwartz, a professor of medicine at Tufts University. Luring physicians to practice in these areas, mainly inner city and rural, will not be easy.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Russia Calls It Price Reform
 
For more than half a century, the Soviet government set prices -- all 25 million of them. Rents were last changed in 1928, bread prices in 1954. But last week, the government moved to close the widening gap between prices and production. It increased prices by 250 percent to 1,000 percent. "They call it price reform, but it is still a set of fixed prices. They're just fixed at higher levels," said Judy Shelton of the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif. Market systems require prices to fluctuate with changes in supply and demand. "But these prices are not established by supply and demand. They have nothing to do with free markets and they won't produce more goods." The popular response to the price rises were riots and strikes.
 
Japan: Friendly, but Changing?
 
 Japan fears being shunned by the United States . So, when the gulf war ended, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met with President Bush, and all was friendly. Japan, the Administration said, made progress on trade, and its surplus with the United States is down to a mere $41 billion last year. But is that progess? Yes and no. American exports to Japan have increased. "You have to look at what we're exporting and importing," said Clyde V. Prestowitz, head of the Economic Strategy Institute. "They're selling us high-value added, high-technology equipment and we're selling them commodities and agricultural products." Not much has changed.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . . And Its Duty to U.S. Auto Workers

BYLINE: By EDWARD RENSHAW; Edward Renshaw is a professor of economics at the State University of New York at Albany.

 BODY:
The number of people working in automobile manufacturing in this country has shrunk more than 20 percent since 1978, and that includes employees at Japan's newly established operations here. Obviously, an even steeper decline has taken place at Detroit's Big Three.
That means Detroit will have fewer employees to fund its retiree benefits obligations. That is especially troubling because American companies are now paying for health-care benefits of retired men and women who contributed to Detroit's prosperity years ago. This is a burden that Japanese transplant companies don't have to shoulder because almost none of their employees are old enough to be eligible for retirement. 
 Skyrocketing health-care costs have made Detroit's burden a heavy one. In 1988 and 1989, the General Motors Corporation paid more than $1 billion in health-care costs for its retired employees. And the health-care retirement burden is almost certain to get worse as Detroit cuts middle management and strives to catch up with the Japanese in terms of automation.
So where is the money for these retiree benefits obligations to come from? Taxpayers could end up bearing some of the burden. Remember the Chrysler Corporation bailout in 1979. If Chrysler had gone out of business, taxpayers would have had to absorb more than $1 billion in Federally insured pension benefits to the company's retired workers.
In terms of health care, there is a way out: Congress could take a page from the Railroad Retirement Act of 1935. By that year, the increased use of cars and the effects of the Great Depression had slashed the number of railroad employees by more than 40 percent from the 1920's levels. Congress responded with an act implementing a system of retirement benefits for all railroad employees. The railroads and their employees were to be "taxed" uniformly to pay for those benefits. This act solved an important social problem -- rising unemployment coupled with the number of retired people with little income -- and helped to create a more level playing field for surviving railroads.
In these treacherous times, the best way to finance a similar system for auto industry health-care benefits would be to levy a uniform sales tax on all motor vehicles and parts sold in this country, including imports.
Taxing imported vehicles would prevent them from having an unfair cost advantage over Detroit's products and taxing parts would help to compensate for the fact that Japanese transplant companies -- by putting artificially high values on imported parts -- are able to largely avoid paying any corporate profit taxes to Washington.
Detroit's Big Three, which are now badgering Washington for special protection, might add this to their agenda. And labor might think about supporting them.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Japan's Sleight of Hand in Trade . . .

BYLINE: By KEVIN L. KEARNS; Kevin L. Kearns is a fellow at the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington.

 BODY:
America's trade deficit with Japan often serves as a rallying point against adversarial Japanese trade practices, but because of the gulf war, the Commerce Department's release of the 1990 trade figures passed almost unnoticed.
America's trade deficit with Japan fell substantially -- to $41 billion from $49 billion the year before -- and the gap stands far below 1987's record of $56 billion. 
 At first glance, it may seem that Japan is opening its protected market and that American industry is meeting the Japanese challenge. That certainly is the spin that American and Japanese officials are putting on the numbers. But first glances are deceiving.
As Tokyo knows -- and Washington must learn -- the "how much" of the deficit no longer tells the whole story. Just as important is trade composition -- what is being traded and where in the global Japanese production base it comes from.
American laissez-faire economists believe it doesn't matter whether a country sells $100 worth of computer chips or $100 worth of potato chips -- since the $100 earned is the same. But not all economic activity creates the same benefits. Making and exporting low-tech and agricultural products doesn't provide the same opportunities to generate wealth and spin off new industries as high-tech production and trade do. The $8 billion drop in the trade deficit masks disturbing trends.
Japan has cut the deficit in several ways. First, it has bought more from America. But the dollar volume of its exports of manufactured goods in most sectors has outpaced the growth in dollar volume of its manufactured imports from America. To offset the persistent deficits in manufacturing, Japan has expanded its purchases of commodities, which is not as good for the United States as manufactured or high-tech items.
Second, Japanese companies have located some assembly plants in the United States. These plants don't provide the same range of jobs or domestic content as their American counterparts, but they do improve the trade numbers by the amount of value added to essentially Japanese goods by American workers.
Finally, Japanese companies have moved assembly plants to countries other than the United States, allowing exports from the Japanese-owned production base to show up in those countries' trade figures and cutting the deficit attributable to Japan.
In Thailand, for example, 46 Japanese electronics companies have been established since 1985. Japan's consumer electronics exports to America fell sharply in the last two years, but exports of microwaves, videocassette recorders and color televisions from Japanese companies in Thailand have soared. Electronics exports from Japanese subsidiaries in other Asian countries and Mexico are also up dramatically.
In the last three years of declining deficits with Japan, the plight of critical American industries, relative to their Japanese competitors, has worsened. What do the statistics indicate about American exports? They say our economic future lies not in such goods as office machines, computers and electrical and power-generating machinery -- where, in spite of the fact that we sold more to Japan, the sectoral trade imbalances of the peak deficit year 1987 have actually expanded by more than $2.3 billion.
Although there have been some success stories in trade deficit reduction since 1987, the majority of the $15 billion improvement came in areas that raise as many questions as they answer. Apparently, the nation's future lies in its economic past: In lumber, for example, breakfast cereals, meat, fish and metal scrap -- where the trade surplus has expanded by $3.6 billion. Are we really a nation of scrap metal collectors and lumberjacks?
Laissez-faire theorists insist that what we make doesn't matter. But Japan and other trading partners do care about the composition of their economies, support particular industries and target American counterparts because they consider those industries to be engines of future growth.
In the past two weeks, the chief executives of the Detroit's Big Three automakers have met with President Bush about Japan's automobile cartels. And the head of the National Association of Manufacturers has written the President requesting a complete review of American-Japanese economic relations.
Our manufacturers know that the decline in the trade deficit with Japan is not an accurate measure of our nation's competitiveness vis-a-vis Japan. It is time for policy makers to stop trumpeting their putative trade successes, put economic ideology aside and look hard at the composition of trade.

HEADLINE: Technology;
A Faster Path to Finished Steel

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

DATELINE: NEW CARLISLE, Ind.

 BODY:
In a wide stretch of quiet farmland in northwestern Indiana, the Inland Steel Company is engaged in a joint venture with the Nippon Steel Corporation to produce finished steel using a new process that cuts manufacturing time to less than an hour, from about 12 days.
The process, in which unfinished steel coils are converted into high quality finished steel, is unique in North America. It is being hailed by some steel industry experts as the most advanced technique for producing high quality steel for the appliance, office furniture and automotive industries. 
 Inland, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, has a great deal riding on the project, which it views as a means to create high quality steel cheaper and more quickly than any competitor. It is looking at the project as a way to help the company emerge from its worst tailspin in years.
Inland's 60 percent stake in the year-old plant here, known as I/N Tek, has so far cost $112 million alone, and there are still start-up expenses. Nippon has put up the rest of the money for the project.
Next to the I/N Tek plant is another joint venture in which both companies have a 50 percent stake in a state-of-the-art plant; this one will produce galvanized steel. Inland's stake in the plant, which will coat steel coils with zinc and nickel for the automobile industry, represents an additional $225 million investment.
Inland has been plagued with a number of operational problems in the last year, making the success of I/N Tek even more important.
A power failure late last year at a factory that produces bar products for the automobile industry caused production in that division to drop 40 percent. And Inland is still losing money from start-up problems with a new processing center at the company's steel distribution unit on the south side of Chicago that began operating last year.
All of that, coupled with the current depressed conditions in the steel industry, has caused Inland's results to plunge to their lowest level since the industry's depressed days of the mid-1980's. The company reported a net loss of $20.6 million for all of last year on sales of $3.87 billion, compared with net income of $120 million on sales of $4.1 billion in 1989. The company's stock has fared badly, slipping to $19.375, from around $48 two years ago and $35 last summer.
Inland has bet heavily on large investments in high technology mills, the star of which is the I/N Tek joint venture.
The expenditures and investments have been "a lot for us to assimilate," said Frank W. Luerssen, the company's chairman and chief executive. "And sometimes we look back and ask ourselves if it was appropriate to do it with such rapidity since it's a risky thing to do and we've suffered through the process. But I suspect that people sitting here two, three or four years from now will look back and say that it was the right thing."
The I/N Tek plant is being watched closely by the industry because it takes the cold-mill steelmaking process and moves it from the traditional batch approach, in which batches of steel are moved through the process one by one, and replaces it with a continuous process.
The I/N Tek mill, which is based on technology designed and manufactured by Nippon, weaves coils of steel through a mill the length of seven football fields. It takes what the industry calls "hot bands of steel," the unfinished coils produced in the company's steelmaking plant 55 miles north of here, and cleans, thins, softens and finishes the metal to enable it to be cut and shaped to customers' specifications for such things as washers, dryers, file cabinets and automobile doors and fenders.
In the first step of the process, coils of steel go through what is called a pickling mill, a cleaning in a bath of weak hydrochloric acid that strips the steel of any rust and dirt. From there, the steel goes through a tandem mill, a series of giant rollers that reduce a half-mile strip of steel an eighth of an inch thick to a 64th-of-an-inch-thick sheet two miles long.
Next, the sheets of steel move into an anealing process, a furnace that reheats the metal to develop the metallurgical properties that make steel malleable instead of brittle.
In the traditional annealing process, coils of steel are heated by large cones that are placed on top of the coils. This causes the edges of the coils to be hotter than the interior, which can lead to lack of uniformity in the finished steel.
But in the I/N Tek process, the sheets of steel are threaded continuously through a 10-story furnace heated to 1,470 degrees Fahrenheit, resulting in uniform heating and a more consistent finished product. The sheets then go into a temper mill, where they are flattened and smoothed before being inspected for quality by a computer.
Throughout, the process is controlled by computers and other high tech equipment, which further assures uniformity and quality, the plant's operators said.
The result is what many industry experts contend is the highest quality finished steel produced anywhere.
Traditionally, this cold-mill process involved physically moving the steel coils in batches from one site to another, which could take as long as two weeks and required as many as 500 employees, compared with the 200 working in nonadministrative jobs at the I/N Tek plant here.
"The I/N Tek facility is clearly a leader in technology," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "It will save production costs because you don't have to start and stop the process, like you do in a conventional processing plant. There is no waste of energy and labor."
Also, Inland has the advantage of having just one steel-producing mill -- compared with the three of the USX Corporation and the four of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation -- to provide the unfinished coils of steel. That plant, perched on the Indiana shores of Lake Michigan, is just 55 miles by rail to the north and uses up-to-date continuous casting technology.
Using the two plants in tandem is expected to give Inland a real advantage.
But none of the investment will help the company much unless the market for steel improves. Analysts, and even Inland officials, expect 1991 to be the toughest year the steel business has seen since 1986. Orders were down 35 percent in February from the similar period last year. And steel prices are now 10 percent lower on average than they were a year ago.
Under these conditions, a price increase at Inland is probably unlikely. And some analysts have criticized Mr. Luerssen's strategy, saying that Inland will need to charge customers higher prices to recoup its investment in the joint venture plant here. "Although the joint venture will lower operating costs, the total cost of production, including interest and depreciation will be higher," said Charles A. Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities Inc. "They seem to be banking on users of steel paying more for higher quality products," Mr. Bradford said. "And in this economic environment, I don't know how realistic that is."
Still, Mr. Luerssen is optimistic. "Even though we turned in a bad year, we're taking steps to get back into profitability. There is no doubt that this project is the right thing for this company," he said of the new plant. "We will recover from this."

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Why the Privacy Issue Will Never Go Away

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

DATELINE: BURLINGAME, Calif.

 BODY:
"It's astonishing the things you can do on a desktop computer in five minutes, which five years ago would have taken overnight computer runs on a mainframe," said Charles W. Stryker, president of Trinet America Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., which provided the data for Marketplace: Business, a listing of American business that the Lotus Development Corporation offered, then withdrew, last year.
Trinet America and its parent, American Business Information Inc. of Omaha, subsequently brought out their own versions of Marketplace: Business, called Lists-on-Disk, for I.B.M. personal computers and compatibles. 
 Business Lists-on-Disk, which costs $750 for a year's license, contains general factual information on 9.2 million private and public businesses, including name and address, a description of the primary line of business, the number of employees, the key purchasing executives, information on ownership and estimated or actual revenues. Using Lists-on-Disk, a marketing company would be able to get accurate names, addresses, contacts and phone numbers for, say, all the advertising agencies in St. Louis, or all the accounting firms in the Southwest.
Lotus withdrew Marketplace: Business at the same time it canceled its plans to introduce Marketplace: Households, a CD-ROM product that contained names, ages, addresses, marital status, estimated income range, buying habits and other data on 120 million citizens, based on United States Census and consumer credit data gathered by Equifax Inc., one of the nation's big credit bureaus.
But such programs will not go away, because personal computers and CD-ROM disks allow small businesses to contact their customers with laser beams instead of shotguns, saving on production costs and greatly increasing chances of success.
Marketplace: Households promised to give small companies and individuals the same access to consumer marketing information that bigger and wealthier companies have long enjoyed. A small business hoping to send an advertising flyer directly to the potential customers most likely to buy their products could create a model of its ideal customer using Marketplace guidelines, and, as quickly as one could say Big Brother, list thousands of names of real people who most closely fit the model.
 Even though Marketplace: Households is dead, the debate over the relationship between personal computers and privacy continued at the First Conference on Computers, Freedom and Privacy, a meeting here sponsored by a group called Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility. The conference, which ended on March 28, attracted about 400 participants from organizations as diverse as the Federal Bureau of Investigation, TRW Information Systems and Services, and the Legion of Doom, a loosely knit group of young computer enthusiasts who have been accused by various law-enforcement agencies of such activities as breaking into computer systems and stealing documents and codes.
"We are going to confront many more debates like Lotus Marketplace in the years ahead," said Marc Rotenberg, director of the Washington office of Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility.
Businesses' desire for such highly targeted marketing lists is also undeniable. "We're moving into a world of much more specialized niches and personalized products," said Tom Mandel, director of the values and lifestyles program at SRI International of Menlo Park, Calif., a market research and consulting concern. "We're in a more slowly growing consumer economy, so there is more pressure on businesses to find good consumers."
A key difference between Marketplace: Households and Lists-on-Disk is that American Business Information contacted all the businesses to verify data before listing them. A.B.I. culled business listings from 5,000 Yellow Page phone books, and called each one, Mr. Stryker said. He said 85 percent of the companies agreed to provide information beyond verification of basic data. For those that declined to provide revenue figures, Trinet provided estimates based on industry averages for the number of employees.
While businesses were contacted about being listed, people listed in Marketplace: Households were not notified. Your name, dear reader, was probably in the Marketplace data base, which was drawn from Equifax's data base of 80 million American households. And chances are that you probably did not consent to the inclusion of your name. Rather, you provided the information for other purposes, like applying for a credit card or a mortgage, or filling out a warranty card for an appliance.
Executives of Lotus, based in Cambridge, Mass., and Equifax, based in Atlanta, canceled the program after months of increasingly vigorous protests from consumers. More than 30,000 people, in what may have been the first grass-roots, personal computer-based consumer protest, contacted Lotus to voice their concerns that Marketplace: Households represented an abuse of private information.
"We don't have any plans to get back in that business," said John A. Ford, assistant vice president for corporate affairs of Equifax, a billion-dollar multinational credit and information bureau. "We believe the decision to stop development was a socially responsible one. We are concerned about the balance between the needs of businesses and individuals' concerns over privacy."
According to a Louis Harris & Associates poll commissioned by Equifax, the majority of consumers do not object to the use of their names in secondary mailing lists so long as they are given the option of removing their names from the list. The process of removing one's name is called "opting out." But critics of Lotus's Marketplace: Households noted that because the program was encoded on a CD-ROM disk, which is not eraseable, consumers could not opt out or correct erroneous information once it was encoded. Such changes would have to await the creation of a new disk.
 Lotus and Equifax officials said the program was misunderstood. It did not allow users to seek information on specific individuals. One could not ask for information on George Bush, for example. But ask for a list of executive males who earn at least $200,000 a year, live on the East Coast and carry an American Express card (even if it is just for identification) and presto!: The list would include George Herbert Walker Bush, age 65, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington.
 "Your privacy is a commodity and it has a value," said Esther Dyson, editor of the newsletter Release 1.0. "I'm a big fan of people owning data about themselves." She said was sorry Lotus had abandoned Marketplace "before the issue of 'ownership' of private information was debated."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Long and Short, the Bond Fund Gap

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
As a general rule, short-term bond funds react more quickly to changing interest rates than long-term funds. After a lag, the yields on long-term funds follow.
That hasn't happened recently. When short-term interest rates began to fall last year, long-term rates held their ground or even moved up. That may have reflected concerns about the weakness of the United States economy, said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services Inc., in Summit, N.J. 
 Whatever the reason, the current yield difference is unusually wide. Eventually, long-term rates should tumble. And for investors, this means "a good possibility of long-term bond fund price advances," Mr. Schoepke said.

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT: Ex Machina;
The Electronic Edge

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
WHEN IT COMES to technology in education, "it's hard to use a crystal ball because the technology is changing every 18 months," said Sam Petruso, coordinator of computer services in the Mill Creek Township School District in Pennsylvania. Still, Mr. Petruso has engaged in a fair amount of crystal-gazing of late, equipping his district's elementary schools with computers, laser disks, compact-disk players, 8-millimeter video camcorders, videocassette recorders and Sony Watchman televisions.
Only a small number of schools nationwide have gone so wholeheartedly into high-technology education. But more and more schools are eyeing the field and sallying forth. The problem for educators, as Mr. Petruso notes, is understanding the new and emerging technologies and the promise they hold, so as to tap the best ones for classrooms of the present and future. 
 As usual, the technology is expected to progress much faster than the ability of schools to pay for it. New technologies are always expensive, and schools and legislators will continue to struggle to find innovative and equitable ways to pay for advanced educational tools, such as the following.
COMPUTERS: The heart of education's technological transformation is the computer, an information-processing and -transferring engine comprising several components, including working and storage memories, video displays and input devices.
One measure of computer processing power is a MIP, for millions of instructions per second. Some of the personal computers used in businesses have about 20 MIP's as against educational computers' measly 1. But 100-MIP personal computers are expected in a few years. More MIP's create opportunities for technologies such as video, speech and handwriting recognition, and realistic simulations of, say, chemical reactions.
The physical form of computers is also evolving, with notebook and hand-held computers becoming more common. Eventually, computers may be integrated into every student's and teacher's desktop. More likely, the computer's decreasing size and weight will enable students or teachers to travel from class to class with their own personal information devices.
Notebook computers, battery-powered computers the size of a stack of typing paper or smaller, can store as much as 60 megabytes, or 60 million characters of data in a magnetic hard disk the size of a cigarette pack. That's the equivalent of about 30,000 book pages of text information. Researchers say that in a few years, notebook computers may store hundreds of megabytes of data on rewriteable optical disks, which resemble audio CD's. And they may be able to tap into huge pools of information by plugging into a school's network, as one would plug a telephone into an outlet, or by using cellular and radio-frequency modems.
NETWORKS: Critical to future educational technology is the network, the system of glass and plastic fiber-optic cables, copper wiring, radio, microwave and satellite technologies that serve as vast data highways.
Within a year, all 180 schools in Florida's Broward County school district will be linked in a vast computer network. With 161,000 elementary and secondary students, and 180,000 adult-education students, the district is the eighth-largest in the nation. "We can see how we could expand curriculum offerings without having to find stand-alone teachers," one for each classroom, said Virgil Morgan, superintendent of schools.
At the Shoreline School District in Seattle, fiber-optic cables -- which transmit data as pulses of light at rates as high as 100 million bits a second -- will soon enable students and teachers to retrieve articles, video clips, slides, photographs and sound recordings from a central resource library. Using two-way video, classes and individual teachers will see and interact with another in the same building or across the district.
The National Science Foundation is planning to establish a high-speed national fiber network by the year 2000 to connect all American universities and, perhaps, most secondary schools. Schools using such a network could draw information from virtually any university library in the nation.
 
 
Wireless Networks vs. Built-in 'Plumbing'
 Some schools are experimenting with wireless networks that send data over low-power radio waves, while other schools are being designed with networking "plumbing" built in. Wireless networks are more flexible than wired ones, and more expensive. But Apple Computer has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to use part of the radio band for computer communications, suggesting that the field may become popular and more economical.
Other networking technologies, including packet radio and cellular modems, may give students at home access to school or museum resources.
TELEVISION: Schools may some day have video wallpaper, where images surround students. In the near term the conventional video monitor -- or television -- will enter most classrooms, but in updated form.
The key is interactive technology, which enables students and teachers to participate in the display of information. Using, for example, the interactive form of the recent public television series on the Civil War, now being developed, students could jump from one topic to related topics, including texts of documents, bibliographies, biographies of key individuals and more.
The video monitor will likely be connected to computers, video camcorders, videocassette recorders, laser disks, compact disk players, cable TV, satellite dishes and other classrooms for live, two-way television broadcasts. Eventually, high-definition television using digital signals will bring photographic-quality images to viewers, along with computer data and graphics. Japanese companies have indicated that they plan to integrate computers and optical disks into new monitors, creating video computers. American companies, by contrast, are trying to integrate video into computers, creating multimedia PC's.
MULTIMEDIA: The combination of computer data, graphics, sound and video is called multimedia and is already used to convey information. The next step is to give more students than the few now using them the tools to produce their own multimedia presentations.
OPTICAL DISKS: This category includes intriguing technologies with names like CD-ROM, CD-V, laser videodisks and CD-I. Most resemble audio CD disks, except that they play data, graphics, sound and video on computer screens or television sets hooked to a computer. Optical disks are already replacing textbooks in some classes because they can be updated rapidly.
The next generation of optical-disk technology will in-<cc11.6volve computers that can record, erase and record again on a single optical disk.
SATELLITES: The recent development of satellite receiving dishes the size of garbage-can lids will eventually allow homes and individual classrooms to pull in signals from satellites. Using portable satellite transmitting stations, professors will beam lectures from remote archeological sites, for example, to schools, while students on field trips will send in reports.
ELECTRONIC MAIL: Electronic mail enables teachers, administrators and students to keep in contact more efficiently than if they used postal mail, interoffice mail or even the telephone. Messages can be sent at any time and stored in a central computer, to be retrieved at the recipient's convenience.
Scholars can use E-mail, as it is called, to keep abreast of developments in their field; to contact colleagues and leading authorities at other universities; to collaborate on research papers, and to publish findings. Students can obtain assignments and have administrative notices or professors' messages sent to their dorm rooms.
VIRTUAL REALITY: Once the stuff of science fiction, virtual reality is now a serious topic of educational research. Students can "travel" to distant locations and sense that they are physically present at, say, the ruins of Pompeii. They move through the artificial environment experience by wearing a specially wired helmet or goggles, by gesturing with a special glove and moving their eyes. Medical students could hone their skills on virtual patients, for example, while architectural students could build virtual buildings.
"One of the positive effects of technology on education will be to teach people to learn to learn, rather than to learn specific facts," said David Nagle, head of the Advanced Technology Group at Apple Computer. The role of teachers, Mr. Nagle added, is not diminished but rather enhanced by these technologies, making it "worthwhile to spend as much time teaching teachers to use the technologies as it is to teach students to learn."

HEADLINE: Black Businesses Work in Schools

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
NEAR the Robert Taylor public-housing project on Chicago's South Side, the Soft Sheen Products Company has developed a special relationship with Beethoven Elementary School. Executives of Soft Sheen, which manufactures hair-care products and is the nation's sixth-largest black-owned company, make themselves available for a host of programs, from developing parents' associations to helping establish tutorial programs. 
 Soft Sheen has also provided materials and equipment for a second public elementary school and two public high schools that it "adopted." But company executives say their most important offering is in their time and personnel.
 
 
Black Role Growing
 Soft Sheen is not alone in its activities. Indeed, there are signs that black companies are playing an increasingly important role in schools. "Black-owned companies are doing more in education," said Frank L. Matthews, publisher of the journal Black Issues in Higher Education and senior scholar at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va.
And they are doing so increasingly on the local level, according to Mr. Matthews and others who study black-owned concerns. "But it's hard to quantify what they do," he said.
The participation of black-owned companies in school systems dates to when many public schools were legally segregated. Companies then commonly established scholarships and made personnel available to teachers. But the recent increase in activities, Mr. Matthews and others contend, is fueled by heightened concern about the nation's public schools, particularly in inner cities, where many large black-owned companies are based.
"School systems have deteriorated so badly that I think black companies feel a greater need than ever to get involved," said Robert L. Johnson, president of Black Entertainment Television, a Washington, D.C., cable network.
"Our work force comes mainly from Chicago public schools," said Frances Williams Gutter, Soft Sheen's manager of special projects. "So it's important that we do whatever our resources allow."
And there are more wealthy black entrepreneurs now to make such resources available. Last year, for example, Reginald F. Lewis, the Wall Street investor and chairman of TLC Beatrice Inc., donated $1 million to Howard University and smaller sums to other historically black colleges. Mr. Lewis also finances scholarships to college-bound New York City public high school students.
 
 
Starting Foundations
 Many black-owned corporations have seen their revenues grow to a point that they can incorporate programs for school systems within their annual budgets. Soft Sheen, for example, which is 27 years old, has established the Soft Sheen Foundation to finance programs associated with its school adoptions. The foundation also finances learning centers and arts and crafts centers in Chicago housing projects.
The Mays Chemical Company in Indianapolis, which last year had $50 million in sales of specialty chemical products, works with a local group, Community Leaders Allied for Superior Schools, and in partnership with the Chamber of Commerce to conduct several programs. These range from contests for students with the greatest improvement in grade point average to assistance from company executives in teaching economics.
"The schools are hungry and open to whatever suggestions we might be willing to make," said the company's president, William G. Mays. "As a black-owned company, we have a special commitment to deal with the inner city and to get through to black males interested in achieving."
More often, however, the educational reach of black-owned companies has been limited. Annual sales last year of the 100 largest black-owned industrial companies and automobile dealerships equaled $6.8 billion, roughly the same as the Ralston Purina Company, which was 69th on the Fortune 500 listing of the nation's largest companies in 1989. Since nearly all black-owned companies are privately held, profitability figures are not available. But their executives say profits often are not robust enough to allow outside expenditures.
"Our limitations are more financial than anything else," said Jeffery B. Cullers, vice president of Vince Cullers Advertising Inc., the nation's oldest black-owned advertising firm. Cullers Advertising has a relationship with the Chicago Board of Education in which the company develops marketing programs "to help make the public aware of the school system's needs," Mr. Cullers said.
Mr. Matthews is optimistic, however. "Black companies are becoming more savvy and are growing in size," he said. "The commitment is already there; now they're getting the resources to do even more."

HEADLINE: THE ROMANIANS SEE MORE WOES AHEAD

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania

 BODY:
The leaders of this country, the unhappiest of the formerly Communist nations of eastern Europe, concede that it is going through hardship as it jettisons the Communist legacy and struggles toward a market economy.
"This year will be dominated by economic difficulties, as last year was by political confrontations," President Ion Iliescu said in an interview in Cotraceni Palace. "There will be problems with the labor force. The number of jobless is mounting. Optimists say there will be 400,000, 500,000 unemployed. Pessimists say up to a million, and perhaps that is more realistic." 
 Coping with mounting material distress is made more difficult by a loss of confidence in the leadership among the intellectual elite, which played a vital role in the overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu in December 1989. Writers and academics, as well as foreign diplomats, said the loss of support deprived the Government of the help of people who could rally mass support for it.
Mircea Dinescu, a dissident poet who was put under house arrest by President Ceausescu's Government, became by circumstance the man who announced the fall of the old regime to the nation over television. Today he says the hopes he cherished have faded.
 
'Servants Took Over'
 "I think if I was Japanese now, a year after the revolution, I would disembowel myself," he said in an interview in his office at the Writers Union, which he heads. "We say in Romania that miracles endure for three days. Like our revolution: after three days the professionals of power took over. The master was killed, his servants took over."
Diplomats agree with the criticism by intellectuals; they are reflected in the State Department's human rights assessment for 1990. The Government is accused of undemocratic practices toward opponents, particularly in connection with the presidential election last May and mob attacks on opponents in June.
Speaking of foreign criticism, Mr. Iliescu singled out the United States. He said a refusal by international banking organizations to grant credits stemmed from American disapproval. He suggested that America lacked respect for his people in doubting the voting that gave him 86 percent in May.
"A popular choice was clearly exercised," he said. "So if you respect a people, you should respect its choice."
 
Security Forces Weakened
 Asked whether he feared economic hardship might lead to a melding of political and social discontent that might bring people into the streets, Mr. Iliescu replied, "That is always possible." He suggested serious consequences because of what he called the former regime's legacy of suspicion, which, he said, deprived "the forces of public order of the necessary force to resolve problems of confrontation."
Prime Minister Petre Roman is responsible for the program to speed change to a market economy. It requires passing on to the 23 million Romanians the true costs of the necessities of life, which under Communism were disguised by ample subsidies to the producers.
"We have made an error," said Alexandru Birladeanu, the Senate President, an 80-year-old economist who resigned from the Ceausescu leadership in 1968. "We are going too fast. In creating the Romania of the year 2000, we are making the Romanians of 1991 pay too high a price."
Inflation has devalued money in people's pockets by 50 percent since October, Government statistics show. The average wage of about 2,000 lei a month is worth less than $10 on the realistic black market.
 
Morale Problem Cited
 The President and the Prime Minister conceded that low morale was hampering transition to democracy. "There is a general illness," Mr. Iliescu said. "We bear a very heavy legacy, an atmosphere of general suspiciousness created by the old regime."
Many Romanians and diplomats hold Mr. Iliescu and Mr. Roman themselves responsible. The root of the "illness," they said, is the survival of former Communists like them as leaders and a belief that thousands of agents of the Securitate, the Ceausescu secret police, continue to serve the Government.
Mr. Birladeanu expressed confidence in the President but added: "I don't exclude that he has some reflexes conditioned by his youth. Perhaps he doesn't quite understand the working of democracy."
Mr. Iliescu, describing Romanian society, said, "There are no pure people who are not linked to the old regime."
 
'Equal Guilt for All'
 This view causes resentment. "They say we were all dirty," said Ana Blandiana, a poet persecuted by the Securitate. "Equal guilt for all, those who were close to power and us others."
Culture Minister Andrei Plesu said: "Ceausescu died, but his spirit lives on," What lingers is "a human type produced by Communism -- people who like privileges, opportunists, people incapable of normal, transparent behavior."
"A post-totalitarian neurosis with a very bad effect on everything" pervades Romania, Mr. Plesu, a writer, continued. "We are all of us infected by a perverse illness. This has created huge social tension and a toxic intolerance."

HEADLINE: New York's Economy: Rebound Seems Distant

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
The New York metropolitan region, which began an economic slide before the rest of the nation, will lag behind a national turnaround, according to several recent forecasts.
The end of the Persian Gulf war, a surging stock market, an awakening housing market and signs that consumer confidence is rising have prompted talk that a national economic revival may not be far off. But economists charting the vicissitudes of New York and New Jersey say both states will suffer more job losses in 1991 and, some believe, 1992. 
 The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in one of the more optimistic of the forecasts, believes that a local turnaround could occur near the end of 1991. But by year's end, the authority projects, New York City will have lost 40,000 more jobs.
A forecast by Matthew P. Drennan, an economist at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, put a turnaround in 1992, with a loss of 71,000 jobs in the city in 1991 and 26,000 more next year.
 
The Signs of a Rebound
 According to a Federal Home Loan Bank of New York forecast, the New Jersey economy should begin to recover in 1992, but the outlook next year for New York State will still be poor, reflecting the "stagnating" New York City and Long Island economies. The two-year forecast estimates that New York State will lose 165,000 jobs and New Jersey 57,000 jobs in 1991.
Rae D. Rosen, the organization's vice president and senior economist, noted the signs of a rebound in the national housing market. "Locally, we're going to get a little bit of a spillover," she said, "but that's not sufficient to pull us out of a recession."
Ms. Rosen said she expected weak gains in personal income of about 2 percent to 3 percent in New York State, not only well below the inflation rate but also the lowest rate of growth in more than 20 years. That suggests that state and local tax revenues will continue to fall below expectations, raising the prospect of higher real-estate and personal-income taxes.
The result, Ms. Rosen said, would be "very sharp" declines in purchasing power. "I can't be optimistic about retail sales," she added.
 
Relocated to Other Cities
 New York City, which in the 1980's enjoyed its most prosperous decade since World War II, is the focus of the region's current economic weakness. In a briefing last month, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, noted that the city had lost 100,000 jobs between September 1989, its recent employment peak, and January 1991.
Last week, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said it would transfer or eliminate 4,000 jobs from its New York headquarters. About 3,000 employees will be relocated to other cities while one of the company's Manhattan buildings is renovated. MetLife said the project is to be completed by 1996, when it will decide whether to bring the workers back to New York.
And the Grumman Corporation said it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, three-fourths of them on Long Island, because of cuts in military spending and a need to trim expenses. The aerospace and transportation company is Long Island's largest private employer.
 
Undergoing Reorganizations
 The March unemployment rates provided more gloomy evidence of the region's faltering economy. The jobless rates for New York and New Jersey both rose to 6.8 percent, while New York City rose to 8.1 percent.
Since the early 1950's, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, New York City has tended to begin recessions about two months before the nation begins a slump and to emerge from them about two months after the nation has revived.
But the city's current downturn, he said, is "not your run-of-the-mill recession," because key parts of its economy, including Wall Street, the legal and accounting professions and department stores and other retailers, were not simply sagging but undergoing reorganizations that have yet to run their course. "There's a lot more uncertainty in New York," he said.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said this downturn has differed from past slumps because it has been led by white-collar sectors that had once been sources of the city's strength. Financial services, which added 115,000 jobs between 1980 and 1987 -- 40 percent of the city's private-industry job growth during that time -- have lost 50,000 jobs since then.
Large declines in the city have also come in trade, which lost 46,000 jobs between September 1989 and January 1991, the labor statistics bureau reported. About 32,000 of the jobs have been in restaurants, department stores and other types of retailing.
Manufacturing has continued its long decline in the city, losing 30,000 jobs in the 16 months after September 1989. Construction, which had gained 50,000 jobs from 1980 to 1987, lost 16,500 jobs in 1990 alone, the bureau said.
The only part of the city's economy that has continued to expand is the services sector, but the growth has mostly been in health, education and social services rather than in more highly paid business and professional services like law and engineering.
Economists say the city's prospects for recovery and growth largely depend on its supply of educated workers and whether its costs become competitive with those in other regions.
One sign of hope, Mr. Ehrenhalt indicated, is that the city's rate of inflation, which had been higher than that of the nation for much of the 1980's, is now essentially even with it.

HEADLINE: Vast Majority of Americans Feel Sting of Recession, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
A large portion of Americans, far more than the 6.8 percent who are unemployed, have been deeply stung by the recession and may be in no position, financially or psychologically, to help bail out the economy by going on a shopping spree, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.
The recession touches the vast majority of Americans in some way, the poll found. Fifty-eight percent said they knew someone well who was currently out of work. Almost half said they were finding it harder to make ends meet. 
 Three out of 10 respondents, and half the blacks, said a family member had been out of work in the past year. One in five whites, and almost half the blacks, said they thought the chances were high that a family member would be laid off in the next year.
The Times/CBS News survey of 1,283 people Monday to Wednesday stands in sharp contrast to record-breaking surges in consumer confidence measured by polls in March that examined long-range views.
In interviews conducted after the poll, nearly all of 20 survey participants said that their spirits had been lifted by the victory in the Persian Gulf and that they were optimistic about the future prospects of the nation's economy. But many said they were deeply concerned about their own families' financial difficulties, brought on by inflation, debts and layoffs.
 
Economy the Paramount Concern
 The survey substantiates the view that the euphoria after the gulf war was just that: a collective sigh of joy.
"I don't think things are getting any better yet," said Craig H. Munson, a 57-year-old iron worker in Saginaw, Mich., who has fallen behind in his utility payments since being laid off in January. "I don't know what I'll do if I don't get a job this month."
The participants in the Times/CBS News survey were selected at random by a computer to represent the nation's diversity. Statistically, their views are not expected to differ by more than three percentage points in either direction from those of all Americans.
The poll found that the state of the economy was still the paramount concern for a third of the nation, ranking far above drug abuse or all other social ills combined. In particular, the level of concern about unemployment now matches levels recorded during the 1981-1982 recession.
No wonder. The number of people seeking unemployment benefits reached an eight-year high of 543,000 people in late March, the Government reported Friday.
The jobless rate for March climbed to 6.8 percent from 6.5 percent, the fifth straight monthly increase, indicating that 410,000 people had lost jobs last month alone, the Labor Department said. In all, two million Americans have lost jobs since last summer.
 
Little Jobs 'So Hard to Get'
 Judy Parker, who is 45 years old and lives near Lexington, N.C., made telephone equipment for A.T.&T. for almost 25 years before the plant closed in late 1989. Her severance pay is spent, her unemployment benefits will run out this month, and she cannot find a job, even one paying the minimum wage. Her 47-year-old husband, Rodney, makes $6.83 an hour building bedroom furniture, but sales are poor and his employer has put him on a part-time schedule.
"I've been out of a job since October 1989, and I can't find anybody to give me a chance," said Mrs. Parker, who made $11 an hour at A.T.&T. "I figured, 'What the heck, I don't have to make a whole bunch of money.' But I didn't realize that these little $4-an-hour jobs are so hard to get. I guess I could be looking harder, but it gets kind of depressing when you're told you're being put on a preferred applicant list for running a cash register for $3.80 an hour."
Her husband, who was not among the survey's respondents, characterized the local job market as "plain dirty as hell."
Young adults in the survey, ages 18 to 29, reported having a particularly hard time. Almost half said a family member had been out of work in the past year and 29 percent said they believed there was a high likelihood of someone in their household losing a job in the next year.
"My husband, Clay, says it's a depression," said Victoria Reimers, 24, of Everett, Wash. She said that she earned $5.25 an hour as a clerk at Sears, Roebuck & Company and that because of slow sales, her schedule was cut to 11 hours a week from 30. Mr. Reimers, a 25-year-old brick mason, cannot find steady work, she said.
The Reimers have borrowed money from parents to pay the rent on their one-bedroom apartment; the rent just increased by $20, to $420 a month. "We go sit in the Jacuzzi to relieve stress," Mrs. Reimers said, adding that animals also have a calming effect on her. She and her husband have two cats, two dogs and a boa constrictor and 14 rats to feed to the snake, she said.
 
Positive View of Future
 How do these American voices mesh with earlier reports apparently brimming with consumer optimism?
The Conference Board, a research organization, reported recently that its March index of consumer confidence jumped 21 points from February, breaking a 24-year record for a single month's gain.
Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's Consumer Research Center in New York, said most of the gain in the board's survey came from a sharp increase in positive views about the economy's future, not from people's views of their own situation. For example, in reporting on their current financial condition, 36 percent of the respondents in the board's survey said they believed jobs were hard to find, as against only 10 percent who said jobs were plentiful. "Normally, optimists outnumber the pessimists," he said.
In additional results from its survey, completed in mid-March, the board said Friday that 25 percent of the respondents said their families had been significantly affected by the recession and nearly 35 percent said they had postponed making a major purchase in recent months.
But, Mr. Linden said, a pent-up demand for products is growing and would probably be unleashed as soon as people feel more confident in their financial situation. The board's national surveys are based on 5,000 interviews, and the margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Psyche vs. Bank Balance
 The return of consumer confidence will have as much to do with people's psyches as their bank accounts or job prospects, said William A. Roiter, a Boston psychologist who counsels laid-off workers. He als an existing $8,000 president of Hurst Associates, which provides employee assistance programs to New England companies.
"People are feeling very insecure and out of control," he said. "People need something they can believe in again before they can recover."
Martha Adkins of Lancaster, Ohio, says her 47-year-old husband, Don, cannot sleep at night because his carpentry business is falling off. "He stays up at night and worries," said Mrs. Adkins, a respondent in The Times/CBS News Poll.
In the last year, she said, his income has fallen to $40,000 from $65,000. To make ends meet, Mrs. Adkins, who is 34 years old, temporarily got a full-time job for four months this winter; almost half her earnings, at $2.50 an hour, went to pay the babysitter for their 4-year-old son, Daniel. The Adkinses are very wary of debt and say they do not use credit cards or plan to carry more than an existing $8,000 mortgage on their $110,000 home.
 
Concern Among Blacks
 Black respondents had the most worries about the economy, with more than half saying the economy was getting worse as against 30 percent of the whites. But Sharon K. Smith, who is black, said it was getting better. "I don't believe things are as bad as some people would have you believe," she said.
But Ms. Smith, a 34-year-old insurance clerk in Atlanta, said companies were much more worried about losses these days than they are about the ethnic make-up of their work force. "It doesn't matter whether you are white, Hispanic, black, blue or green anymore," she said. "We have been told in no uncertain terms, 'If you're not productive, you are out.' "
The survey's respondents were split, 40 percent to 41 percent, on whether the economy was "fairly good" or "fairly bad." But while an additional 2 percent said the economy was "very good," 16 percent more called it "very bad." Wishful feelings were revealed behind the positive responses, since 72 percent also said the economy was in recession.
But the vast majority polled felt the touch of recession in some way. A total of 77 percent said that either they had had a family member out of work recently or were having difficulty making ends meet or knew someone well who was out of work.
Older people in the survey held a slightly rosier view of the economy than the young held, perhaps because those over 64 have attained some financial independence, are secure in their retirement benefits, or they simply know how to can a jar of peaches.
"The recession may be having a deep effect on everybody else, but not for me," said Lillian Ascetta-Ackerman, a 75-year-old widow who supplements her Social Security income by growing and canning her own fruit and vegetables at her home in Matamorus, a rural part of northern Pennsylvania. "I learned to live sparsely in the Depression," she said. "Young folks today, they get a steak, and they have to have mushrooms with it. They haven't learned to make do."
Florence Stray says that she struggles to get by on her $650-a-month Social Security check, but that she remains a flag-waving optimist. "You've got to have faith in your country, that it's going to get better," said Mrs. Stray, a retired social worker, who lives by herself in San Diego.
"I'd be living under a bridge with the rest of them if I didn't have a subsidized apartment," said Mrs. Stray. She said she drives a 20-year old car, never eats in restaurants and shops for clothing in a local thrift shop.
Many people have not yet been hurt by the recession, and some survey participants seemed to exhibit survivors' anxiety. "I'm embarrassed to say the recession really hasn't affected us at all," said Mickey Pleasants, who is 48 years old and lives in Raleigh, N.C. "My husband, Riley, is a dentist."

 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN

The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Monday to Wednesday with 1,283 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits so unlisted numbers could be called along with listed ones. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus about 10 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
