HEADLINE: Cast as Villains in Drought, Rice Farmers Defend Water Rights

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROBBINS, Calif., April 5

 BODY:
Any day now, the rice farmers in the Sacramento Valley will burn, disk, furrow, fertilize and flood their fields and plant the crop that has made them the arch-villains of California's drought.
These men say the work will be a welcome distraction from the badgering of state officials who tried to the buy their water and the criticism of people from one end of California to the other who wonder why anyone is paid by the government to grow a monsoon crop in this desert landscape. 
 When Governor Pete Wilson inaugurated a voluntary "water bank" program to transfer water from the state's haves to its have-nots without the cost or ecological risk of building news dams and aqueducts, the rice farmers seemed the most promising donors.
But while the water bank was more successful than expected, the rice growers, who use more water each year than all the households in Los Angeles and San Francisco put together, hunkered down and refused to sell.
 
State Offers to Pay Farmers
 "None of us here want to be knot-headed about it," said Al Driver, who grows 1,046 acres of rice on a 2,400-acre ranch here. "But we don't care for it and we're not going to do it."
Under decades-old agreements, the farmers pay the government as little as $7 for the water they consume on each acre of land. This year, the state offered about $450 for that amount of water. But accepting the offer would force the farmers to idle land, thus losing income from rice. Some farmers would also lose a $260 Federal subsidy for each idled acre.
The farmers secured the rights to cheap, abundant water over generations, and their biggest fear is that selling water now would endanger those rights in the future.
They are not the only farmers to guard their water jealously, but no other group, not even the alfalfa farmers, whose crops consume more water, has been singled out for so much criticism. In large part, the rice farmers' special status reflects their historical privilege.
 
History of Water Rights
 The ancestors of these rice farmers were the first settlers on the banks of the Sacramento River, and they dipped their buckets into the water at their doorsteps and irrigated their crops. Under a system of property rights that harks back to English courts, Mexican pueblos and Western mines, these families owned the land and the water that flowed past it; it was their livelihood and their patrimony.
Then, in the 1930's, the Federal Government came calling, set on building the Shasta Dam to tame the wild snow-fed rivers that tumbled from the Sierra Nevada and pumping some of the water to the arid south where the population was growing. Would the farmers be willing to give the Government their water and then buy it back?
The farmers struck a tough bargain. Their water would forever be the cheapest and most plentiful in the state, with assured deliveries even in times of scarcity and prices as low as 1 percent of what others pay.
This winter, the rice farmers were asked again for their water, this time by state officials with open checkbooks and hard-luck stories about drought-striken cities and farms, about fellow Californians who could no longer flush their toilets or irrigate their orchards.
 
This Time, No Deal
 But this time virtually all rice farmers said, "No thank you." Their worry about jeopardizing their future water rights had special urgency because they face renegotiation of their water contracts with the Federal Government over the next several years.
"We don't trust the system," said Tim Leathers, the manager of Reclamation District 108, a water district near the town of Grimes.
Pat Tennis, whose grandfather began rice farming here in the 1920's and helped build the levees, worried that there would be nowhere to turn if promises about water rights proved hollow. "Are you protected by law or subject to the political arena?" asked Mr. Tennis, who farms with his son, Jim, and son-in-law, Darrin Schmidt. "Do you seek relief from the Legislature or the courts?"
 
More Fear in Rice Fields
 Such fears were fed when Governor Wilson said he might invoke emergency powers if the drought worsened and when Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is the vice chairman of the House Interior Committee, pleaded with state and Federal officials to seize the rice farmers' water rather than let them "shake down" taxpayers by buying it for so little and then selling it for so much.
The rice farmers say they had other fears as well.
They are afraid that idling their land will cost them their subsidies, which are worth about one-third of their income. The subsidies bring the market price of rice, currently $7.26 for 100 pounds, to $10.71. The Federal program allows the farmers to idle half their land and still get 92 percent of their total subsidy payments. Under a complicated formula, if they idle more than that to sell water, some of them will retain their subsidies and others will not. It is unclear which farmers fall into each category.
A professor at the University of California at Davis has computed how the rice farmers would fare economically if they sold their water.
The state offered $125 for each acre- foot, enough water to cover one acre one foot deep. According to the professor, Richard Howitt, a farmer who loses his subsidy of $260 an acre would need to get $200 for each acre-foot to break even. A farmer who continued to get the payments would break even at only $60 an acre-foot.
The rice farmers are also wary of ruining their markets. Rice farming is a fragile industry, with growers scrambling for markets and battling foreign trade barriers. California, which produces 25 percent of the nation's crop, is the No. 2 producer in the nation, behind Arkansas, and the crop dominates the economies of half a dozen counties. The 1988-89 crop in the state was worth $442 million, with most of the sales to cereal and beer manufacturers.
Another fear of rice farmers is the economic collapse of their tightly knit communities if they idle land. Here in Robbins, equipment dealers and crop dusters would likely suffer, along with truck drivers and fertilizer dealers.
Driving through the hamlet of 100 people recently, Phil Illerich, a retired rice farmer, pointed to the hulking mill that belongs to the Farmers Rice Cooperative, of which he is a member. "What do you do with the help?" he asked. "Put them on welfare for a year? And there's a half million dollars in property taxes. What about that?"
The water bank, which stopped solicitations this week because its goal had been met, made most of its purchases from farmers in the delta area, down river from here, where growers took corn and sugar beets out of production. The water will be sold to cities and to fruit and nut growers in Kern and Fresno Counties, who have inferior water rights and have been forced to halt irrigation this year.
Proponents of the water bank, who see it as the best way to adjust for the historical irrationalities in pricing and distribution, say the rice farmers may be more willing to sell next time around, especially if local communities do not unduly suffer and if cooperative growers are rewarded with public appreciation and the sympathy of lawmakers.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
BAGHDAD FORMALLY AGREES TO 'UNJUST' U.N. CONDITIONS FOR PERMANENT CEASE-FIRE

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
Iraq's acceptance today of a punishing United Nations cease-fire resolution has forced Saddam Hussein to accept the full consequences of his arrogance and of the defeat that the United States and its allies imposed on him and his people in the Persian Gulf war.
But as stringent as the demands are in forcing Iraq to complete the destruction of its chemical, biological and nuclear industries and pay reparations to Kuwait, they have not produced the outcome that the Bush Administration continues to pursue publicly and privately: the removal of President Hussein from power. 
 While Mr. Hussein may take his personal survival as a victory, it is by no means a victory for the Iraqi people, who have had little to say about the course of his two decades of rule, especially on the crucial and catastrophic decisions to invade Iran in 1980, invade Kuwait in 1990, and go to war against the American-led coalition in 1991.
The Iraqi people have mortgaged a piece of their sovereignty to the United Nations and to the coalition, whose bureaucrats and inspectors will in coming months oversee the destruction of the country's high-technology military laboratories. In the name of enforcement, they also control Iraq's trade for the indefinite future as a means to garnish a suitable part of oil revenues to pay damages to Kuwait.
Even Iraq's ballistic missile program, which a few years ago instilled pride across the Arab world as a step toward pan-Arab satellites and space industries, will be dismantled and destroyed, stripping the country of weapons that all of its enemies from Teheran to Damascus to Tel Aviv still possess.
Mr. Hussein, who told a Soviet envoy on Oct. 30 that if his choice were to surrender in Kuwait or fight, he was inclined to fight, has long inspired official fear in Saudi Arabia that he would someday lead an assault by the so-called have-not Arab countries of Yemen and Jordan against the rich oil-producing emirates and monarchies of the Arabian peninsula.
The Iraqi leader's decision to hold on to Kuwait -- along with his refusal to pull out of Kuwait without a fight at the last minute, an act that would have left him still the most powerful hand in the region -- may go down as one of the most colossal miscalculations in modern history.
But Mr. Hussein may well think that his mistakes, while regrettable, may be overcome. After all, he has the rebellion by Shiites in southern Iraq and by the Kurds in northern Iraq under control.
 
Military Stretched Thin
 But the Iraqi military is stretched thin in holding onto major cities and oil-producing areas. The prospect of low-intensity guerrilla warfare that will sap the strength of the Government is a real threat to the stability Mr. Hussein must re-establish if he is to rebuild his country.
The humanitarian airlift that this week will send American C-130's into the mountains of northern Iraq will be dropping food, blankets and tents not only to civilian Kurdish refugees, but also to the Kurdish rebel fighters who are traveling among them. In that sense, the airlift is lending direct aid to the insurrection.
With the vote of Iraq's National Assembly today ratifying the decision to accept the cease-fire terms, Mr. Hussein has shown that he is not ready to resign and is handling decisions in the manner he has in the past. This was the same Assembly that ratified, after the fact, Mr. Hussein's decision to go into Kuwait, to release hostages taken in Kuwait and Iraq and to go to war against the coalition.
If his error in Kuwait forces Mr. Hussein to loosen the reins of control, it is unlikely that Iraqis outside the inner circle will have any role except in the civic affairs agenda: repairing electrical, water and sewage services, reopening schools and providing public health services. Any attempt at debate on foreign policy in Iraq appears destined to be reserved for the Revolutionary Command Council, where Mr. Hussein is likely to remain rampant.
Though a United States intelligence report two weeks ago predicted Mr. Hussein's downfall within a year, some longtime analysts inside the Government suggest that Mr. Hussein's grip on Iraq's security services, and the leadership of both the military establishment and Baath Socialist Party, will protect him from any internal rivals.
These analysts and Iraq specialists expected Mr. Hussein to accept terms he considered onerous because that was the only way to get his nation moving again by ending United Nations trade sanctions and removing the blockade on the shipment of Iraqi crude oil to world markets.
 
Clearing the Obstacles
 Middle East specialists in the Administration and the intelligence agencies say that once the Iraqi economy is moving forward again, Mr. Hussein and his cosmetically rearranged Cabinet can be expected to try to whittle, chisel and needle their way around every obstacle that the cease-fire resolution has placed before them.
As American military forces withdraw from the region, they say, Mr. Hussein is likely to waste little time in channeling his regained oil revenues both into domestic rebuilding programs, and also in repairing his military machine so he can once again enforce central control throughout the country.
And politically, they say, he will seek to press United States policy in the region to use the same standards of pressure it has applied to Iraq to bringing Israel into compliance with United Nations resolutions calling for the return of occupied territories.
If Mr. Hussein is able to exact any measure of revenge for the humiliation he has been made to suffer in the eyes of many in the world, it will be in the political arena. There still are millions of Palestinians, Jordanians, Yemenis and North Africans who supported him in the war and may still clamor for the same measure of justice that Washington fought for in the name of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
BAGHDAD FORMALLY AGREES TO 'UNJUST' U.N. CONDITIONS FOR PERMANENT CEASE-FIRE

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, April 6

 BODY:
Five weeks after the United States and its allies drove Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, Iraq today accepted United Nations terms for a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.
In accepting the conditions, the National Assembly in Baghdad, which follows Mr. Hussein's dictates, called the arrangement "unjust," but it acknowledged that Iraq had little choice if it was to avert further degradation. 
 The message of Iraqi acceptance was delivered in New York to the offices of the United Nations Secretary General and to the chairman of the Security Council by the Iraqi representative at the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari. He told reporters that Iraq accepted the terms "without conditions," but added that he considered the resolution "one-sided and unfair."
 
Cease-Fire Now Official
 Under the terms of Security Council Resolution 687, adopted on Wednesday, Iraq's acceptance automatically activates a permanent cease-fire between the opponents in the gulf war. But the Pentagon did not immediately issue orders to American forces in the Persian Gulf region proclaiming a formal end to hostilities.
 [In Houston, where he is spending the weekend, President Bush said the Iraqi letter "appears to be positive." But h said he did not "want to get too far out front until we get the analysis." Mr. Bush took note of "some griping" in the Iraqi letter about the conditions. "That's just too bad," he said. "Saddam Hussein is in no position to barter."]
The Iraqi acceptance clears the way for a series of steps to insure the peace. Those include the establishment of a United Nations peacekeeping force, the destruction of Iraq's biological and chemical weapons and its long-range missiles, and the payment of Iraqi reparations to Kuwait for damage suffered after the invasion last Aug. 2.
 
Embargo's End in Sight
 Iraq's move will also clear the way for the eventual end to the economic embargo against Baghdad, and it will ease the withdrawal of American troops occupying 15 percent of Iraqi territory in the south of the country,
The Iraqi acceptance is a major diplomatic milestone in the campaign begun by the United Staes and its allies last August to expel Iraqi forces from Kuwait and strip Mr. Hussein of the military power that made his army the most feared in the Arab world.
But the allied campaign against President Hussein has not ended the Iraqi leader's hold on power. He still appears firmly in control and his army has apparently crushed rebellions by Kurds in the north of Iraq and Shiite Muslim dissidents in the south.
Hundreds of thousands of Kurds continued to flee from the Iraqi Army today, fearing reprisals after their revolt in the north. In Baghdad, the Iraqi leader dismissed his Defense Minister and replaced him with a son-in-law, sharpening the nepotistic profile of a Government that has come to depend increasingly on clan and blood ties as the gulf crisis has unfolded.
The United States, which has declined to give the rebels direct military aid, has announced that starting on Sunday, American helicopters with Air Force cover will drop non-military supplies to Kurds stranded in northern Iraq. Other Kurdish refugees continued to enter Iran, which called again today for increased international aid.
 
A Rubber Stamp
 The vote in the 250-seat Iraqi Parliament accepting the Security Council resolution was said by Iraqi officials to be 160 to 31, although the numbers, like the assembly itself, represent little more than window-dressing for decisions of the the Supreme Revolutionary Command Council, which met under Mr. Hussein's chairmanship last night.
"While declaring that this resolution is unjust, they have found there was no other choice than to accept it in order to defeat the American-Zionist plot," the Parliament speaker, Saadi Mehdi Saleh, said. Drawing on Koranic texts, he said, "We must sometimes, for our own good, accept that which displeases us."
The allied air war destroyed much of Iraq's roads, bridges, oil refineries, water-purification plants, electricity-generating stations, sewage plants and communications networks. To rebuild them, Iraq needs to free itself of the economic and other sanctions imposed by the United Nations after Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait.
But Resolution 687, approved by the Security Council on Wednesday and accepted by the Iraqi parliament today, makes the lifting of trade sanctions conditional on the destruction of Baghdad's chemical, biological and nuclear weapons potential under United Nations supervision.
 
Terms of Trade Ban
 Until those capabilities are destroyed, a trade ban remains in force, and until Iraq can resume oil exports, it has no way of earning money to finance its own reconstruction. At the same time, the resolution mortgages part of Iraq's oil revenues to pay reparations to Kuwait.
Baghdad's effort to quickly restore its economy may also be impeded by a separate Security Council resolution, adopted on Friday, calling on Iraq to halt its repression of the Kurds and the Shiites. Because it asserts that the international movement of Kurdish and other refugees is a threat to global security for which the Iraqi Government may be held responsible, the resolution could be used as a basis for continued sanctions against Baghdad.
While the terms of Wednesday's resolution have been widely condemned in Baghdad as an American ploy to destroy Arab military potential in the fight against Israel, the Iraqi Parliament's acceptance today seemed part of an effort by Baghdad to secure its own survival after months of crisis, war and insurrection that have brought not only destruction by allied bombing but the worst uprisings in Iraq's modern history.
Those twin civil wars have left a legacy of bitterness and fear. Iranian officials reported today, for instance, that 300,000 Iraqi Kurds had fled into Iran, braving minefields and harsh conditions to escape anticipated retribution from loyalist Iraqi units known for vengeance.
On Friday, Baghdad offered a conditional amnesty to rebellious Kurds, but Kurdish rebel officials in Damascus dismissed the offer today as what one rebel spokesman called a "sick joke."
 
Panoply of Revolt
 Confronted by this panoply of revolt, destruction and challenge, President Hussein has rewarded family loyalty and reinforced the power of his own clansmen. Thus, Brig. Gen. Hussein Kamel, a cousin and son-in-law from the Iraqi leader's native Tikrit region, was given the Defense portfolio today, replacing a military commander, Gen. Sadeh Tuma Abbas.
General Kamel had previously been charged with building Iraq's military, now likely to be truncated all the more under the terms of the resolution.

Baker to Middle East
 HOUSTON, April 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived here today to see President Bush before flying to Turkey and the Middle East.
Mr. Baker said the main purpose of his trip would be to "take advantage of the window of opportunity in the aftermath of the gulf war" to see if progress could be made on a settlement of disputes between Israelis and Arabs.
At a news conference, Mr. Bush said he did not rule out using American troops as part of a peacekeeping force in the gulf. But he said "a lot of United States troops" would not be involved, adding, "I have no intention of leaving our forces there."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL '91;
Majors' Umpires Stop Work

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Major league umpires stopped working yesterday and do not plan to work regular-season games beginning with tomorrow's opening-day schedule. The umpires' lawyer said the umpires were being locked out; the owners' chief negotiator said the umpires were engaged in a work stoppage.
 Whatever the terminology in the game of labor-strife semantics, amateur ("alternate," according to the leagues) umpires are scheduled to man the season-opening games in eight cities while major league umpires meet in Chicago to determine when and where to establish picket lines. 
 "They have not been told they would be locked out," Robert Kheel, the owners' lawyer, said yesterday, "but they have given us no assurances that they intend to work Monday or any other time so the leagues have made appropriate arrangements for replacement umpires."
 
Talks Collapse
 Intensive negotiations between the two sides broke down just before 3 A.M. yesterday. The umpires were prepared to agree to allow the league presidents to select umpires for post-season games, a major demand by management, but the league presidents refused to accept the umpires' proposal on salaries. Under the existing system all umpires get to work post-season games on a rotating basis. The league presidents want to designate umpires for the games so that the best umpires will be working.
At Shea Stadium, four former minor league umpires worked yesterday's game between Toronto and the Mets. At Wrigley Field, a crew of four Big Ten umpires worked the game between Milwaukee and the Chicago Cubs.
Richie Phillips, the major league umpires' lawyer, said the two sides were only $750,000 a year apart on the total amount the leagues would spend on salaries over four years.
 "It's incredible that we're $750,000 apart and it's not getting resolved," Phillips said by telephone from his office in Philadelphia.
 Phillips, who had been uncharacteristically quiet throughout the negotiations, said the owners' representatives, referring to post-season selection of umpires, had given "every indication if I made a certain move, they would meet the salary requisites. I said O.K. I'm prepared to make this final concession, provided that you make the salary concession, and that would do it."
 Kheel, Phillips said, "came back into the room and shocked me. After we had moved closer and closer to a deal for 15 hours, he said no, they don't want to do it."
 Kheel acknowledged having said that the clubs would make "significant economic concessions" in return for regaining control of post-season assignments. "I view us as having met whatever commitment he perceived us as having made," Kheel added.
 Phillips immediately informed the umpires of the breakdown in talks, and they decided not to work the final two days of the exhibition schedule, yesterday and today.
 Phillips said the umpires had received neither crew nor game assignments for the regular season.
 "If they would permit the umpires to work Monday, then we'd have to deal with that," he replied. He later said: "I'm not saying we would work under the circumstances. I've let them know there is that possibility we would work for some time while we negotiate if it's meaningful."
 The last time the umpires did not work was during the 1984 post-season playoffs.
 Kheel said that the owners' offer would incease the umpires' total compensation by 50 percent. Phillips disputed that representation, saying that in the major economic areas the owners had offered a 50 percent raise in post-season pay but had not come near 50 percent on salaries, per diem expenses and pension contribution.
 On salaries, he said and Kheel confirmed, the owners offered these raises: minimum -- $41,000 to $57,500; 5-year umpire -- $49,000 to $72,500; 10-year -- $67,000 to $91,300; 15-year -- $87,000 to $110,000; 20-year -- $105,000 to $128,800. Kheel said that the owners also added a higher maximum, for 25-year umpires, at $155,000.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL '91;
1941: An Unmatchable Summer

BYLINE: By RAY ROBINSON; Ray Robinson is the author of "Iron Horse: Lou Gehrig in His Time," (W.W. Norton, 1990) and "The Home Run Heard 'Round the World," which is to be released this month by HarperCollins.

 BODY:
On a gleaming spring day in Florida 50 years ago, Joe DiMaggio, eager as usual to get to work, received a traffic ticket for speeding. As things turned out, so the exaggeration goes, it was the only time that the New York Yankees' center fielder was stopped during that enchanted year.
DiMaggio's elegant presence and 56-game hitting streak were hardly the only reasons that 1941 merits inclusion in any baseball time capsule. That summer, as the United States edged toward entry into World War II, the game produced a blend of grand-scale heroics from Ted Williams and his .406 batting average, Bob Feller, Lefty Grove, Bucky Walters, Pete Reiser, Tommy Henrich, Whitlow Wyatt, Cecil Travis, Country Slaughter, Johnny Vander Meer, Leo Durocher and Dixie Walker. 
 That summer, in the waning days of the Great Depression when more than nine million remained unemployed, baseball seemed to provide a cocoon for many Americans amid lingering economic woes of the past and Hitler's ominous conquests in Europe. The basic nourishment at ball parks was the nickel hot dog, and, after the game, a full-course dinner at a good restaurant could be eaten for half a dollar. Tickets to the ball park ranged from 50 cents for a perch in the bleachers to $1.10 for general admission to $3 for the best seat in the house.
On the field, New York boasted 3 of the 16 major league ball clubs. The Yankees, under Joe McCarthy, were set to scale the heights again, after losing to Detroit in 1940. The Brooklyn Dodgers, pennant-less since 1920, played under the strident lash of the former pool hall hustler from Massachusetts, Leo Durocher. At the rusty old Polo Grounds, the Giants were being managed by Bill Terry, who had hit .400 in 1930, something no one had done since then.
It was DiMaggio, however, who set the tone for the season. After winning batting titles in 1939 and 1940, the 26-year-old outfielder had become the acclaimed successor to Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. In 1941, he was playing for $37,500 (the average big league salary that year was $7,300), but only after being forced to stage a holdout against a hardened Yankee front office.
 As the 1941 season began, DiMaggio had already hit in 19 straight games in spring training. He added eight games at the beginning of the regular season before drifting into a brief slump. On May 15, a day sticky as flypaper at Yankee Stadium, DiMaggio singled against Chicago's Edgar Smith. Baseball's most sustained skein of batting brilliance had begun.
The tapestry of consistency continued through May, days that were cluttered with speculation about Rudolf Hess's unscheduled aerial adventure in a stolen plane from Augsberg to Scotland, apparently attempting to arrange peace with the British. There were also fallacious reports that the German boxer Max Schmeling had been killed by the British in Crete while trying to escape capture.
And the news of war intersected with the news of sports. Hank Greenberg, a bachelor with no dependents and runner-up for the most valuable player award in the American League in 1940, played the first three weeks of the 1941 season, then became the first star player to be drafted into the Army. His salary went from $55,000 a year down to $21 a month. By the end of the year, four other big leaguers had gone into the service.
By June 2, DiMaggio was one-third of the way through a record that was captivating America (soon Alan Courtney's lyrics -- "Joe, Joe DiMaggio, we want you on our side" -- were composed in tribute). That night, baseball lost Lou Gehrig, the mighty oak, whose consecutive game streak of 2,130 games had endured through Prohibition, the Roaring Twenties, the Great Depression and F.D.R.'s New Deal. The first basemen died in the Riverdale section of the Bronx three weeks short of his 38th birthday after a two-year battle against amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, an affliction since named after him.
DiMaggio's streak went to 30 games on June 17, an all-time Yankee mark. That night, Joe Louis retained his heavyweight boxing crown when he knocked out the converted light heavyweight, Billy Conn, in the 13th round. A spectator at the Polo Grounds fight, DiMaggio drew thunderous applause as he entered the park.
DiMaggio raised his number to 54 with a lucky infield hit on July 13. The same day, the movie producer Samuel Goldwyn said he intended to film Gehrig's life story. Mentioned as a candidate to play the ill-fated player was a former baseball broadcaster and actor named Ronald Reagan. Gary Cooper eventually won the part.
DiMaggio's streak went to 55 on July 15, against Ed Smith, who had fed him the pitch on May 15 that started the historic barrage. On the same afternoon, the Secretary of the Interior, Harold Ickes, blasted Charles Lindbergh, the heroic lone eagle of the 20's, for his isolationist policies. War was creeping closer.
The next day the streak reached 56 as DiMaggio collected three hits in four trips in Cleveland.
A crowd of 68,000 showed up in Cleveland on July 17, but ill fortune finally caught up with DiMaggio, as third baseman Kenny Keltner snared two vicious ground balls and threw him out. In his last time at bat, Dimaggio hit Jim Bagby's pitch into a double play. The streak was ended.
Would he have liked the streak to have gone on forever? DiMaggio was asked afterward. "When they take them away from you, like Keltner did," he said quietly, "there's nothing a fellow can do."
The next day DiMaggio began another binge that lasted for 16 games.
Meanwhile, in Boston, Williams, whose eyesight was reputed to be keen enough to spot a poor dry cleaning job from 30,000 feet up, was on a seasonlong tear. On Sept. 27, the 23-year-old Red Sox slugger went to bed in Philadelphia with a batting average of .3996, enough to grant him entry into the pantheon of .400 hitters. The last player in the American League to hit .400 had been Harry Heilmann of Detroit, at .403 in 1923.
Joe Cronin, the Red Sox manager, assured Williams on Sunday morning that nobody would hold it against him if he chose to sit it out in that afternoon's doubleheader with a Philadelphia club that was 37 games behind the flag-winning Yankees. The Red Sox, in second place, were 17 games out. Nothing was at stake in the games.
"It's entirely up to you," said Cronin. "You've got .400 in the bank now. What do you say: play or sit it out?"
Williams needed only seconds to respond.
"A man is a .400 hitter or he isn't," Williams said. "I'm going to play. I don't want anyone to say I walked in through the back door. I'm going to prove it."
On a damp day, 10,628 fans came out. Facing three pitchers in the first game, Williams went four for five, including his 37th homer. In the second game, he continued his bravura display, with two hits in three times at bat. When the curtain came down, Williams was at .406.
Marveling at what his protege had accomplished, Eddie Collins, the general manager of the Red Sox, said, "All Ted has ever lived for is his next turn at bat."
But there was still more to come in this wonderful season. The Dodgers won the National League pennant, clawing and scratching to defeat the Cardinals, even though a young player who hit out of an unorthodox corkscrew stance was brought up from Rochester in September to help the Cards. His name was Stan (the Man) Musial, and his measly .426 average in 12 games was not enough to sidetrack Durocher's team. But it was the first of many years in which Musial would never fail to hit at least .300.
In the World Series, the Yankees won two of the first three games. But it was the fourth at Ebbets Field that long-suffering Dodger fans remember.
Pete Reiser's two-run homer had given the Dodgers a 4-3 lead into the ninth. With Hugh Casey, Brooklyn's most rugged relief pitcher, snarling down at the Yankees, it seemed a good bet that the Series was on the verge of a two-all deadlock. When Johnny Sturm and Red Rolfe were retired, the Yanks were down to their last out.
With a count of three balls and two strikes on the Yankees' Old Reliable, Tommy Henrich, Casey unleashed a pitch -- could it have been a spitter? -- that Henrich swung at and missed. But the Dodgers' catcher, Mickey Owen, who hadn't committed an error in a year, also missed. The ball tore through his grasp and rolled to the grandstand as Henrich sped to first base.
Already on their way to take their post-game showers, the Yankees returned to the playing field. A game beyond recall had taken on a new life. In quick succession, a despondent Casey gave up a single to DiMaggio, a double to Charlie Keller, a walk to Bill Dickey, a double to Joe Gordon and a walk to Phil Rizzuto. When the slaughter ended, the Yankees had won, 7-4, and they won the next day, too.
"I'm only sorry about one thing," Owen said later. "I should have called time and stopped the game, giving Casey and myself a chance to get over the shock. I've always kicked myself for not doing that."
Less than two months later, on Dec. 7, the Japanese navy rained bombs down on the Hawaiian island of Oahu. The attack on Pearl Harbor, a place unknown to most Americans, cost 2,280 American lives and wounded more than 1,000.
In recalling that time, the author William Manchester would write: "It had been a fine, golden autumn, a lovely farewell to those who would lose their youth, and some of them their lives, before leaves turned again in a peace-time fall."

LENGTH: 1206 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
How Accurately Does The Government Measure The Pinch of Inflation?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO many consumers, suffering such real-life financial jolts as $140 traffic tickets, $50 drugstore prescriptions and $1,000-plus annual increases in college tuitions, the nation's official retail inflation gauge seems somewhat disconnected from reality.
Their perception, particularly at a time of slowly growing incomes, is that prices bound ahead even when the Government reports, as it did at its latest reading last month, that inflation during the latest three months ran at the relatively modest annual pace of 3.9 percent. 
 Anecdotal evidence, economists have learned, can be dangerous, but it does underline some of the limitations inherent in the closely watched Consumer Price Index, which monitors the rate of inflation. Most economists view the index as one of the more reliable of the Government's statistics.
And at the moment, most economists say, the index seems to be giving an accurate reflection of inflation . Still, an understanding of some of its limitations can provide a better understanding of both individual circumstances and the shape of the economy overall.
Of the various criticisms leveled against the index, one of the most often cited is that it fails to adjust sufficiently for improvements in the quality of a product, such as faster computers, or more sophisticated medical care, or changes in the configuration of a product, such as automobile producers making more options standard. Some critics have suggested that taxes ought to be considered as a factor.
"We don't know how to measure all of these things," said Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist for First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. He cites banking services and computer software as areas where output -- and thus unit cost -- is particularly difficult to gauge.
Another source of confusion is that the price index is designed to measure inflation, not the cost of living. Its so-called basket of goods and services rarely changes even though in hard times consumers tend to substitute cheaper products for more expensive ones -- they eat hamburger instead of steak.
And even if the index were perfect, psychology suggests that perceptions of inflation would be skewed by everyday experience. The typical consumer observes the price of a gallon of gasoline daily but may well go for years without knowing, say, the going rate for a new roof.
 
Perception and Reality
 "People's perception of inflation tends to be higher than the actual inflation rate," said Jason Bram, associate economist at the Conference Board, a business research group.
In addition, producers and distributors find it relatively easy to impose big percentage increases on frequently purchased, low-priced goods such as candy or postage stamps. Consumers will notice but probably not object.
 One of the biggest criticisms of the consumer index comes from Albert Sindlinger, the veteran researcher whose data come from polling. Taxes should be not be left out, he said. By his calculations, an appropriately constructed index would show that, primarily because of taxes, consumer prices over the last year climbed more than twice as fast as the 5.3 percent posted by the Government's rate.
"Inflation is far from under control," Mr. Sindlinger insisted. His own inflation index was "in tandem" with the Government's throughout 1988 and 1989, he said, but it has jumped 13.5 percent over the last year.
To one degree or another, many economists agree with Mr. Sindlinger: Consumers have less money available now for discretionary purchases than is generally assumed, and they will be financially unable to fuel an economic rebound even though confidence has revived.
"Conceptually, he's right," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Manufacturers Hanover Company, who once created his own index of so-called nuisance items such as toothpaste and candy. "I wouldn't want to be pinned down to his specific number."
For all its deficiencies, the consumer index is defended by an array of private economists as well as its sponsors within the Labor Department.
Martin Fleming, chairman of the statistics committee of the National Association of Business Economists, and an economist for the Cahners Publishing Company, a Massachusetts-based company with a string of trade magazines, called it "one of the better" Government statistical series and said the omission of income taxes -- the consumer index does include excise and other taxes -- is quite proper.
"It really stretches the notion of what a consumer price index is" to calculate inflation as Mr. Sindlinger does, Mr. Fleming said, suggesting that in any event the burden of recent tax increases has fallen mainly on the well-to-do, who, among other things, lost a long-time favorable treatment on the sale of capital assets in the 1986 tax overhaul. .
During the early part of last year the consumer index almost certainly overstated inflation because of the foot-dragging way it measures housing, Mr. Fleming asserted. The Government includes six-month-old housing prices, which have the effect of overstating inflation when prices are in a downtrend. The cost of medical care, he added, is almost always too high because there is no prompt adjustment for quality improvements.

 
Britain Includes V.A.T.
 Over the last 20 years or so, considerable work has been done on how income and Social Security taxes might be incorporated into the consumer index so it would be more accurate for wage escalation and certain other purposes. Britain adopted such a gauge in the 1970's when it imposed a value added tax.
However, Government and academic researchers in this country have calculated that a tax and price index would have shown only moderately higher inflation than the consumer index, at least through the mid-1980's. According to Robert Gillingham, a former Labor Department official who is now a deputy assistant Treasury secretary, tax and price index inflation averaged 6.9 percent between 1967 and 1985, just seven-tenths of a point more than the 6.2 actually posted by the consumer index.
He said he was "skeptical" of Mr. Sindlinger's current results, asserting that there has been no appreciable increase in income taxes during the last year or so to cause the Sindlinger index to accelerate sharply. "There's some quirk going on if it's 13 instead of 6," Mr. Gillingham said, referring to the inflation rate.
Mr. Sindlinger said his information consisted of responses to a survey question he has asked consistently since 1972: Are all forms of taxes costing more, less or the same compared with a year earlier?
"It's a psychological question," Mr. Sindlinger said, acknowledging that many taxes, including property taxes, are directly or indirectly included in the consumer index. "It all comes from interviewing."
In the end, debate over whether the consumer index is significantly underestimating inflation can seem rather abstract to the householders on whose views Mr. Sindlinger has built a handsome business and who regard themselves, correctly or not, as financially pinched.
"Higher tax rates are cutting into disposable personal income," Mr. Sindlinger said. "Consumers are complaining to us -- and can't take much more."

LENGTH: 1021 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
1992 Election Is Far Off, But Not Far Enough for Some

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is a measure of President Bush's strength and the opposition's woes that Democratic leaders have been selling a poignantly simple message in recent weeks: As one party strategist puts it, "Yes, Virginia, there will be a Presidential election in 1992."
Party leaders from Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to George J. Mitchell, the Senate Majority Leader, have found themselves defending, explaining and justifying the notable lack of activity in Democratic Presidential politics. They say the American public will be better served by a shorter campaign. They reject the notion that the Democratic nomination has become a hollow prize, devalued by the extraordinary post-war popularity of President Bush. 
 "The word is out that Democrats are in trouble, that we can't win the White House in '92, that our Senate majority could be in jeopardy, that there could be a massive realignment in the House and in the state legislatures in November 1992," Senator Lloyd Bentsen said in remarks prepared for delivery to a Democratic Party dinner in Detroit last night. "I don't believe a word of it, and you shouldn't either."
But it is easier to persuade people that Democrats will be competitive in the 1992 Presidential election when some of them actually begin to compete. As a result, many in the party breathed a sigh of relief in recent weeks as a few signs of incipient Presidential campaigns finally appeared.
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, the first black person ever elected governor, announced that he was forming a Presidential exploratory committee and embarked on a round of speeches and interviews about his "new mainstream" philosophy -- tempering traditional Democratic compassion with conservative fiscal policies.
Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee says he is giving active consideration to a second run for the Democratic nomination, and behaved like a candidate last week when he called on the Bush Administration to change its policy and provide more help to the Kurds of Iraq. Mr. Gore's stock has risen among many in his party because he was one of 10 Senate Democrats to vote for the resolution authorizing war in the Persian Gulf; that means he can approach foreign policy issues these days with something other than defensiveness.
There is stirring as well among some less well-positioned Democrats: Paul Tsongas, the former Massachusetts senator, is considering a race, as is George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic nominee who lost 49 states. And the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has run twice before for the Democratic nomination, is flirting with a third try and says he will make a decision sometime this fall.
 
Biding Time
 But most of the political heavyweights -- including Senator Bentsen, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt -- remain circumspect. Each has his personal reasons; Mr. Cuomo, for example, is still struggling with the New York State budget. But each also has the financial base, the political network and the name recognition that make it possible to enter the Presidential race much later than most candidates could.
Some broader forces are also slowing this race down.
Foremost is the lingering afterglow of the war. Some strategists say that the country is still on a wartime footing, in political terms, still rallying 'round the President and the flag. This makes it difficult and even dangerous to engage in partisan debate with the President.
 
Prime-Time Patriotism
 Last week, for example, CBS broadcast a special "All-Star Salute to Our Troops" in which Mr. Bush was presented as every inch the resolute Commander in Chief, part of a patriotic pageant. The fact that the show's co-executive producer was Roger Ailes, the President's media consultant in the 1988 campaign, only heightened the chagrin of some Democrats who watched.
The nation's post-war psychology also makes it hard for potential candidates and their advisers to assess the political landscape of 1992.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, conducted Monday through Wednesday, found Mr. Bush's job approval rating had dipped slightly from the historic levels recorded just after Operation Desert Storm, but was still at 80 percent. The telephone survey of 1,283 adults nationwide has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
No one knows how long these still-remarkable ratings can last. Many a Democrat can outline some turn of events whereby Mr. Bush becomes vulnerable: a worsening economy, further deterioration in the Persian Gulf, rising concern over domestic issues. What seems a hollow prize today, some argue, could turn into something worth having. Indeed, the latest unemployment figures -- the jobless rate rose to 6.8 percent in March, highest since late 1986 -- surely have given the White House pause. Moreover, Mr. Bush came under increasing criticism last week for the plight of the Kurds. At the very least, one Democratic strategist said, "You can see that soon we'll get back to a situation where you can have more normal political discourse in this country."
But it is a measure of the conventional wisdom about the Democrats' chances in 1992 that much of the talk here centers on the question of whether a candidate who runs next year will be helped or hindered for a 1996 race. Recent history would suggest that having run for the nomination before is a help; both Ronald Reagan and George Bush had previous campaigns under their belts before they ultimately prevailed. But the Democratic Party has not been kind, in recent years, to those who won the nomination but lost the election.
In the meantime, Democrats wait for the race to begin. Four years ago this week Gary Hart officially announced his candidacy for the 1988 Democratic nomination; he had a full-time staff of 36 and was the third Democrat to formally enter the race, after Mr. Gephardt and former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt. Eight years ago this month, Democratic candidates were fighting it out in straw polls.
Today, Democrats are making do with a few signs of life.

HEADLINE: The Region: Q & A -- Klepper of the T.A.;
Keeping Riders In the Hard Stretch That Lies Ahead

 BODY:
ALAN F. KIEPPER, president of New York City's Transit Authority, took charge 13 months ago after an eight-year career in the Houston transportation system and 10 years in Atlanta's. His agency now has a $215 million budget gap, and service cuts and fare increases are almost certain. In an interview last week with Stephanie Strom, a reporter for The Times, Mr. Kiepper discussed the system, which transports millions of riders daily in 3,565 buses and over more than 700 miles of tracks, and what those riders might expect in a time of financial crisis. Here are excerpts from the interview. 
 Question. How will the Transit Authority solve its $215 million deficit?
Answer. I think it's going to take a fare increase. I think it's going to take budget cuts on the part of the Authority. It will take some additional assistance from the state, hopefully, and possibly from the city. I think probably what's going to happen is that sort of a patchwork will be knit together of assistance from all of those sources in order to keep us afloat. But it's got to come soon because we're trying to cut our expenses. There's certainly a level below which we can't cut unless we want to begin to dismantle the system. We haven't reached that yet, but if we don't get some help, we run the risk of doing that.
Q. Do you still plan to cut service by $15 million?
A. The service changes are under revision, but I'm certainly going to recommend that there be some changes. We really need the whole $15 million, but we have made some rather extensive modifications based on public comment that will probably yield about $9 million, if approved by the board. The bus substitutions for rail service have been taken out, and a number of the bus changes have been modified. We've taken the A train and made extensive changes in that. We still will run the A train to Washington Heights and Inwood, and it will run to 11 o'clock at night, which some people were very concerned about.
Q. Why should riders pay more for less?
A. There's no other way to balance the budget and keep the system running. I'm sure it's difficult for people to understand: service is being cut back, yet the fare is going up. Even at $1.50 -- and I'm not predicting that's where it will go -- it's the best bargain in town.
Q. How have you addressed the fear of crime in the subways?
A. When I came here a year ago, crime was increasing between 20 and 25 percent per month. We had what I would characterize as a moribund police department: morale was low. There was a very low police presence on the system. There was not a vigorous enforcement of regulations. There wasn't follow-up to assure that warrants issued were being effectively enforced.
Since October, we have had a decrease in crime every month. There is a much greater police presence now, and I believe the system is getting safer. The statistics bear that out. Only 3 percent of major crimes in New York occur in the subways. We had 27 homicides last year, which represented less than 1 percent of the total in the city.
Q. If the system is getting better, why are you losing customers?
A. I'm convinced that the main reason we're losing passengers now is that less people are going to work. There's been 100,000-plus jobs lost in New York over the last three years, and a lot of that has been in areas like finance, insurance and real-estate industries, which use stations in the Wall Street area. We're holding our own pretty well in some other areas. Most of our losses are concentrated in areas where we normally get heavy work trips on the subway. We're not attracting more customers, but we are making efforts to hold on to the ones we have in this recession.
Q. What efforts are you making?
A. We are working on the public address system, and making a special effort to get the fidelity and the operation up to snuff. We are proceeding with replacing or repairing all of the booth communication systems. The really big effort, which I think has been the most successful, has been the increase in personal security represented by the reinvigoration of the police. We're working on getting more customer amenities in stations, escalators, elevators, public address, customer service attitude on the part of employees.
Q. What are you doing to reduce fare evasion, which increased after the last fare hike?
A. Fare evasion reached its peak last August. We're proceeding to harden fare control areas by putting in new ironwork, eliminating slam gates. We have unarmed guards in some 70 stations, and the transit police are covering another 40 or so. In those where we have completed the ironwork and also have police protection and or property protection agents, we've reduced fare evasion by over 70 percent.
Q. Won't another fare hike increase the incidence of fare evasion?
A. I think there isn't any question about it. It's also going to discourage some riders. But we're in a dilemma. We get our funds from two sources: 55 percent come from the fare box and the remaining 45 percent is from subsidies. The only source of revenue that the Transit Authority and the M.T.A., its parent, control is the fare.
Q. Couldn't the authority cut its own expenses more instead of increasing fares?
A. We are cutting our expenses. We've got 3,000 less people working for the Transit Authority now than were on the payroll about 18 months ago, and it's gone down virtually every month. But eventually we also reach a point of diminishing returns because to maintain a decent level of service requires a certain number of people. Whether we carry 2,000 people on a train or 1,500 you still need the same number of people.
Q. Will the financial crisis force the authority to abandon the war on graffiti?
A. While we have had an increase in graffiti hits on our trains -- that is a fact -- you haven't seen any of them riding around the system. We are committed that whenever graffiti is identified, the train doesn't go out of the yard or goes out of service as soon as it completes its run.
Q. You have said there will be cuts in the car cleaning force. How can you continue to improve cleanliness in the subways?
A. We haven't distributed the people as efficiently as we should, and we can and have reduced the size of the cleaning force without really affecting the standard. We're also going to more automated types of cleaning. We can take a team of about six people with an automated mobile wash unit and we can clean a station in a matter of hours to a level that the mop-and-bucket crew couldn't do in six months.
Q. Are you doing anything to reduce the lines at token booths that resulted from the last fare hike?
A. Yes. We are trying to get people to use token vending machines and we're purchasing 75 more machines. We're getting good response to them. We're also entering into a number of cooperative marketing arrangements where we'll be doing cooperative promotion with fast-food and retail outlets. We're really trying to prepare for the fare card days under the automated fare collection system, so that people who ride the bus don't have to go to a subway station to buy a fare card.

HEADLINE: The World;
Jittery Asia Has Visions Of a Nuclear North Korea

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
THE destruction of Saddam Hussein's nuclear capability in the opening hours of the Persian Gulf war was met with more than a little cheering here. It was the right idea, a senior South Korean official said recently, adding with a wry smile, "too bad it was the wrong reactor."
The candidate for destruction that he and many other Asians have in mind sits in a heavily guarded complex near Yongbyon, a town 60 miles north of Pyongyang, North Korea's capital. By various estimates, the increasingly isolated government of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's aging "Great Leader," may be only four or five years away from producing a crude but effective atomic bomb. If true, Mr. Kim is already far closer to becoming a nuclear power than Mr. Hussein ever was. And that prospect figures in virtually every disaster scene that the Americans, Japanese and now even the Soviets dream up about the balance of power in Asia in the 1990's. 
Though North Korea signed the nuclear nonproliferation treaty more than five years ago, Mr. Kim has refused to allow international inspectors to see the Yongbyon reactor. While contending that the reactor is for peaceful purposes, Mr. Kim insists that inspection will be permitted only when the United States withdraws its nuclear arsenal from the South.
Mr. Kim's refusal is taking its toll on his country. After initial confusion and hesitation, Japan has finally made it clear to Pyongyang that the price of diplomatic relations with the North, and its accompanying billions of dollars in Japanese aid to its moribund economy, is regular inspection of the plant. Even the Soviets, who gave Mr. Kim the technology that got him started, have joined in, and restraining North Korea's nuclear ambitions may be the only substantive issue Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu agree on when the Soviet leader lands in Tokyo in 10 days.
But no one expects Mr. Kim to back down soon, especially if he hopes to block South Korea's growing relationship with his former patrons. Over the past year the Soviets have established diplomatic relations with the South, and now South Korean companies are rushing to offer Mr. Gorbachev what he cannot get from Pyongyang: investment, consumer goods and some basic industrial technology. Soviet officials have already agreed to support South Korea's application for entry into the United Nations, a move the North opposes. Pyongyang may hope to use a promise to abandon the program as leverage -- either to get American forces out of the Korean Peninsula, or to win better terms in the sputtering negotiations between North and South.
 
Reactor With a Guest House
 Officials in the South -- to say nothing of the Japanese -- are increasingly unnerved by what they are learning about the North Korean nuclear program. They are acutely aware that one of North Korea's few successful exports these days is an improved version of the Soviet-made Scud missile. Seoul is so close to North Korea that the South Korean Government decided recently not to buy a Patriot missile defense system, because it would not have time to react to a launching from the North. Nervousness was only increased last fall, when American defense intelligence and nuclear experts came through Tokyo and Seoul with the latest spy satellite photographs of the plant itself.
According to descriptions from officials who have seen the photographs, there is an unusually big "research" reactor and a much larger one under construction. They are all powered by natural uranium mined in North Korea and Japanese experts say the new reactor should have an output of 100,000 to 200,000 kilowatts. That, in turn, should produce spent fuel that should yield between 20 and 50 kilograms of plutonium every year, plenty for upwards of a half-dozen simple nuclear devices. A plant to refine the fuel into weapons-grade material appears to be under construction. Experts laugh when they hear North Korea's protests that the reactor is for research into power generation.
"Everything is there except transformers and power lines," says Toshibumi Sakata, the director of Tokai University's Research and Information Center. Higher resolution spy satellites, the Japanese say, show anti-aircraft guns around the plant -- and a guest house, perhaps for Mr. Kim.
 A nuclear-armed North Korea would undoubtedly spur the South to revive a nuclear program that it reluctantly shelved -- or said it shelved -- in the 1970's at American insistence. Another unknown is the Japanese, who themselves are within Scud range.
The other night in Tokyo, a senior Japanese diplomat began speculating that if North Korea gets the bomb, right-wing groups will push for Japan to abandon its commitment to stay nuclear-free. "I can't think of any scenario in which a majority of Japanese would say 'Yes, Japan should go nuclear,' " cautioned the diplomat. But if North Korea remains so evasive on inspection, he said, "it will increase anxieties, and there would be people who would ask, 'Can we rely on the Americans?' "
 Indeed, politics, not technology, is the only obstacle to Japan's building a nuclear deterrent. It already has some of the world's most sophisticated nuclear-power generating equipment, and to many engineers building a compact nuclear weapon seems less daunting than building a 64-megabit memory chip.
"How long would it take Japan?" mused Richard Rhodes, the author of "The Making of the Atomic Bomb." "About three months."
A Japanese government expert, asked about the estimate recently, thought about it for a few seconds and then said, "Yes, it might take that long."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 3; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Double Dose of Pain for the Poor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN their State of the State messages this year, many of the nation's governors emphasized the importance of investing in the health and welfare of children, even as they proposed cutbacks in social welfare programs serving low- income families with children.
This seeming contradiction symbolizes the plight of the poor in 1991. The states, ever more burdened in the decade since Ronald Reagan's "new federalism" began shifting a host of new responsibilities to them, are less able to meet those responsibilities because the recession has dried up tax revenue. The resulting cuts in state budgets often have a disproportionate effect on the poor, who depend on public welfare and public services more than other citizens. 
 One example: Michigan officials last month cut 17 percent from payments in the main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Gerald H. Miller, director of the Department of Social Services under Michigan's new Republican Governor, John Engler, said in an interview that the cuts were "very devastating" and might well result in increased evictions and an increase in people who "will not be able to purchase basic needs like soap."
 
Shrinking Benefits
 The across-the-board welfare cuts shaved $85 off the average payment of $501 a month for a family in Michigan, reducing public assistance grants below the levels in effect in May 1988.
Many state legislatures are still in session, so it is too early to say for sure how the latest state budget problems are affecting the nation's most vulnerable residents. But legislators in almost every state have considered cuts in health, welfare or housing programs, even as the demand for assistance rises. The states' current problems represent the culmination of a trend that has been developing for several years.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research institute with liberal leanings, said, "If we look at governors' proposals and state legislative actions to date, the results suggest that 1991 will be a year when poor people suffer the largest budget cuts since Ronald Reagan's first year as President in 1981." Mr. Reagan's cuts, in programs like welfare and food stamps, affected mainly the working poor and those just over the official poverty line. But Mr. Greenstein said that cuts being made or contemplated by states this year would also hit some of the "poorest of the poor," those with incomes of less than 75 percent or even 50 percent of the official poverty level.
Robert Rector, a policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation, contends that reports of cutbacks in selected welfare programs are misleading. "Overall spending for welfare programs continues to grow considerably faster than the rate of inflation," he said.
State officials report that the number of households receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children rose in January for the 18th consecutive month, to 4.3 million, and the number of individual welfare recipients reached 12.3 million, up 8.8 percent from January 1990. In the first month of this year, 105,000 children were added to the rolls, bringing the total number of child welfare recipients to 8.3 million.
As the welfare population has increased, the purchasing power of their benefits has decreased. From 1970 to 1990, the maximum benefit for a three-person family in a typical state grew to $364 a month, from $184. But that increase lagged behind the rise in consumer prices. After adjusting for inflation, the purchasing power of that welfare income declined by 39 percent.
California is one of the few states where welfare benefits kept up with inflation, partly because of a state law that automatically increased benefits for inflation. But California withheld the cost-of-living increase this year, and Stephen K. Larsen, chief of welfare policy at the state Department of Social Services, said that for the 1991-92 fiscal year, officials wanted to reduce the grants for the first time in memory.
Facing a revenue shortfall of more than $12 billion in the coming year, the new Governor of California, Pete Wilson, has proposed that welfare benefits be cut by 8.8 percent. That would reduce the maximum payment for a family of three, now $694 a month, to $633, the level prevailing in early 1988. Mr. Wilson, a Republican, has also proposed eliminating a program that provides cash to homeless families to pay for temporary shelter while they search for permanent housing. The proposals are pending before the California Legislature, where the outcome depends on negotiations to resolve the state's budget crisis.
Governor Wilson has resisted calls by some Democrats for an increase in the state's personal income tax, contending that such increases could worsen the state's economic problems. Noting the Governor's position, Casey S. McKeever, a lawyer at the Western Center on Law and Poverty, a legal aid group in Sacramento, asserted: "Poorer families are singled out for special attack in this budget. No other group has been asked to suffer as much as needy families with children."
In Illinois, Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican, proposed to reduce a state welfare program known as general assistance by forcing local governments to pick up a larger share of the tab for payments to able-bodied adults.
 
Where's the Money?
 The state now pays about 90 percent of program costs; under Mr. Edgar's proposal, the state and localities would share costs equally. Where Chicago and local townships are supposed to get the money is not clear. The Governor's proposal would also set a six-month limit on general assistance payments to adults; there is no time limit now.
In addition, Mr. Edgar is proposing a 5 percent cut in Medicaid payments to hospitals and doctors who treat the indigent, and he wants to curtail some of the Medicaid services that are optional under Federal law: dental, optometric, podiatric and chiropractic services, and hospice care for the terminally ill.
Alicia S. Pelrine, director of human resources at the National Governors Association, said that about half the states, burdened by new Federal mandates for maternity and child care, were cutting back optional Medicaid services and optional coverage of people who are not necessarily poverty-stricken, but whose resources have been depleted by high medical bills.
No program causes governors more distress than Medicaid. They feel powerless to control it because the cost of health care is soaring and the Federal Government is continually mandating expanded eligibility and additional services. Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri, a Republican, describes Medicaid as "the Pac-Man of the state budget," because it gobbles up an ever-growing share of state revenues. Washington and the states split the cost of Medicaid, with Washington's share ranging from 50 percent to about 80 percent, depending on a state's per capita income.
 
Ax-Wielding in Ohio

In Ohio, Gov. George V. Voinovich, facing what he calls "a budget problem unparalleled in Ohio history," has proposed ending the state's general assistance program, which now provides $300 million a year in aid to poor people. He would replace it with two smaller programs costing the state $195 million. "Most Ohioans have had enough welfare, enough poverty, enough drugs, enough crime," he said in his State of the State speech last month.
In Maine, Democratic state legislators beat back efforts to cut the Medicaid program this year. "The low-income population has less ability to bear the brunt of the state's fiscal problems," said State Representative Charlene B. Rydell, a Democrat who heads the health committee of the National Conference of State Legislatures.
"In hard times," she said, "government becomes much more important as a safety net to people who are suffering the most."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Atlanta and the Olympics: The Games Have Already Begun

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
WHEN Atlanta pulled off the remarkable coup of being chosen to host the 1996 summer Olympics, it marked the culmination of a zealous marketing effort aimed at portraying an image of unity, prosperity and racial harmony.
So much for the easy part. Now, as the $1.2 billion effort to stage the games gears up, it is occurring in a place that seldom bears much resemblance to the idealized blend of Martin Luther King and Scarlett O'Hara sold to the International Olympic Committee. 
 Instead, the process has begun with a power struggle between the overwhelmingly white group that won the games and the black Mayor of a city that is 70 percent black; an upscale neighborhood's successful effort to block a proposed Olympic tennis stadium and protests by residents of two inner city neighborhoods who fear the games will displace the poor.
For the most part, Atlanta is still basking in the glow of the Olympic victory. Almost everyone agrees that the games, if handled right, could provide an infusion of resources for the poor as well as a luminous platform and a business bonanza for the city.
"The power and the passion of the people is clearly on the side of staging a successful games consistent with the leadership that we've developed," said Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games. "This is a situation where everybody can win."
But there is also widespread recognition that the effort to stage the games will be played out over a Byzantine power grid, along numerous fault lines of race and class. Potential conflicts include not just interracial ones, but also intraracial ones -- some low income blacks are suspicious of the alliance between black politicians and the city's business interests.
"This is not a settled time in urban life anywhere and certainly not in Atlanta," said Steve Suitts, executive director of the Southern Regional Council, a non-profit civil rights and educational group here. "If the economics of the games look good, that creates some elbow room for some real accommodation of interests. But if you have projections showing that large deficits are a possibility, then I think it's going to be messy and unpleasant and enduringly so."
Almost no one took much notice in 1987 when Mr. Payne, a real estate lawyer and former University of Georgia football star, came up with what seemed like the wildly eccentric idea of trying to bring the Olympics to Atlanta. Along the way, the committee enlisted the support of broad segments of the community without relinquishing any control.
When Atlanta's bid won its surprise victory, governmental bodies woke up to find the private Olympic committee dominated by affluent whites in control of what is likely to be the largest economic enterprise in the history of a city that, despite the economic boom that has enriched its suburbs, remains one of the nation's poorest. Putting on the games will involve an estimated $418 million in construction, including a new Olympic stadium, Olympic village and two high-rise housing towers.
After some edgy negotiations, the city and the Olympic committee worked out an agreement that left the committee firmly in control, but already several politically and racially sensitive issues have arisen.
Some residents of the Summerhill area, a poor black neighborhood parts of which were bulldozed 25 years ago for the construction of the Atlanta-Fulton County stadium, have vowed to stop construction of the Olympic stadium planned for their neighborhood.
"They came in here 25 years ago and took over people's homes," said Ethel M. Mathews, an organizer of the effort to stop the stadium. "They disappeared like ants. We want the Olympics to come to Atlanta, but we don't want them to take our homes to build parking lots."
Atlanta City Council President Marvin Arrington last week proposed that another low-income housing project, the Techwood homes be demolished to make way for housing for the Olympics. After the games are over, the facilities would be used as dramatically upgraded housing for the poor, he said.
Residents there are leery.
"I would like to see some community-based people sitting on the boards," said Maggie Smith, president of the tenants association at Techwood homes. "Right now the only thing everybody's interested in is the Olympics coming here and making money out of it."
But Atlanta's politics have come along way since the stadium was built in Summerhill. For instance, Mr. Payne said the Olympics will have the most aggressive minority business program in the city's history.
"There's no question those people's voices are heard in a way they were not 25 years ago," said Mr. Suitts.
One reason for optimism is what could be an economic windfall expected to come from European television rights, which are now expected to bring in at least twice the $125 million organizers had anticipated. Such a cushion could facilitate some of the economic and political trade-offs needed to satisfy the disparate interests.
But some observers question whether the group is prepared for the turmoil that could develop.
"The real question is how this is handled over the next several years, not by public relations people, but by people who are politically sensitive," said Alvin Boskoff, an Emory University sociologist. "And I don't think the members of that committee are politically sensitive."
Mr. Payne thinks his committee is up to the job.
"I don't expect anything that is going to be a challenge to the successful staging of the games," he said. "I see some things that are going to require the full measure of our business and political acumen, but we're not exactly rookies at this. We know what we're doing."

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Learning Process

 BODY:
Bo Jackson, who knows baseball, football, endorsements and commercials, last week ended his brief acquaintance with unemployment. Jackson, who sustained a career-threatening hip injury while running the football for the Los Angeles Raiders three months ago, was released last month by his baseball team, the Kansas City Royals, after the team doctor concluded that the outfielder's career might be over. During the two-week waiver period that followed, no team showed an interest in taking on his $2.4 million Royals contract with no guarantee that he could play. But then Jackson was up for bids, and the Chicago White Sox spoke up. The team will pay him as little as $700,000 for one year or, if his hip and his hitting hold up, as much as $8.15 million over three years. But the deal could mean more to Jackson than any White Sox pay check. Since his football days are over, the end of his baseball career might also have meant an end to his endorsements, which reportedly bring him about $5 million a year.

HEADLINE: Why the Rich Should Pay an Extra Tax Share

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Why is the rate of income tax higher for income above a certain level? That question is asked by J. Thomas Pearson (letter, March 18), who objects to richer people paying an extra share of tax, and it indicates the failure of our schools to educate their students on the history of income sharing in the United States. 
 Our country, like every capitalist country, has the problem noted by Will and Ariel Durant (authors of the monumental books on the history of civilization) of the tendency of wealth to become increasingly concentrated. People with surplus capital are the ones who can seize new opportunities to gain more wealth, and their economic power generally provides political power, which can influence government decisions favoring their ventures.
Land subsidies for railroads, and mail subsidies for steamships and airlines are classic examples.
The battle waged against industrial trusts by President Theodore Roosevelt was one attempt to limit the power of concentrated wealth. President Franklin D. Roosevelt sought to limit the concentration of wealth and its transmission from one generation to another through sharply progressive income taxes and high inheritance taxes.
In the long run, the wealthy have managed to circumvent or undo antitrust and progressive taxation legislation, and the result has been a continuing concentration of wealth and political power, which undermines the economic and social health of our country.
The disposable income of poor people is steadily eroded by ever higher sales taxes. At the same time, the old stock transfer tax, which was like a sales tax for the rich, was ended, and our government officials fear reinstating it because stock brokerage houses might move elsewhere, rather than pay it, notwithstanding the dire need of revenue to sustain essential services and the quality of life in New York City, which could be the beneficiary.
 
FREDERICK S. LIGHTFOOT
Greenport, L.I., March 18, 1991

HEADLINE: Why the Rich Should Pay an Extra Tax Share;
Less Local Freedom

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Seymour J. Harris argues (letter, March 26) that state and local taxes should become deductible from (a credit against) Federal income taxes. This is a dangerous proposal and would prove counterproductive. 
 Under this scheme, state and local governments would be able to increase their expenditures manyfold, indeed right up to the level of the Federal taxes that are paid by their districts, without any increase in the total tax liability of their constituents, and therefore without any political resistance.
This would remove all restraint on such spending. Finance for needed schools, highways and police would become easier, but so would indulgence in less useful or even outright wasteful projects.
I suspect that almost all state and local authorities would exploit their new freedom to spend unwisely. But even if only a minority did so, it would be necessary to control them by imposing nationwide guidelines on local spending.
The result would be less local freedom to set priorities, Mr. Harris's goal, not more.
 
AVINASH K. DIXIT
University Professor of Economics, Princeton University
Princeton, N.J., March 26, 1991
