HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Newark's Loss May Really Be Its Renaissance

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Newark may be America's most incredible shrinking city, but its ego is growing.
No bigger city in the United States lost a greater fraction of its population during the last decade, the census concluded -- giving a new dimension to its nickname as "the Gateway" and reducing its official count to the lowest since 1900. 
 But as Newark marks its 325th anniversary, it is also touting itself as "the Renaissance City" -- a reference that holds the promise of rebirth even as it risks reminding America of the riots that seared the city in the national consciousness nearly a quarter-century ago and made Newark synonymous with urban decline.
"What defined Newark was the Central Ward and that's where the cameras keep coming back," says Richard A. Monteilh, the city's business manager, referring to abandoned, burned-out buildings and empty lots. "Increasingly, they will have little left to film."
The census found that Newark lost 16.4 percent of its population in the 1980's -- dropping to 275,221 from 329,248 -- after a nearly 14 percent decline in the previous decade. The latest exodus from Newark represented a greater percentage loss than occurred in Detroit, which actually lost more people, and a larger number of people than in the 23.2 percent decline recorded in Gary, Ind.
Officials in Newark estimate that its population actually fell less than 4 percent in the 1980's. They say the hemorrhaging, to whatever degree it happened, was stanched in the middle of the decade by a continuing influx of Hispanic immigrants, who were not accurately counted. Anyway, the officials express confidence that less is more.
"We were too large at close to 500,000," Mr. Monteilh said of Newark's population, which has been declining since 1950, but still makes it New Jersey's largest city.
Some of the decline reflects a national phenomenon: the suburbanization of America, as both blacks and whites found incentives as well as opportunities to move away. (The white population declined by 22 percent; the decline among blacks was nearly as great -- 16 percent.) Some poor people apparently left, too.
 The shrinkage wasn't planned. But it represented an opportunity that Mayor Sharpe James has exploited. Public housing is being upgraded as the vacant hulks of high-rise projects are replaced by tracts and pockets of garden apartments and town houses. Newark now has more police officers per resident than any major city except Washington.
Newark's airport, seaport, mass transit and the Prudential Insurance Company's decision not to abandon its downtown headquarters provided a base that enabled the city to survive hard times better than Gary or East St. Louis, Ill., and other largely one-industry towns.
"If you've got things you can build around, you can take the town back," Mr. Monteilh said, adding that one airport is not enough to carry New York, but can have a lot more impact on a smaller city like Newark.
Blue Cross-Blue Shield is returning. Seton Hall University's law school is staying. The Port Authority opened an office building to attract tenants from the legal profession and communications industries. A postal service processing center is being wooed. An architect has been hired to design a major performing arts center. A promenade is being planned along the Passaic River.
For the first time in two decades, market-rate housing and a local movie theater are being built. The abundance of vacant land inspired K. Hovnanian Enterprises to build hundreds of town houses in the Central Ward. A 100-apartment city experiment in affordable housing drew 5,500 applications from prospective buyers.
"What's happening in Newark is the price is right," said Harold Lucas, director of development. "Some of the bogymen people used to see are no longer a major concern."
Yet despite visible signs of renewal and diminishing physical legacies of the riots, renaissance is more an ambitious goal than an accomplished fact.
The gilded dome that now crowns City Hall was the gift of a local developer whose glittery Renaissance Mall shopping center nearby stands unfinished -- a victim of the recession and the credit crisis. Inside this City Hall and others, mayors hold less sway with Trenton than they used to. New Jersey's six largest cities now account for about 10 percent of the state's population and about the same percentage of jobs.
Still, Newark is poised to defy its reputation. It hopes to re-house its poorer residents and to rebound by attracting more middle-class taxpayers. "How that trend plays out," Mr. Monteilh says, "will dictate what kind of city we have in five years."

HEADLINE: 2 Business Advisers Urge Dinkins To Take 3 Steps to Save Millions

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The leaders of Mayor David N. Dinkins's business-labor advisory panel on management are prodding him to adopt three of the group's recommendations that they say could eventually save New York City hundreds of millions of dollars a year and reduce the need for crippling service cuts and higher taxes.
In an Op-Ed article in The New York Times today, the advisers, Roger C. Altman and Donald D. Kummerfeld, urge Mr. Dinkins to save on Medicaid payments by changing the way the city provides medical services to the poor, to cut the city work force with an early-retirement program and to consolidate the city's seven economic development agencies. 
 Mr. Dinkins has been considering these ideas and others as he seeks to bring the city's fiscal problems under control for the next few years. But all three recommendations pose political or managerial difficulties for the Mayor, and his advisers' public recommendation seemed intended to spur him and to open a debate.
 
Opportunities Amid Crisis
 "Today's fiscal crisis, like the last one, creates opportunities for long-overdue changes," wrote Mr. Altman, who was an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Administration of President Jimmy Carter, and Mr. Kummerfeld, a former Deputy Mayor under Abraham D. Beame. "City Hall has recognized this, and budget and management reforms are emerging. If Mayor David Dinkins steps up the pace, government can be downsized without eliminating essential services and driving away businesses with ruinous tax increases."
Senior city officials said they had seen a draft of the article but were not aware that it was to be published today.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said, "The Mayor is inclined to accept these recommendations, and what really needs to be done in several cases is sortiing out the implementation details."
 
Pilot Health Program Due
 Adopting a system of so-called managed Medicaid is especially sensitive for Mr. Dinkins. The idea involves requiring Medicaid patients to choose from designated clinics or hospitals for their medical care and is intended to provide better follow-up and lower-cost care, instead of leaving patients to use hospital emergency rooms where their medical history is not known and efforts may be duplicated at higher cost. But some health-care advocates contend the system limits freedom of choice for the poor.
In a pilot program to begin soon in Brooklyn, Mr. Steisel said, patients will be able to choose from a number of options. He said it remained to be determined just how city health-care agencies could best manage such a system citywide.
In an interview, Mr. Altman said he and Mr. Kummerfeld had made their recommendations public because they were tired of hearing complaints that the business community was not doing its share in working with City Hall to address the city's fiscal problems, even though the Mayor appointed the Management Advisory Task Force late last year.
"There's a very strong sense among the 17 or 18 people on our task force that that was baloney," Mr. Altman said. "Here we are in the trenches, working hand in glove with the Mayor, and we wanted people to know that. City Hall is not twiddling its thumbs. The Mayor's been totally supportive in every respect."
In their article, the advisers say that an early-retirement program for city teachers might avert thousands of layoffs. City officials have said that they are negotiating such a possibility with the teachers union but that it would be harder to realize similar savings in other agencies where there is not such a wide spread between starting and senior salaries.
